Title: Russian Anti-War Protester Speaks Out After Escaping House Arrest
Text: The anti-war protester who stormed the set of Russiaâ€™s state-run evening news broadcast in March has escaped house arrest, she confirmed in a social media post on Wednesday. Marina Ovsyannikova, who was an editor at the Channel One station where she staged her internationally recognized protest, issued the update on Telegram, a chat app Russians have used to share information about the war in Ukraine after government crackdowns on other social media platforms. â€œI consider myself completely innocent, and since our state refuses to comply with its own laws, starting from September 30, 2022, I refuse to comply with the preventive measure in the form of house arrest and release myself from it,â€ Ovsyannikova declared in her post, written in Russian. In a video posted to the app, Ovsyannikova gestured toward her ankle bracelet and called for Russian President Vladimir Putin to wear one as punishment for committing war crimes. The Kremlin has kept her under house arrest since August for staging a series of protests, including the one in which she held up a sign during the live broadcast reading: â€œStop the war. Donâ€™t believe the propaganda. They are lying to you.â€ Ovsyannikova could face more than a decade in prison. Itâ€™s unclear how she escaped, and her new location remains undisclosed. Her former husband Igor Ovsyannikov, who works for the pro-Kremlin RT network, told the station last weekend that heâ€™d alerted government authorities that she and their 11-year-old daughter had gone missing and he did not know where they were. Ovsyannikov did not appear for a Wednesday morning court appearance, her lawyer, Dmitry Zakhvatov, told Reuters. If the government finds her, sheâ€™ll be taken into custody immediately, he said, adding â€œwe hope, however, that this will not happen.â€

Title: Zelenskyy Calls Out Elon Musk Over Suggestions For Ending Putin's War In Ukraine
Text: Tesla and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk on Monday sparked controversy by sharing several polls on Twitter asking his followers to weigh in on his suggestions for achieving â€œUkraine-Russia peace.â€ Musk listed four provisions under which the two countries could potentially reach an agreement that would see the end of the conflict that Russian President Vladimir Putin provoked when he invaded Ukraine on Feb. 24. Musk suggested redoing â€œelectionsâ€ in the four Ukraine regions Putin annexed â€œunder U.N. supervision,â€ adding that Russia would then exit the territories â€œif that is will of the people.â€ The so-called elections Musk referred to have been described as â€œshamâ€ referendums the Kremlin held in Donetsk, Luhansk, Kherson and Zaporizhzhia, and have been widely condemned by Ukrainian officials and the West. Muskâ€™s proposal also stated that Crimea, the Ukraine territory that Putin illegally annexed in 2014, become â€œformally part of Russia, as it has been since 1783 (until Kruschchevâ€™s mistake.)â€ Former Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev â€œgiftedâ€ the Crimea Peninsula to Ukraine in 1954, according to NPR. Years later, after the fall of the Soviet Union, Ukraine, Russia, the U.K. and the U.S. signed the Budapest Memorandum in 1994 agreeing â€œto respect the independence and sovereignty and the existing borders of Ukraineâ€ and â€œto refrain from the threat or use of forceâ€ against it, according to The Brookings Institution, a think tank based in Washington, D.C. Putin defied that agreement when he went ahead with Crimeaâ€™s annexation. The remaining elements of Muskâ€™s proposal included guaranteeing water supply to Crimea, which Ukrainian officials curtailed after the annexation by blocking water from Ukraineâ€™s Dnipro River to the peninsula. The water supply seems to have been restored following Putinâ€™s invasion of Ukraine earlier this year. Finally, Musk proposed Ukraine maintain its neutrality, which could be implied as pushing for the country to abandon its application to be a member of the NATO military alliance. Ukraine fast-tracked its membership bid Friday and has already earned the backing of some members of the alliance. Ukraine-Russia Peace:- Redo elections of annexed regions under UN supervision. Russia leaves if that is will of the people.- Crimea formally part of Russia, as it has been since 1783 (until Khrushchevâ€™s mistake).- Water supply to Crimea assured.- Ukraine remains neutral. â€œThis is highly likely to be the outcome in the end â€” just a question of how many die before then,â€ Musk added. He continued: â€œAlso worth noting that a possible, albeit unlikely, outcome from this conflict is nuclear war.â€ Putin has stepped up his warnings in recent weeks, vowing to protect the four annexed regions by â€œall available means,â€ which was interpreted as a threat of using nuclear weapons. U.S. officials have stressed that while Putinâ€™s nuclear threats are unlikely to materialize for the moment, they should be taken seriously. Following criticism of his earlier poll, Musk went on to release a further survey, asking his followers whether â€œthe people who live in the Donbas & Crimea should decide whether theyâ€™re part of Russia or Ukraine.â€ Letâ€™s try this then: the will of the people who live in the Donbas & Crimea should decide whether theyâ€™re part of Russia or Ukraine Muskâ€™s tweets prompted the response of Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, who posted a poll of his own: â€œWhich @elonmusk do you like more?â€ with two possible answers: â€œone who supports Ukraineâ€ or â€œone who supports Russia.â€ Which @elonmusk do you like more? To which Musk responded that he backs Ukraine, but is â€œconvinced that massive escalation of the war will cause great harm to Ukraine and possibly the world.â€ Apart from Zelenskyy, Musk earned the scorn of other world leaders, including the Lithuanian president. â€œDear @elonmusk, when someone tries to steal the wheels of your Tesla, it doesnâ€™t make them legal owner of the car or of the wheels. Even though they claim both voted in favor of it. Just saying,â€ Gitanas NausÄ—da wrote on Twitter. Dear @elonmusk, when someone tries to steal the wheels of your Tesla, it doesn't make them legal owner of the car or of the wheels. Even though they claim both voted in favor of it. Just saying. Andrij Melnyk, the Ukrainian ambassador to Germany, also had stark words for the billionaireâ€™s first Ukraine-Russia poll. â€œFuck off is my very diplomatic reply to you,â€ Melnyk wrote on Twitter. Fuck off is my very diplomatic reply to you @elonmusk Musk also said his company SpaceX has spent about $80 million to operate Starlink â€” a satellite constellation that delivers internet access â€” in Ukraine, which has also been used in the field to keep Ukrainian forces connected, according to The Wall Street Journal. SpaceXâ€™s out of pocket cost to enable & support Starlink in Ukraine is ~$80M so far. Our support for Russia is $0. Obviously, we are pro Ukraine.Trying to retake Crimea will cause massive death, probably fail & risk nuclear war. This would be terrible for Ukraine & Earth. Kyiv Post, a Ukrainian news organization, recognized Muskâ€™s contribution through Starlink, before adding that it would â€œbe so very wonderful if you were to carry out votes on things that you know about.â€ â€œWe donâ€™t carry out votes on apartheid and Nelson Mandela,â€ it said. Elon, youâ€™re a cool guy and thanks for the Starlink but itâ€™d be so very wonderful if you were to carry out votes on things that you know about. We donâ€™t carry out votes on apartheid and Nelson Mandela. Musk is currently embroiled in a legal battle with Twitter that will determine whether he has to carry through with his initial bid to buy the company for $44 billion.

Title: 'There Are No Checks' On Vladimir Putin Over Nuclear Threat In Ukraine: Defense Sec.
Text: Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin on Friday said â€œthere are no checksâ€ on Russian President Vladimir Putin and he would be the only person in his country to determine whether to use nuclear weapons in Ukraine. Putin on Friday vowed to use â€œall available meansâ€ to protect the four Ukraine regions he annexed â€” Donetsk, Luhansk, Kherson and Zaporizhzhia â€” following referendums Moscow held in those territories. The votes have been denounced as a â€œshamâ€ by Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and condemned by the West. Putinâ€™s statement has been interpreted as a threat over the use of nuclear weapons. Austin told CNNâ€™s â€œFareed Zakaria GPSâ€ he has in the past spoken to his Russian counterpart, Sergei Shoigu, and warned him against going in that direction, but the decision will ultimately be made by Putin himself. â€œI do think he heard my message, but to be clear, the guy who makes that decision â€” I mean, itâ€™s one man. There are no checks on Mr. Putin,â€ Austin said. â€œJust as he made the irresponsible decision to invade Ukraine, he could make another decision. But I donâ€™t see anything right now that would lead me to believe that he has made such a decision.â€ Last month, Putin had issued a similar warning, saying he wasnâ€™t bluffing about doing anything in his power to protect Russia. â€œWhat we have to do is take it very seriously, watch for signs of actual preparations,â€ CIA Director William Burns told CBS Evening News last week. Austin also spoke on the progress of Ukraineâ€™s counteroffensive, which appears to be weakening Russiaâ€™s position in the battlefield, and in part the trigger for Putinâ€™s decision to move ahead with the annexations. â€œWhat weâ€™re seeing now is a kind of change in the battlefield dynamics,â€ Austin told CNNâ€™s Fareed Zakaria. â€œTheyâ€™ve done very, very well in the Kharkiv area and moved to take advantage of opportunities. The fight in the â€” the Kherson regionâ€™s going a bit slower, but theyâ€™re making progress.â€ Putin also called up to 300,000 reservists to join his countryâ€™s forces in Ukraine. That order has been met with challenges, with Russians in some regions reportedly getting drafted despite their failure to meet the eligibility criteria. Over the weekend, Ukraine retook control of the city of Lyman in the east, and continued moving into the Luhansk region, CNN reported, citing pro-Russian officials. Meanwhile, Ukraine has fast-tracked its application to join the NATO military alliance. While it has earned the support of nine countries, it needs to have the backing of all 30 members to join.

Title: 9 NATO Countries Throw Support Behind Ukraine Membership
Text: Leaders of nine NATO countries in Europe released a joint statement on Sunday throwing their support behind a path to membership for Ukraine, which applied to join the military alliance just days earlier. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy applied on Friday for the country to get fast-tracked NATO membership in response to Russia annexing four regions in violation of international law. Ukraine and the West have denounced as a sham Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s referendums to annex the regions â€• his latest move in the months-long war. A country needs approval from all 30 members to join NATO, and Ukraine has received mixed responses in the past from the alliance due to its geographic proximity to Russia. Being at war complicates the countryâ€™s request to join the military alliance. The nine NATO countries that voiced support for Ukraineâ€™s membership are the Czech Republic, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, North Macedonia, Montenegro, Poland, Romania and Slovakia. All of the countries are in Central and Eastern Europe, and could face Russian aggression next if it isnâ€™t stopped in Ukraine. We do not recognize and will never recognize Russian attempts to annex any Ukrainian territory,â€ the statement said. â€œWe firmly stand behind the 2008 Bucharest NATO Summit decision concerning Ukraineâ€™s future membership.â€ At the 2008 summit, NATO members welcomed Ukraine and Georgiaâ€™s desires to join the alliance, but declined to provide a clear timeline for the countriesâ€™ path to membership. The letter on Sunday also did not provide such a timeline, though Zelenskyy thanked the countries for publicly supporting Ukraine becoming a member. Finland and Sweden officially applied to join NATO on a fast-track in May out of security concerns following Russiaâ€™s invasion. Most member countries have already ratified their applications, and the two nations are on track to join the alliance. White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan said Friday that the U.S. has long supported an open-door policy for NATO, but that the application process for Ukraine â€œshould be taken up at a different time.â€ â€œRight now, our view is that the best way for us to support Ukraine is through practical, on-the-ground support in Ukraine,â€ Sullivan said. NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg gave a similar response on Sunday, telling Chuck Todd on NBCâ€™s â€œMeet the Pressâ€ that Ukraine has the right to choose what kind of security arrangements it wants to be part of, but that â€œany decision on membership has to be taken by consensus.â€ After the annexation, the U.S. sanctioned over 1,000 people and firms connected to Russiaâ€™s invasion, including its Central Bank governor and families of National Security Council members. Sullivan said that sanctions have been a â€œcritical elementâ€ to the White Houseâ€™s strategy against Putinâ€™s regime because of the â€œeconomic pressure that we are placing on Russia, and the denial of their ability to gather what they need to be able to regenerate their war machine.â€

Title: Russian Billionaire Oleg Deripaska Charged With Violating U.S. Sanctions
Text: The Southern District of New York charged Russian billionaire Oleg Deripaska on Thursday for violating U.S. sanctions, according to ABC News. A new indictment accused the aluminum tycoon of paying two women, Olga Shriki and Natalia Mikhaylovna Bardakova, for personal services in the U.S. between 2018 and 2020. Deripaska has faced sanctions since 2018 for what the Treasury Department called â€œthe Russian governmentâ€™s ongoing and increasingly malign activities,â€ referring to the annexation of Crimea and other world events. In or around 2019, Shriki allegedly helped Deripaska sell a $3 million music studio in Burbank, California, according to The New York Times. Both Shriki and Bardakova are accused of helping his girlfriend, Ekaterina Voronina, enter the U.S. to deliver his child in 2020. â€œAdditionally ... Deripaska routinely had Shriki and Bardakova purchase various products in the United States for Deripaskaâ€™s personal use and as gifts for others on his behalf,â€ the indictment said. The indictment also alleged that Voronina tried to enter the U.S. again this year but failed. She is charged with making false statements to the Department of Homeland Security in June when claiming that her parents, and not Deripaska, had paid for the airfare. Shriki and Bardakova are further accused of receiving hundreds of thousands of dollars from Deripaska to arrange care and housing for Voronina and her baby. Shriki allegedly destroyed evidence regarding this investigation, while Bardakova is charged with lying to U.S. government officers. Deripaska had made a comfortable living for himself in the U.S., despite his â€œcozy ties with the Kremlinâ€ and â€œwealth acquired through ties to a corrupt regime,â€ said Andrew Adams, the head of the Justice Departmentâ€™s KleptoCapture task force. â€œDeripaska did all he could to lead a life in a stable, free, democratic society â€• even if that meant lying and evading U.S. sanctions,â€ Adams told ABC News. Deripaska, Bardakova and Voronina, who are Russian nationals, have yet to be arrested, The New York Times reported, adding that they are considered fugitives. Shriki, a U.S. citizen, was arrested in New Jersey on Thursday. The billionaire has faced scrutiny from the U.S. government for years. In 2021, the FBI searched Deripaskaâ€™s New York and Washington properties as it looked into possible sanctions violations. In 2020, he was accused of laundering money for Russian President Vladimir Putin, according to the Financial Times. He was also referenced in special prosecutor Robert Muellerâ€™s inquiry into potential Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, though he was never charged. A 2019 report from Mueller claimed that Paul Manafort, a presidential campaign chairman for Donald Trump in 2016, had offered Deripaska data related to campaign briefings and polling. New York prosecutors said this week that they intend to seize Deripaskaâ€™s assets in Manhattanâ€™s Greenwich Village and Washingtonâ€™s Embassy Row neighborhoods for forfeiture. On Friday, the U.S. Treasury Department issued a new round of sanctions against more than 1,000 people and firms connected to Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine.

Title: â€˜Trump Explodedâ€™: 2016 Meltdown Over Russia Interview Questions Revealed In New Book
Text: Donald Trump â€œexplodedâ€ in anger after ABC Newsâ€™ George Stephanopoulos grilled the then-presidential candidate over Russia and his relationship with Vladimir Putin during an interview before the 2016 election, according to a new book. â€œOnce the cameras turned off, storm clouds came over Trumpâ€™s face,â€ New York Times reporter Maggie Haberman detailed in â€œConfidence Man,â€ an advance copy of which was obtained by CNN this week. Trump, said Haberman, railed at ABC News producer John Santucci that the Russia and Putin questions were â€œbullshit.â€ â€œEight fucking follow-ups â€” are you fucking kidding me?â€ Trump reportedly snarled before launching into this analogy about domestic violence: Itâ€™s like asking me if I beat my wife. You ask me once, I say â€˜Fuck no,â€™ and we move on. You donâ€™t then ask if I hit her with a fucking baseball bat or a fucking golf club. That was bullshit and you better fucking fix it in the edit. â€œTrump explodedâ€ when Stephanopoulos later â€œchuckledâ€ and said his team told him â€œI didnâ€™t ask you enoughâ€ about Russia, said Haberman. The future president reportedly fired back: â€œAre you fucking kidding me? Eighteen fucking follow-ups â€” how many different ways do I have to say I donâ€™t know the guy?â€ As president, Trump lavished Putin with praise, took his word over that of U.S. intelligence agencies and tried to extort Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy into smearing his likely 2020 election rival Joe Biden.

Title: Putin's 'Partial Mobilization' Plan Sputters As Nuclear Threat Looms
Text: Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s order last week calling up about 300,000 reservists to join his forces fighting in Ukraine has hit roadblocks, but CIA Director William Burns said Russiaâ€™s menacing nuclear threat should be taken â€œvery seriously.â€ Men reportedly were being forcibly taken for Putinâ€™s military with little to no training, and Russians in some regions were drafted despite their failure to meet the eligibility criteria. Even media outlets typically in favor of Russiaâ€™s invasion have cast doubt on how the â€œpartial mobilizationâ€ orders have been carried out. Rybar, a pro-war blog, wrote on Telegram it knew of several men who had been drafted despite health issues or limited training experience, according to The New York Times. Meanwhile, thousands of Russians have fled the country, and many others have taken to the streets to protest Putinâ€™s plans. The Russian presidentâ€™s escalation apparently was triggered by Ukraineâ€™s successful counteroffensives. The Institute for the Study of War, a policy research organization based in Washington, said the addition of inexperienced men to Russiaâ€™s military is â€œunlikelyâ€ to change the dynamic of the conflict. â€œMobilized men with a day or two of training are unlikely to meaningfully reinforce Russian positions affected by Ukrainian counteroffensives in the south and east,â€ the institute said. Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov on Monday admitted â€œerrorsâ€ had been made in executing Putinâ€™s troop call-up. â€œThese cases of noncompliance with the required criteria are being eliminated,â€ Peskov said, according to the Times. â€œAnd we hope that the rate of elimination will increase and all errors will be corrected.â€ Burns told CBS Evening News that manpower is far from the only trouble facing the Russian military. â€œEven if heâ€™s able to mobilize 300,000 troops, itâ€™s not as if throwing people like cannon fodder toward the front, many of whom are not going to be well trained, many of whom are not going to have the kind of equipment that they need or the logistical support that they need as well,â€ Burns told CBSâ€™ Norah Oâ€™Donnell on Monday. Burns continued: â€œHis military has a lot of other problems; manpower is only one of them.â€ In an exclusive interview, CIA Director Bill Burns told @norahodonnell that U.S. intelligence is evaluating Vladimir Putinâ€™s nuclear threats and that the rhetoric he and other senior Russian leaders are using is reckless.  Last week, Putin said he wasnâ€™t bluffing about using every means available to support Russia, according to The Associated Press. The statement was interpreted as a warning that he is prepared to use nuclear weapons. Burns said U.S. intelligence agencies had no â€œpractical evidenceâ€ that Putin is taking steps to act on his nuclear threat, but said we should not ignore his warnings. â€œWhat we have to do is take it very seriously, watch for signs of actual preparations,â€ Burns said. Burns added policymakers should also â€œcommunicate very directly the severe consequences that would flow from any use of nuclear weapons.â€ National security adviser Jake Sullivan said the U.S. has already done so. â€œRussia understands very well what the United States would do in response to the use of nuclear weapons in Ukraine because we have spelled it out for them, Sullivan told NBCâ€™s â€œMeet the Pressâ€ on Sunday. â€œRussia will make its decisions, but it will do so fully understanding that the United States will respond decisively.â€

Title: Officials Say Putin Is â€˜Struggling Badlyâ€™ Based On Russiaâ€™s Latest Actions
Text: U.S. officials said this weekend that Russia is showing signs of â€œstrugglingâ€ in its war against Ukraine, evidenced by President Vladimir Putinâ€™s latest nuclear threats, attempts to annex parts of the neighboring country, and calls to round up hundreds of thousands of civilians as reservists. White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan spoke with George Stephanopoulos on ABCâ€™s â€œThis Weekâ€ about Russian civiliansâ€™ protests against Putinâ€™s mobilization of about 300,000 reservists and sham annexation referendums in Russian-occupied regions of Ukraine. â€œWhat you see inside Russia right now, this call-up of troops, the sham referenda that theyâ€™re trying to run in the occupied territories â€• these are definitely not signs of strength or confidence,â€ Sullivan said on Sunday. â€œQuite the opposite: Theyâ€™re signs that Russia and Putin are struggling badly. â€œIt will be the Russian people, ultimately who make the determination about how Russia proceeds and the extent to which that there is resistance pushback to what Vladimir Putin has tried to do, calling up these hundreds of thousands of young men,â€ he continued. National security adviser Jake Sullivan tells @GStephanopoulos that Putin calling up troops and holding "shame" referendums in Russian-occupied Ukraine are signs that "Russia and Putin are struggling badly.â€  Sullivan also said that the U.S. has warned Moscow there would be â€œcatastrophic consequencesâ€ if Russia used a nuclear weapon in its war against Ukraine, telling Chuck Todd on NBCâ€™s â€œMeet the Pressâ€ that Russia is very aware of what the U.S. would do in response to nuclear weapon use. The White House is taking the threat seriously, according to Sullivan, who added that this is not the first time Putin has made a nuclear threat in the current conflict. Sen. Tim Kaine (D-Va.), who serves on the Senate Foreign Relations Budget and Armed Services Committee, said on Saturday that he believes Putin is dangerous because â€œhe has his back against the wall,â€ but that his threat of nuclear weapon use is â€œa big bluff.â€ â€œThe use of nuclear weapons, Ali, would pose massive fallout risks to Russian citizens,â€ Kaine told Ali Velshi on MSNBC. â€œUsing nuclear weapons anywhere â€¦ is not just going to invite a coordinated international response that will be overwhelmingly catastrophic for Russia, but the use of nuclear weapons also poses fallout risks in Russia. And so I think itâ€™s a big bluff.â€

Title: UN Report Reveals Russian Forces Raped, Tortured Ukrainian Children
Text: Russian troops raped and tortured children in Ukraine, and brutally executed a â€œlarge numberâ€ of civilians among an appalling list of â€œwar crimesâ€ uncovered in a shocking investigation for the United Nations. The Independent International Commission of Inquiry on Ukraine â€” convened in March and staffed by international legal experts â€” reported the disturbing findings Friday in Geneva, describing a long list of appalling abuses and atrocities by Russian forces. â€œBased on the evidence gathered by the commission, it has concluded that war crimes have been committed in Ukraine,â€ Erik Mose, a Norwegian judge and chairman of the three-member commission, said in a statement to the U.N. Human Rights Council. "War crimes have been committed in Ukraine."-- Independent International Commission of Inquiry tells @un_hrc. Among the most disturbing crimes the commission has documented involve cases in which children were â€œraped, tortured and unlawfully confined,â€ according to the findings. The age of â€œvictims of sexual and gendered-based violence ranged from 4 to 82 years,â€ Mose said in a statement. In some cases â€relatives were forced to witness the crimes,â€ Mose noted in his statement. Children were also killed and wounded in â€œindiscriminate attacksâ€ on civilians by Russian forces using explosive weapons, the investigation found. Commission members â€œwere struck by a large number of executions and other violations by Russian forces, and the Commission received consistent accounts of torture and ill-treatment,â€ Mose noted in his statement. The commission is continuing to investigate executions in 16 towns and settlements, and has â€œcredible allegations regarding many more cases of executions, which we are documenting further,â€ Mose added. Many of the examined bodies showed evidence of â€œprior detention of the victims, as well as visible signs of executions ... such as hands tied behind backs, gunshot wounds to the head, and slit throats,â€ the commission found. The findings have been consistent with reports of war crimes from other international human rights groups, Western governments and Ukrainian authorities. The U.N. Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine earlier this year documented illegal killings â€” including summary executions of civilians â€” in more than 30 settlements in the Kyiv, Chernihiv, Kharkiv and Sumy regions by Russian armed forces while they controlled these areas in late February and March. The Independent International Commission headed by Mose also investigated atrocities in the same areas. Investigators visited 27 towns and settlements and interviewed more than 150 victims and witnesses, according to the report. They also inspected â€œsites of destruction, graves, places of detention and torture,â€ as well as remnants of weapons, said Mose.

Title: Tucker Carlson's Take Awkwardly Backfires When He Accidentally Slams Trump
Text: Tucker Carlson mistakenly took a dig at the financial woes and marital life of former President Donald Trump on Thursday. Carlson, in a segment about the war between Russia and Ukraine on Thursday, called the U.S. response to the invasion â€œclassic mission creep,â€ in which the country extends the militaryâ€™s stay for a purpose thatâ€™ll hurt America in the long term. He later played a clip of former Lt. Gen. Keith Kellogg telling Fox News host John Roberts that the U.S. should stay â€œall inâ€ and noted that the nation hasnâ€™t given Ukrainians weapons, such as an attack cruise missile, that can reach all of Crimea. â€œIt really can put the Russians at threat, but we havenâ€™t done that. And I think we should put them at threat,â€ said Kellogg, who served from 1967 to 2003. â€œUntil [Vladimir Putin] really believes that weâ€™re seriously going after him, heâ€™s going to continue to make these threats.â€ Carlson, in response to Kelloggâ€™s take, said anyone who had a hand in the last five wars that hurt the U.S. long-term â€œshould probably bow out of the conversation about the latest war,â€ The reason for not listening to Kellogg about aiding Ukraine would be â€œfor the same reason that you wouldnâ€™t, say, take financial advice from someone who had gone bankrupt or go to marriage counseling with some whoâ€™s been mmm ... divorced three times because theyâ€™ve demonstrably failed in their so-called area of expertise.â€ Carlsonâ€™s blow adds to a history of the Fox News host defending Russia and Putin, peddling a Russian conspiracy theory and dropping pro-Russia talking points on his show since the start of the invasion of Ukraine earlier this year. You can watch a clip of Carlson accidentally slamming Trump below. Tucker: For the same reason you wouldnâ€™t take financial advice for someone who had gone bankrupt or go to marriage counseling with someone whoâ€™s been mâ€” divorced three times  Carlsonâ€™s comparison wasnâ€™t lost on Twitter users who believed the Fox News host almost let â€œmarried three timesâ€ slip out of his mouth. Trump has been married three times and whose businesses have filed for bankruptcy protection on six occasions. Ummm...who's gonna tell him? ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ Watching him catch himself as he's about to say "married three times" is priceless  Imagine taking advice from someone whoâ€™s gone bankrupt and been married three times. Or making them president, AMIRITE The moment when Tucker Carlson realizes the implications of what heâ€™s about to say? Priceless.

Title: GOP Unveils 'Commitment To America' Plan With Stock Videos Of Russia, Ukraine
Text: House Republican leaders on Friday unveiled their â€œCommitment to Americaâ€ agenda for 2023 â€• and with it, an inspirational video chock full of scenes presented as exceptional imagery of America but that are actually stock footage from Russia and Ukraine. The GOPâ€™s video, â€œThe Preamble to the Commitment to America,â€ opens with a narrator highlighting aspects of what it means to be an American. â€œWe celebrate the rich heritage of the American story and the vibrancy of the American Dream,â€ the voice says, over footage of a drilling rig at sunrise. But this video snippet, an apparent nod to Americaâ€™s natural resources, wasnâ€™t even filmed in America. Itâ€™s stock footage created by Serg Grbanoff, a filmmaker based in Russia. Grbanoff told HuffPost that he filmed this scene in Russiaâ€™s Volgograd region. Hereâ€™s a screenshot of the image in the House Republican leadersâ€™ video, versus an original shot on Shutterstockâ€™s website: Itâ€™s not the only instance where Grbanoffâ€™s work appears in the GOPâ€™s video celebrating America. In another scene, a boy is seen smiling and running in a field with a toy airplane. The words â€œLiberty, and the pursuit of happinessâ€ appear on the screen, a reference to the Declaration of Independence. This clip was also created by Grbanoff, and also filmed in the Volgograd region of Russia. Hereâ€™s a screenshot of the image in the GOPâ€™s video versus an original shot on Shutterstockâ€™s website: At another point in the video, Republicans take a shot at Democrats on the economy. â€œDemocrats have led America off track,â€ the narrator says. The words â€œCrippling inflation and rampant crimeâ€ appear on the screen, over a shot of a woman walking through a grocery store. But this is footage from a European grocery store. If you look closely at the screenshot, you can see a tag hanging on one of the store shelves that says â€œAKCIA,â€ a Slovak word meaning â€œaction.â€ Informally, â€œAKCIAâ€ is used to designate sales in Slovakian stores. House Republicans almost certainly used imagery from Ukraine in their video about America, too. The video includes a clip of a farmer carrying a bag on his shoulder in a field of corn, as the words â€œAnd the vibrancy of the American Dreamâ€ appear on the screen. This is also stock footage sourced from a Shutterstock contributor, DedovStock. The man featured in the clip works for DedovStock, and has a page of his work on its website. His page features shots of him in Ukraine and the Carpathian Mountains, which stretch through Ukraine and parts of Eastern Europe. HuffPost reached out to House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) for comment on why GOP leaders rolled out their plan for America with a video featuring stock footage from Russia. â€œInteresting how you guys arenâ€™t remotely interested on the issues facing the American people in the video,â€ responded McCarthy spokesman Mark Bednar.

Title: Moscow Official Dies In Staircase Fall, Joins Long List Of Mysterious High-Profile Deaths
Text: The former head of a Kremlin-linked engineering institute died Wednesday in an apparent accident, according to CNN â€” adding to the long list of Russian CEOs and officials who have met a mysterious end this year. Russian news outlet Izvestia reported that Anatoly Gerashchenko â€œfell from a great heightâ€ down numerous flights of stairs inside the Moscow Aviation Instituteâ€™s headquarters, according to The Daily Beast. The instituteâ€™s press office described his death as â€œthe result of an accident.â€ Gerashchenko, who led the organization from 2007 to 2015, was serving as an adviser to the instituteâ€™s current rector when he died, according to state-controlled outlet RIA Novosti. He spent 45 years rising through the ranks there and was honored with government awards, such as the Merit to the Fatherland medal. While the Moscow Aviation Institute might sound like a flight school, the university conducts research in fields with potential military applications, from avionics and aerospace to drones and artificial intelligence, according to Insider. It has ties with the countryâ€™s Ministry of Defense. The institute called Gerashchenkoâ€™s death a â€œcolossal lossâ€ and said it would establish an internal commission to investigate. That panel would include members of multiple government bodies and the university itself, it said. Gerashchenko is the latest in a series of high-profile Russians to die this year under unexpected circumstances. Ravil Maganov, who chaired Russiaâ€™s second-largest oil company, Lukoil, reportedly leaped to his death from the sixth floor of a hospital earlier this month. Billionaire Alexander Subbotin, a former manager at Lukoil, was found dead in May of an apparent heart attack in the home of a shaman, according to Newsweek. Meanwhile, local news reported that Leonid Shulman â€” an executive at the countryâ€™s third-largest bank, Gazprombank â€” hanged himself in his cottage in January, according to Reuters. The next month, former Gazprombank executive Alexander Tyulyakov was also found hanged, the New York Post said. Vladislav Avayev, a former vice president at the bank, was found shot to death in April next to the bodies of his wife and daughter. The following day, Sergei Protosenya â€” an ex-manager of Russiaâ€™s second-largest gas producer, Novatek â€” was found hanged in a Spanish villa. Thus far, authorities have not said that foul play caused any of the menâ€™s deaths.

Title: 'Russia Will Be Forced To End This War': Zelenskyy Demands Punishment In UN Address
Text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy implored world leaders to punish Russia for its war on his country and asserted that with united opposition Russia â€œwill be forced to end this war.â€ â€œA crime has been committed against Ukraine, and we demand just punishment,â€ Zelenskyy told the U.N. General Assembly on Wednesday, speaking remotely. He continued: â€œThe crime was committed against the values that make you and me a community of the United Nations. And Ukraine demands punishment for trying to steal our territory.â€ Zelenskyy called for Russia to be stripped of the veto power it enjoys as a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council. â€œSo long as the aggressor is a party to decision-making in the international organizations, he must be isolated from them â€” at least until aggression lasts,â€ Zelenskyy said. â€œReject the right to vote. Deprive delegation rights.â€ Other countries with veto power include the U.S., China, France and the U.K. President Joe Biden, who also addressed the U.N. General Assembly Wednesday, accused Russia of â€œshamelesslyâ€ breaching the â€œcore tenets of the United Nations Charter.â€ â€œLet us speak plainly: A permanent member of the United Nations Security Council invaded its neighbor and attempted to erase a sovereign state from the map,â€ Biden said. Earlier on Wednesday, Russian President Vladimir Putin called up 300,000 reservists to fight in Ukraine after a successful Ukrainian counteroffensive in the Kharkiv region. Large swaths of Russians tried to flee the country following Putinâ€™s announcement, and over 1,300 people were arrested in anti-war demonstrations on Wednesday, The Guardian reported, citing a protest monitoring group. Russia also announced what it called referendums in occupied parts of Ukraine to ask residents whether they want to join Russia â€” a plan that runs afoul of Ukrainian and international law, according to The Washington Post. Zelenskyy said this shows Russia has no real intent to engage in negotiations to end the war. â€œThey talk about the talks, but announce military mobilization, he said. â€œThey talk about the talks but announce pseudo referendums in the occupied territories of Ukraine.â€ He continued: â€œBut Russia will not be able to stop the course of history. Mankind and the international law are stronger than one terrorist state. Russia will be forced to end this war.â€ Biden referred to evidence that Russia has committed war crimes in Ukraine. The most recent example is the mass grave found near the city of Izyum, which Ukrainian forces recaptured in their counteroffensive. â€œThis war is about extinguishing Ukraineâ€™s right to exist as a state, plain and simple, and Ukraineâ€™s right to exist as a people,â€ Biden said. â€œWherever you are, wherever you live, whatever you believe â€” that should make your blood run cold.â€ Zelenskyy made reference to Izyum, as well as the atrocities in Bucha, where Ukrainian forces found bodies with signs of rape and torture, according to The Associated Press. â€œAsk, please, the representatives of Russia why the Russian military are so obsessed with castration,â€ Zelenskyy said. â€œWhat was done to them so that they want to do this to others?â€ Ukraine accused Russia of â€œnuclear terrorismâ€ after it said a Russian missile struck near a nuclear power plant in southern Ukraine on Monday. â€œRussian radiation blackmailing is something that should concern each and every one of you, because none of you will find a vaccine against radiation sickness,â€ Zelenskyy warned. Russia is due to address the U.N. General Assembly later this week, but Putin wonâ€™t attend, according to AP.

Title: 'Postcards From Ukraine' Project Shows Devastation To Ukraine Culture By Russian Invasion
Text: More than six months after the Russian invasion of Ukraine started, with thousands dead and many cities demolished, one organization is keeping track of another aspect lost in the war â€• Ukrainian cultural sites. The Ukrainian Instituteâ€™s â€œPostcards from Ukraineâ€ project documents before-and-after images of historic sites and buildings damaged by Russian troops, combining them to show the dramatic contrast between the past and present. The organization is encouraging people to share the postcards on social media in order to record the damage done to these Ukrainian landmarks.
