Title: Biden Rebukes Russia For Violating â€˜Core Tenetsâ€™ Of UN With Aggression
Text: President Joe Biden made a strong rebuke of Russiaâ€™s war against Ukraine on Wednesday, telling the United Nations that the country has violated the â€œcore tenetsâ€ of the charter with its aggression. â€œLet us speak plainly: A permanent member of the United Nations Security Council invaded its neighbor and attempted to erase a sovereign state from the map,â€ Biden told the General Assembly, adding that the war was â€œchosen by one man, to be very blunt. â€œRussia has shamelessly violated the core tenets of the United Nations Charter.â€ Biden mentioned Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s announcement on Wednesday of a partial mobilization to call up 300,000 reservists in response to Ukrainian forces retaking control of large stretches of territory near Kharkiv. Putin also announced plans to hold referendums to annex Russian-occupied regions in eastern and southern Ukraine, and accused the West of engaging in â€œnuclear blackmail.â€ The reservist announcement has led to Russians rushing to book one-way flights out of the country while they still could. â€œThe world should see these outrageous acts for what they are. Putin claimed he had to act because Russia was threatened â€“ but no one threatened Russia, and no one other than Russia sought conflict,â€ Biden said, adding that Ukraine now faces taxes on schools, railway stations, hospitals, and attacks on centers of Ukrainian history and culture. Biden also mentioned the latest evidence of Russiaâ€™s war crimes: a mass grave discovered earlier this month in the recently liberated northeastern Ukrainian city of Izyum. Investigators found over 440 men, women and children at the grave, their bodies showing signs of torture. Ukrainian authorities said they also found evidence of â€œtorture chambersâ€ in the Kharkiv region that Russia had occupied. â€œThis war is about extinguishing Ukraineâ€™s right to exist as a state, plain and simple, and Ukraineâ€™s right to exist as a people,â€ Biden told the U.N. â€œWherever you are, wherever you live, whatever you believe â€“ that should make your blood run cold. â€œBecause if nations can pursue their imperial ambitions without consequences, then we put at risk everything this very institution stands for.â€ In his remarks, Biden announced that the United States would provide $2.9 billion to support strengthening global food security, which he said is at risk due to the climate crisis, the pandemic and the consequences of Russiaâ€™s invasion. According to the president, about 193 million people around the world experience acute food insecurity â€“ an increase of 40 million from last year. â€œRussia, in the meantime, is pumping out lies trying to pin the blame for the food crisis on the sanctions imposed by many in the world for the aggression against Ukraine,â€ Biden said. â€œSo let me be perfectly clear about something: Our sanctions explicitly allow Russia the ability to export food and fertilizer, no limitation. Itâ€™s Russiaâ€™s war thatâ€™s worsening food insecurity, and only Russia can end it.â€

Title: 2 U.S. Veterans Held By Russian-Backed Forces In Ukraine Freed In Prisoner Swap
Text: Two U.S. veterans held for months by Russian-backed forces in Ukraine were freed as part of a prisoner swap, Saudi Arabia, which brokered the deal, said Wednesday. Alexander Drueke and Andy Tai Huynh were released alongside eight other prisoners of war, including citizens from the U.K., Morocco, Sweden and Croatia. Drueke, a former Army staff sergeant who served in Iraq, and Huynh, a former Marine, were captured near the Ukrainian border city of Kharkiv in June. The pair had traveled from Alabama to fight against invading Russian forces. The Saudi Foreign Ministry said that the prisoner swap was brokered by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. The country added that itâ€™s also working to repatriate all the POWs. Itâ€™s unclear who was released to Russia as part of the deal. Dianna Shaw, Druekeâ€™s aunt, told The Washington Post on Wednesday that his mother had spoken to him for about 10 minutes after his release. â€œHe sounded clearheaded, with clear speech,â€ Shaw told the paper. â€œHe sounded like himself.â€ The prisoner exchange came at a pivotal moment in the Kremlinâ€™s invasion. Russian President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday said he would call up about 300,000 reserve troops to bolster his countryâ€™s ongoing attack. The effort comes amid staggering losses for the Russians as its seven-month assault drags on. British Prime Minister Liz Truss thanked Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelenskyy and the Saudis for releasing the U.K. prisoners, saying the exchange had ended â€œmonths of uncertainty and suffering for them and their families.â€ â€œHugely welcome news that five British nationals held by Russian-backed proxies in eastern Ukraine are being safely returned,â€ she tweeted. â€œRussia must end the ruthless exploitation of prisoners of war and civilian detainees for political ends.â€ Hugely welcome news that five British nationals held by Russian-backed proxies in eastern Ukraine are being safely returned, ending months of uncertainty and suffering for them and their families.

Title: Russian Cosmonaut Valery Polyakov Who Broke Record With 437-Day Stay In Space Dies At 80
Text: Dr. Valery Polyakov, a physician-turned-cosmonaut who spent 437 days in outer space and set the world record, died at 80. Russian space agency Roscosmos announced his death on Monday without disclosing the cause or location. â€œHis research helped prove that the human body is ready for flights not only to near-Earth orbit, but also to deep space,â€ Roscosmos wrote in a Telegram post. â€œWe express our deepest condolences to the relatives and friends of Valery Vladimirovich.â€ He was born Valery Ivanovich Korshunov on April 27, 1942, but changed his name after being adopted in 1957, according to the New Mexico Museum of Space History. Polyakov began as a physician and joined the Institute of Biomedical Problems in Moscow in 1971, according to CNN. After undergoing spaceflight training to demonstrate he could administer assistance to fellow astronauts in orbit and passing his exams in 1972, Polyakov became one of the first doctor-cosmonaut trainees in history. He earned his Candidate of Medical Sciences degree in 1976. Polyakovâ€™s first lengthy space mission in 1988 lasted eight months, and he became deputy director of the institute he once joined as a young man upon returning back to Earth. It was his second and final mission, however, that made history. Now a specialist in the nascent field of space medicine, Polyakov volunteered to prove human beings could withstand microgravity and reach Mars, according to Wired. His flight to dock with Russiaâ€™s Mir space station launched on Jan. 8, 1994 â€” and Polyakov didnâ€™t return until March 22, 1995. Polyakov orbited Earth 7,075 times and traveled around 187 million miles during those 14 months â€” during which millions of people back on Earth had marveled at the launch of the Netscape Navigator internet browser, the opening of the English Channel Tunnel and O.J. Simpsonâ€™s high-speed police chase. According to â€œThe Story of Manned Space Stationsâ€ by Philip Baker, American astronaut Norman Thagard said Polyakov returned to Earth â€œbig and strongâ€ and looked â€œlike he could wrestle a bear.â€ Polyakov exercised during his mission and refused assistance upon landing, opting to walk on his own. â€œWhen his capsule landed in Kazakhstan he walked from it to a nearby chair, a tremendous achievement,â€ wrote Baker. â€œHe also stole a cigarette from a friend nearby, but could hardly be blamed for that. He sipped a small brandy and inwardly celebrated his mission.â€ While NASA astronauts Scott Kelly and Mark Vande Hei respectively spent 340 and 355 consecutive days in space and Peggy Whitson spent 665 cumulative days in space, the consecutive 437-day stay accomplished by Valery Polyakov remains unprecedented. â€œHis record still stands today,â€ wrote Baker, â€œand it is unlikely to be broken until man ventures to Mars.â€

Title: â€˜Beautiful And Sad At The Same Timeâ€™: Ukrainian Cultural Festival Takes On A Deeper Meaning This Year
Text: SILVER SPRING, Md. â€” For some, itâ€™s hearing air raid sirens while talking with relatives back in Ukraine. For others, itâ€™s the fear that Ukraine may become an economic basket case, even if it wins the war. Or that the world may forget the countryâ€™s plight altogether. Ukrainans, their friends and those simply curious about the country thatâ€™s fought Russia to standstill gathered on a sun-splashed weekend at St. Andrew Ukrainian Orthodox Cathedral in suburban Washington for the regionâ€™s biggest annual Ukrainian cultural festival. Amid women wearing garlands in their hair, men wearing vyshyvanka â€” white shirts with intricately patterned embroidery down the front â€” and accompanied by traditional and pop Ukrainian music, the war was never far from peopleâ€™s minds. What in past years had been a chance to showcase the culture and drink some beers from the home country had taken on a different, somewhat deeper meaning. â€œThis year is particularly beautiful and sad at the same time,â€ said the church pastor, the Rev. Volodymr Steliac, as he formally opened the festival Saturday. â€œWe have seen the worst of humanity but at the same time we have seen the best of humanity.â€ The festival opened on Day 206 of the invasion and came amid good news for Ukraine: a surprise counteroffensive in the northeast that in a few days cleared Russians from towns and villages they had fought weeks to take earlier in the war. But the victory came with a price. In the strategic town of Izium, mass graves were found, similar to those seen in the capital Kyivâ€™s suburb of Bucha when the war began. â€œWe have seen the worst of humanity but at the same time we have seen the best of humanity.â€ Oksana Sukhina, who was staffing the booth of the U.S. Ukraine Foundation, where she is project director, said she wanted to see what the impact of the latest reports of atrocities will be on Europe. In the past, she said, some people suspected Ukrainians have exaggerated the cruelty of the Russians with reports of horrific claims like rape as a weapon of war and the theft of household goods then shipped to Russia. â€œThen you see Bucha, you see now Izyum. And we have yet to see Kherson and Mariupol and other places,â€ Sukhina said. Sukhina, 50, immigrated to the U.S. from Kyiv in 2020. Warned by former colleagues in the State Department about the likelihood of invasion, her parents arrived in Washington only days before the war. But as the prospect of Kyivâ€™s being captured receded, they went back, as did one of her daughters. They joined a 23-year-old son who left his IT job in Chicago in March to help deliver food and medical supplies in Kyiv. Sukhina said she tried to convince him to stay, but could not forbid him to leave because she had participated in pro-democracy protests in 2004 and 2014. â€œIâ€™m proud of them. They are trying to do whatever they can. And this is what makes us win,â€ she said. Steliac said the church was open 24-7 when the war began. He was only getting two or three hours of sleep a night as volunteers dropped off humanitarian aid, organized it and shipped it to Ukraine. In one 48-hour period, he said, two of those young volunteers lost their fathers back in Ukraine. â€œThe war is not there alone; the war is here as well,â€ Steliac said. Even though the process of gathering and sending aid has become more routine, even keeping in touch with family back home, he said, can be painful. â€œWhat was traumatic was that they were communicating with their relatives and they said, â€˜Oh, a bomb fell just a couple of neighborhoods overâ€™ and then they tried to connect again and the phone connection doesnâ€™t go through,â€ Steliac said. â€œYou think of the worst.â€ Alex Naumovych, a 36-year old mortgage loan officer from Ternopil in the western part of Ukraine, said heâ€™s had calls interrupted by the air raid sirens, although now he said the alarms are likely to be ignored. Ternopil, a city of about 250,000, has no military targets, but he said his parents still hear the sirens daily. Ukraine tracks incoming missiles and activates local warning systems based on where they could potentially land, so even residents of cities not targeted are warned. â€œIâ€™m worried that, sooner or later, one of those missiles may hit my city, like my parentsâ€™ place,â€ Naumovych said. Naumovych arrived in the U.S. almost 11 years ago. He had about $440 to his name then, he said, and started a landscaping business he sold years later for more than $1 million. â€œIâ€™m worried that, sooner or later, one of those missiles may hit my city, like my parentsâ€™ place.â€ â€œI love this country. Like you can come with $400 and six, seven years later you can be a millionaire,â€ he said. One of his big worries for Ukraine now is its economy, with so many people out of work because of the war and inflation projected to hit 30%. â€œThe economy is in bad shape,â€ Naumovych said. â€œA lot of people left Ukraine and Iâ€™m not sure theyâ€™re coming backâ€ The parents of software engineer Serhiy Vorobiov, 43, are near the warâ€™s front line in Zaporizhzhya, a Russian-speaking region that includes Europeâ€™s largest nuclear power plant. Russia has captured the plant and Ukrainians and others fear they will use it for blackmail. But Vorobiov said his parents, only 25 miles from the front lines in the city of Zaporizhzhya, still think everything is relatively safe. He said he chats with them with about the same frequency as before the war. â€œMaybe because there is no very high emergency at this point. I know itâ€™s not to my defense, but thatâ€™s how it is,â€ he said. Vorobiov, his wife Oksana, 33, and their three young children, Yaromyr, Myroslava and Oksana, have lived in the U.S. since 2020. He said the war has reinforced his belief in getting rid of any Russian influence on their upbringing. â€œI always dreamed of it, I just didnâ€™t want to be very tough in that. But now I have all the rights and I want to use it,â€ Vorobiov said. â€œI want them to forget [the] Russian language. We are from [the] Russian-speaking part of Ukraine, but now we are fixing it, as much as we can. Forget Russian, forget we were ever together, [forget] Soviet Union. Iâ€™m happy they donâ€™t know what Soviet Union is.â€ But in her remarks to open the festivities, Oksana Markarova, the Ukrainian ambassador to the United States, advised focusing on the present, not the past. â€œPlease be joyful today,â€ she counseled. She said Russian leader Vladimir Putin and the Russians want Ukrainians to â€œsit down and cryâ€ at the devastation. â€œThis is what Russians want us to do. And we will not give it to them.â€

Title: Russia Recruits Convicts For War Due To 'Increasingly Severe' Manpower Shortage, UK Says
Text: Russia is being forced to recruit prison inmates due to an â€œincreasingly severeâ€ manpower shortage, according to the U.K. Ministry of Defense. Inmates are being offered cash payments and having their sentences commuted to persuade them to sign up for the war in Ukraine. The news comes after Ukraine re-took large parts of previously occupied land in the north and east of the country in what many see as a potential turning point in the war. According to the latest MoD intelligence update, Kremlin-linked private military company the Wagner Group is carrying out the prison recruitment drive. They said the scheme was first launched in July, but has now been â€œreinvigoratedâ€ as Moscow continues to suffer major losses in the war. Latest Defence Intelligence update on the situation in Ukraine - 16 September 2022 Find out more about the UK government's response: #StandWithUkraine ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦  The MoD said: â€œPrisoners have been offered commutation of their sentences as well as cash incentives. â€œThis has been reinvigorated, with recently posted video highly likely showing Wagner owner Yevgeny Prigozhin making a recruitment pitch to prisoners. In the video, Prigozhin emphasises that he is only seeking â€˜fighters for assault units.â€™â€ In a further sign of Russiaâ€™s need to get more troops to the frontline, the MoD said Moscowâ€™s military academies â€œare shortening training courses and bringing cadets graduation dates forwards.â€ â€œThis is almost certainly so cadets can be deployed to support the Ukraine operation,â€ they said. â€œThe impact of Russiaâ€™s manpower challenge has become increasingly severe. â€œThe acceleration of officer cadetsâ€™ training, and Wagnerâ€™s demand for assault troops suggests that two of the most critical shortages within the military manning crisis are probably combat infantry and junior commanders.â€

Title: Russian Energy Executive Found Dead Near Vladivostok In Mysterious Circumstances
Text: A 39-year-old Russian energy executive was found dead after reportedly falling off his boat near Vladivostok over the weekend, adding to a string of mysterious deaths associated with the countryâ€™s energy industry. Ivan Pechorin, the managing director of the Corporation for the Development of the Far East and the Arctic, is the ninth Russian businessperson to die by suicide or in mysterious circumstances since January, and is among six deaths affiliated with the countryâ€™s energy sector, according to CNN. Pechorin reportedly fell off his boat close to Russky Island near Cape Ignatiev, the British Metro newspaper reported, citing Russian daily Komsomolskaya Pravda. â€œIvanâ€™s death is an irreparable loss for friends and colleagues, a great loss for the corporation. We offer our sincere condolences to family and friends,â€ the company said in a statement, according to the English translation. Pechorin attended the Eastern Economic Forum headlined by Russian President Vladimir Putin last week, where he was listed as a panelist and moderator for two discussions around strengthening aviation accessibility and airport infrastructure in the Far East and Arctic. Pechorinâ€™s company was tasked with developing the Arctic, a vast source of gas and oil for Russia, according to British newspaper Mirror. Pechorinâ€™s boss, CEO Igor Nosov, 43, died suddenly in February after a stroke, Mirror reported. Another Russian executive, Ravil Maganov, who chaired Russiaâ€™s second-largest oil company Lukoil, died after falling out a window at Central Clinical Hospital in Moscow earlier this month, The Guardian reported, citing the Interfax news agency. Lukoil said Maganov died â€œfollowing a severe illness.â€ Lukoil previously criticized Putinâ€™s war in Ukraine, and in March called for an end to the conflict. â€œWe strongly support a lasting ceasefire and a settlement of problems through serious negotiations and diplomacy,â€ the companyâ€™s board said in a statement a week after Putin invaded Ukraine. Former Lukoil executive Alexander Subbotin was found dead at the house of a shaman in May, Newsweek reported, citing Russian local media. Other Russian executives who have died in recent months include Sergey Protosenya, who worked for Russian energy company Novatek; Vladislav Avaev, the former vice president of bank Gazprombank; and Alexander Tyulyakov, Gazpromâ€™s deputy general director of the Unified Settlement Center for Corporate Security, according to Newsweek. Meanwhile, Ukraineâ€™s president visited the recaptured city of Izyum on Wednesday as his countryâ€™s counteroffensive in northeastern Ukraine continues routing Russian troops, according to The Associated Press. U.S. officials have been cautious against premature excitement over Ukraineâ€™s success, AP said.

Title: War Put Ukraineâ€™s Biggest Nuclear Plant At Risk. Will It Threaten Atomic Energyâ€™s Revival?
Text: In the early 2000s, with the threat of climate change coming into focus, the declining nuclear power industry, with its capacity to generate huge volumes of emission-free electricity, looked to be on the cusp of a revival. Then the 2011 disaster at the Fukushima atomic generating station in Japan stoked old fears that nuclear energy could never be safe enough. Japan mothballed its reactors. Germany fast-tracked shutting down its whole fleet. The U.S. gave up on its nuclear ambitions, abandoning its Yucca Mountain waste-disposal project and permanently closing dozens of safe but financially uncompetitive reactors. A decade later, soaring emissions, failing power grids and buckling renewable-energy supply chains are already setting the groundwork for a new nuclear power renaissance. Once Russian tanks rolled into Ukraine and gas markets became a key battleground in the global conflict, even anti-nuclear stalwarts started embracing atomic power. In a matter of weeks, Japan ordered its old plants reopened and new reactors built, Germany opened the door to keeping its remaining facilities running and California lawmakers voted to save the stateâ€™s last nuclear station. Now, though, battles raging around the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in southeastern Ukraine risk triggering the first major radiation accident since Fukushima, unleashing chaos in a war zone where Russia has already threatened to use atomic weapons. At present, crews have kept Europeâ€™s largest nuclear station running even as shells explode around its six reactors. On Sunday, Energoatom, Ukraineâ€™s state-owned nuclear operator, said it has powered down the plantâ€™s last operating reactor, reducing the risk of any kind of accident. But the International Atomic Energy Agency, the United Nationsâ€™ nuclear watchdog, warned Friday that the situation was â€œunsustainableâ€ and â€œbecoming increasingly precariousâ€ after shelling in a neighboring town destroyed electrical infrastructure that the plant depends on as a backup to keep its cooling systems running. â€œThis is completely unacceptable,â€ IAEA chief Rafael Grossi said in a video statement. â€œIt cannot stand.â€ If the worst happens, would a disaster at Europeâ€™s largest nuclear plant prove a setback for an industry whose nascent comeback could make quitting fossil fuels much easier? There is no obvious answer, in part because the scale of any radiation leak resulting from something as unpredictable as artillery combat is impossible to predict. An accident would almost certainly temper demand for nuclear power in some places; citing just the potential for a disaster, Greenpeace urged the European Union to disqualify reactors from green energy funding. But experts in the industry say that what happens in Ukraine is unlikely to derail most countriesâ€™ newfound atomic ambitions. â€œI donâ€™t see one incident that I can imagine that is going to turn back the tide or flip the coin on nuclear,â€ said Craig Piercy, chief executive of the nonprofit American Nuclear Society. â€œA military-driven destruction of something is not going to sour people. Frankly, I feel like the support is building and itâ€™s durable.â€ Attitudes toward nuclear energy vary by country. In Finland, where reactors generate a huge chunk of the countryâ€™s electricity, support for atomic energy is exceptionally high. In the United States, separate surveys over the past year from the pollsters Ipsos, Gallup and the Pew Research Center show Americans are split on fission. In Germany, where the government has pursued one of the worldâ€™s most aggressive nuclear phaseouts, a major national poll in August found that only 15% of Germans supported the current plan, suggesting a major divide between the country and its leaders. But the relationship between public opinion and the past nuclear accidents isnâ€™t as direct as it may seem. After each of the worldâ€™s three major nuclear power disasters â€• the 1979 partial meltdown at Pennsylvaniaâ€™s Three Mile Island, the 1986 Chernobyl catastrophe and the earthquake and tsunami at Fukushima â€• it took three years for public support for atomic energy to drop, according to an analysis of polling data released last year. While politicians in Germany and South Korea moved swiftly to shutter nuclear plants after the most recent accident in Japan, a study by Ann Bisconti, a longtime nuclear industry consultant whose surveys have tracked public opinion on atomic energy for decades, found that support for nuclear energy dropped well after the disasters as a result of shifting politics around energy, namely that the demand for new reactors decreased because the global supply of fossil fuels increased. â€œWhat happened was the need for nuclear energy was the driver of public attitudes, not the accidents,â€ Bisconti said. â€œIf thereâ€™s a strong need, I think the same may be true now.â€ Over the past seven decades, atom-splitting reactors have safely generated stupendous sums of electricity in more than 30 countries â€• with few exceptions. Just four people died from radiation in three of the four worst accidents in the history of nuclear energy. But the 1986 Chernobyl meltdown, about 500 miles north of the Zaporizhzhia plant, irradiated a vast area and caused a spike of thousands of cases of thyroid cancer, making the stakes of a full-scale nuclear disaster easy for anyone with an HBO subscription to visualize. Experts caution that a repeat of the Soviet-era disaster is nearly impossible and that artillery hitting other industrial facilities, such as chemical plants, could do as much if not more damage. The reactors at the so-called ZNPP are differently designed machines altogether, devoid of the features that doomed Chernobyl. Unlike Chernobylâ€™s â€œfundamentally unstableâ€ reactors, virtually all modern reactors, including those at ZNPP, are â€œdesigned to operate in a stable state,â€ according to Jaakko LeppÃ¤nen, a researcher and expert in reactor safety in Finland, which generates much of its electricity from fission. â€œThis means that the energy-producing chain reaction is a self-regulating process that does not require external control or special adjustment measures to maintain it,â€ LeppÃ¤nen wrote in a recent blog post, translated from Finnish using Google software. â€œThe power of the reactor cannot start increasing without reason. Even in the event of a disturbance, the chain reaction breaks off by itself when the temperature rises high enough.â€ Shutting down a nuclear reactor is no simple task. The reactor fuel continues to produce residual heat that requires active cooling systems, which usually circulate cold water. If the electricity powering those systems fails â€• as happened in Fukushima, when the tsunami destroyed backup generators â€• â€œthe result can be overheating and melting of the fuel,â€ LeppÃ¤nen said. â€œThese backup systems are in a way also the institutionâ€™s weak point,â€ LeppÃ¤nen wrote. â€œDamage to a single device or system does not on its own endanger the cooling of the reactor, but if the plant is deliberately destroyed, the risk is the simultaneous loss of all electrical systems.â€ Even then, the ZNPP reactors have something Chernobyl lacked: a thick concrete dome enclosure over the reactors themselves. After five years, spent fuel, which remains dangerously radioactive for thousands of years, is moved outside the dome to air-cooled storage systems called dry casks. Long-cooled fuel produces less heat, and many of its most dangerous radionuclides, such as iodine-131, have already had time to disappear through radioactive decay, LeppÃ¤nen wrote. But a direct missile strike could cause radiation to leak into waterways. The Russians and Ukrainians blame each other for continuing the shelling. Tea TÃ¶rmÃ¤nen, a pro-nuclear environmental advocate in Finland, said that â€œitâ€™s not in anyoneâ€™s interest to damage the plants.â€ â€œTo the Russians, itâ€™s an asset, so destroying them wouldnâ€™t make sense, and itâ€™d mostly harm the soldiers in the area,â€ she said. A Russian attempt to permanently annex the facility could be another potential threat. For now, the plant depends on power systems Ukraine controls to safely operate. In an Aug. 25 interview with the U.S. government-funded Voice of America news service, an anonymous engineer at the ZNPP accused the Russians of wanting â€œto arrange a small accident and stop ZNPP for a short time, then supply us with electricity from Crimea and automatically switch the nuclear power plant to the Russian energy system.â€ Calling that a â€œvery dangerous plan,â€ the engineer said the â€œRussians have not touched the management of the nuclear power plant, although I think it will happen soon. The pressure is getting stronger.â€ Last week, shelling in the neighboring city of Enerhodar, where much of the ZNPPâ€™s staff and their families live, destroyed the electrical infrastructure and caused a total blackout, which left the plant reliant on the lone reactor that had been running until Sunday. But the IAEA said â€œoperating a reactor at low power is not a sustainable solution for a longer period because it could over time damage key equipment of the nuclear power plant, such as electricity-producing turbines and pumps.â€ While a backup power line to the Ukrainian grid was eventually restored on Sunday, the uncertain connection means the plant will depend on its 20 diesel generators to keep systems running if thereâ€™s another blackout. â€œWe are trying to keep this unit running as much as possible, but eventually it will have to be shut down and then the station will switch to diesel generators,â€ Petro Kotin, head of Energoatom, told The Associated Press on Thursday, adding that such generators are â€œthe stationâ€™s last defense before a radiation accident.â€ A controlled nuclear accident at ZNPP would be unlikely to upend the nuclear industryâ€™s revival plans, said Najmedin Meshkati, a University of Southern California nuclear engineering expert who studied the Fukushima catastrophe. After years of struggling to build large-scale reactors on time and on budget, the U.S. and other countries are banking on the commercialization of small modular reactors, scaled-down fission machines that can be manufactured to be safer and less expensive. The novelty of the technology could offer an industry dogged by bad perceptions a chance to rebrand. Recalling a conversation with the late Hungarian chemist George Olah, Meshkati quoted the Nobel laureate as saying, â€œYou guys in the nuclear industry, youâ€™re not as smart as doctors.â€ Asked why, Olah told him: â€œMRI technology used to be called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging. But the medical industry dropped the nuclear part from the name. Itâ€™s just MRI.â€ That, Meshkati said, represented â€œexactly the transformation that will happen in public relationsâ€ once the small modular reactor industry takes off. Nuclear safety regulators in the U.S. and elsewhere are currently assessing various so-called SMR applications. Industry analysts generally suggest the sector could become viable in the early 2030s. But humans tend to â€œoverreact to extreme risks and underestimate slower-moving, less dramatic risks,â€ said Rich Sorkin, chief executive of Jupiter Intelligence, a U.S.-based consultancy that models climate risk. â€œItâ€™s not a surprise that thereâ€™s a phrase â€˜If it bleeds, it leads,â€™â€ he said. â€œThereâ€™s no question that a nuclear disaster is at the top of things that people would be focused on from a distance.â€ The pinch of soaring energy prices and the high probability of rationing fuel across Europe this winter are more likely to â€œtop everyoneâ€™s priorities right now,â€ TÃ¶rmÃ¤nen said. Anyway, she said, radiation is hardly the only potential disaster from warfare. â€œThere are many other chemical plants that are very dangerous if thereâ€™s a war, but nobodyâ€™s talking about ending the production of many chemicals that are very dangerous,â€ TÃ¶rmÃ¤nen said. â€œIt seems like a ridiculous idea that we plan our energy system in all countries based on what we would do if thereâ€™s a war in our country.â€ Bisconti, the nuclear industry consultant, said an accident may still prove a setback for nuclear energy in countries like Germany. â€œBut what countries decide to do versus public opinion are not necessarily the same thing,â€ she said.

Title: Gen. Milley Says Russia Has Failed To Meet Strategic Objectives But War Isn't Over
Text: Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Mark Milley said Thursday that Russia has failed to meet its strategic objectives in the first six months of President Vladimir Putinâ€™s brutal campaign against Ukraine. Speaking alongside Defense Secretary Austin Lloyd in Germany following a meeting of the Ukraine Defense Contact Group, the top general said the Ukrainian people have shown â€œsuperior tactical proficiencyâ€ and â€œa superior will to fight.â€ â€œThe war is not over, but so far, the Russian strategic objectives have been defeated,â€ Milley said. Milley added that the U.S. and other allies have helped supply Ukraine with the weapons systems it needs to defend itself, noting the detrimental effect this has had on Russiaâ€™s ability to continue fighting. â€œRussian lines of communication and supply channels are severely strained,â€ Milley said. He continued: â€œTheyâ€™re having great difficulty resupplying their forces and replacing their combat losses.â€ But Russia on Thursday disputed that Western weapons have helped Ukraine make progress, according to The Associated Press. â€œThe Russian army consistently, with minimal risk for its soldiers and civilians is destroying not only the old weaponry of Soviet models, which the Eastern European countries are discharging, but also the modern NATO weapons,â€ said Vassily Nebenzia, Russiaâ€™s ambassador to the United Nations. Milley also provided a rundown of the war, pointing to Russiaâ€™s early strategic failures after it invaded Ukraine on Feb. 24. â€œThey didnâ€™t seize the capital, they didnâ€™t topple the government, they didnâ€™t get to the Dnipro River, and they didnâ€™t seize Odesa,â€ Milley said, using the Ukrainian name for the Dnieper River. That forced Russian forces to pivot in mid-April and focus instead on seizing the Donbas and holding Odesa at risk, Milley explained. These efforts have also been unsuccessful, he said. â€œThey have only crossed the Dnipro River in the south, in the vicinity of Kherson,â€ Milley said, adding that at the start of this month the Ukrainians launched their own counteroffensive in the south. Austin on Friday told reporters that Ukraine has recently made progress in this operation. â€œWe see success in Kherson now. We see some success in Kharkiv, and so that is very, very encouraging,â€ Austin said, according to Reuters. The U.S. officials, though, were keen to emphasize that the conflict is far from over. â€œRussiaâ€™s a big country. They have very serious ambitions with respect to Ukraine. So sustainment of Ukraine to continue their fight for their survival will be necessary,â€ Milley said. Secretary of State Antony Blinken visited the Ukrainian capital Kyiv as the U.S. released a package of over $2 billion in military support to Ukraine and 18 neighboring countries threatened by Russian aggression, in addition to the $675 million Austin announced just for Ukraine, the AP reported.

Title: Ukraine's Defense Ministry Quotes Rapper Pusha T To Report Russian Combat Losses
Text: The Ukrainian Defense Ministry used a lyric from rapper Pusha T on Wednesday to announce current Russian casualties and equipment losses in the war. Since Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s troops invaded Ukraine in February, the Russian military has lost more than 50,000 troops, 4,500 armored combat vehicles and 2,000 tanks, according to the defense ministryâ€™s Twitter post. â€œI put numbers on the boards,â€ the post reads, tagging Pusha T. "I put numbers on the boards."@PUSHA_T Total combat losses of the enemy from Feb 24 to Sep 7:  The post is part of a broader effort by Ukraine to engage with popular culture to bolster its cause. That includes quips about casualties. On Tuesday, the defense ministry posted a similar update with the line â€œI see dead peopleâ€ from the movie â€œThe Sixth Sense.â€ Previously, the ministry has quoted songs by Queen, Bananarama and The Game, as well as references to movies like Rambo, The Big Lebowski, Pulp Fiction and celebs like Mike Tyson, according to NME.com. Pusha T responded to the tweet on Tuesday, writing, â€œGreat taste in music for the win...â€ Great taste in music for the winâ€¦

Title: Russian Oil Chief Dies In Fall From 6th Floor Window; Company Blames Death On 'Illness'
Text: Ravil Maganov, the chairman of the board of Lukoil â€” the second-largest oil company in Russia â€” died amid mysterious circumstances Thursday, according to The Daily Beast. State-owned news outlet Tass quoted sources that said he fell from a sixth-floor hospital window in Moscow. Tass later added that Maganov took his own life by jumping, according to the BBC. Lukoil omitted any mention of a fall in its news release and said Maganovâ€™s death at the Central Clinical Hospital resulted from underlying health issues he suffered. â€œWe deeply regret to announce that Ravil Maganov, Chairman of PJSC LUKOIL Board of Directors, passed away following a severe illness,â€ Lukoil wrote. â€œRavil Maganov immensely contributed to the development of not only the Company, but of the entire Russian oil and gas sector.â€ Russian news outlet RIA Novosti reported that the hospital confirmed Maganovâ€™s death and that authorities were investigating the matter. Tass cited an unnamed law enforcement official claiming Maganov had been hospitalized for a heart attack and was on antidepressants when he died, according to Bloomberg. Maganov joined Lukoil in 1993 and became chairman in 2020. His company notably condemned Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine and wrote in a February letter to shareholders that Lukoil supports â€œthe immediate cessation of the armed conflict,â€ according to the Daily Beast. The 67-year-old joins a substantial roster of Russian bankers and oil and gas executives who have died under suspicious circumstances this year. Lukoilâ€™s billionaire ex-manager Alexander Subbotin was found dead of an apparent heart attack in the home of a shaman in Mytishchi in May, according to Newsweek. Tass reported that voodoo rituals occurred at the home and that Subbotin was intoxicated when he died. Leonid Shulman â€” an executive at Russiaâ€™s third-largest bank, Gazprombank â€” was found dead at his Leningrad cottage in January of an apparent suicide, according to the New York Post. The next month, former Gazprombank executive Alexander Tyulyakov was found hanged in his St. Petersburg garage. Former vice president of Gazprombank, Vladislav Avayev, was found dead in April of a gunshot wound next to his wife and daughter at their Moscow home. Authorities said they suspected the incident was a murder-suicide. One day later, Sergei Protosenya â€” the wealthy ex-manager of Russiaâ€™s second-largest gas producer, Novatek â€” was found hanged in a Spanish villa. His wife and daughter were found dead with stab wounds. Investigators theorized the incident a murder-suicide as well. Russian President Vladimir Putin awarded Maganov with the Order of Alexander Nevsky at the Kremlin in 2019, according to EuroNews. Maganov leaves behind a family, including his brother Nail Ulfatovich Maganov, who is the CEO of Tatneft â€” a sizable Russian oil producer.

Title: Mikhail Gorbachev's 1998 Pizza Hut Ad Resurfaces After His Death
Text: Tuesdayâ€™s death of Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev, the Soviet Unionâ€™s last leader, is bringing new attention to his accomplishments â€• and his 1998 Pizza Hut commercial. Yes, after the end of the Cold War, the former Russian leader chose to sell hot pizza as a way to raise money for a research foundation, according to a 1997 CNN article. â€œIâ€™m in the process of creating a library and a perestroika archive, and this project requires certain funds,â€ Gorbachev said at the time. â€œPerestroika (restructuring) gave impetus to Russia and to the whole world. It is very important that everything that happened be preserved in these two centers.â€ While Gorbachev didnâ€™t confirm how much he was paid, sources claimed he was reportedly paid nearly $1 million to do the advertisement, according to The New York Times. The commercial, which shows him dining at a Pizza Hut with his granddaughter Anastasia, debuted all over the world. However, in Russia Gorbachev was still unpopular at the time and the ad was not aired despite it being filmed in Moscow, The New York Times reported. Negotiations between Pizza Hut and Gorbachev took a bit of time because while he was willing to take the dough for the ad, he said â€œnyetâ€ to eating the pizza on camera, according to reports. Hence, the casting of his granddaughter, who willingly chowed down on a slice to appease Pizza Hut executives, according to a 2019 deep dive into the commercial by Foreign Policy. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, initially feared doing commercials would harm his reputation. But he ended up also doing a 2007 magazine ad for Louis Vuitton where heâ€™s sitting in a car next to remaining parts of the Berlin Wall. HuffPost reached out to Pizza Hut for comment, but no one immediately responded. Many Twitter users, on the other hand, had tons of saucy comments about Gorbachevâ€™s Pizza Hut past. My generation knew Communism was dead when we saw Gorbachev in a Pizza Hut commercial. Last few decades must have been awfully lonely and strange for Gorbachev. Also, apologies in advance if I caused you to learn of Gorbachev's death via a Pizza Hut ad The best way to honor the death of Mikhail Gorbachev would be for Pizza Hut to return to its 90s decor  "I'm at the Pizza Hut, I'm at the Taco Bell...I'm at Gorbachev's funeral at the combination Pizza Hut and Taco Bell" Under Gorbachev Russia got to taste Pizza Hut and KFC.Under Putin, Pizza Hut and KFC left. R.I.P. Mikhail Gorbachev (1931â€“2022). He may have been unable to prevent the USSR collapsing, but he did help @pizzahut sell pizza.  But one person felt obligated to remind the world that Gorbachev isnâ€™t the only world leader who shilled for Pizza Hut. Yep, Donald Trump did too! Lots of people retweeting the Pizza Hut commercial that Gorbachev was in. However, did you know Trump did one too?

Title: Fox News Host Quickly Comes To Russia's Defense By Shutting Down His Own Guest
Text: Fox News host Jesse Watters swiftly shut down his own guestâ€™s national security concerns on the documents discovered at former President Donald Trumpâ€™s Mar-a-Lago estate earlier this month. Watters spoke to Ronald Kessler, a former investigative reporter at The Washington Post and a writer of several books related to matters of intelligence and politics, during his show on Thursday. Kessler detailed the â€œbeyond top secret, beyond sensitive compartmentedâ€ nature of the classified documents. He said it could very well include plans for counter-striking against Russia in the event of a nuclear attack. Kessler added that Russians â€œvery possiblyâ€ recruited spies to get the documents. Watters, however, smirked at his guestâ€™s take and wasnâ€™t having any of it. â€œRon, youâ€™re saying that they could be there. We have no idea if theyâ€™re there or not and weâ€™ll never know,â€ Watters replied. The host then launched an attack on federal officialsâ€™ intent. You can catch a clip of Wattersâ€™ shutdown below. Iâ€™m not sure they expected their own guest to say this

Title: Boris Johnson Makes Surprise Visit To Kyiv On Ukraine's Independence Day
Text: U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has made a surprise visit to Kyiv on Ukraineâ€™s independence day. The country is celebrating 31 years since it declared independence from the Soviet Union. It is also six months since Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine started. The British prime minister shared a photograph of himself alongside President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and tweeted: â€œWhat happens in Ukraine matters to us all. â€œThat is why I am in Kyiv today. That is why the UK will continue to stand with our Ukrainian friends. â€œI believe Ukraine can and will win this war.â€ What happens in Ukraine matters to us all. That is why I am in Kyiv today. That is why the UK will continue to stand with our Ukrainian friends.I believe Ukraine can and will win this war.  Zelenskyy has vowed to fight against Vladimir Putinâ€™s invasion â€œuntil the endâ€ and pledged he would not make â€œany concession or compromiseâ€ to end the conflict. â€œWe donâ€™t care what army you have, we only care about our land. We will fight for it until the end,â€ Zelenskyy said in a video address on Wednesday. The history of Ukraine's independence is quite dramatic and inspiring. Ukrainian nation was fighting for centuries and continues to do so since Feb 24. Devotion, bravery, freedom. Our land - our independence. Brief historic update by @United24media:  Back in London, Downing Street is adorned with sunflowers, the national flower of Ukraine, to mark the occasion. Johnsonâ€™s visit comes amid concerns that European support for Ukraineâ€™s battle against Russia could dry up amid the cost of living crisis. The Telegraph reported that U.K. diplomats have been travelling to European capitals to make the case against cutting aid to Kyiv.

Title: Senators Call On Blinken To Classify U.S. Teacher Held In Russia As 'Wrongfully Detained'
Text: A bipartisan group of U.S. senators on Tuesday urged Secretary of State Antony Blinken to designate an American teacher sentenced to 14 years in prison in Russia as â€œwrongfully detained.â€ Marc Fogel, a longtime educator, was arrested in August 2021 at a Russian airport after local authorities found 17 grams of medical marijuana in his belongings. Fogel was on his way back to Russia to teach at the Anglo-American School in Moscow. In June, he was sentenced to 14 years in a maximum-security Russian penal colony. â€œThe United States cannot stand by as Mr. Fogel wastes away in a Russian hard labor camp,â€ the senators wrote in a letter to Blinken. The letter was first reported by CNN. The lawmakers added that the punishment doesnâ€™t fit the crime, explaining medical marijuana was recommended to Fogel as a treatment for chronic pain. â€œThough Mr. Fogel did violate Russian law by bringing 17 grams of marijuana to the country, his sentence is grossly disproportionate to similar cases,â€ the letter reads. â€œAs Russian lawyers have pointed out, the most common sentence in similar cases is five years of probation. Drug traffickers who have committed much worse offenses have received shorter sentences.â€ The nine senators include: Bob Casey (D-Pa.), Pat Toomey (R-Pa.); Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), Jon Tester (D-Mont.), Steve Daines (R-Mont), John Hickenlooper (D-Colo.), Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.), Shelly Moore Capito (R-W.Va.), and Tim Kaine (D-Va.). The bipartisan group argued Fogel was being â€œused as a political pawnâ€ by Russian President Vladimir Putin, adding the educator qualifies for the â€œwrongfully detainedâ€ classification by meeting six of the 11 criteria, including â€œbeing detained substantially because he is a U.S. citizen.â€ The senators also referred to the efforts the White House has made to secure the release of WNBA star Brittney Griner, who was sentenced to nine years in prison on drug possession charges after she was arrested for carrying cannabis oil in vape containers in her suitcase at a Moscow airport in February. Her lawyers appealed her sentence on Aug. 15. Blinken offered Russia a prisoner exchange deal to trade Griner and former U.S. Marine Paul Whelan for Russian drug dealer Viktor Bout. Both Griner and Whelan have been designated as â€œwrongfully detained.â€ Earlier this month, Russian news agency TASS reported talks were underway. â€œFogelâ€™s case warrants the same degree of political attention and diplomatic intervention,â€ the senators said. Last month, John Kirby, the national security council coordinator for strategic communications at the White House, did not directly answer a question on why Fogel was not part of the proposed deal. â€œWeâ€™re focused on all Americans who are held hostage and wrongfully detained around the world. What weâ€™re talking about with this particular proposal is for those two individuals,â€ Kirby said, referring to Griner and Whelan. â€œThat doesnâ€™t mean that weâ€™re not also working in real-time on other Americans who are unjustly detained around the world,â€ he continued. Fogelâ€™s niece Kelly Leguineche told CBS News their family was not given a clear answer by the State Department as to why Fogel hasnâ€™t been designated as â€œwrongfully detained,â€ or why he was not part of the exchange deal. â€œItâ€™s devastating because it feels like this was our last opportunity to save his life, and we just couldnâ€™t get the momentum we needed for it to matter to them,â€ Leguineche said. Fogel was teaching in Russia for the past nine years and previously worked in other countries around the world including Malaysia, Mexico, Colombia,Oman and Venezuela.

Title: Steven Seagal Promotes Russian Claims That Ukraine Killed Its Own POWs
Text: Actor Steven Seagal, an outspoken supporter of Russian President Vladimir Putin who has become an official Kremlin representative, visited a prison where at least 53 Ukrainian prisoners of war were killed in disputed circumstances last month to promote Russiaâ€™s version. The actor, who became a special representative for Russiaâ€™s foreign ministry in 2018, toured the ruins of Olenivka prison in Donetsk, Ukraine, on Tuesday for state-controlled media outlet TVZvezda, according to Insider. Footage showed Seagal repeating Russian propaganda talking points at the Russian-occupied site. The Kremlin has alleged Ukraine destroyed the prison with HIMARS rockets provided by the United States. Ukraine has said Russian shelling destroyed the site and called the attack a war crime. â€œThis is where HIMARS hit, 50 people were killed, another 70 were injured,â€ Seagal said. â€œIt definitely looks like a rocket. If you look at the burning and other details, of course, itâ€™s not a bomb. Not to mention the fact that Russia really has a lot of artifacts from HIMARS.â€ Military experts said thereâ€™s no evidence supporting the claim that U.S. rockets caused the destruction, according to The Washington Post. Seagal also called the dead Olenivka prisoners â€œNazisâ€ and alleged Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy himself destroyed the facility to kill one of the inmates, according to New York Post. The â€œGlimmer Manâ€ actor, who developed a friendship with Putin after obtaining Russian citizenship in 2016, has no expertise in rocketry or forensics. Heâ€™s recording his visits to sites like Olenivka for an upcoming documentary. Seagal, whose official title is special representative of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, was given access to the prison even before the International Red Cross Committee, according to The Moscow Times. U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has said the U.N. had been promised Russia and Ukraine would cooperate in the investigation of Olenivka.

Title: GOP Suddenly Not OK With Using Power Of The State To Go After Political Opponents
Text: Republicans defended former President Donald Trump when he reportedly attempted to use the power of the U.S. presidency to extort Ukraine into smearing then-presidential candidate Joe Biden in the middle of the 2020 presidential campaign, acquitting him during his first Senate impeachment trial. Now, GOP lawmakers and conservative commentators are up in arms about the FBI raid on Trumpâ€™s home in Florida on Monday, accusing Biden of personally directing the Department of Justice to go after his political opponents. The White House repeatedly denied that Biden had any involvement or knowledge of the search on Tuesday. â€œThe president was not briefed, did not â€• was not aware of it. No. No one at the White House was given a heads up. No, that did not happen,â€ White House Press Secretary Karine Jeane-Pierre said. â€œThe Justice Department conducts investigations independently, and we leave any law enforcement matters to them. It would not be appropriate for us to comment on any ongoing investigations,â€ Jeane-Pierre added. But Republicans are pointing the finger at Biden anyway, claiming without evidence that he ordered an apparent search for classified documents Trump allegedly took after leaving office. The National Archives said earlier this year that it had obtained 15 boxes of presidential records that Trump had failed to turn over at the end of his term, contrary to the Presidential Records Act, which states that a presidentâ€™s papers belong to the public. â€œBiden is playing with fire by using a document dispute to get the [Department of Justice] to persecute a likely future election opponent,â€ tweeted Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.). â€œBecause one day what goes around is going to come around.â€ Rubio went on to add, â€œUsing government power to persecute political opponents is something we have seen many times from third-world Marxist dictatorships.â€ Rubio wasnâ€™t the only Republican with something to say on the matter, Rep. Fred Keller (R-Pa.) also jumped in to share his two cents. â€œBiden is weaponizing the DOJ against his political opponents,â€ Keller tweeted on Monday. â€œIf they can do this to the former president of the United States, imagine what they can do to you.â€ Many of these same Republicans voted against Trumpâ€™s impeachment after he held up delivery of U.S. military aid to Ukraine in July 2019, while demanding Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky announce an investigation into Biden ahead of the 2020 U.S. presidential election. The aid was released after the scheme became public. Democrats claimed Trump had abused the power of his office by asking a â€œfavorâ€ of Zelensky, while Republicans echoed Trump in saying that it was a â€œperfectâ€ conversation. GOP lawmakers arenâ€™t the only ones crying foul over the raid on Mar-A-Lago, Trumpâ€™s estate in Florida. Gov. Ron Desantis (R-Fla) also issued a statement decrying the search, calling it â€œanother escalation in the weaponization of federal agencies against the regimeâ€™s political opponents, while people like Hunter Biden get treated with kid gloves.â€ DeSantis, a potential 2024 presidential contender, is no stranger to using the power of his office to go after his opponents. As governor, he has cracked down on LGBTQ rights and moved to punish Disney for protesting his stateâ€™s â€œDonâ€™t Say Gayâ€ law. Last week, DeSantis suspended a state attorney who signed a pledge that would not prosecute people under the stateâ€™s newly enacted abortion law. Republican grievances about the recent FBI probe into Trump gloss over the way they cheered in the past over the FBIâ€™s investigation into former Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton over mishandling classified information. â€œItâ€™s like overnight all the Republicans who talked for six years nonstop about the FBI investigation of Hillary Clinton just magically erased it from their memory so they could create this new fictional world in which only Republicans get investigated by the FBI,â€ Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) tweeted Tuesday.

Title: Volodymyr Zelenskyy Wants West To Restrict All Russian Travelers
Text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy on Monday pleaded with Western leaders to further isolate the Kremlin by closing their borders to Russian travelers as the war approaches the six-month mark. â€œThe most important sanctions are to close the borders â€” because the Russians are taking away someone elseâ€™s land,â€ Zelenskyy told The Washington Post. He added that Russian citizens should â€œlive in their own world until they change their philosophy,â€ noting the whole country should face consequences for Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. â€œTheyâ€™ll understand then,â€ he continued. Zelenskyy told the Post restricting Russian travelers for a year coupled with a ban on Russian energy would be a stronger deterrent to Putinâ€™s continuing war, calling current sanctions â€œweak.â€ While Europe and the U.S. have already closed their airspace to Russia, they have not prohibited Russian citizens from entering their countries. Some European countries are already heeding Ukraineâ€™s calls for tighter restrictions. â€œItâ€™s not right that at the same time as Russia is waging an aggressive, brutal war of aggression in Europe, Russians can live a normal life, travel in Europe, be tourists,â€ Finlandâ€™s Prime Minister Sanna Marin told Yle. Estonian Prime Minister Kaja Kallas also tweeted in support of the proposal. â€œStop issuing tourist visas to Russians,â€ Kallas wrote. â€œVisiting [Europe] is a privilege, not a human right.â€ The U.S. on Monday said it would send Ukraine $1 billion in military equipment, including rockets, according to The Associated Press. Read the full Washington Post story here.

Title: Ex-UN Ambassador Expects '2-For-2' Prisoner Swap Will Win Brittney Griner's Release
Text: A former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations on Sunday said he is â€œoptimisticâ€ about winning Brittney Grinerâ€™s release after the WNBA star was sentenced to nine years in a Russian prison on a drug conviction. Bill Richardson told ABCâ€™s â€œThis Weekâ€ he believes Griner will be released alongside former U.S. Marine Paul Whelan in a two-for-two prisoner swap with Russia. â€œIâ€™m optimistic,â€ Richardson said. â€œI think sheâ€™s going to be freed. I think she has the right strategy of contrition, a good legal team. Thereâ€™s going to be a prisoner swap, though. And I think it will be two-for-two involving Paul Whelan. We canâ€™t forget him. Heâ€™s an American Marine wrongfully detained, too.â€ Basketball star Brittney Griner and former Marine Paul Whelan should hopefully be released from Russia as part of a "two-for-two" prisoner swap, former U.S. Amb. to the U.N. Bill Richardson tells @GStephanopoulos. "My view is optimistic.â€  Secretary of State Antony Blinken said last month the U.S. made a â€œsubstantial offerâ€ to Russia in exchange for Griner and Whelan in a surprise announcement. The offer reportedly involved exchanging the two Americans for convicted Russian arms dealer Viktor Bout. On Friday, Lavrov told reporters Russia was prepared to discuss the prisoner exchange deal, but warned the U.S. against making public statements about negotiations. â€œIf the Americans again try to engage in public diplomacy and make loud statements about their intention to take certain steps, itâ€™s their business, I would even say their problem,â€ Lavrov said, according to The Associated Press. â€œThe Americans often have trouble observing agreements on calm and professional work.â€ Richardson, who told ABCâ€™s George Stephanopoulos he serves as a â€œcatalystâ€ for the negotiations between the U.S. and Russia by holding talks with each side, said he would have taken a different approach to communicate the offer. Richardson and Lavrov served as U.N. ambassadors around the same time. â€œI wouldnâ€™t have gone public as much as they did on the Bout for Griner and Whelan,â€ Richardson said. â€œBut it was done. Sometimes when negotiations are not working, you want to throw a little bit of a bomb, and I think thatâ€™s what they did.â€ Richardson declined to get drawn into questions over why another American detainee in Russia, educator Marc Fogel, is not part of the swap negotiations, saying â€œall of these that are wrongfully detained need to come home.â€ The former ambassador also addressed claims that prisoner exchange deals could backfire in encouraging more U.S. adversaries to detain Americans. He said there is no data to support this argument. â€œAs unpleasant as [prisoner exchanges] are, we have to bring American hostages home, especially those wrongfully detained, especially those that have served in our military,â€ Richardson said. Former U.S. Amb. to the U.N. Bill Richardson tells @GStephanopoulos that prisoner exchanges are â€œunpleasantâ€ but necessary.â€œWe have to bring American hostages home, especially those wrongfully detained, especially those that have served in our military.â€

Title: Trevor Noah Busts Putin For 'Another S**tty Thing' He's Doing To Screw With U.S.
Text: â€œThe Daily Showâ€ host Trevor Noah called out Russian President Vladimir Putin for yet â€œanother shitty thingâ€ Russia is doing.
