Title: Brittney Griner Found Guilty, Sentenced To 9 Years For Drug Possession In Russia
Text: WNBA star Brittney Griner was found guilty and sentenced to nine years in Russian prison Thursday for allegedly having a small amount of cannabis in vape cartridges packed in luggage she brought through a Moscow airport earlier this year. Russian prosecutors asked the judge for a nine-and-a-half-year sentence for the Phoenix Mercury player; she faced up to 10 years. Any sentence, however, would be thrown out if American and Russian authorities struck a deal on a prisoner swap. Secretary of State Antony Blinken confirmed last week that the U.S. had put forth a â€œsubstantial offer,â€ reportedly suggesting that Griner and another American prisoner, former Marine Paul Whelan, be exchanged for convicted Russian arms dealer Viktor Bout. Griner pleaded guilty to charges of drug possession, but said in court Thursday that she had made an honest mistake and apologized for bringing â€œembarrassmentâ€ on her Russian teammates. â€œI want to also apologize to my parents, my siblings, the Phoenix Mercury organization back at home, the amazing women of the WNBA, and my amazing spouse back at home,â€ she added. Griner has been married to her wife, Cherelle Griner, since 2019. â€œI know everybody keeps talking about â€˜political pawnâ€™ and politics, but I hope that that is far from this courtroom,â€ she said, according to multiple outlets. â€œI want to say again that I had no intent of breaking Russian laws. I had no intent. I did not conspire or plan to commit this crime.â€ President Joe Biden said the sentence was â€œone more reminder of what the world already knew: Russia is wrongfully detaining Brittney.â€ â€œItâ€™s unacceptable, and I call on Russia to release her immediately so she can be with her wife, loved ones, friends, and teammates,â€ Biden said in a statement. â€œMy administration will continue to work tirelessly and pursue every possible avenue to bring Brittney and Paul Whelan home safely as soon as possible.â€ Arms dealer Bout, who sold off large quantities of weapons after the fall of the Soviet Union, is currently around halfway through a 25-year sentence for allegedly taking part in a conspiracy to kill Americans. He was eventually captured in a sting operation in Thailand in 2008. Griner was arrested in February while going through customs at Sheremetyevo Airport, outside of Moscow, for allegedly carrying 0.702 grams of hashish oil, a product that contains cannabis, in two vape cartridges. Days later, Russia invaded Ukraine. Grinerâ€™s arrest was announced in early March, prompting concerns that her detention was largely political, and Blinken later declared her a wrongful detainee. The two-time Olympic gold medalist had been playing for Russiaâ€™s UMMC Ekaterinburg during the WNBA off-season periodically since 2014, as womenâ€™s basketball players are often better paid overseas than in the U.S. In a handwritten letter to Biden that was also released in part to media outlets in early July, Griner said that she was â€œterrifiedâ€ she might never see the outside of a Russian prison. White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre told reporters that Biden read the letter and American officials were â€œgoing to use every tool that we possibly canâ€ to bring Griner home.

Title: Josh Hawley Was The Only Senator Who Voted Against NATO Expansion
Text: WASHINGTON â€• The Senate overwhelmingly voted to add Finland and Sweden into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on Tuesday, a historic move aimed at countering Russiaâ€™s aggression in Europe. Only one senator, Sen. Josh Hawley (R-Mo.), opposed the ratification. Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.), meanwhile, voted â€œpresent.â€ Hawley, a potential 2024 presidential contender, argued that Finland and Sweden would have trouble spending on their own defense, putting the onus on the U.S. to get even more involved in the region. He said the U.S. should focus instead on countering China, and that it wouldnâ€™t be able to do both. â€œOur foreign policy should be about protecting the United States, our freedoms, our people [and] our way of life,â€ Hawley said in a floor speech. â€œExpanding NATO, I believe, would not do that.â€ NATO was founded after World War II to create a pact of mutual defense among member nations in the event of Soviet aggression. NATO member countries are treaty-bound to defend any member in the event of an armed attack. Hawley, who led the effort to overturn the 2020 electoral results in Congress that gave rise to the Jan. 6 insurrection, called for adopting a â€œnationalistâ€ foreign policy. He later went on Tucker Carlsonâ€™s Fox News show to make his case. Carlson was an early critic of U.S. efforts to counter Russia, amplifying the Kremlinâ€™s talking points as it launched its brutal invasion of Ukraine. Nearly every one of Hawleyâ€™s GOP colleagues disagreed with his rationale. â€œBoth countries already participate in NATO and American-led missions,â€ Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) said Tuesday. â€œFinland already meets NATOâ€™s 2% spending target, and Sweden is making significant investments in modernizing its military.â€ â€œIf any senator finds a defensible excuse to vote no, I wish them good luck,â€ McConnell added. NATO members have pledged to spend at least 2% of their gross domestic product on defense, a target that some nations have met and others havenâ€™t yet. Sweden is in the latter group, though it has said it will meet the goal. Hawley has said the target should be higher. Sen. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.) appeared to accuse Hawley of hypocrisy â€• albeit without naming him â€• for opposing Finland and Sweden joining NATO while voting in favor of North Macedonia joining the alliance in 2019. â€œIt would be strange indeed for any senator who voted to allow Montenegro or North Macedonia into NATO to turn around and deny membership to Finland and Sweden,â€ Cotton said. â€œI would love to hear the defense of such a curious vote.â€ The Arkansas Republican is another official who seems to be laying the groundwork for a presidential bid in 2024, making several trips to the early nominating state of Iowa this year. Hawley told HuffPost on Thursday that he doesnâ€™t think Finland and Sweden joining NATO would be at all comparable to North Macedonia and Montenegro doing so. â€œTheir entrance to NATO presents no strategic implications for the United States in terms of our posture, our military forces in Europe,â€ Hawley said. â€œFinland and Sweden present huge, huge strategic implications for the United States. Finland has an 830-mile border with Russia. Sweden already wants increased U.S. naval presence in the Baltic Sea.â€ Hawley also questioned whether Finland will maintain its current military spending, and argued that adding the two countries to NATO would ultimately burden the U.S. Cotton, on the other hand, said that adding Finland and Sweden to NATO would make it easier, not harder, for the U.S. and its allies to defend themselves from Russia. â€œAside from their military strength and economic power, Finland and Sweden also allow us to turn the Baltic into a NATO lake, bottle up Russiaâ€™s Baltic Fleet, cut off its isolated military base at Kaliningrad, and expose Russia itself to much greater risk in the event of a conflict,â€ he said. Finland and Swedenâ€™s entry into NATO is not yet a done deal. All NATO parliaments must ratify new members, and Turkey has threatened to block their accession. But the overwhelming Senate vote on Tuesday sent an unmistakable message of bipartisan unity in support of Europe, with ambassadors from Finland and Sweden watching the proceedings from the public gallery above the Senate floor. â€œWe are at an unparalleled moment in history,â€ Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) said. â€œSince Vladimir Putinâ€™s cruel, unjustified invasion of Ukraine, people all over the world have been waking up out of a two-year plague, out of a slumber, to realize just how fragile our democracy is.â€ â€œWe realized it here in this building when, not so long along, insurrectionists invaded this Chamber,â€ Klobuchar said, referring to the events of Jan. 6, 2021. Hawley played a starring role that day â€” raising his fist to the Donald Trump supporters who stormed the Capitol and then, after the attack, voting against certification of Trumpâ€™s 2020 election loss. â€œWe didnâ€™t just sit back and say, â€˜Well, there goes our democracy,â€™â€ Klobuchar said. â€œWe stood up. We stood up, Democrats and Republicans, in this very chamber.â€

Title: U.S. Targets Vladimir Putin's Reputed Girlfriend With New Russia Sanctions
Text: The U.S. on Tuesday announced a new round of sanctions targeting Russian companies and elites, including a 39-year-old former Olympic gymnast who is reportedly romantically involved with Russian President Vladimir Putin, as the war in Ukraine enters its sixth month. The Treasury Department said it is sanctioning, among others, Olympic gold medalist Alina Maratovna Kabaeva, a former state Duma member and head of a pro-Kremlin media empire. She has a â€œclose relationship to Putin,â€ Treasury said. Treasuryâ€™s list also includes Putin ally Andrey Grigoryevich Guryev, who served in the Russian government and owns a leading chemical company, as well as his yacht Alfa Nero, which Treasury said has â€œreportedly shut off its location tracking hardware in order to avoid seizure.â€ The sanctions extend to Guryevâ€™s son, Andrey Andreevich Guryev. Viktor Filippovich Rashnikov, the owner of one of the worldâ€™s biggest steel companies who Treasury said provides a big source of revenue for the Kremlin, is also subject to sanctions, as is Natalya Valeryevna Popova, the deputy director of a Russian technology company. â€œAs innocent people suffer from Russiaâ€™s illegal war of aggression, Putinâ€™s allies have enriched themselves and funded opulent lifestyles,â€ Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said. We â€œwill use every tool at our disposal to make sure that Russian elites and the Kremlinâ€™s enablers are held accountable for their complicity in a war that has cost countless lives,â€ Yellen added. The State Department on Tuesday also announced further sanctions on 24 Russian defense and technology-related entities. â€œRussia has systematically focused on exploiting high-technology research and innovations to advance Moscowâ€™s war-fighting capabilities â€“ the same defense capabilities that Russiaâ€™s military is using in its vicious attacks hitting Ukraineâ€™s population centers and resulting in the deaths of civilians, including children,â€ Secretary of State Antony Blinken said. Blinken singled out three Russian oligarchs: Dmitry Aleksandrovich Pumpyanskiy, Andrey Igorevich Melnichenko and Alexander Anatolevich Ponomarenko. The State Department has also issued visa restrictions on 893 Russian Federation officials and 31 foreign government officials who have supported Russiaâ€™s annexation of Crimea. â€œThe United States will not waver in its support for the brave people of Ukraine and will continue to promote accountability for President Putin and his cronies whose actions have caused so much suffering and destruction in Ukraine,â€ he said. Daniel Fried, a former coordinator for U.S. sanctions policy in Barack Obamaâ€™s administration, commended U.S. efforts to punish Putin but said they were not enough. He told The New York Times a global price ceiling on the purchase price of Russian oil, which G-7 leaders discussed in June, would be a stronger measure. â€œThey need to deliver â€” itâ€™s been a month,â€ Fried said. â€œThey need something effective to eat into Putinâ€™s income. This package is good, but the need requires even more.â€

Title: Trump Sides With Russia Again, Calls Jailed American Brittney Griner 'Spoiled'
Text: Former President Donald Trump lashed out Sunday at American WNBA star Brittney Griner as â€œspoiled,â€ and indicated he wouldnâ€™t make any deals to get her out of prison in Russia because she â€œmakes a lot of money.â€ Griner was arrested in Moscow in February as she entered the country for a tournament when officials discovered vape cartridges with cannabis oil in her luggage. Trump claimed on the Clay Travis & Buck Sexton Show that Griner entered Russia â€œloaded up with drugs.â€ In fact she had .7 grams (.024 ounces) of cannabis oil, which is legal in her home state of Arizona and in many other states in America. Russian media, which reported the amount, said officials considered it â€œsignificant.â€ Griner, who said she had a doctorâ€™s note for the cannabis oil, explained in a Russian court when she pleaded guilty early this month that she had forgotten that it was in her bag and brought it into the country inadvertently. The athlete was arrested as Russian officials were railing against Western sanctions for its invasion of Ukraine. Griner faces up to 10 years in prison if convicted of transporting drugs. Trump criticized reports that the U.S. is considering trading notorious Russian arms dealer Viktor Bout, being held in an American prison, to secure the release of Griner and former U.S. Marine Paul Whelan, who is serving a 16-year sentence in Russia on what U.S. officials call baseless espionage charges. Griner â€œknew you donâ€™t go in there loaded up with drugs, and she admitted it,â€ Trump said. â€œI assume she admitted it without too much force because it is what it is, and it certainly doesnâ€™t seem like a very good trade, does it?â€ he added. Bout is â€œabsolutely one of the worst in the world, and heâ€™s gonna be given his freedom because a potentially spoiled person goes into Russia loaded up with drugs.â€ Griner â€œwent in there loaded up with drugs into a hostile territory where theyâ€™re very vigilant about drugs,â€ Trump complained. â€œThey donâ€™t like drugs. And she got caught.â€ He added: â€œNow weâ€™re supposed to get her out â€” and she makes, you know, a lot of money. Weâ€™re supposed to get her out for an absolute killer and one of the biggest arms dealers in the world. Killed many Americans. Killed many people, and heâ€™s going to get a free card,â€ Trump added. Trump called WNBA star Brittney Griner, â€œspoiled,â€ and implied he wouldnâ€™t have made the deal to get her out of prison in Russia.  Critics accused Trump of singling out Griner for criticism because sheâ€™s Black, gay and a woman. He also has a long history of standing up for Russia, even against American interests, and frequently touts his great friendship with Russian President Vladimir Putin. When Putin launched the invasion into Ukraine earlier this year, the former president called it â€œgenius.â€ Trump openly asked for Russiaâ€™s help in 2016 to hack into rival Hillary Clintonâ€™s emails, and then used material stolen by Russian spies to attack Clinton in the final stretch of the election. A lot of drugs Aka a weed pen But he would happily pardon a plethora of criminals. Yea he would just pardon all of his criminal associates instead.Oh, he already did that. Coming from the most spoiled person on earth. Lets call it what it is ...she is a gay black woman....something the GOP and Trump* hate. He wanted to say uppity, but he has a hard time with words that have more than two syllables.

Title: I'm A UkrainianÂ Refugee. Here's What No One Is Telling You About The War.
Text: People ask me how Iâ€™m doing in exile. Well, letâ€™s see â€• my city is being bombed, my countryâ€™s future is under threat from a superpower, the father of my children is at war, and Iâ€™m a thousand miles from home in a country where I donâ€™t speak the language, have no job, and can only watch my savings dwindle to zero while I try to provide for my two boys, my mother and our dog. Then thereâ€™s the guilt for abandoning the fight, when a big part of me would like to be in Donbas killing every Russian soldier I can find. Until late February, I was an independent, self-supporting woman â€• a journalist and the main breadwinner for my family. When the bombs started to fall near our apartment in Kyiv, I had a terrible decision to make: stay and fight, or take my family away from the bombs. With no one else to ensure their safety, I chose the latter. First we went to Lviv â€• spending long hours in a packed van to get there â€• to stay with an online gaming acquaintance from â€œClash of Clansâ€ who Iâ€™d never met in person. When the bombs started falling there, too, we spent hours in the basement, and then joined the refugee flow heading west, which meant several more days of traveling with all of us and the dog. As a journalist, Iâ€™ve covered refugee camps. Now, along the way, I found myself living in one. In my former life, I gave to charities (I still do, whenever I can). On the road, I was accepting the charity of strangers: food, transport, a night in a hotel when we were on the verge of collapse. Our destination was a small town in central Italy, where I knew exactly one person â€• another member of our Clan. Iâ€™m not one to shrink from a challenge. Once we finally arrived, I got the kids into school, settled my mother in our borrowed house, and found some part-time jobs: kitchen work at a pizzeria, then at a steakhouse, later as a maid in a hotel packed with Ukrainian refugees. (That will be a whole chapter in my book someday!) On top of all that, I discovered that millions of Ukrainian refugee women like me are the target of online ridicule from some of our fellow citizens who think we left the country because weâ€™re â€œlazyâ€ and â€œcowardly,â€ and that we did it for the aid money. The money? One recent morning, I traveled 300 kilometers (186 miles) to arrive at the Ukrainian Consulate at 8:00 a.m. Even though it wouldnâ€™t open for another two hours, there were 25 women in front of me, most with kids, hoping to qualify for 300 Euros ($316) per month for each adult and half that for each child â€• and only for a maximum of three months. I was so thankful for that money, but it didnâ€™t last long. A woman in line said to me, â€œEvery day is Friday the 13th here.â€ One person tried to guilt me on social media by writing, â€œI know someone who brought her four kids to a friend in Western Ukraine and came back to Kyiv to work for victory.â€ Please tell me, where do I find such friends? And if I did, could I stand to leave my boys with them for the long term? Exile is particularly hard on the children â€• anger, tears, acting out. If at all possible, they need at least one parent with them. Thereâ€™s nothing Iâ€™d rather do than go home, if only I could do so and still take care of my family. I salute those who are able to stay, and I work to help them in any way I can. But my reasons for leaving, like those of any refugee, are enough. We donâ€™t have to justify our decisions to anyone, particularly people who put in earbuds to tune out politics and listened to Russian rap for the past eight years while some of us worked to raise the alarm about the simmering conflict. We know who really cares about us. Theyâ€™re the people who write, as five of my friends did one recent day when bombs fell on Kyiv: â€œItâ€™s too dangerous. Stay where you are.â€ Still, many of the refugees I meet are mired in despair, sadness and depression, which seem to be the only socially acceptable emotions for them to feel or express. God forbid anyone should post a photo of themselves on the beach or at a football match. Such a person would have to be a heartless traitor! But succumbing to that view is a crime in two ways: It doesnâ€™t make our lives easier, and it wonâ€™t help win the war. Instead, I donâ€™t let my emotions stop me from doing everything I can to contribute to the war effort, and I encourage others to do the same. Itâ€™s hard to be productive or creative when youâ€™re depressed, so I fight it. I share, tweet and retweet constantly. I speak to my foreign friends about Ukraine, about our courage and all the best of our nation. I use social media to spread the truth about Ukraine, because Russia never stops spouting its lies. When I can, I use my contacts to facilitate the shipment of ammo, flak jackets and medicine to our brave fighters. And I try not to feel guilty about those moments when I can enjoy life â€• when I can laugh with my kids, sample the local food, and yes, even go to the beach. When I was a journalist traveling in Donbas and Crimea from 2014 through 2021, my colleagues and I had a motto: â€œEnjoy life whenever you can.â€ We would go out for dinners and vodka, and laugh while the bombs fell, because we knew the next one could fall on us. Here in exile, we are safe from the bombs. But the weight of the war is on us, along with worry about our childrenâ€™s future and fear for our friends and family left behind. And the guilt is here, too, in spite of my efforts to shed it. All of that will slowly kill your spirit, as surely as a bomb will kill your body. We Ukrainians have had enough sadness and despair to last the rest of our lives, and thereâ€™s likely more to come. In the meantime, we must all do our part, and respect and love each other for it. And, to our foreign friends: We are no longer in the headlines every day, but please do not forget us. We need all of you â€• not just your governments â€• to do everything you can to help us secure our democracy and protect the West from Russiaâ€™s aggression. (Two organizations that are doing excellent work and could use more support are the Women Veterans Foundation and Come Back Alive.) So, how am I doing? On the bright side, I learned to make pizza. Maria Zavialova is a Ukrainian journalist living temporarily in exile. You can find more from her on Twitter. Do you have a compelling personal story youâ€™d like to see published on HuffPost? Find out what weâ€™re looking for here and send us a pitch.

Title: CIA Chief William Burns Says Vladimir Putin Is 'Entirely Too Healthy'
Text: CIA Director William J. Burns on Wednesday dismissed suggestions that Russian President Vladimir Putin is in poor physical condition, calling him â€œentirely too healthy.â€ â€œThere are lots of rumors about President Putinâ€™s health and as far as we can tell, heâ€™s entirely too healthy,â€ Burns told NBCâ€™s Andrea Mitchell in an interview in Colorado as part of the Aspen Security Forum. â€œItâ€™s not a formal intelligence judgment,â€ Burns added. Spy chief William Burns quips the Russian leader is "entirely too healthy" and also addresses tensions with China over Taiwan.Click the link to read more ğŸ‘‰  Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov on Thursday also said Putin feels â€œfineâ€ and is in â€œgood health,â€ according to CNN. Assertions to the contrary are â€œnothing but hoaxes,â€ Peskov added. Putinâ€™s reality-defying statements, disappearances from public view or even slight stumbles in public often set off speculation about his health. Burns explained Putinâ€™s style of decision-making. â€œHis views have hardened, in my experience over the years, but heâ€™s got his own way of looking at reality,â€ Burns said. â€œAnd as we, you know, could see in the first stages of this war, it was based on some profoundly flawed assumptions and some real illusions, especially about Ukraine and the will to resist in Ukraine, which heâ€™s helped to create in many ways by aggression now over a period of at least the eight years since 2014.â€ Putin this week visited Iran in only his second international trip the Ukraine invasion. The Russian leader earned the support of Tehran, according to The Associated Press. Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei said Russia would have faced an attack by NATO if it hadnâ€™t attacked Ukraine â€” a claim that echoes a Putin pretext to justify the invasion. Asked if Iranâ€™s missile and drone system should be a concern to the U.S. and its allies, Burns said itâ€™s â€œcertainly an increasingly significant threat.â€ â€œThey have the biggest arsenal of missiles of anyone in the Middle East right now,â€ Burns said. â€œAnd you know, itâ€™s a mark of the development of their armed drone system that you have the Russians now trying to acquire some as well.â€ The White House said earlier this month that Russians have visited an airfield in Iran twice looking at drones to use in their war against Ukraine, according to AP.

Title: Kyiv Mayor And Boxer Vitali Klitschko Wins ESPY's Arthur Ashe Award For Courage
Text: The ESPY Awards honored Vitali Klitschko, mayor of Kyiv and an International Boxing Hall of Fame member, for his courageousness on Wednesday. The sports award show named the Ukrainian mayor this yearâ€™s recipient of the Arthur Ashe Award for Courage, described as an award meant for someone who shows â€œstrength in the face of adversity, courage in the face of peril and the willingness to stand up for their beliefs no matter what the cost,â€ ESPN said. Klitschko, Kyivâ€™s longest-serving mayor and multiple-time world heavyweight champion along with his brother Wladimir, is a vocal Vladimir Putin critic and has defended Ukraine along with his brother while in Kyiv. The boxer had never been knocked out in his career and â€œrarelyâ€ lost a round , according to ESPN. Actor Dwayne Johnson accepted the honor on Klitschkoâ€™s behalf and, according to people, remarked that he is â€œa man who will tell you very plainly, that sports is part of the reason he is where he is.â€ â€œVitali is a hero, who has shown the world what courage truly looks like.â€ Past recipients of the award have included Nelson Mandela, Muhammad Ali, Billie Jean King and Jim Valvano. Klitschko, in a video speech shared on Twitter, quoted Mandela who once said â€œsport has the power to change the world.â€ You can watch Klitschkoâ€™s full speech regarding the award below. "This award is not for me. This award is for every Ukrainian who is fighting ... for the future of democracy, for the future of our homeland."The Arthur Ashe Award for Courage this year goes to Vitali Klitschko.

Title: Brittney Griner Honored On Jerseys Of All 22 Players At WNBA All-Star Game
Text: All the players at Sundayâ€™s WNBA All-Star game took to the court in jerseys bearing fellow player Brittney Grinerâ€™s name and number. Griner, a star of the Phoenix Mercury, has been detained in Russia on drug charges since February, after vape cannisters with cannabis oil were allegedly found in her luggage at Moscowâ€™s Sheremetyevo Airport. She pleaded guilty last week. Players on both teams wore jerseys with the number 42 throughout the second half of the All-Star contest at Chicagoâ€™s Wintrust Arena. The Phoenix Mercury logo and Grinerâ€™s name also appeared on the uniforms. Grinerâ€™s wife, Cherelle Griner, was seated courtside during the display. Several players hugged her. Every player in the #WNBAAllStar Game came out to start the second half in Brittney Griner's No. 42 jersey.  â€œWe are not going to stop until everyone understands how serious this really is,â€ Aâ€™ja Wilson, a Las Vegas Aces forward and captain of one of the All-Star teams, said. Griner, who has played seven All-Star games in her career, has been designated by the U.S. State Department as wrongfully detained in Russia. She pleaded guilty on Thursday to drug possession and smuggling, but said she had no intention of committing a crime, telling the Moscow court she packed in a hurry and included the canisters by accident. She could face up to 10 years in prison if convicted of large-scale transportation of drugs. She had been returning to Russia to play in the Russian League, where she plays in the WNBA off-season.

Title: Army Reportedly Seeks To Recoup Money From Michael Flynn For His Pay From Russia, Turkey
Text: The U.S. Army is going after retired Army Gen. Michael Flynn to recoup a portion of hundreds of thousands of dollars in payments he received from Russia and Turkey before he became Donald Trumpâ€™s national security adviser in 2017, The Washington Post reported Friday. The Army is seeking nearly $40,000 from Flynn after he was cited by the Defense Department inspector general for failing to disclose lucrative speaking engagements and other business arrangements with foreign entities, according to the Post. Investigators determined that Flynn received nearly $450,000 from Turkish and Russian interests in 2015, including for an appearance in Moscow with Russian President Vladimir Putin, while failing to seek government approval beforehand, as required. He was also paid to appear at an October 2015 conference sponsored by Kaspersky Government Security Solutions, â€œan entity that appears to be controlled by the Russian government,â€ according to a memo early last year by Sean Oâ€™Donnell, the acting Defense Department inspector general, the Post reported. The Emoluments Clause of the Constitution prohibits retired military personnel from receiving money from foreign governments without prior authorization. Flynn could not be reached for comment. Flynn left the Trump administration within weeks over his connections to Russia amid the investigation into Kremlin interference into the 2016 presidential election. He later pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about his Russian connections during Trumpâ€™s campaign and transition into the White House. He was sentenced to prison, but Trump pardoned him in 2020.

Title: Megan Rapinoe Honors Brittney Griner While Receiving Presidential Medal Of Freedom
Text: Megan Rapinoe offered a sweet and subtle tribute to basketball star Brittney Griner this week as the soccer great visited the White House to receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom. The U.S. Womenâ€™s National Soccer team star attended the Thursday afternoon ceremony in an ivory-colored suit with Grinerâ€™s initials and a flower embroidered on the lapel. She shared a close-up of the design, which wasnâ€™t noticeable from afar, on her Instagram story. â€œThe most important part of today,â€ the two-time World Cup champion wrote. â€œBG we love you.â€ Today, Megan Rapinoe â€” along with Simone Biles â€” will receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom at the White House.Rapinoe posted this photo on her Instagram Stories of her outfit with a nod to Brittney Griner.ğŸ“¸ @mPinoe  Griner, a two-time Olympic medalist and a center for the Phoenix Mercury, has been detained in Russia since Feb. 17, when officers said vape canisters with cannabis oil were found in her luggage at a Moscow airport. In May, the U.S. State Department classified the WNBA starâ€™s arrest as wrongful detainment. Last week, Griner wrote a letter to President Joe Biden pleading for his help. Earlier on Thursday, Griner pleaded guilty to charges of smuggling drugs into Russia but said she did so â€œinadvertentlyâ€ and that â€œthere was no intent.â€ She now faces up to 10 years in prison, though experts say her freedom could be secured via a â€œprisoner exchangeâ€ that would involve the release of a Russian held in the U.S. In a second post to her Instagram story, Rapinoe said that Griner was being used as a â€œpolitical pawn,â€ adding, â€œWe need to bring her home immediately.â€ â€œThis plea doesnâ€™t change that [Biden] needs to and is working hard to get her home,â€ she continued, according to People. Rapinoe was among 17 people selected by Biden to receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nationâ€™s highest civilian honor, this year. Other 2022 recipients include former Rep. Gabrielle Giffords (D-Ariz.) and Olympic gymnast Simone Biles.

Title: Paul Whelan's Family Laments 'Inconsistency' In Treatment After Biden Calls Griner's Wife
Text: The sister of Paul Whelan, a U.S. Marine veteran imprisoned in Russia, on Wednesday expressed frustration over President Joe Biden calling the wife of WNBA star Brittney Griner, who is also being held in the country, but not making contact with their family. Elizabeth Whelan retweeted a screenshot of the readout of Bidenâ€™s call with Cherelle Griner, the wife of the WNBA star, adding that she was â€œcrushedâ€ the Whelan family still has not received a call from the president. Whelan was arrested in Moscow in 2018 and was sentenced to 16 years in prison on espionage charges, according to The Associated Press. â€œStill looking for that press release saying @POTUS has spoken to anyone in OUR family about #PaulWhelan, wrongfully detained in #Russia for 3.5 years,â€ Whelan tweeted. â€œI am crushed. If he wants to talk about securing Paulâ€™s release, he needs to be talking to the Whelans! What are we to think?!â€ Whelan continued. Speaking to CNNâ€™s â€œThe Leadâ€ Wednesday afternoon, Whelan explained she did not â€œbegrudge the Griner family and their supporters.â€ â€œI think our concern is, you know, why the outreach to some families and not others. There are 55-plus families who would like to have that same degree of attention,â€ Whelan said. Paul Whelan's sister wants families of detained Americans to see a more even-handed outreach from the Biden administration. @elizabethwhelan talks with @EricaRHill following a Biden & Harris phone call with Brittney Grinerâ€™s wife  Whelan added that her brother has written to Biden, as well as Donald Trump when he was president, and members of Congress multiple times. â€œI was astonished this morning to hear about this call and it did make me wonder: Should we be pushing for a meeting with the president? Is that what itâ€™s going to take to bring my brother home? What I would really like to see is a functioning process that didnâ€™t require that,â€ Whelan continued. David Whelan echoed his sister, telling CNNâ€™s â€œNew Dayâ€ Thursday he was pleased to hear of the call to Griner but lamented the administrationâ€™s â€œinconsistency.â€ â€œI was thrilled that President Biden and Vice President Harris took the time to speak with Ms. Griner,â€ Whelan said. â€œI think that the frustration to the extent that it is out there is directed towards the inconsistency of how the U.S. government interacts with wrongful detaineesâ€™ families,â€ Whelan added. "We sort of feel like we're not going anywhere..."@davidpwhelan on his brother Paul Whelan who has been detained in Russia since 2018.  Biden spoke to Grinerâ€™s wife Wednesday and also sent a letter to Griner herself. â€œThe President called Cherelle to reassure her that he is working to secure Brittneyâ€™s release as soon as possible, as well as the release of Paul Whelan and other U.S. nationals who are wrongfully detained or held hostage in Russia and around the world,â€ the White House said in a statement. â€œHe also read her a draft of the letter the President is sending to Brittney Griner today.â€ Griner reportedly pleaded guilty to drug charges Thursday, but added that she was not intending to act unlawfully, according to The Associated Press. If convicted, Griner would face 10 years in prison. While the White House is working on both cases, it is unclear whether the government could cut a deal releasing both Americans at the same time or whether each would be released individually, according to the AP. Paul Whelan was left out of a prisoner exchange the U.S. made with Russia in April, which led to the release of Trevor Reed, a U.S. Marine veteran. Reed told CNNâ€™s Jake Tapper he initially thought Whelan was also coming back to the U.S. with him and was disappointed to realize this was not the case. â€œThe fact is that the United States should have got him out, and we have to get him out at â€• at any cost,â€ Reed said.

Title: Brittney Griner's Wife Says She Hasn't Heard From White House Following Letter To Biden
Text: The wife of Brittney Griner said the White House has not yet responded to a letter from the WNBA star asking for President Joe Bidenâ€™s help in getting her released from Russian detention. Griner, a 31-year-old two-time Olympic gold medalist and center for the Phoenix Mercury, was arrested in February when she traveled to Russia and authorities claimed they found cannabis oil in her luggage. On July 4, she wrote an impassioned letter to Biden asking him not to â€œforget about me,â€ and expressing fears that she â€œmight be here forever.â€ Brittney Grinerâ€™s wife Cherelle says it is â€œvery dishearteningâ€ that she still has not heard back from the White House â€” after Brittney penned a handwritten letter to Pres. Biden from a Russian prison pleading for help.  Grinerâ€™s wife, Cherelle Griner, told CBS News that the letter to Biden was the latest effort to get the presidentâ€™s attention about the Olympianâ€™s detention. Though the White House confirmed to The Associated Press that Biden received the letter, Cherelle Griner said the lack of response from the president has been â€œvery disheartening.â€ â€œIt kills me every time that, you know, when I have to write her and sheâ€™s asking, â€˜Have you met with [the White House] yet?â€™ And I have to say no,â€ Cherelle told the outlet Tuesday. â€œIâ€™m sure she is like, â€˜Iâ€™m going to write him and ask now because my family has tried to no avail, so Iâ€™m going to do it myself.â€™â€ In her letter, Griner said she has been â€œterrifiedâ€ as she sits alone in a Russian prison cell. â€œAs I sit here in a Russian prison, alone with my thoughts and without the protection of my wife, family, friends, Olympic jersey, or any accomplishments, Iâ€™m terrified I might be here forever,â€ she wrote to Biden. Cherelle Griner said her wifeâ€™s words should be taken seriously. â€œShe is probably the strongest person that I know, so she doesnâ€™t say words like that lightly,â€ Cherelle told CBS News. â€œThat means she truly is terrified that she may never see us again. You know, I share those same sentiments.â€ Grinerâ€™s trial began last week, and the athlete faces up to 10 years in prison if convicted.

Title: Brittney Griner Writes To White House Asking Biden Not To â€˜Forget About Meâ€™
Text: Brittney Griner, the WNBA star detained in Russia, sent an appeal to President Joe Biden asking him not to â€œforget about me,â€ saying she was worried she â€œmight be here forever.â€ â€œAs I sit here in a Russian prison, alone with my thoughts and without the protection of my wife, family, friends, Olympic jersey, or any accomplishments, Iâ€™m terrified I might be here forever,â€ Griner, 31, wrote in the letter, excerpts of which were released by her agent. â€œOn the 4th of July, our family normally honors the service of those who fought for our freedom, including my father who is a Vietnam War Veteran. It hurts thinking about how I usually celebrate this day because freedom means something completely different to me this year.â€ Griner, a two-time Olympic gold medalist and a center for the Phoenix Mercury, was detained in February after Russian authorities said they found cannabis oil in her luggage while returning to the country to play for her Russian team. Her trial began last week, and she faces up to 10 years in prison if convicted. NEW: A letter from Brittney Griner was sent to the White House today, making a direct appeal to President Biden for her freedom. Representatives shared the following excerpts:  The White House confirmed to The Associated Press that it had received Grinerâ€™s letter, adding the U.S. believed Russia was â€œwrongfully detainingâ€ her. The entirety of the letter is being kept private. â€œPresident Biden has been clear about the need to see all U.S. nationals who are held hostage or wrongfully detained abroad released, including Brittney Griner,â€ Adrienne Watson, a spokesperson for the National Security Council, told the AP. â€œThe U.S. government continues to work aggressively â€“ using every available means â€“ to bring her home.â€ The outlet added fewer than 1% of defendants in Russian criminal cases are acquitted, and those acquittals can be overturned. Legal experts told The New York Times she is likely to be found guilty, and her supporters have urged the White House to arrange a prisoner swap with the Kremlin. The U.S. and Russia did so in April, exchanging Trevor Reed, a former U.S. Marine held on assault charges, with a Russian pilot sentenced to 20 years in prison in the U.S. for drug trafficking. â€œI realize you are dealing with so much, but please donâ€™t forget about me and the other American detainees,â€ Griner wrote to Biden. â€œPlease do all you can to bring us home.â€ Vanessa Nygaard, the coach of the Mercury, addressed the letter Monday during a pre-game news conference. â€œIt made me cry, you know, just hearing her words talking about her father being a Vietnam vet, her new perspective on freedom, her wanting to be with her family and her teammates, her not knowing if sheâ€™ll ever be free again,â€ Nygaard said, The Guardian reported.

Title: John Kirby Says Biden Will Not Pressure Ukraine Into Settlement With Russia
Text: John Kirby, the National Security Councilâ€™s coordinator for strategic communications at the White House, said Sunday the U.S. will continue to support Ukraine, but will not pressure the country to negotiate an end to the war with Russia. When asked if it is time for President Joe Biden to push the two sides to the table as the war drags on, Kirby told â€œFox News Sundayâ€ the U.S. is committed to helping Ukraine fight Russiaâ€™s invasion. â€œItâ€™s time for the United States to continue to support Ukraine, and thatâ€™s what weâ€™re doing,â€ Kirby said. Kirby said the goal is to help Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and his country prevail in the war so they are in a strong position to negotiate when that time comes. Kirby added Russian President Vladimir Putin has shown no interest in peace talks, pointing to the latest airstrikes in Kyiv. While G7 leaders were meeting in Europe on June 26, Kyiv mayor Vitali Klitschko said Russian airstrikes hit at least two residential buildings, killing at least one person, according to The Associated Press. Last week, Russia reportedly struck a shopping mall in Kremenchuk, Ukraine killing at least 20 people, while Russian missiles in Odesa killed at least 19 people Friday. â€œPresident Zelenskyy, he gets to determine how victory is decided and when and on what terms,â€ Kirby said. â€œAnd [what] weâ€™re going to do is continue to make sure that can succeed on the battlefield so that he can succeed at the table. But even President Zelenskyy will tell you that the time is not now for those discussions.â€ The former Pentagon spokesman noted U.S. alone has spent over $7 billion to support the Ukrainians since the beginning of the war in February. â€œWe donâ€™t want to see Ukraine defeated by Russia and thatâ€™s why we are continuing to rush aid and assistance,â€ Kirby said. Meanwhile, on Monday Russia scored a victory in the eastern Ukrainian region of Luhansk after Ukrainians withdrew their forces from the area on Sunday, according to The Associated Press. â€œRussiaâ€™s focus will now almost certainly switch to capturing Donetsk Oblast, a large portion of which remain under the control of Ukrainian forces,â€ tweeted the British Ministry of Defense. (3/8)The city was the last remaining major population centre in Luhansk Oblast under Ukrainian control. Russiaâ€™s focus will now almost certainly switch to capturing Donetsk Oblast, a large portion of which remain under the control of Ukrainian forces.

Title: Congress Wary Of Calling Russiaâ€™s Actions In Ukraine â€˜Genocideâ€™
Text: More than 350 Ukrainian villagers held in an overcrowded school basement for 28 days, leaving 10 dead. More than a million Ukrainians forcibly relocated to Russia since the war in Ukraine started, including more than 180,000 children. An 11-year-old Ukrainian boy, raped as his mother was tied to a chair and forced to watch. The mounting allegations against Russia over its invasion of Ukraine have been described as war crimes or even crimes against humanity. But human rights groups and others are debating if they amount to genocide, at least as defined in international law. Declaring Ukrainians to be the victims of a genocide may not have huge practical implications, but the historic weight of the word, with its overtones of the Holocaust, the killing fields of Cambodia and the breakup of Yugoslavia, may matter more. War crimes and crimes against humanity are deplored, but genocide by its nature implies the need for more forceful, immediate action. And though President Joe Biden has said he thinks itâ€™s genocide, that concern over the obligations the label would impose may be why thereâ€™s wariness on Capitol Hill to follow suit. Rep Steny Hoyer (Md.), the second-ranking Democrat in the House and a former chair of the human rights-focused U.S. Helsinki Commission, said he was not sure if the word â€œgenocideâ€ was applicable because he thought of it in terms of ethnic groups. â€œThe way I think about genocide is Hitler getting rid of the Jews or, frankly, to some degree, what we did with Indians or what Christians did to the Muslims because they were Muslims in the Crusades,â€ he said. Though that perception is widely shared, itâ€™s actually not the definition under international law. â€œPeople confuse genocide with mass murder and mass atrocities,â€ said Azeem Ibrahim, director of special initiatives for the New Lines Institute for Strategy and Policy in Washington, pointing to the definition in a 1948 international treaty. â€œThe number of people being killed is not relevant to what the Genocide Convention actually says. What is relevant is the intent of the parties to eliminate a group in whole or in part using all the various means at their disposal,â€ he said. If that intent exists, genocide can include: The accusations against Russia certainly check off many of those boxes. Aside from the above incidents cited in a report by New Lines and the Raoul Wallenberg Centre for Human Rights, Russia has been accused of indiscriminately bombing civilian targets, including apartment buildings and malls; blocking the transport of and stealing Ukrainian grain exports; and bombing health care facilities, including a maternity hospital in Mariupol. In April, Dmitry Peskov, a spokesperson for Russian President Vladimir Putin, denied Russian troops had committed atrocities. Russia has also claimed that conditions in the eastern part of Ukraine it had seized were akin to genocide for Russian-speaking people before it invaded. Still, the report by New Lines and the Wallenberg Centre said Russia was guilty of â€œincitement to commit genocideâ€ and a â€œpattern of atrocitiesâ€ from which an intent to destroy the Ukrainian people could be inferred. Human Rights Watch, a New York-based group, said it is observing and documenting whatâ€™s happening in Ukraine. Rachel Denber, the groupâ€™s deputy director for Europe and Central Asia, said it was documenting â€œgrave breachesâ€ of international law and â€œheinous acts of murder, torture, inhuman conditions of detention.â€ â€œI think itâ€™s really important to focus on the evidence that we are documenting and what it is that our findings are so far because theyâ€™re really quite serious. The crime of genocide has a very specific threshold for intent, and while evidence of intent may become apparent, for now the most effective thing we can do is to continue to do our documentation of the conduct of the Russian forces,â€ she said. But even some old foreign policy hands on Capitol Hill are reluctant to go as far as the human rights community may be headed. â€œI donâ€™t put this in the same category as the Holocaust,â€ said Rep. Brad Sherman (D-Calif.), a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee since 1997. â€œI guess if you looked at the whole of Ukraine together, you could add up a lot of atrocities that might add up to [genocide].â€ Sherman, who supports aiding Ukraine, said the cost of justice has to be weighed against the costs to the U.S., the costs to the Ukrainians fighting and the risk of a nuclear war. Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), a staunch Ukraine supporter, also demurred when asked if he thought Russia had crossed the line. â€œIâ€™m in favor of helping Ukraine and giving them what they need to beat the Russians,â€ he said. â€œIf you could walk the streets of Irpin and Hostomel, like I did, and listen to the stories that those people told about what the Russian soldiers did â€” this is a genocide. The world needs to recognize it as such.â€ The State Department, which has recognized three instances of genocide since 2021 â€” the treatment of Muslim Uyghurs in China, the Rohingya in Burma and the Armenians in Turkey in 1915 â€” also has yet to follow Bidenâ€™s lead to add Ukraine to that list. â€œWe are aware of the New Lines Institute report. We are deeply concerned by the reportâ€™s findings and by what we are seeing, particularly with respect to the apparent gratuitousness of violence by members of Russiaâ€™s forces,â€ a State Department spokesperson told HuffPost. â€œThat is why we are working with allies and partners to gather, review and preserve evidence of atrocities and make it available to the appropriate bodies to hold those responsible to account.â€ In the Senate, though, two members of the Foreign Relations Committee have no doubts. â€œThere is no question that what Russia is doing in Ukraine is a genocide,â€ Sen. Jim Risch (Idaho), the top Republican on the panel, told HuffPost. â€œIf you could walk the streets of Irpin and Hostomel, like I did, and listen to the stories that those people told about what the Russian soldiers did â€• this is a genocide. The world needs to recognize it as such,â€ he said. â€œI think theyâ€™ve passed the international definition of genocide,â€ said Sen. Ben Cardin (D-Md.). â€œI thought they passed that a while ago. Transporting people, in some cases unaccompanied children, into Russia with clear intentions of removing them from their culture, thatâ€™s genocide.â€ Under the Genocide Convention, countries are required to take measures to prevent and punish genocide. The U.S., which has signed on to the treaty, has provided assistance to Ukraine to investigate and document â€œwar crimes and other atrocitiesâ€ in addition to imposing punishing economic sanctions and providing weapons and training to Ukraine. â€œThe â€˜preventâ€™ comes first. The entire purpose of the convention, its primary purpose, is to prevent genocide from happening.â€ Risch said the United States is already doing a lot, but not enough. â€œI personally would do more,â€ he said, declining to elaborate. Risch said he thinks the wariness to call what is happening genocide may stem from unfamiliarity with the definition. â€œThe Holocaust is the Holocaust. This, like many genocides, has its own marks and should be judged in that regard,â€ he said. Ibrahim, from New Lines, said the focus should not be on whether the definition has been met because the mere risk of genocide, which has been documented in their report, was enough to trigger the genocide treatyâ€™s obligations. The question, he said, was whether the 150-plus countries that signed the Genocide Convention would live up to their obligations. â€œThis is important because whatâ€™s happened too often in our lifetimes is whether something is a genocide or not becomes an academic exercise after the fact,â€ he said. â€œThe â€˜preventâ€™ comes first. The entire purpose of the convention, its primary purpose, is to prevent genocide from happening.â€

Title: Evidence Shows Russia Lied About Deadly Ukraine Shopping Mall Attack
Text: Firsthand witnesses and closed circuit television footage have discredited Russiaâ€™s several â€” and often conflicting â€” claims about a deadly missile strike on a shopping mall in Kremenchuk, Ukraine. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said Russia attacked the mall on Monday while over 1,000 people were inside. The attack killed at least 18 people, while 36 remain missing, according to Human Rights Watch. Russiaâ€™s defense ministry denied the attack was meant to target civilians, according to Reuters. â€œIn Kremenchuk, Russian forces struck a weapons depot storing arms received from the United States and Europe with high-precision air-based weapons,â€ the ministry said in a daily statement Tuesday on the state of the war. The Russians also disputed Zelenskyyâ€™s statement that the mall was crowded. â€œThe detonation of stored ammunition for Western weapons caused a fire in a non-functioning shopping centre located next to the depot,â€ the statement continues. CCTV footage, cited by The Guardian, showed there were two missiles fired in the area within minutes of each other. The first hit the shopping mall, while the second struck a nearby factory, the one Russia claims was used to store weapons. Human Rights Watch said it conducted two in-site investigations at the factory in question and did not uncover any evidence to support Russiaâ€™s claims that the facility was used to store military equipment provided by the West. â€œItâ€™s a place for making road equipment, machines for road construction,â€ Svitlana Rybalko, from the regional State Emergency Service, told the BBC. â€œThereâ€™s also a greenhouse nearby where workers grow cucumbers.â€ The BBC reported that the factory is about 300 meters away from the shopping center, separated by a wall and rail tracks. This shows that Russiaâ€™s claims that â€œsecondary explosionsâ€ are responsible for a fire inside the mall are â€œunlikely,â€ the BBC wrote. Witnesses have also cast doubt on Russiaâ€™s allegation that the mall was not in operation. The BBC labeled the claim as â€œfalseâ€ after talking to several staff and shoppers, including a woman living in a village nearby who regularly visits the area for shopping and said the mall has been â€œconstantly open.â€ The woman showed the BBC video shot inside the mall two days before the attack, with shoppers walking around and stores open for business. Human Rights Watch said it spoke to 15 people, including local officials and some of those injured in the attack, who confirmed the center was open to the public. Dmitry Polyanskiy, Russiaâ€™s deputy ambassador to the United Nations, on Monday presented another allegation â€• which contradicts the defense ministryâ€™s statement on Tuesday â€• claiming the attack was staged. â€œLooks like we are dealing with a new #Bucha-style #Ukrainian provocation,â€ Polyanskiy tweeted. Russia previously claimed that photos and videos of atrocities committed by its soldiers in Bucha, Ukraine, were fake. Looks like we are dealing with a new #Bucha-style #Ukrainian provocation. One should wait for what our Ministry of Defence will say, but there are too many striking discrepancies already. Exactly what Kiev regime needs to keep focus of attention on #Ukraine before #NATOSummit In another Twitter message, reported by the BBC, Polyanskiy said his tweet did not contradict Russiaâ€™s Ministry of Defense. Polanskiy added reports of the attack â€œwill be used by Ukraine to attract as much attention as possible through promoting [a] false version of what happened.â€ Reports of the incident have garnered the attention of world leaders. French President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday called the attack â€œa new war crime.â€ â€œRussia cannot and should not win,â€ Macron said at the end of the G-7 summit in Germany, according to The Associated Press. Zelenskyy also addressed the U.N. Security Council on Tuesday saying Russia is a â€œterrorist state,â€ committing â€œdaily terrorist acts.â€ â€œWe need to act urgently to do everything to make Russia stop the killing spree,â€ Zelenskyy said.

Title: Ukraine Is Now Officially A Candidate For The European Union
Text: European leaders gave Ukraine the status of a European Union candidate at a summit on Thursday in a key sign of ongoing support for Ukrainian resistance against Russian invaders and confidence in Ukraineâ€™s future. The president of the European Council, former Belgian prime minister Charles Michel, announced the news on Twitter. â€œA historic moment,â€ Michel wrote. â€œOur future is together.â€ The council â€” which comprises the heads of state of all EU member countries â€” additionally approved candidate status for Moldova, which also worries about Russian ambition regarding its territory. Neither country will immediately join the 27-country bloc: European officials want both countries to improve their judicial systems and tackle systematic corruption to meet EU standards before beginning membership negotiations, which are unlikely to start any time soon. But gaining candidate status is likely to boost Ukrainian morale amid tough fighting in the countryâ€™s east, and analysts say the move should help Ukrainian activists secure difficult domestic reforms. Ukraine applied to join the EU days after Russian President Vladimir Putin launched an invasion of the country in February. Top Ukrainians, including President Volodymr Zelenskyy, and their international supporters have spent months promoting the idea of membership for Kyiv â€• and won broad European agreement in an extremely short time considering the difficulty of securing unanimous support from EU members. The European Commission, the executive branch of the EU, recommended candidacy status for Ukraine last week, and even EU states close to Russia, such as Hungary, have not sought to block the plan. Though Putin has cited Ukraineâ€™s ties to the West as a concern that helped drive his decision to invade, he has said he does not have a problem with seeing the country as an EU member. Still, Zelenskyy has warned of possible Russian retaliation to the move, like an uptick in assaults on Ukrainian targets. The EU has a mutual defense clause, but most governments see it as far weaker than the joint defense agreement in the NATO military alliance, which also includes the United States and former E.U. member Britain. Thatâ€™s a key reason why European Union members Sweden and Finland reacted to Russiaâ€™s incursion into Ukraine by rushing to join NATO. Moving toward EU membership could be a major boon for Ukraine. Symbolically, it would demonstrate Kyivâ€™s independence from Russia, where Putin and his allies have repeatedly questioned whether Ukrainians should be acknowledged as separate from Russians. And economically, drawing closer to the EU would likely make Ukraine more attractive to international investors, while eventual membership could come with major development grants from the union. â€œSincerely commend EU leadersâ€™ decision... itâ€™s a unique and historical moment,â€ Zelenksyy wrote on Twitter after the news broke. Several other countries, including Turkey and Serbia, are also EU candidates, yet their membership processes are largely frozen. European solidarity with Ukraine â€• and horror at Russian brutality during the war â€• makes Kyivâ€™s bid seem more likely to succeed in the years ahead. And for now, the stamp of approval from the heads of state of EU members could also help address the growing war-weariness among some Europeans, showing that assistance to Ukrainians extends beyond weapon shipments. The EU has separately imposed several rounds of unprecedented sanctions on Moscow to try to pressure Putin to halt his assault, including a ban on most imports of oil from Russia.

Title: Ukrainian High School Grads Pose For Heartbreaking Photos In War-Torn Homeland
Text: Ukrainian high school seniors recently posed for a series of poignant graduation photos, juxtaposing their youth and tentative optimism with the horrifying devastation of war in their homeland. Photographer Stanislav Senyk told Reuters he wanted to document the â€œvery important storyâ€ of roughly 40 students graduating from schools in Chernihiv in northern Ukraine after witnessing the horrors of the war there. â€œI saw the children who were there and it was like some kind of surrealism going on,â€ Senyk said. â€œI realized that I could write a very important story at that moment, about schoolchildren who were graduating and who had witnessed the war, and because of that their graduation, their prom, their everything, just cracked,â€ he said. â€œIt was very important to capture that memory.â€ Photographer Stanislav Senyk has used the destruction in the eastern Ukrainian city of Chernihiv as a sobering backdrop for an album of graduating high school students, amid the ongoing conflict with Russia  One of the photos features a group of students huddled atop a tank. Another includes a group of girls in a bombed-out building, with others looking down from the gutted floors above. The students called the experience difficult â€” but important. â€œWe wanted to show that we live in such realities,â€ Olha Babynets, 17, told Reuters. â€œWe wanted to show our pain, which is there and has never subsided. It was difficult emotionally, but we tried to hold on. And I think we managed to do that.â€ In a separate set of photos shot by Abdullah Unver for the Anadolu Agency, Ukrainian students forced to skip their prom posed in their dance clothes in the rubble of their bombed-out school in Kharkiv.

Title: 2 Alabama Men Fighting With Ukraine Are Missing, Could Be First U.S. POWs
Text: Two Alabama men who joined Ukraineâ€™s fight against Russia have gone missing, according to statements made by their families amid fears they might have been captured by Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s forces. The men missing are Alexander John-Robert Drueke, a 39-year-old from Tuscaloosa, Alabama, who served as a U.S. Army staff sergeant, and Andy Tai Ngoc Huynh, a 27-year-old from Hartselle, Alabama, who served as a Marine. Their families said they last heard from them on June 8. Joy Black, Huynhâ€™s fiance, told CNN the families have no information on what happened or the two menâ€™s whereabouts. â€œWe donâ€™t want to make assumptions about what might have happened at this time,â€ Black said. â€œObviously theyâ€™re looking at several scenarios. And one of them is that they might have been captured. But we donâ€™t have absolute confirmation of that at this time.â€ Druekeâ€™s family said in a statement that the two men disappeared when their unit was met with â€œheavy fireâ€ on June 9 in the Kharkiv region of Ukraine. Subsequent searches for them did not yield any results. â€œThis could mean they are in hiding or it could mean they have been captured,â€ said Druekeâ€™s mother, Bunny Drueke, according to The New York Times. The State Department said Wednesday that officials â€œare aware of unconfirmed reports of two U.S. citizens captured in Ukraine,â€ according to CNN. â€œWe are closely monitoring the situation and are in contact with Ukrainian authorities,â€ the spokesperson continued. â€œDue to privacy considerations, we have no further comment.â€ If the men were captured by the Russians, they would be the first U.S. prisoners of war in this conflict. John Kirby, National Security Council coordinator for strategic communications, said at a White House briefing Wednesday that he was unable to confirm the reports. â€œIf itâ€™s true, weâ€™ll do everything we can to get them safely back home,â€ Kirby told reporters. Kirby said Americans should not be traveling to Ukraine at this time. â€œIf you feel passionate about supporting Ukraine, thereâ€™s any number of other ways to do that that are safer and just as effective,â€ Kirby said. â€œUkraine is not the place for Americans to be traveling.â€ Bunny Drueke and Black did a joint interview with CNNâ€™s Anderson Cooper Wednesday evening. Drueke spoke about her sonâ€™s motivation for going to Ukraine. â€œHe is one of the most loyal Americans you would ever hope to meet and he was proud to serve his country,â€ Drueke said. â€œHe said, â€˜Mom, I really need to go and help fight in Ukraine because if Putin is not stopped there, he is not going to be satisfied, he will become emboldened and eventually Americans will be threatened.â€™â€ Black said she is proud of her fiance. â€œHeâ€™s just so strong and he has such a big heart,â€ Black said. â€œHe didnâ€™t go there for selfish reasons or anything. He really had this gnawing at his heart and this big burden on him to go and serve the people however he can.â€ â€œI know itâ€™s not a great situation, but Iâ€™m still very proud of him and I just want to see him back safely,â€ Black said. Two Americans who were fighting alongside Ukrainian forces north of Kharkiv have been missing since June 9th. CNNâ€™s @andersoncooper has more on the efforts to find them.  The State Department announced Wednesday the U.S. is sending an additional $1 billion to Ukraine for military assistance. This brings the total amount the U.S. has contributed since Russia invaded the country on Feb. 24 to $5.6 billion. President Joe Biden said he told Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy Wednesday the U.S. will also provide $225 million in humanitarian assistance for Ukrainians. â€œI reaffirmed my commitment that the United States will stand by Ukraine as it defends its democracy and support its sovereignty and territorial integrity in the face of unprovoked Russian aggression,â€ Biden said.

Title: Antony Blinken Says He's 'Personally' Focused On Bringing Brittney Griner Home
Text: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Wednesday that itâ€™s a personal priority for him to bring home WNBA star Brittney Griner, who has been detained in Russia for months. â€œItâ€™s something that Iâ€™m personally focused on,â€ Blinken told a group of LGBTQ reporters at a Wednesday roundtable at the State Department, in a show of the departmentâ€™s support for Pride Month. â€œThereâ€™s a limit to what I can say publicly. But we are very focused on this. We are determined to bring her home.â€ Griner, a two-time Olympic gold medalist who is lesbian and plays basketball in Russia during the WNBA offseason, was detained at a Moscow airport in February after local authorities claimed she was carrying vape cartridges containing cannabis oil. They accused her of â€œsmuggling significant amounts of a narcotic substance,â€ an offense punishable in Russia by up to 10 years in prison. Last month, the State Department reclassified Grinerâ€™s status as â€œwrongfully detained,â€ meaning the United States will work more aggressively to secure her release. Russian officials on Tuesday extended Grinerâ€™s detention for the third time. That means she will remain in Russian custody through at least July 2. During Wednesdayâ€™s roundtable, Blinken said he has spoken to Grinerâ€™s partner and his team has spoken â€œextensivelyâ€ to Grinerâ€™s lawyers, advocates and teammates about the situation. Beyond that, he wouldnâ€™t give details about the status of talks with Russian officials. â€œJust know this is a matter of intense focus for us,â€ he said. When asked why it took two months for the State Department to classify Griner as â€œwrongfully detained,â€ Blinken said thereâ€™s a formal process the department has to go through, and a set of specific criteria for meeting that definition. Those criteria include whether someone is being detained as a political pawn, whether someone is being held simply because he or she is an American, and whether due process is being afforded. Blinken said the department weighs all criteria before concluding if someone has been wrongfully detained overseas. â€œWe have to follow the letter of the law,â€ he said. â€œThis is a situation that we have in a multiplicity of countries. The first thing is to make a determination about whether any individual is being unjustly detained ... And thatâ€™s what we did in the case of Brittney Griner.â€

Title: LeBron James Demands Biden Bring Brittney Griner Home â€˜Swiftly And Safelyâ€™
Text: LeBron James is sharing his public support for Brittney Griner as the WNBA player and two-time Olympic gold medalist remains in Russia, where she has been detained for more than 100 days. Our voice as athletes is stronger together,â€ James said in a tweet pleading for support. â€œAs a decorated Olympian and member of an elite global sport community, BGâ€™s detention must be resolved out of respect for the sanctity of all sport and for all Americans traveling internationally,â€ James wrote on Twitter. Title: European Union Slashes Russian Oil Imports In Major Blow To Vladimir Putin
Text: The European Union agreed to block most oil imports from Russia, cutting off a key income source for Russian President Vladimir Putin in an effort to convince him to halt his invasion of Ukraine. In a Monday evening tweet, European Council president Charles Michel announced the deal and said it would hit Moscowâ€™s â€œwar machine.â€ â€œMaximum pressure on Russia to end the war,â€ Michel continued. The deal is a huge step for the EUâ€™s 27 economies â€• for which Russia is a major source of energy â€• and a big boost for the Ukrainians. The policy will cut off around 70% of Russian oil immediately by halting tankers, and officials say it will eventually cease over 90% of Russian oil sales. Though the plan exempts oil transfers by pipelines for now, European diplomats say that trade could also ultimately be stopped. #Unity Agreement to ban export of Russian oil to the EU. This immediately covers more than 2/3 of oil imports from Russia, cutting a huge source of financing for its war machine. Maximum pressure on Russia to end the war. #EUCO More than a quarter of the EUâ€™s imported oil came from Russia last year. Ukraineâ€™s government and prominent international commentators have blasted Europe for continuing to pay Russia for oil and gas even after the war began in late February â€• specifically criticizing Germany, the EUâ€™s biggest economy. A third of Berlinâ€™s oil comes from Russia, and experts in the country say that cutting off that supply, along with Russian gas, could cause severe economic pain for Germans. Germany began signaling in late April that it was open to an oil ban. But Hungary â€• whose government has a close relationship with Russia and is a major Russian oil importer via pipeline â€” aggressively resisted the policy as EU negotiations intensified. European leaders struggled to finally craft an agreement that would satisfy Hungary, spurring fears that the bloc was becoming less supportive of Ukraineâ€™s resistance. Top EU figures finally reached a compromise after a summit in Brussels on May 30. European nations had earlier decided to stop importing coal from Russia, and has instituted five previous sets of unprecedented sanctions on Russian government officials and institutions like major banks. The U.S. and Britain have already barred imports of Russian oil. Global oil exports earn Moscow hundreds of millions of dollars each day. That revenue provides a major share of Putinâ€™s total budget for undertakings like his assault on Ukraine. Russia also earns billions by pumping gas to Europe. In April, Putin shut off gas exports to Poland and Bulgaria in response to their support for Ukraine, leading to anxiety in Europe about the continentâ€™s dependence on Russian energy supplies. This is a developing story. Check back for updates.

Title: Woman Strips On Cannes Red Carpet To Protest Russian Rapes In Ukraine
Text: A protester was whisked away by security guards on Friday after she stripped on the red carpet of the Cannes Film Festival to protest Russian rapes in the Ukraine war. The unidentified protester was painted with messages, including one reading: â€œStop raping usâ€ in the blue and yellow of the Ukrainian flag. As men in tuxedos and women in gowns streamed by, or watched, stunned, she began screaming, The Independent reported. The protest unfolded just ahead of the premiere of director George Millerâ€™s film â€œThree Thousand Years of Longing.â€ A tweet identified her as an activist from SCUM, which appears to refer to the 1967 radical feminist SCUM Manifesto. Une activiste SCUM s'introduit sur le tapis rouge du festival de #Cannes2022 pour dÃ©noncer les violences sexuelles infligÃ©es aux ukrainiennes dans le contexte de la guerre.#cannes2022redcarpet  There have been reports of legions of rapes and other sexual violence committed against Ukrainian civilians by Russian forces as a weapon of war. U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said last month that the particularly disturbing horrors in the town of Bucha were â€œnot the random act of a rogue unitâ€ but a â€œdeliberate campaign to kill, to torture, to rape, to commit atrocities.â€ On Tuesday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy delivered an address to the festival via video link. He quoted from â€œThe Great Dictator,â€ Charlie Chaplinâ€™s film satirizing fascism. â€œThe hate of men will pass, and dictators die, and the power they took from the people will return to the people,â€ Zelenskyy said. â€œAnd so long as men die, liberty will never perish.â€ He added: â€œAgain, then as now, there is a dictator. Again, then as now, there is a war for freedom. Again, then as now, cinema must not be silent.â€ He received a standing ovation. On Wednesday, Ukrainian filmmakers at the festival were horrified by the warfare theatrics of a French fighter jet display to honor actor Tom Cruise and the film â€œTop Gun: Maverick,â€ Agence France-Press reported. Title: Russia Is Firing Its Senior Commanders. What Does That Mean For Ukraine War?
Text: The Kremlin has fired several senior officials managing its invasion of Ukraine, yet another sign that the Russian war effort is significantly faltering. In its latest Twitter update, the British Ministry of Defence (MoD) claimed that Moscowâ€™s centralized command is only going to come under more pressure as it tries to re-establish control behind the scenes. The MoD explained that Russia â€œhas fired senior commanders who are considered to have performed poorly during the opening stages of its invasion of Ukraine.â€ Lieutenant General Serhiy Kisel, who commanded the elite 1st Guards Tank Army, has been suspended after he was unable to capture Ukraineâ€™s second-largest city Kharkiv. Ukrainian resistance â€œappear to have won the battle of Kharkivâ€ according to the U.S. think tank Institute for the Study of War, after Russian units were unable to hold their lines around the city. Russia has been bombarding the city since the war began three months ago, but the troops were not able to even encircle Kharkiv and were subsequently expelled. The commander behind Russiaâ€™s Black Sea Fleet, Vice Admiral Igor Osipov, is also likely to have been suspended after the cruiser Moskva sank in April. It was Russiaâ€™s flagship Black Sea missile cruiser which was struck down by two Ukrainian missiles, a huge symbolic and military blow to the Kremlin at a time when it was already losing morale. The U.K. officials also think that Russian chief of the General Staff Valeriy Gerasimov is still in post, â€œbut it is unclear whether he retains the confidence of President Putin.â€ Without a clear command system, the Russian forces â€“ already said to be disorganized and lacking supplies â€“ are unlikely to secure any victories in Ukraine any time soon. As the MoD summarized: â€œA culture of cover-ups and scape-goating is probably prevalent within the Russian military and security system. â€œMany officials involved in the invasion of Ukraine will likely be increasingly distracted by efforts to avoid personal culpability for Russiaâ€™s operational set-backs. â€œThis will likely place further strain on Russiaâ€™s centralized model of command and control, as officers increasingly seek to defer key decisions to their superiors. â€œIt will be difficult for Russia to regain the initiative under these conditions.â€ Latest Defence Intelligence update on the situation in Ukraine - 19 May 2022 Find out more about the UK government's response: #StandWithUkraine ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦  There seems to be a major problem with top military officials within the Russian forces right now. Ukraineâ€™s ministry of defense claimed earlier this month that U.S. intelligence has helped it to find and kill 12 Russian generals since the war began. Neither Russia nor the U.S. have confirmed this number, although the U.S. National Security Council later claimed that it was providing â€œbattlefield intelligenceâ€ to Ukraine, and did not have intent â€œto kill Russian generals.â€ While the details of this claim remain unclear, this is just one of many signs that central control is falling apart in Russia. President Vladimir Putin is also said to have taken over the day-to-day management of the war, despite such tasks typically falling to more junior commanders. â€œWe think Putin and Gerasimov are involved in tactical decision-making at a level we would normally expect to be taken by a colonel or a brigadier,â€ a Western military source said, according to the Guardian. Yohann Michel, defence and military research analyst at the International Institute for Strategic Studies, told the i newspaper: â€œIf youâ€™re trying to be both general and captain, you are usually doing neither and you are creating uncertainty at every level of the chain of command.â€ He added: â€œThe Russian armed forces donâ€™t need to have this level of micro-management from the top who have problems of their own.â€ Russiaâ€™s war effort is going so badly even a retired colonel broke rank on state TV and admitted: â€œSometimes information is being spread about some sort of psychological breakdown in Ukraineâ€™s Armed Forces, suggesting some sort of a breakthrough is imminent. â€œNone of this has a basis in reality.â€

Title: George Bush Calls Iraq Invasion 'Unjustified' In Cringey Slip-Up
Text: Itâ€™s a Bush-ism for the ages. Former President George W. Bush made a major slip-up when he detailed the â€œwholly unjustifiedâ€ invasion of Iraq during a speech in Dallas on Wednesday. Bush, who has dealt with his fair share of slip-ups over the years, made the error while referencing Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s invasion of Ukraine and silencing of political opponents. â€œThe decision of one man to launch a wholly unjustified and brutal invasion of Iraq,â€ Bush said before correcting his error. â€œI mean, of Ukraine... Iâ€™m 75.â€ You can watch Bushâ€™s major fumble below. Speaking in Dallas this afternoon, former President George. W Bush made a significant verbal slip-up while discussing the war in Ukraine. He tried referencing what he described as the â€œwholly unjustified and brutal invasionâ€ â€” but said Iraq, instead of Ukraine.  The slip-up brings to mind the former presidentâ€™s 2003 invasion of Iraq, a move by his administration to take away weapons of mass destruction he alleged were in the country. United Nations inspectors later discovered no evidence of weapons of mass destruction existed in the country before the U.S. attack. Critics have extensively panned Bush over the attack in the nearly two decades since. Bushâ€™s error came during part of an event focused on election safety and the U.S. democracy at the George W. Bush Presidential Center in Dallas, according to the Dallas Morning News. The former president made his â€œmost extensive public commentsâ€ about the invasion of Ukraine. His speech included a comparison of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to a 21st-century Winston Churchill.
