Title: Why 'Battle For The Donbas' Is A Significant New Phase Of Russia-Ukraine War
Text: A new phase of the war between Russia and Ukraine has begun, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said Monday night. â€œNow we can already state that the Russian troops have begun the battle for the Donbas,â€ he said in a video address about the long-feared, full-scale offensive to take control of Ukraineâ€™s east. With a â€œsignificant part of the entire Russian armyâ€ now deployed in the region, according to Zelenskyy, hereâ€™s what you need to know about what could be a turning point in the conflict. On February 24, Russia invaded neighboring Ukraine. Tanks and soldiers streamed across the border, in scenes more reminiscent of World War II than the remote cyber warfare that modern conflict was supposed to be dominated by. Russiaâ€™s invasion has damaged or destroyed up to 30% of Ukraineâ€™s infrastructure at a cost of $100 billion, Ukrainian officials have said, as the United Nations revealed the civilian death toll has now surpassed 2,000. About 4 million Ukrainians have fled the country. But Russiaâ€™s swift march to victory did not materialize. Driven back by Ukrainian resistance in the north, Moscow has refocused its ground offensive in the two eastern provinces known as the Donbas, while launching long-distance strikes at other targets including the capital, Kyiv. The Donbas is Ukraineâ€™s mostly Russian-speaking industrial heartland in the east, where Moscow-backed separatists have been fighting Ukrainian forces for the past eight years and have declared two independent republics that have been recognised by Russia. In recent weeks, the Kremlin declared the capture of the Donbas its main goal of the war after its attempt to storm Kyiv failed. After withdrawing from the capital, it began regrouping and reinforcing its ground troops in the east for what could be a climactic battle. On Monday, Ukraine military generals said Russian forces were increasing assaults in the Luhansk and Donetsk regions â€” both of which are part of the Donbas â€” as well as in the area of Zaporizhzhia. They also said Russia was sending reinforcements to the Crimean peninsula â€” seized from Ukraine in 2014 â€” and to the Rostov-on-Don area, which borders Ukraine. Zelenskyyâ€™s chief of staff Andriy Yermak called it â€œthe second phase of the warâ€ and assured Ukrainians that their forces could hold off the offensive. â€œBelieve in our army, it is very strong,â€ he said. The Associated Press reported a senior U.S. defense official saying there are now 76 Russian combat units in eastern and southern Ukraine, up from 65 last week. That could translate to around 50,000 to 60,000 troops. âš¡ï¸Foreign minister: Battle of Donbas will be similar to World War II.â€œThis will not be a local operation based on what we see from Russiaâ€™s preparations,â€ Dmytro Kuleba said, adding that he expects large-scale operations involving thousands of tanks, armored vehicles, aircraft. Russiaâ€™s stuttering campaign means control of eastern Ukraine has taken added significance, and may prompt the fiercest fighting yet. Russia needs some kind of â€œwinâ€â€” recognizing Russiaâ€™s claims in the Donbas and Crimea has also been the central plank of Vladamir Putinâ€™s demands at failed peace talks â€” and following the sinking of its Black Sea lead ship, Putin will not be contemplating further embarrassment. The new offensive in the east came as a Russian missile attack killed seven people in Lviv, the first civilian victims in the western city about 40 miles from Poland. It was one of a multitude of other targets across Ukraine in what appeared to be an intensified bid to grind down the countryâ€™s defenses. Lviv has seen only sporadic attacks during almost two months of war and has become a haven for civilians fleeing the fighting elsewhere. Now President Zelensky, in a new public address, says Russia has begun the battle for the Donbas and concentrated a large part of its army there for an all-out offensive in eastern Ukraine.  In other developments, Ukrainian troops remained holed up at a mammoth steel mill in Mariupol, the last known pocket of resistance in the devastated southern port city. The capture of Mariupol, where Ukraine estimates 21,000 people have been killed, is seen as key, and not just because it would deprive Ukraine of a vital port and complete a land bridge between Russia and the Crimean peninsula. General Richard Dannatt, a former head of the British Army, told Sky News that Russia is waging a â€œsoftening-upâ€ campaign ahead of the Donbas offensive. The U.S. defense official said that if Russian forces succeed in taking full control of Mariupol, that could free up nearly a dozen combat units for use elsewhere in the Donbas. Given the changing dynamics of the war, Ukraine is calling for an increasing supply of Western weapons. Last week, U.S. President Joe Biden announced an additional $800 million in military assistance to Ukraine, expanding the aid to include heavy artillery ahead of the wider Russian assault expected in eastern Ukraine. The U.S. military expects to start training Ukrainians on using howitzer artillery in coming days, with the training taking place outside Ukraine. EXC: Britain will hand Stormer armoured missile launchers to Ukraine to unleash hell on Mad Vlad Putinâ€™s jets and choppersMajor boost to Ukrainian air defences dubbed 'best kit yet' sent to hero Zelensky after display on Salisbury Plain two weeks ago.  The Sun reported that U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to provide Ukraine with tank-mounted Stormer armoured missile launchers, another sign the West is prepared to offer as much military hardware as possible without triggering a wider NATO vs. Russia conflict.

Title: Grandmaster Garry Kasparov Predicts 'Palace Coup' May Oust Putin Over Ukraine
Text: Russian chess legend Garry Kasparov on Monday explained what may lead to Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s ouster by his inner circle in a â€œpalace coup.â€ CNNâ€™s Paula Reid asked the longtime Putin critic and political activist if he expected to see more anti-Kremlin sentiment building in Russia as its invasion of Ukraine falters. â€œEventually, yes,â€ replied Kasparov, a chess grandmaster for the former Soviet Union and Russia. Kasparov then laid out â€œthe order of moves that cannot be reversed.â€ â€œFirst, the Russian public and Russian elite, they have to recognize the war is lost,â€ he said. â€œThe bad news coming from Ukraine will inspire more people to rise because economic hardship will increase.â€ â€œSo, military defeat in Ukraine, social-economic revolt and then you will have conditions, the right conditions, for a palace coup,â€ Kasparov predicted. â€œBecause many of Putinâ€™s inner circle will be looking for a scapegoat and itâ€™s always a dictator who should be blamed for all the failures.â€ Putin knows losing the war on Ukraine â€œis not an option for him,â€ said Kasparov. â€œItâ€™s a matter of political survival and in many cases â€¦ of physical survival,â€ he added. â€œThatâ€™s why he has to pretend he is winning the war.â€ Watch the interview here:

Title: Ex-MSNBC Analyst Joins Fight Against Russia In Ukraine: â€˜Iâ€™m Done Talkingâ€™
Text: Clad in combat gear and armed with an assault rifle, former MSNBC intelligence analyst Malcolm Nance revealed Monday that he had joined Ukrainian forces fighting on the ground against the Russian invasion. â€œI spent quite a bit of time here in the pre-war period,â€ Nance, a U.S. Navy veteran, told MSNBCâ€™s Joy Reid via video link from Ukraine. â€œAnd when the invasion happened, I had friends who were in Donetsk, who were in the Ukrainian army, who were writing to us and telling us, â€˜We are not going to survive tonight. We have been hit 500 times.â€™â€ â€œThe more I saw of the war going on, the more I thought, â€˜Iâ€™m done talking, all right? Itâ€™s time to take action here.â€™â€ He said he had joined the International Legion of Defense of Ukraine, a unit of Ukraineâ€™s army opened by President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in order to allow foreigners to join the resistance against Russia. An MSNBC spokesperson told The Daily Beast that Nance is no longer an analyst for the network now that he has joined the international legion. â€œIâ€™m here to help this country fight what is essentially a war of extermination,â€ he said. â€œThis is an existential war, and Russia has brought it to these people and they are mass murdering civilians. And there are people here like me who are here to do something about it.â€ .@MalcolmNance fighting in #Ukraine: "Let me say something to the president of the United States. Give them counter-battery long range artillery... Something that can out-range their artillery. If you do that, you stop the attacks on civilians." #TheReidOut  Iâ€™m DONE talking. #JoinTheLegion #StopRussia #SlavaUkraini  He said the international troopsâ€™ sole purpose is to â€œprotect the innocent people of Ukraine from this Russian aggressionâ€ against civilians. â€œThey massacre men, women and children, and that is the reason everyone [in the legion] is here.â€ He appealed directly to President Joe Biden for â€œcounter-battery long-range artilleryâ€ to guard civilians against rocket attacks. â€œRussia has one advantage on the battlefield, and that is long range artillery,â€ he said. After serving in the Navy, Nance, 61, began appearing on MSNBC and other national news networks as an intelligence and terrorism expert and foreign policy analyst. He has written several books on those subjects. The U.S. State Department has urged Americans not to travel to Ukraine. â€œU.S. citizens who travel to Ukraine, especially with the purpose of participating in fighting there, they face significant risks, including the very real risk of capture or death,â€ State Department spokesperson Ned Price said last month. â€œThe United States, as you know, is not able to provide assistance to evacuate U.S. citizens from Ukraine, including those Americans who may decide to travel to Ukraine to participate in the ongoing war.â€ CORRECTION: An earlier version of this article identified Nance as an MSNBC analyst. He is a former MSNBC analyst.

Title: Senator Chris Coons Suggests U.S. Troops May Be Needed At Some Point In Ukraine
Text: Sen. Chris Coons (D-Del.) suggested the U.S. may need to step up its military support for Ukraine if Russian President Vladimir Putin escalates further and repeats the horrific tactics used in the 11-year-old war in Syria. â€œI deeply worry that whatâ€™s going to happen next is that we will see Ukraine turn into Syria. The American people cannot turn away from this tragedy in Ukraine. I think the history of the 21st century turns on how fiercely we defend freedom in Ukraine and that Putin will only stop when we stop him,â€ Coons said Sunday on CBSâ€™s â€œFace the Nationâ€ when asked if he supported direct U.S. military involvement in Ukraine. Last week, Coons said U.S. policymakers need to set clear guidelines about the use of military force â€• including the sending of troops â€• if Russia uses chemical weapons or if some sort of accident leads to the death of U.S. service members in the region. â€œWe are in a very dangerous moment where it is important that, in a bipartisan and measured way, we in Congress and the administration come to a common position about when we are willing to go the next step and to send not just arms but troops to the aid in defense of Ukraine,â€ the senator, who sits on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said during a discussion hosted by the University of Michigan. He added: â€œIf the answer is never then we are inviting another level of escalation in brutality by Putin.â€ President Joe Biden has repeatedly ruled out sending U.S. troops to Ukraine, a move that could risk opening a wider war between two nuclear powers: the U.S. and Russia. The idea of sending troops to directly aid Ukraine is also broadly unpopular on Capitol Hill; even some of the staunchest war hawks on the Republican side of the aisle are opposed to it. Coons sought to clarify his remarks on Monday, tweeting that he was â€œnot calling for U.S. troops to go into the war in Ukraine.â€ The senator said the global community â€œmust be willing to take more forceful steps, from broadened sanctions to sending more advanced weapons to being prepared to respond if he escalates further in his war crimes against Ukraine.â€ Biden hasnâ€™t shied away from describing the horrors in Ukraine as a â€œgenocideâ€ or calling Putin a â€œwar criminal.â€ The president also approved another $800 million of weapons systems and other security assistance to Ukraine, on top of billions of dollars in aid already approved by Congress. Top lawmakers have suggested Congress will need to pass another security assistance package as Russia regroups and prepares a new offensive in eastern Ukraine. As the war in Ukraine, which began at the end of February, turns to a new phase, journalists and Ukrainian authorities have reported horrific scenes in towns and villages left by fleeing Russian troops, including mass graves, executions, torture, rape and looting involving Ukrainian civilians. â€œThe most terrible war crimes weâ€™ve seen since the end of World War II are being committed,â€ Ukraineâ€™s president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, said in a televised speech to the United Nations General Assembly earlier this month, later arguing that â€œRussia wants to turn Ukraine into silent slaves.â€

Title: Volodymyr Zelenskyy: 'Substantial Evidence' Points To Russia Committing Genocide
Text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy once again called on global leaders to take punitive action against Russia, saying â€œsubstantial evidenceâ€ in his country points to Russia committing genocide against his people but â€œnot everyone has got the gutsâ€ to stand up and stop the bloodshed. â€œItâ€™s clear that is not even a war; itâ€™s a genocide. They just killed people, not soldiers. People. They just shot people in the streets,â€ he told CNNâ€™s Jake Tapper of the numerous atrocities seen throughout the country since the start of Russiaâ€™s invasion, while highlighting the slaughter of people in Bucha, a suburb of Kyiv, in particular. â€œThese were not soldiers; they were civilians. They bound their hands; they forced children to watch as they raped their mothers; then they threw them in a well or in mass graves. Children, adults, the elderly. And we have substantial evidence that points to this being a genocide, audio and video where they talk about just how much they hate us,â€ he said in an interview that aired in full Sunday. Ukrainian President Volodymyr @ZelenskyyUa tells CNN's @jaketapper that his country has "substantial evidence" that Russia is committing genocide. #CNNSOTU  Video and satellite images taken in Bucha in recent weeks show bodies lining the streets while Russiaâ€™s military was in control of the region, rebutting Russiaâ€™s claim that the bodies had been placed there after its military left. Some of the bodies were seen with their hands bound behind their backs and gunshot wounds to the head. Zelenskyy, a father of two, expressed particular heartbreak over a recent video circulating that shows a mother finding her childâ€™s body down a well in the village of Buzova near Kyiv. He called the video â€œthe most horrifying thing I have seen in my life.â€ â€œI canâ€™t watch it as a father, only because all you want after this is revenge and to kill. I have to watch it as the president of a state where a lot of people have died and lost their loved ones,â€ he said. â€œAnd there are millions of people who want to live. All of us want to fight. But we all have to do our best for this war not to be endless. The longer it is, the more we would lose.â€ He further shared his belief that the violence could escalate beyond Ukraineâ€™s borders, stressing that Russia could use chemical or nuclear weapons and the rest of the world should â€œbe ready.â€ â€œFor them, life of the people is nothing,â€ he said. President Joe Biden on Tuesday also said he believes the killings in Ukraine are genocide but that he will â€œlet the lawyers decide, internationally, whether or not it qualifies.â€ French President Emmanuel Macron, who has engaged in diplomatic discussions with Russian President Vladimir Putin since the start of the war, has meanwhile stopped short of using such a label, saying an â€œescalation of wordsâ€ wonâ€™t bring peace. Zelenskyy said he has addressed Macron directly about that opinion and has invited the French leader, as well as Biden, to visit Ukraine to see the death and destruction firsthand. â€œHeâ€™ll come and see, and I am sure he will understand,â€ Zelenskyy said of Macron. Genocide is a crime recognized under international law as an act that intends â€œto destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnical, racial or religious group,â€ according to the Genocide Convention, which was ratified by the U.S. in 1988. The U.S. has recognized genocide only eight times since the Holocaust, with the government most recently in March accusing Myanmar of committing genocide against its minority Rohingya population. That recognition came nearly five years after the peak of the violence and follows similar recognitions by other countries, including Canada, France and Turkey.

Title: Ukrainian PM Says Mariupol â€˜Still Has Not Fallenâ€™ Despite Defying Deadline To Surrender
Text: Ukrainian Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal said that Mariupol, which has been under siege for nearly two months, has not yet fallen to Russian forces despite defying a Sunday deadline for the devastated port city to surrender. The city of Mariupol has gained international attention in part due to the vast documentation of its nonstop destruction at the hands of the Russian military. The shell of a city appeared on the brink of falling to the Russians on Sunday after Ukrainian defenders did not submit to Moscowâ€™s midday deadline for their surrender, but Shmyhal maintained that the city still belongs to Ukraine. â€œNo, [the] city still has not fallen. There is still our military forces, our soldiers, so they will fight to the end. As for now, they still are in Mariupol,â€ he told George Stephanopoulos on ABCâ€™s â€œThis Week.â€ â€œBut there is [a] huge humanitarian catastrophe because there is more than 100 civilians which are suffering for more than 40 days of this humanitarian crisis â€¦ in this besieged city,â€ he continued. â€œAnd they have no water, no food, no heat, no electricity. And we ask all of our partners to support and help to stop this humanitarian catastrophe in Mariupol.â€ Ukrainian Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal tells @GStephanopoulos that the city of Mariupol has not yet fallen to Russian forces because Ukrainian soldiers â€œwill fight till the end.â€ â€œBut there is a huge humanitarian catastrophe.â€  Mariupol has been under relentless attack by Russian forces that pounded most of the buildings and, according to Ukraine, killed at least 21,000 people. Russian military fired a lethal airstrike at a maternity hospital in the first couple of weeks of the invasion, and about 300 Ukrainians were reported killed in a theater where civilians, including children, were taking shelter. The city was home to about 450,000 before Russia invaded. An estimated 100,000 now remain, according to The Associated Press. The Russian military claims that about 2,500 Ukrainian fighters are holding out at a steel plant in the last pocket of resistance in Mariupol. That claim could not be independently verified. This is â€œwhat the Russian Federation did, deliberately did. And deliberately continues to destroy cities. Russia is deliberately trying to destroy everyone who is there in Mariupol,â€ Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said Saturday in a virtual address, adding that the situation in the port city remains as â€œsevere as possibleâ€ and that the devastation is â€œjust inhuman.â€ Capturing Mariupol would be Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s biggest victory in Ukraine after two months of costly fighting, major military deaths and forced withdrawal from some cities, as well as a worsening economy in Russia from increasing Western sanctions. The nuclear superpower also recently faced the humiliating loss of the flagship of its Black Sea Fleet to what Ukraine claimed was a missile attack. Russiaâ€™s potential seizure of Mariupol would allow Putin to secure a land corridor to the Crimean Peninsula â€” which it annexed from Ukraine in 2014 â€” and deprive the smaller country of a major port. The seizure would also allow more Russian troops to be available for the offensive on the east. Shmyhal said Sunday that Ukraine will try to stop the war â€œin any way,â€ including diplomatically when possible. But if Russians refuse to negotiate in good faith, â€œwe will fight to the end, absolutely.â€ â€œWe will not surrender. We wonâ€™t leave our country, our families, our land,â€ he continued. â€œSo we will fight absolutely to the end, to win in this war.â€

Title: Volodymyr Zelenskyy Bashes Mariupol Devastation As 'Just Inhuman'
Text: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said Saturday that the situation in the port city of Mariupol remains as â€œsevere as possible,â€ adding that itâ€™s â€œjust inhuman.â€ This is â€œwhat the Russian Federation did, deliberately did. And deliberately continues to destroy cities. Russia is deliberately trying to destroy everyone who is there in Mariupol,â€ Zelenskyy said in a virtual address. He pointed to the horrifying tragedy to again plead for the international community to give Ukraine â€œall necessary heavy weaponsâ€ and planes â€œimmediatelyâ€ to defend itself against the brutal invading forces. â€œI want to be heard right now: There has not been a single day since the blockade of Mariupol that we have not sought a solution â€” military or diplomatic, anything to save people. But finding this solution is extremely difficult. So far, there is no 100% valid option,â€ Zelenskyy said. Title: Ukraine's Defense Minister Mocks Sunken Russian Warship As New Black Sea 'Dive Site'
Text: Ukraineâ€™s defense minister, Oleksii Reznikov, hailed the sinking of Russiaâ€™s renowned guided missile cruiser the Moskva as the Black Seaâ€™s newest â€œdiving siteâ€ on Friday. Ukraine officials reported â€” and a Pentagon source confirmed â€” that the Russian navyâ€™s Black Sea fleet flagship sank Thursday after at least two Ukrainian Neptune missiles struck it. Russia acknowledged a fire on board but did not admit the ship had been hit. Kremlin officials said the Moskva sank in stormy seas as it was being hauled to a port after it was evacuated. The once-mighty warship will now make a â€œworthyâ€ dive site, quipped Reznikov, whoâ€™s an ocean diver. â€œWill definitely visit the wreck after our victory in the war,â€ he added in a tweet that featured a photo of him on a dive. A "flagship" russian warship is a worthy diving site. We have one more diving spot in the Black Sea now. Will definitely visit the wreck after our victory in the war.BTW, I already have 300 scuba dives  The loss of the Moskva is both a real and a devastating symbolic loss for Russia. Itâ€™s also one that holds particular significance for Ukrainians. During the first days of the war, it was reportedly officers on the Moskva who ordered Ukrainian soldiers stationed on Snake Island in the Black Sea to surrender. Instead, they replied via radio: â€œRussian warship, go fuck yourself.â€ It was initially believed all the Ukrainian soldiers were killed in the confrontation. Some did die, but others were captured by Russia, Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy told journalists last month. Those captured â€” including the soldier who actually transmitted the message to the warship â€” were released as part of a prisoner swap, and all were honored in Ukraine as heroes. After the showdown, Ukraine quickly issued a new stamp highlighting the soldiersâ€™ defiant response that featured an image of one of them flipping off the warship. #Ukraine Roman Hrybov, the Ukrainian soldier, who said the now-famous "Russian warship, go fuck yourself" phrase when asked to surrender, returned home. It was initially thought that Hrybov and all the border guards on Snake Island were killed. Hrybov was captured by Russians

Title: Zelenskyy: 'Countries Have To Be Worried' About Putin Possibly Using Nuclear Weapons
Text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said the rest of the world should be prepared for the possibility that Russian President Vladimir Putin could use nuclear weapons in his invasion of Ukraine. Speaking to CNNâ€™s Jake Tapper in Ukraineâ€™s capital city of Kyiv on Friday, Zelenskyy warned that â€œcountries have to be worriedâ€ about the potential use of tactical nuclear and chemical weapons. â€œNot only me, all of the world, all of the countries have to be worried, because it can be not real information, but it can be truth,â€ Zelenskyy, who spoke in English, told Tapper during their sit-down interview. â€œChemical weapons ... they could do it,â€ Zelenskyy added. â€œFor them, the life of the people is nothing.â€ The invasion of Ukraine by Russian forces entered its 50th day this week, and Zelenskyy praised the resolve of Ukrainians in an address to the nation, pointing out that Russia had planned to take Kyiv within a matter of days. That hasnâ€™t happened, but Russiaâ€™s military has continued its brutal assault and shelling of civilian cities, killing over 5,000 civilians in the city of Mariupol alone, according to its mayor. Russia has also suffered cataclysmic losses, including the deaths of more than 15,000 soldiers, according to NATO estimates from late March. And the flagship of Russiaâ€™s Black Sea fleet was destroyed this week after it was targeted by Ukrainian missiles. Last month, CNNâ€™s Christiane Amanpour asked Kremlin press secretary Dmitry Peskov if Putin was considering using nuclear weapons in his assault on Ukraine. â€œPresident Putin said that if anybody tries to stop him, very bad things will happen,â€ Amanpour said. â€œAnd I want to know whether you are convinced or confident that your boss will not use that option.â€ Peskov didnâ€™t rule it out. â€œWell, we have a concept of domestic security, and, well, itâ€™s public,â€ Peskov responded. â€œYou can read all the reasons for nuclear arms to be used. So, if it is an existential threat for our country, then [nuclear weapons] can be used, in accordance with our concept.â€

Title: Former Russian Lawmaker Says He's Fighting Alongside Ukrainian Troops
Text: A former member of the Russian legislative assembly is fighting alongside Ukrainian troops in the war waged by Russian President Vladimir Putin. Ilya Ponomarev, a Putin critic from Siberia who served in Russiaâ€™s State Duma from 2007 to 2016, spoke to CNNâ€™s Jake Tapper about how he ended up fighting with Ukrainian forces in Kyiv. He has lived in the Ukrainian capital since 2016. â€œWhat else could I do under those circumstances?â€ he said. â€œWhen Putinâ€™s forces were advancing, we needed to defend the country. We needed to defend the capital.â€ Ponomarev was the only lawmaker to vote against Russiaâ€™s annexation of the Ukrainian region of Crimea in 2014. The vote passed 445-1. Former member of Russian Parliament Ilya Ponomarev talks to CNN's @jaketapper about why he is fighting on the front lines with Ukrainian forces.  Ponomarev said heâ€™s been warned that he is on a Russian hit list, but that hasnâ€™t stopped him from wanting to fight. He believes Putin is losing the war, though the president may try to claim an â€œimaginary victory,â€ he added. â€œThe reality is that he is losing the war. And I think that the Ukrainian army and the Ukrainian people would not stop before Ukraine certainly will be free,â€ he said. â€œAnd I believe it will.â€ He said what Ukraine needs most now is clear skies. Many Ukrainian officials, including President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, have called for enforcement of a no-fly zone over the country to try to repel airstrikes that have targeted both the military and civilians. Western powers have resisted implementing one over concerns it could provoke open conflict with Russia, with the potential to evolve into a nuclear war. During his time in office, Ponomarev ran afoul of his colleagues and the Kremlin by speaking out against government corruption. In 2012, he led antigovernment street protests that rattled Moscow before Putinâ€™s return to the presidency. He was exiled from Russia and stripped of his legislative immunity from prosecution within a few months of voting against the annexation of Crimea.

Title: Trump Brags About Relationship To Putin As Fox News Shows Body Bags In Ukraine
Text: Former President Donald Trump skipped another opportunity to call Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s actions evil on Wednesday, then boasted about how well he knew the dictator. â€œI knew Putin very well. Almost as well as I know you, Sean,â€ Trump told his close confidante, Fox News host Sean Hannity, as the network aired graphic images of dead bodies and the damage left by Russian troops in Ukraine. â€œI will tell you, we talked about it, we talked about it a lot, he did want Ukraine, but I said, â€˜Youâ€™re not going into Ukraine,â€™â€ Trump continued. â€œHe would never, ever have gone into Ukraine.â€ Minutes earlier, Hannity had prompted Trump to denounce Putin. â€œI asked you the last time you were on, whether you think that this is evil in our time,â€ Hannity said. â€œDo you believe this is evil in our time?â€ Trump did not answer the question; instead ,he ranted about NATO. â€œDonâ€™t forget, I rebuilt NATO,â€ Trump falsely claimed. Trump also called what was happening in Ukraine a â€œgenocide,â€ joining President Joe Biden in characterizing Russiaâ€™s atrocities as such. Trump: I knew Putin very well. Almost as well as I know you Sean.  Last month, Hannity tried twice to get Trump to condemn Putin during an on-air interview, to no avail. Trump also faced backlash after initially praising what he called the authoritarian leaderâ€™s â€œgeniusâ€ strategy for invading Ukraine. He has repeatedly insisted that Putin would not have dared invade Ukraine if he was still president. Hannity and Trumpâ€™s eldest sons have offered their own commentary on the former presidentâ€™s relationship to Putin. Hannity said Trumpâ€™s praise of the Russian president was â€œtaken out of context.â€ Donald Trump Jr. claimed his dadâ€™s affection for dictators was an act in order to â€œplay these guys.â€ And Eric Trump lauded his fatherâ€™s â€œgreat relationshipâ€ with Putin and claimed that if he was still running the country, he would have simply called Putin and said, â€œVladimir, donâ€™t even think aboutâ€ invading Ukraine. There have been thousands of civilian casualties in Ukraine since the war began in February and Russian troops have been accused of indiscriminately bombing residential areas and targeting civilian shelters. The mayor of Mariupol said this week that more than 20,000 civilian residents had been killed in the invasion. According to the United Nations, some 10 million people in Ukraine have fled their homes.

Title: Rep. Ilhan Omar: Accountability For Russia Means Abandoning U.S. â€˜Hypocrisyâ€™
Text: Mounting evidence of widespread Russian atrocities in Ukraine is spurring the Biden administration and lawmakers from both parties to demand justice at a global level â€” specifically, at the International Criminal Court in The Hague. Now Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-Minn.) is challenging them to boost that prospect by making the U.S. a member of the court and repealing a George W. Bush-era law that requires the U.S. to block the court from investigating Americans. â€œWeâ€™ve engaged in a process for a long time of delegitimizing these international institutions that essentially call for accountability, and I think it is really disturbing that we now think they are powerful enough â€¦ to hold Russia accountable. Itâ€™s easy for people to see the hypocrisy in those two statements when weâ€™ve said previously that we donâ€™t believe in the ability of the court to [be] unbiased,â€ Omar said on Wednesday. The congresswoman spoke with HuffPost to discuss a new plan to introduce a package of legislation in the House of Representatives on Thursday that would set the U.S. on a course to join the court. She shared previously unreported aspects of the package: revoking the 2002 measure known as the Hague Invasion Act and enshrining the position of the State Departmentâ€™s Office of Global Criminal Justice, a team that the Trump administration considering shutting down. â€œItâ€™s really important for us not to have a law on the books that says in many ways it is OK for everyone to be prosecutedâ€ but not Americans, Omar told HuffPost. â€œThink about just how much more powerful of a statement it would be if we didnâ€™t just call for accountability for war crimes in Ukraine in holding Russians accountable for the possible war crimes they have committed but if we actually had skin in the game.â€ Progressives like Omar see developing a loud, nuanced position on Ukraine as critical to expanding their influence over national security policy and reforming the U.S.â€™s approach to global affairs. Conservatives and the Pentagon have argued for years that if the U.S. joined the court, American officials would face unfair and politically motivated investigations. But every Republican in the Senate recently voted for legislation recommending the court as a venue for probing Russiaâ€™s abuses, and House Republicans are supporting a bill urging the court to prosecute Putin if any harm befalls Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. Meanwhile, Biden administration officials are discussing how to support the courtâ€™s work on the Ukraine war, according to The New York Times, and former senator Chris Dodd and former White House lawyer John Bellinger say it is possible for the U.S. to do so despite domestic laws limiting the courtâ€™s reach. Echoing the discussion about greater international accountability, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations said on Tuesday that she backs a proposal to call U.N. General Assembly sessions after a member of the U.N. Security Council uses their veto power over U.N. actions. That step could make it harder for Russia to use the veto to shield itself â€” but also increase scrutiny of Americaâ€™s vetoes. â€œEverybody is coming around to recognizing that these bodies that uphold international law are an important part of international accountability,â€ Omar told HuffPost. â€œIf we all agree with that statement then we have to re-assume the mantle of leadership and give full backing and legitimacy to the court.â€ Noting that President Bill Clinton made a limited effort to join the court before President George W. Bush launched a foreign policy largely rejecting any degree of global governance, Omar said she sees the U.S. failure to participate as an abandonment of Americaâ€™s historic role in efforts like prosecuting Nazi atrocities at Nuremberg. And it places the U.S. in a small, awkward club: Russia is one of the minority of other nations that does not work with the court. Omar criticized a separate 1999 law that prevents taxpayer dollars from being spent on helping the court. Noting that former President Donald Trump placed sanctions on court officials and their family members when the court began to consider alleged American excesses in Afghanistan, the congresswoman said the U.S. has to â€œremedy that harm.â€ Her effort may attract some surprising support. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) told the Times that he sees the court as â€œthe only venueâ€ for investigating Putin and he would â€œlook at the laws on the books and see if they need to be changed to make sure these investigations can be supported, either financially or to provide any intelligence or manpower.â€ Given reservations among Republicans and more moderate Democrats including President Joe Biden, any tweaks to the regulations could ultimately be minimal. Omar said she will seek support â€œfar and wide,â€ including inside the Biden administration, and reminded her colleagues that their counterparts could take either a positive or a worrying message from the U.S.â€™s debate over the court. She pressed Secretary of State Antony Blinken on the court at a hearing last year, and he responded that America had its own mechanisms for justice. â€œMany people around the world can say that if they want,â€ the congresswoman told HuffPost. â€œTrue justice is blind and if we are to say we are the people who respect law and order, we canâ€™t create exemptions where our people arenâ€™t subjected to the rule of law and order.â€

Title: Joe Biden Approves $800 Million In New Military Aid For Ukraine
Text: President Joe Biden will send Ukraine additional military aid worth $800 million, equipping the country with helicopters and howitzer artillery as it prepares for a new round of major battles with Russian forces. â€œThe steady supply of weapons the United States and its Allies and partners have provided to Ukraine has been critical in sustaining its fight against the Russian invasion,â€ Biden said in a statement Wednesday. â€œIt has helped ensure that Putin failed in his initial war aims to conquer and control Ukraine. We cannot rest now.â€ The aid package includes radars, drones, armored vehicles, body armor and ammunition, according to a Pentagon statement later in the day. Six weeks into its attack on Ukraine, Moscow is now focused on capturing two regions in the east of the country, Luhansk and Donetsk, Ukrainian officials and military analysts say. Fresh U.S. shipments could help Ukrainian troops stop Russia from capturing strategic towns and supply routes. â€œThis will be a knife fight. This could be very bloody and very ugly,â€ a senior American defense official said of the next phase of the war in a briefing with reporters last week. In preparation, the U.S. also recently allocated $100 million in anti-tank Javelin systems for Ukraine. Biden has already directed more than $2.4 billion in military support and more than $300 million in humanitarian aid to the country. Congress last month approved nearly $10 billion for such programs. American allies including Britain, Australia, Slovakia and other nations are also pumping supplies, such as air defense equipment and medical gear, to the Ukrainians. Russiaâ€™s vicious approach to the conflict â€• including the apparent mass murder of everyday Ukrainians in occupied areas and repeated strikes on civilian targets â€• has made Ukraine even more determined to resist. Between the evidence of atrocities and Ukraineâ€™s battlefield prowess so far, Ukrainian activists and officials say there is a clear imperative for foreign governments to provide all the help they can. And Russian President Vladimir Putin seems set on further fighting, too. He recently appointed a new top commander for the war â€” one who led brutal assaults in Russiaâ€™s intervention in Syria, according to U.S. intelligence. Putin said Tuesday that he sees peace talks as dead. â€œPutin is just trying to wipe out the idea of even being a Ukrainian,â€ Biden said on Tuesday. He suggested that Washington views Russiaâ€™s campaign as â€œgenocide,â€ and he has previously called Putin a war criminal.

Title: Finland And Sweden Move Closer To Joining NATO Amid Russia's Ukraine War
Text: Finland and Sweden are inching closer to abandoning their long-held neutrality and joining NATO as Russiaâ€™s unprovoked assault on Ukraine continues to yield devastation some have called genocide. Finnish Prime Minister Sanna Marin said Wednesday that her country would decide whether to join the seven-decade-old military alliance within â€œweeks.â€ Her party has already begun weighing the pros and cons of applying. Marin was joined at a news conference by her Swedish counterpart, Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson. Both Nordic leaders said Russiaâ€™s Ukraine invasion had changed how they think about their national security. â€œThe European security architecture has changed fundamentally after Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine,â€ Marin said. â€œThere is a before and after 24th of February,â€ Andersson added, referencing the first day of the invasion. â€œThe security landscape has completely changed.â€ A larger NATO is exactly what Russian President Vladimir Putin did not want, and the Kremlin has warned both nations against joining the alliance. Finland shares an 830-mile border with Russia, but has so far declined to join NATO, which aims to curtail Russian aggression. Swedenâ€™s neighbor to the west, Norway, is already a NATO member. Public support for joining NATOâ€™s 30 member countries is around 60% in Finland and 50% in Sweden, according to The Guardian, citing multiple opinion polls. On Tuesday, atrocities revealed after Russian troop movements prompted President Joe Biden to accuse Putin of committing â€œgenocideâ€ against Ukrainians, echoing assertions by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

Title: BBC Works To Remove Fake Video Claiming Ukraine Bombed Its Own Train Station
Text: A video that appeared to be from the BBC suggesting Ukrainian missiles were behind the attack on a train station in Kramatorsk, in eastern Ukraine, where at least 52 people were killed on Friday, is fake, according to a statement released by the network. â€œThe BBC is taking action to have the video removed,â€ the BBC News Press Team account tweeted on Wednesday. We are aware of a fake video with BBC News branding suggesting Ukraine was responsible for last weekâ€™s missile attack on Kramatorsk train station. The BBC is taking action to have the video removed. We urge people not to share it and to check stories on the BBC News website. The video was aired on Russian state TV and shared on social media platforms, the BBC said, according to The Guardian. This is not the first lie being spread during Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. The Kremlin has been using disinformation to shift blame for the atrocities its forces are committing on the ground. Steve Rosenberg, the BBCâ€™s Russia Editor, interviewed the widow of a Russian soldier killed during the war, who dismissed allegations that Russian forces are responsible for war crimes in Ukraine. Later that evening, Rosenberg saw a picture of himself interviewing the woman being featured in a piece published on a Russian website. â€œItâ€™s easy to guess how the recently widowed resident of Stavropol must have felt talking to journalists from a country that is an accessory to the death of her husband,â€ the article reads, according to a translation provided by Rosenberg, suggesting the U.K. was in part responsible for the manâ€™s death. Russian state media sought to discredit photos and video depicting the atrocities in Bucha, Ukraine, while claiming Ukraine was behind those attacks as well. Russian President Vladimir Putin himself said Ukraineâ€™s claims that Russian soldiers killed civilians in the city were â€œfake,â€ in a rare public appearance Tuesday. During the same news conference, Putin said Russia â€œhad no other choiceâ€ in continuing the war to â€œensure Russiaâ€™s own securityâ€ and claimed the operation was going according to plan, despite failing to capture Kyiv, Ukraineâ€™s capital. Meanwhile, Russian media are banned from using the words â€œwarâ€ and â€œinvasionâ€ to describe the invasion, which Putin says is a â€œspecial military operationâ€ to help â€œdenazifyâ€ Ukraine. Ukraineâ€™s president is Jewish, and a United Nations investigation found no evidence to support Putinâ€™s claims. Last month, the last independent newspaper left in Russia was forced to suspend its operations, following a second warning by the countryâ€™s media regulator.

Title: Team Ukraine Arrives Safely Ahead Of Prince Harry's Invictus Games: 'We Are Delighted'
Text: Against all odds, Team Ukraine has arrived safely in the Netherlands ahead of the Invictus Games. â€œWe are delighted to share the safe arrival of Team Ukraine ahead of their participation in the Invictus Games The Hague 2020,â€ the Invictus Games Foundation Twitter account said in a statement on Wednesday, alongside photos of the athletes. â€œThey have been training for this event as part of their recovery for the last 3 years, and are looking forward to being a part of the Invictus community in person once again,â€ the statement added. Prince Harry founded the games, which are a Paralympic-style multisport event for wounded service people, back in 2014. The games were originally supposed to take place in The Hague two years ago, hence the official titleâ€™s reference to 2020. They are finally set to kick off from April 16 to April 22 after being delayed and rescheduled multiple times due to the coronavirus pandemic. We are delighted to share the safe arrival of Team Ukraine ahead of their participation in the Invictus Games The Hague 2020. They have been training for this event as part of their recovery and are looking forward to being a part of the Invictus community in person once again.  For Team Ukraine, the journey to get to The Hague has been an unfathomable one as Russiaâ€™s deadly invasion of Ukraine continues and nearly 5 million Ukrainians have evacuated the country. Tragically, four members of Ukraineâ€™s Invictus community have died in the invasions: Serhii Karajvan, Dmytro Oliynyk, Vladimir Motelchuk and Sergey Smilin. â€œAll were Warrior Games trialists and competitors, and whilst they were not preparing for the Invictus Games The Hague 2020, they were all extremely active in the international Invictus community on the We Are Invictus platform,â€ the Invictus Games Foundation said on its website earlier this month. â€œCompeting in events over the past year including the virtual London Marathon, and online Rowing championships.â€ At the time, it wasnâ€™t known whether Team Ukraine would be competing virtually or in person, which is what makes Wednesdayâ€™s news so important. â€œThis is HUGE. There has been a load of, understandable, uncertainty as to whether @invictusgamesua would make it to @InvictusGamesNL,â€ tweeted veteran JJ Chalmers on Wednesday. Chalmers is a friend of the Duke of Sussex and an Invictus Games medalist and will be announcing at this yearâ€™s games. â€œThank you to everyone who made this possible, I canâ€™t wait to get out there and see you guys.â€ As the crisis in Ukraine continues, both the Duke and Duchess of Sussex have voiced support for Ukraine, made donations to help people and media organizations on the ground, and supported organizations giving aid. â€œPrince Harry and Meghan, The Duke and Duchess of Sussex and all of us at Archewell stand with the people of Ukraine against this breach of international and humanitarian law and encourage the global community and its leaders to do the same,â€ the royals said in an announcement on their website in February. Both Harry and Meghan will be at the opening ceremonies of the games, which are set to kick off on Saturday. The games hold a special place in the coupleâ€™s story, as the two made their first public appearance together (while already secretly engaged) at the 2017 Invictus Games in Toronto.

Title: Trevor Noah Has Bad News For Russian Influencers Cutting Up Their Chanel Bags
Text: Trevor Noah has unfortunate news for Russian influencers whoâ€™ve been cutting up their Chanel bags to protest the companyâ€™s withdrawal from their country: â€œChanelâ€™s already got your money.â€ â€œWhile the rest of the world is focused on the Ukrainian victims of Putinâ€™s war, many Russian Instagram influencers, well, they feel like theyâ€™re the real victims of whatâ€™s happening in Ukraine,â€ the â€œDaily Showâ€ host said Monday. A number of Russian social media stars have recently posted videos of themselves destroying their designer handbags after Chanel suspended operations in Russia. Chanel also asked customers in global stores to declare that items they purchased would not be used in Russia. â€œThis doesnâ€™t hurt Chanel,â€ Noah said. â€œYou think when youâ€™re cutting up that purse, Coco Chanel is in Monaco on a yacht feeling it like a designer voodoo doll?â€ (The comedian added that yes, he is aware the brand founder is actually dead). Watch his roast below:

Title: WNBA Players Union President Says Gender Pay Gap Helped Lead To Brittney Grinerâ€™s Arrest
Text: Nneka Ogwumike, the head of the WNBA players union, on Tuesday shared an update on Brittney Griner, the seven-time WNBA All-Star who was arrested in Russia in February and remains in custody overseas. Ogwumike, president of the Womenâ€™s National Basketball Players Association, appeared on â€œGood Morning Americaâ€ Tuesday to discuss the leagueâ€™s efforts to bring Griner home. Griner was arrested on Feb. 17 in Russia â€• a week before that country invaded Ukraine â€• after officers with the Russian Federal Customs Service allegedly found vape cartridges containing hash oil in Grinerâ€™s luggage. â€œItâ€™s tough ... That could have been us,â€ Ogwumike said of Griner, a Phoenix Mercury star and two-time Olympic gold medalist. â€œWeâ€™re really most concerned about her health and safety, especially her mental health. Weâ€™re hearing that in that respect, sheâ€™s OK, but we want her home.â€ â€œBG is us,â€ she emphasized, referring to Griner by her initials. â€œWe are BG.â€ EXCLUSIVE: WNBA Players Association President @nnekaogwumike speaks to @GMA about efforts to bring Brittney Griner home from Russia. Ogwumike also explained why sheâ€™s speaking out about Griner now. â€œWe move intentionally, and given the nature of Brittneyâ€™s situation, when it happened â€• it was very important for us to be intentional about doing the best thing to ensure that we donâ€™t compromise her coming home,â€ she told â€œGMAâ€ anchor Robin Roberts. â€œA lot of that had to do with educating ourselves about the details of what was going on,â€ she went on. â€œAs much as we could know. But then understanding how important it was for us to be strategic about when and how we speak about her.â€ Ogwumike and Roberts talked about how problems of gender inequality helped to land Griner in her current situation. â€œItâ€™s disappointing that the question of it being a gender issue is top of mind now, when it comes to this type of circumstance,â€ she said. â€œThe reality is, sheâ€™s over there because of a gender issue â€• pay inequity.â€ The highest-paid player in the WNBA earns $228,000 a year, while some top NBA players make more than $1 million, according to ABC News. Itâ€™s not unheard of for WNBA players to travel overseas during the offseason to earn some extra money. â€œWe go over there to supplement our incomes,â€ said Ogwumike, who herself previously played in Russia for four years, China for two years and Poland for one.

Title: Joe Biden Calls Russia's Deadly Attack On Ukraine 'Genocide'
Text: President Joe Biden called Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine a genocide, saying â€œPutin is just trying to wipe out the idea of even being a Ukrainian.â€ On Tuesday, in remarks during a trip to Iowa, the president spoke about rising gas and other consumer prices amid Russiaâ€™s war on Ukraine. â€œYour family budget, your ability to fill up your tank, none of this should hinge on whether a dictator declares war and commits genocide a half a world away,â€ he said, according to CNNâ€™s DJ Judd. Biden later doubled down on his comments in remarks to reporters, saying lawyers would decide whether Russiaâ€™s actions meet the international definition of genocide, â€œbut it sure seems that way to me.â€ â€œYes, I called it genocide â€” itâ€™s become clearer and clearer that Putin is just trying to wipe out the idea of even being a Ukrainian,â€ he added. Previously, the president had condemned the Kremlinâ€™s attacks on Ukraine by saying Putin was a â€œwar criminalâ€ and should face a trial for war crimes. The United Nations defines genocide as killing or causing serious harm to a group â€” national, ethnic, racial or religious â€” with the intent to destroy the group in whole or in part. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, who had previously described Russiaâ€™s actions as genocide, responded to Bidenâ€™s remarks on Twitter: â€œCalling things by their names is essential to stand up to evil.â€ He added that Ukrainians â€œurgently need more heavy weapons to prevent further Russian atrocities.â€ Since Russia began its attack on Ukraine in late February, the U.N. has tracked nearly 2,000 deaths and over 2,500 injuries, noting the actual numbers are likely â€œconsiderably higher,â€ with reports of mass deaths in some areas, including Mariupol, still to be confirmed. Mariupolâ€™s mayor said this week that over 10,000 civilians in his city have died in Russian attacks. Over 4 million Ukrainians have fled their country due to the violence. Earlier this week, Rep. Liz Cheney (R-Wyo.) said Russiaâ€™s brutal attack â€œclearly is genocide.â€

Title: Julian Lennon Performs 'Imagine' For First Time To Benefit Ukraine
Text: John Lennonâ€™s first-born son Julian performed his dadâ€™s famous song â€œImagineâ€ for the first time publicly to benefit war-torn Ukraine and its people. He sang the song Saturday as part of the Global Citizenâ€™s social media rally, Stand Up For Ukraine. Julian Lennon, 59, had vowed never to perform his dadâ€™s song, which imagines an ideal world of peace and love, free of hunger and pain, created through human intention. But the â€œunimaginable tragedyâ€ in Ukraine moved him to respond in the â€œmost significant way I could,â€ he wrote on YouTube. â€œSo today, for the first time ever, I publicly performed my Dadâ€™s song, â€˜Imagine,â€™â€ he added. â€œI had always said that the only time I would ever consider singing â€˜Imagineâ€™ would be if it was the â€˜End of the Worldâ€™ â€¦ Because within this song, weâ€™re transported to a space, where love and togetherness become our reality, if but for a moment in time,â€ Lennon explained. â€œThe song reflects the light at the end of the tunnel that we are all hoping for.â€ Lennon called on the world to support Ukraine â€” and all refugees. â€œAs a result of the ongoing murderous violence, millions of innocent families, have been forced to leave the comfort of their homes, to seek asylum elsewhere,â€ he wrote. The social media rally also featured several other celebrities, including Bruce Springsteen, Elton John, Billie Eilish and Madonna. More than $10 billion was pledged to help Ukraine and Ukrainians by Saturday, Deadline reported.

Title: NATO Expects To Maintain Heavy, Long-Term Military Presence On Its Eastern Border
Text: NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg has indicated that the multinational alliance plans to heavily bolster its eastern border long-term with a military force that would be capable of taking on an invading army. Stoltenberg, in an interview published Saturday in The Telegraph, said military commanders for NATOâ€™s 30 member countries are preparing a â€œresetâ€ of the alliance that must include an increase in national defense spending in order to ward off future threats. Some members still do not meet the allianceâ€™s guideline on defense spending. Members are instructed to allocate at least 2% of their gross domestic product to defense. â€œWe have to ensure that we continue to be able, in a more dangerous world, to protect and defend all NATO allies,â€ Stoltenberg said. The secretary-general described NATOâ€™s previous presence along the border â€• prior to the start of Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine in February â€• as a mere â€œtripwireâ€ that was more symbolic of the allianceâ€™s unity than anything. It was not designed to repel an invasion. â€œRegardless of when, how, the war in Ukraine ends, the war has already had long-term consequences for our security,â€ he said. â€œNATO needs to adapt to that new reality. And thatâ€™s exactly what we are doing.â€ Stoltenberg said NATO will adopt a new Strategic Concept document in June at the 2022 Madrid Summit. This formal strategy document will not only outline NATOâ€™s defense efforts against Russia, but for the first time is expected to mention China as a growing threat. â€œI expect China to be an important part. Because the rise of China, the shifting global balance of power, has direct consequences for NATO,â€ Stoltenberg told The Telegraph. â€œIt is also of concern that we see that Russia and China are working more and more closely together. This is something that matters for our security.â€

Title: Liz Cheney Says Russia's War On Ukraine â€˜Clearly Is Genocideâ€™
Text: Rep. Liz Cheney (R-Wyo.) said Sunday that Russiaâ€™s brutal attacks on Ukraine constitute genocide, a term the White House has so far avoided using when talking about the war. Cheney appeared on CNNâ€™s â€œState of the Union,â€ where she spoke with host Jake Tapper about the mass killing of Ukrainian civilians since Russia invaded the neighboring country. â€œI think this clearly is genocide. I think that you asked exactly the right questions,â€ she told Tapper. â€œI think that Europe needs to understand and grapple with the fact that youâ€™ve got a genocidal campaign â€• the first kind of horrific genocidal campaign that we have seen certainly in recent decades.â€ "I think this is clearly a genocide."CNN's @jaketapper asks Rep. Liz Cheney (R-WY) about a missile strike on a Ukrainian train station that left dozens dead and how she thinks European allies should respond. #CNNSOTU @CNNSotu  Article II of the United Nations Genocide Convention defines genocide as â€œany of the following acts committed with intent to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnical, racial or religious groupâ€ â€• followed by a list of actions such as â€œkilling members of the group,â€ â€œimposing measures intended to prevent births within the group,â€ â€œforcibly transferring children of the group to another group,â€ and deliberately inflicting â€œconditions of lifeâ€ meant to bring about the groupâ€™s physical destruction. The U.N. treaty has been criticized since its 1948 adoption, both by those who feel its definition of genocide is too narrow and others who believe the term can be applied to too many situations. As defined by the treaty, the most recent act of genocide took place in 1994 in Rwanda. The International Criminal Court, however, issued an arrest warrant for Sudanâ€™s president in 2010 on genocide charges; the U.S. in 2016 accused the Islamic State of genocide in Iraq and Syria; Gambia submitted a case to the International Court of Justice in 2017 accusing of Myanmar of genocide against Rohingyas; and several nations formally accused China last year of genocide against the Uyghurs in Xinjiang. Ukrainian officials, including President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, have described Russiaâ€™s attacks on civilians as a genocide â€• raising comparisons to the horrors of the Holodomor, where millions of Ukrainians died of a famine engineered by the Soviet government in 1932. The International Criminal Courtâ€™s prosecutor is currently conducting an investigation on the atrocities stemming from the Russian invasion. Though White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan was comfortable saying Russiaâ€™s actions constitute war crimes, he hesitated on Sunday to describe the attacks as genocide. â€œLook, in my opinion, the label is less important than the fact that these acts are cruel and criminal and wrong and evil and need to be responded to decisively. And that is what we are doing,â€ Sullivan told Tapper. â€œAnd weâ€™re doing that not just by supporting international investigations and gathering evidence to hold the perpetrators all the way to the highest levels accountable. Weâ€™re doing it by providing sophisticated weapons to the Ukrainians that are making a major difference on the battlefield.â€ Congress voted on Thursday to suspend normal trade relations with Russia and to ban oil imports, while the European Union approved an embargo on coal imports. The U.N. General Assembly voted to suspend Russia from its Human Rights Council. Sullivan pointed out that banning oil imports is harder for European countries that are much more reliant on Russian energy. The U.S. is â€œsurging exports of U.S. liquefied natural gas to Europeâ€ so other countries can wean off Russian oil and gas. Cheney said Sunday that European nations need to pull the plug on Russian imports if they truly support Ukraine in the war. â€œEuropeans need to understand that theyâ€™re funding that genocidal campaign,â€ she told Tapper. â€œI understand the economic consequences to countries in Western Europe, if they were to impose the kind of oil and gas embargo that the U.S. has imposed against Russian oil and gas, but they need to do it. And we need to do everything we can to increase our own domestic production, to help make sure that we can supply them with as much as possible.â€ â€œBut they need to understand that every single time, every single day that they are continuing to import Russian oil and gas,â€ she went on, â€œtheyâ€™re funding Putinâ€™s genocide in Ukraine.â€

Title: Boris Johnson Visits Kyiv To Speak With Zelenskyy And Pledge Weapons
Text: U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson made a surprise visit to Kyiv on Saturday to meet with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy after Russian forces retreated from the area earlier in the week. Johnson pledged to send more defensive weapons and financial aid to the war-ravaged country in what he called â€œa testament of our commitment to [Zelenksyyâ€™s] countryâ€™s struggle against Russiaâ€™s barbaric campaign.â€ Surprise ğŸ˜‰  The British government announced a new Â£100 million ($130 million) aid package on Friday that includes more than 800 NLAW antitank missiles, an unspecified number of Javelin antitank weapons and Starstreak air defense systems, along with body armor and other supplies. The U.K. previously pledged Â£350 million in military aid to Ukraine since Russia began its war around six weeks ago. Western military officials initially feared the Ukrainian capital would fall within days of Russiaâ€™s invasion. Yet while Russian forces attempted to encircle Kyiv, they did not manage to take the city, now a symbol of Ukrainian resistance. Johnsonâ€™s visit came one day after European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen made a trip to the Ukrainian capital city to offer support and speak with Zelenskyy about bloc membership. She said a decision on whether to welcome Ukraine to the European Union would be made in â€œa matter of weeks,â€ instead of the usual yearslong timeline. â€œRussia will descend into economic, financial and technological decay, while Ukraine is marching towards the European future. This is what I see,â€ von der Leyen said at a press conference, according to Reuters. Today I met my friend President @ZelenskyyUa in Kyiv as a show of our unwavering support for the people of Ukraine.We're setting out a new package of financial & military aid which is a testament of our commitment to his country's struggle against Russiaâ€™s barbaric campaign.  The EU president also toured the Bucha region northwest of Kyiv, where authorities say Russian soldiers committed atrocities against civilians â€• allegedly dismembering people before killing them and looting peopleâ€™s homes on their way out. Zelenskyy said Thursday that the situation in nearby Borodyanka was even worse. As Russians appear to regroup in eastern Ukraine, the countryâ€™s leaders are urging NATO countries to resupply its weapons stores ahead of the next phase of the war. Activists visited the White House on Friday to request more military support, arguing that the Russian attack on a train station that killed more than 50 people hours before was proof more help was needed.

Title: Volodymyr Zelenskyy Says He Never Thought Defending Freedom Would Be 'So Costly'
Text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said his people are fighting for freedom against Russiaâ€™s attacks on civilians in a sit-down interview inside a Kyiv government building. â€œThey say weâ€™re defending Western values,â€ Zelenskyy told CBSâ€™s â€œ60 Minutesâ€ for Sundayâ€™s program. â€œI always say, what are Western values? Someone who lives in the United States or Europe, do they also not like children? Do they not want their children to go to university, do they not want their grandfather to live for 100 years? We have the same values.â€ â€œI never thought this right was so costly,â€ he added. "We are defending the right to live."Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy tells Scott Pelley "human values" are on the line. Sunday, on 60 Minutes.  Zelenskyy this week visited the Kyiv suburb of Bucha, where Associated Press journalists documented dead civilians, some with their hands tied behind their backs and others displaying signs of torture and rape. Asked to describe what he saw with his own eyes in Bucha, Zelenskyy said, â€œDeath, just death.â€ Russia has denied committing atrocities and blamed the Bucha killings on Ukraine. Russian President Vladimir Putin is now reportedly shifting his attention to eastern Ukraine. Russian forces on Friday launched a missile attack on a train station in Kramatorsk, in the eastern Donetsk region, killing over 30 people and injuring more than 100.

Title: Nobel Prize-Winning Russian Newspaper Editor Attacked With Paint In Moscow
Text: Dmitry Muratov, the Nobel Peace Prize-winning editor of Russiaâ€™s major independent newspaper, was showered with red paint during an attack Thursday inside a Moscow train car, according to Novaya Gazetaâ€™s website. Muratov said his eyes were burning after an unknown person threw oil paint with acetone on him inside a train car at Kazansky railway station. â€œMuratov, hereâ€™s to you for our boys,â€ the assailant shouted, according to Muratov. Pictures released by the paper show Muratovâ€™s head, shirt and arms covered in red paint. A second photo shows red splashes resembling bloodstains over what appears to be a table, window and pillows inside the train carriage. Novaya Gazeta editor and Nobel laureate Dmitry Muratov, one of the few independent journalists still in Russia, was attacked with paint while on a train, the paper says.  Novaya Gazeta said the Telegram channel of a group called â€œUnion Z paratroopersâ€ assumed responsibility for the attack in a post that has since been deleted. According to an English translation of the post, the group vowed to come after those supporting what they falsely claimed were lies about atrocities in Bucha, Ukraine. State-backed media in Russia have sought to discredit some pictures and video from Bucha showing dead civilians. Russia claims Ukrainians staged the slaughter in the Kyiv suburb. Meanwhile, Russia is stepping up its assault on eastern Ukraine. Ukrainian officials said Friday that Russia is responsible for a rocket attack on a train station used to evacuate civilians in Kramatorsk, in the eastern Donetsk region. Over 30 people were killed, according to authorities, and more than 100 were wounded. Last week, Novaya Gazeta announced it was forced to stop publishing until the Ukraine war ends after receiving a second warning from Roskomnadzor, Russiaâ€™s media regulator. Journalists from Novaya Gazeta on Thursday launched a new venture called Novaya Gazeta Europe, not officially associated with the Russian publication, according to Reuters. Muratov, along with journalist Maria Ressa, won the 2021 Nobel Peace Prize â€œfor their courageous fight for freedom of expression in the Philippines and Russia.â€ Muratov said in March he intends to auction off his Nobel medal to support Ukrainian refugees. He told the BBC in December that he was dedicating his award to journalists murdered on the job. â€œThose of our journalists who died for their profession, it is their award and I am really gladâ€Nobel laureate Dmitry Muratov, editor-in-chief of Novaya Gazeta, says the prize is for his colleagues killed in the line of duty

Title: With Le Pen Breathing Down Macron's Neck, Is France About To Have Its Brexit?
Text: And just like that, everyoneâ€™s talking about France and whether itâ€™s about to have its â€œBrexit/Trump momentâ€. The first round of the French presidential election takes place on Sunday, and what might have been a formality only of domestic interest is suddenly generating a much bigger buzz. This is thanks to a series of polls suggesting Marine Le Pen, the far-rightâ€™s standard bearer for more than a decade, could pull off a shock win over incumbent Emmanuel Macron. With the help of HuffPost Franceâ€™s political correspondent Romain Herreros, hereâ€™s everything that you need to know about the vote to determine who runs one of Europeâ€™s biggest economic and military powers as a war rages on the continent. Franceâ€™s presidential election is to be held in two rounds on April 10 and 24. Polls have for weeks consistently pointed to Macron leading the first round ahead of Le Pen, with both qualifying for a run-off. It would mean a replay of the 2017 election that Macron won comfortably (66% to 34%). But this time around itâ€™s set to be much closer. According to some polls, Le Pen has narrowed the gap enough for victory to be within the margin of error. There are 12 official candidates. Outside Macron and Le Pen, the names to note in an election where radical positions set the tone are far right-writer-turned-candidate Ã‰ric Zemmour and veteran left-winger Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon. While itâ€™s unlikely either will make the final cut, the second choice of their voters could be crucial in a narrow run-off. A Le Pen win would send shockwaves around the world, not least given the Westâ€™s united front against Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. Having someone who has shown pro-Vladamir Putin sympathies deal with the fallout would be less than ideal. And make no mistake of Franceâ€™s importance: Brexit compounded its status as the European Unionâ€™s main military power and, with Angela Merkelâ€™s exit as German chancellor, Macron has taken a more prominent role in Europe. The 53-year-old leader of the National Rally, a movement long known for anti-Semitism, Nazi nostalgia and anti-immigrant bigotry, is running for the third time. The â€œLe Penâ€ name is notorious in France thanks to her father, Jean-Marie Le Pen, the firebrand leader of what the same party when it was the National Front. Since her 2017 defeat, Le Pen has worked to soften her image â€“ stressing her love of cats among other things â€“ and changed the party name. She has strived to appear as a potential leader rather than a radical anti-system opponent. Her campaign has focused on cost of living concerns â€“ amid a huge increase in energy prices and growing inflation â€“ and the candidacy of Zemmour, who is even further to the right than Le Pen, has also helped her appear more palatable to voters. Herreros says many felt another far-right candidate would split their vote, undermining Le Penâ€™s chance. â€œBut, in fact, Zemmour was very hard, very radical. So Le Pen looked more soft. People are less afraid of her compared to Zemmour. When we look at the polls, we see that.â€ Below, poll aggregator showing how Macronâ€™s lead over Le Pen has narrowed in recent days. See here for latest update. That explains in part why the context is not quite 2016. â€œThe last election was just one year after Brexit and Trumpâ€™s election, so we were in a populist moment,â€ Herreros says of Macronâ€™s 2017 ascent to power. â€œNow we have seen that Brexit was not what the British people expected, and we saw (Brazilâ€™s populist president) Bolsonaro is a nightmare in Brazil. But Le Pen is not playing the populist role â€“ she says she doesnâ€™t want to leave the euro this time, that sheâ€™s not that extreme like Zimmour. â€˜Trust me, Iâ€™m not evilâ€™.â€ But, make no mistake, the core of her partyâ€™s programme has not changed. â€œShe is still far-right,â€ Herreros explains. â€œShe is proposing the same thing on immigration as Zemmour, but with different words. Itâ€™s just a different package.â€ She would end a number of welfare benefits for foreigners, stop family reunification, give preference to the French for jobs and social housing, ban the hijab in public spaces and kick unemployed foreigners out of France. The early obsession among the chattering classes was the rise of Zemmour and his fledgling Reconquest! party. A TV pundit who styles himself as a Donald Trump figure and guardian of Old France, he has proposed a Ministry of â€œRemigrationâ€ equipped with airplanes to expedite the expulsions of what he says are undesirable migrants. Zemmour pushes the white nationalist conspiracy theory known as the â€œgreat replacementâ€, which argues France and Western nations are being overrun by immigrants and other people of colour â€” notably Muslims. Reflecting Le Penâ€™s superficial changes, a batch of her officials and supporters have left for Zemmour. The only one Le Pen spared criticism was her niece, Marion Marechal, a former politician who has returned to the frontline to help Zemmour. Perhaps what worries most is the two far-right candidates together are drawing more support than the centrist president. In a scenario where Le Pen inherits around 80% of Zemmourâ€™s votes in the second round â€“ a not unreasonable prospect, say analysts â€“ it puts her â€œclose to victoryâ€, says Herreros. For Macron, Le Pen is the candidate to beat, and his camp has worried openly about an â€œaccidentalâ€ win for Le Pen â€“ perhaps if moderate voters fail to turn up at the polls. The 44-year-old former investment banker, elected in 2017 with little political experience with his centrist La Republique en Marche, saw his pristine reputation dented by The Yellow Vest protests and imposing coronavirus restrictions. His election campaign has been disrupted by the war in Ukraine, with Macron delaying his pitch to the country because of Franceâ€™s central role in the Westâ€™s response. While absence from the campaign trail has its own problems, wartime leadership has allowed him to be presented dealing with the big issues facing the world (see the unusual pictures of him working nights and weekends at the Elysee palace, looking tired and unshaven, in jeans and a hoodie). It may have helped with an initial poll boost, but that appears to have waned. Herreros explains Macron is popular for this stage of his presidency â€“ higher than predecessors FranÃ§ois Hollande and Nicolas Sarkozy â€“ but he has come unstuck by two factors. â€œHe went too late in the campaign,â€ says Herreros. â€œIt was difficult for him to say â€˜hey, Iâ€™m the candidateâ€™ when Putin was invading Ukraine. If he went in January or February, it would have been easier for him. He left the space for the far-right.â€ He also bound himself to Le Pen, thinking France would never actually put her in power. â€œHe always thought he would be automatically re-elected against Marine Le Pen. During his presidency he would â€˜wink, winkâ€™ to right-wing voters, some of his ministers talked in a way that could be used by Le Pen. Now people are saying you played with fire, now we have the result of what you have done.â€ The neck-and-neck polling doesnâ€™t tell the whole story, say Herreros. A low turnout could kill off all the pre-election anticipation as Le Pen is relying heavily on the working class vote to come out in support. Le Penâ€™s party is still stinging from her partyâ€™s failure in last summerâ€™s regional balloting, blamed on a turnout of only 33% of voters in the first round. There may also be a moment of clarity. â€œIn France, when the far-right are close to power, people wake up,â€ says Herreros. â€œAnd they lose every time.â€ In 2015, Le Pen, who had appeared to be on the cusp of winning the northern region of Nord-Pas-de-Calais-Picardie, lost out in the second round, and her aforementioned niece, thought to be one of the partyâ€™s best hopes in the regional elections, also lost in the southern Provence-Alpes-Cote dâ€™Azur. â€œThey lost,â€ says Herreros. â€œBut who knows how the voters will react? Le Pen will say, â€˜Macron is the system, vote for me. Youâ€™re from the left and donâ€™t like Macron, vote for meâ€™. Itâ€™s the same thing we saw with Brexit. Maybe people will think ... letâ€™s try it.â€

Title: Train Station Atrocity Shows Ukraine Needs More Military Support Against Russia: Activists
Text: WASHINGTON â€” The U.S. and other allied countries arenâ€™t doing enough to stop Russian attacks on Ukraine, a group of prominent Ukrainian activists said Friday, hours after a massacre at a packed train station. The activists were gathered in Washington to meet with U.S. lawmakers and the Biden administration when they received news that a Russian rocket strike had hit the station in Kramatorsk in eastern Ukraine. Officials say at least 50 civilians were killed, including five children. â€œAll we need now is to arm our army and our territorial defense units to prevent more graves in the backyards of innocent people, to prevent more collective rapes, to prevent more missiles hitting railway stations,â€ said Daria Kaleniuk, the executive director of the Anti-Corruption Action Center nonprofit. â€œThere is no alternative but just to fight.â€ Hanna Hopko, a former member of Ukraineâ€™s Parliament who now runs the International Center for Ukrainian Victory advocacy group, said the attack on civilians Friday â€œshowed that the war against Ukraine is not a war only by [Russian President Vladimir Putin]... it demonstrates that this is according to the United Nations classification a genocide.â€ Ahead of a White House meeting Friday morning and after scores of meetings on Capitol Hill, the Ukrainian delegation met with reporters at the German Marshall Fund think tank to convey a strong message: They appreciate international support but believe it is still insufficient. Washington was too slow to realize that Ukraine could resist the Russian invasion launched in February, assuming that Moscowâ€™s much larger army would triumph in a matter of days, Kaleniuk said. Instead, Ukraineâ€™s military and everyday civilians have kept Russian troops from capturing the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv and targets like the strategic port of Mariupol, preventing the Russians from consolidating their control in the areas they have captured. But Russiaâ€™s determination to hurt Ukrainians is increasingly clear and alarming, according to Maria Berlinska, another member of the group who co-founded an organization for female veterans of Ukraineâ€™s military. Berlinska pointed to a recent shift in Russiaâ€™s narrative about the invasion in its state media: a growing emphasis on mass punishment for Ukraine that observers of Russian politics have also highlighted in recent days. â€œBefore that, Putin emphasized, â€˜Our main enemy is America â€¦ we would like to have a common state with Ukrainians,â€™â€ Berlinska said. â€œAs of now, it is, â€™We would like to kill them all, it doesnâ€™t matter: kids or elderly, doctors or teachers, color of skin, traditional family or LGBT.â€ As Russia has withdrawn from some Ukrainian towns, journalists, rights groups and officials have discovered evidence that Russian forces are committing atrocities against civilians, including executions and rape. Kaleniuk said U.S. assistance to Ukraine should include added anti-missile capabilities and that Americans should realize that millions in already-approved aid are going to support countries other than Ukraine, such as Poland, and to resupply U.S. weapons stocks to replace those sent to the Ukrainians. The Ukrainian delegation wants President Joe Biden to send jets, drones that can hit medium-to-long-range targets, and more armored vehicles and ammunition.
