Title: Here's What You Need To Know About The Russia-Ukraine Peace Talks
Text: The Russia-Ukraine peace talks are gaining momentum, as Russia said Tuesday it would scale back its operations in the cities of Kyiv and Chernihiv to â€œincrease trustâ€ in the negotiations, as delegations for both sides wrapped up for the day in Istanbul, Turkey. Russiaâ€™s Deputy Defense Minister Alexander Fomin said the announcement is intended â€œto create conditions for further negotiations,â€ according to The Associated Press. The country has also now floated the possibility of a meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, CNN reported. â€œIf that was to be the case, it is another major concession to President Zelenskyy who has asked from the very beginning, even before the invasion, to have face-to-face talks with President Putin,â€ CNNâ€™s Christiane Amanpour said. Any ceasefire canâ€™t come soon enough for Ukrainian civilians, who have borne the brunt of Russiaâ€™s frustrated and stalled land offensive.  Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, whose country hosted Tuesdayâ€™s talks, called on both sides to end the war. â€œProlonging the conflict is not in anyoneâ€™s interest,â€ Erdogan said. Putin explained the reasons behind the war he described as a â€œspecial military operationâ€ in Ukraine during a televised address to the Russian people on Feb. 24. â€œThe purpose of this operation is to protect people who, for eight years now, have been facing humiliation and genocide perpetrated by the Kyiv regime,â€ Putin said, according to an English translation of the speech by Bloomberg. â€œTo this end, we will seek to demilitarize and denazify Ukraine.â€ The Kremlin has also wanted Russian to be the official second language in Ukraine. While the Financial Times reported Monday that those demands were not in the draft agreement prepared as part of the peace talks, Russia is still asking for Ukraine to stay out of the NATO alliance. Besides, Moscow is continuing to argue for Crimea â€” which it annexed in 2014 â€” and Luhansk and Donetsk â€” two territories held by Russian-backed separatists in the eastern region of Donbas â€” to be officially recognized as Russian. On Crimea, Ukrainian negotiators said Tuesday they could continue holding talks over a 15-year period, assuming both countries held off from using armed forces to address the issue. Zelenskyy said Sunday he wants a â€œcompromiseâ€ in Donbas, according to Reuters, while Russiaâ€™s defense minister told military officials Tuesday the country had nearly completed the initial phase of its operation and was now turning its attention to the â€œmain goal â€” the liberation of Donbas,â€ according to AP. Ukraine is asking for a cease-fire, security guarantees and that its sovereignty and territorial integrity stay intact, according to the BBC. While Ukraine has ruled out joining NATO, it still applied to join the European Union, something that Russia said it is open to allowing, according to the Financial Times. â€œRegarding NATO, I have cooled down regarding this question long ago after we understood that NATO is not prepared to accept Ukraine,â€ Zelenskyy told ABC News on March 8, according to Insider. Zelenskyy confirmed he is open to neutrality in Ukraine, which would also mean the country would have to remain impartial in any future conflicts and no foreign military bases would be allowed on its territory. â€œSecurity guarantees and neutrality, non-nuclear status of our state. We are ready to go for it,â€ Zelenskyy told Russian journalists Sunday, according to an English translation provided by Reuters. All other countries in Europe that are considered neutral, including Austria, Finland and Ireland, continue to have their own militaries to be able to fight back in case they are attacked, according to Vox. Still, Zelenskyy added that a cease-fire agreement would have to be reached before any deal, including a neutrality commitment, goes to a referendum. A â€œreferendum is impossible when there is the presence of troops,â€ he said. Ukraine has also sought security guarantees from countries including Russia, the U.S., Germany and China, David Arakhamia, head of Zelenskyyâ€™s party in Parliament and a member of Ukraineâ€™s negotiating team, told the Financial Times. Those guarantees would work similarly to NATOâ€™s Article 5 clause where countries are committed to support a member being attacked, Arakhamia explained. Even as Russia has signaled it is prepared to walk back some of its initial demands and deescalated part of its offensive, the West and Ukraine are not confident an imminent breakthrough is possible. U.S. President Joe Biden is holding talks over the phone with the leaders of France, Germany, Italy and the U.K. to discuss the latest developments, according to the BBC. â€œEverything I have seen is [Putin] is not willing to compromise at this point,â€ an anonymous senior U.S. State Department official told Reuters Monday. Mykhailo Podolyak, a senior aide to Zelenskyy, told ABC News on Thursday that even though there was genuine engagement from Russia in the peace talks, it could still be months before any conclusion is reached. â€œTheyâ€™re absolutely real negotiations,â€ Podolyak said. â€œThereâ€™s no attempt to stall for time. Thatâ€™s definitely not there.â€ Previous talks held by delegations for the two countries in Belarus and virtually have failed to yield results.

Title: Putin May Be Accused Of War Crimes In Ukraine, But Trump's Still Asking For His Help
Text: WASHINGTON â€• Russian dictator Vladimir Putin may be accused of slaughtering children and overseeing other war crimes in Ukraine, but thatâ€™s not stopping longtime admirer and former U.S. President Donald Trump from asking him for political help again. Trump, who tried to overthrow American democracy in an attempt to retain power despite losing the 2020 election, is now asking Putin to find damaging information on his successorâ€™s son. â€œI would think Putin would know the answer to that,â€ Trump said in an interview airing on Real Americaâ€™s Voice, a pro-Trump website, regarding a payment a decade ago from a Russian oligarchâ€™s wife to a company founded by Hunter Biden, son of President Joe Biden. â€œI think he should release it.â€ Trumpâ€™s staff did not respond to HuffPostâ€™s queries about the matter. Itâ€™s been nearly six years since Trump called on Russia to â€œfindâ€ emails from then-Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, Trumpâ€™s rival in the 2016 presidential election. â€œRussia, if youâ€™re listening, I hope youâ€™re able to find the 30,000 emails that are missing,â€ he said at a July 27, 2016, news conference. Subsequent investigations determined that Russia did, in fact, honor Trumpâ€™s request, starting that same day. Putinâ€™s intelligence services carried out a multifaceted effort to boost Trumpâ€™s campaign, including the theft of thousands of documents from the Democratic National Committee and Clintonâ€™s campaign advisers. Putin then began releasing the stolen material in the final month of the campaign through the allied WikiLeaks group, and Trump â€• even though he had been told by U.S. intelligence agencies that Russia had carried out the theft â€• centered the last few weeks of his campaign on that material. â€œWe love WikiLeaks!â€ he would proclaim from the stage. Trump, angry afterward that U.S. prosecutors were investigating his campaignâ€™s links to Russia, seized on a new conspiracy theory being spread by Russian spies: that Ukraine had actually helped Clinton in 2016, and that a server containing her emails had been cached somewhere in that country. His obsession with that theory and Hunter Biden, who had used his fatherâ€™s name and position as vice president to win consulting business in Ukraine in 2014 and 2015, ultimately led to Trumpâ€™s first impeachment, after he tried to extort that countryâ€™s new president into announcing an investigation into Joe Biden, whom Trump feared most as a 2020 challenger. Trumpâ€™s affinity for Putin, though, long predates even his 2016 presidential campaign. He repeatedly praised Putin for at least a decade as he tried to build a condominium tower in Moscow. In a 2007 letter, Trump told Putin he was â€œa big fan.â€ He continued to push his â€œTrump Tower Moscowâ€ project even as he ran for president in 2015 and 2016, and publicly lauded Putin as a better leader than then-President Barack Obama. Once in the White House, Trump continually attacked NATO and the European Union â€• actions that aligned with Putinâ€™s long-term objectives of weakening or destroying both institutions. He falsely claimed that the military alliance created by the United States after World War II and the free-trade zone were somehow cheating American taxpayers. He mused about withdrawing from NATO entirely, and reportedly had intended to do so if heâ€™d won a second term. Trump also kept praising and defending Putin, even telling the world in 2018 that he believed Putin over his own intelligence agencies regarding the dictatorâ€™s work to get Trump elected. A year later, he tried to have Russia readmitted to the G7 group of large democratic economies, from which it was expelled for invading and annexing Crimea in 2014. Trump said he understood Russiaâ€™s need to keep the Crimean Peninsula because it had built a base there for its â€œlarge and powerful submarines.â€ Even on the day Putin sent his armies into Ukraine last month, Trump called him a â€œgeniusâ€ and â€œvery savvyâ€ for having invaded. Since then, as images and stories of Putinâ€™s slaughter have emerged, Trump has criticized the invasion, but still has not been critical of Putin personally. After losing the 2020 election by 7 million votes nationally and 306-232 in the Electoral College, Trump became the first U.S. president in more than two centuries of elections to refuse to hand over power peacefully. His incitement of the 2021 assault on the U.S. Capitol, a last-ditch attempt to remain in office, killed five people, including one police officer. That dayâ€™s violence also injured another 140 officers and led to four police suicides. Nevertheless, Trump remains the dominant figure in the Republican Party and is speaking about running for the presidency again in 2024.

Title: Joe Biden Slaps Down Question From Fox News' Peter Doocy: 'You Got To Be Silly'
Text: President Joe Biden snapped at Fox News reporter Peter Doocy on Monday, responding to the journalistâ€™s question by saying: â€œWhy should I tell you?â€ Doocy had asked what the U.S. would do specifically in response to a possible chemical weapons attack by Russia on Ukraine. Biden said Russiaâ€™s use of such weapons would trigger a â€œsignificant response.â€ Doocy replied: â€œWhat does that mean?â€ â€œIâ€™m not going to tell you,â€ Biden answered. â€œWhy would I tell you? You got to be silly.â€ â€œThe world wants to know?â€ Doocy offered. â€œThe world wants to know a lot of things,â€ Biden retorted. â€œIâ€™m not telling what the response would be, then Russia knows the response.â€ Doocy: When you said that chemical weapon use by Russia would trigger a response in kindBiden: It will trigger a significant responseDoocy: What does that mean?Biden: Iâ€™m not going to tell you. Why would I tell you?  NATOâ€™s deputy secretary-general, Mircea GeoanÄƒ, said last week that if If Russia employs chemical or nuclear weapons in its military assault on Ukraine, the defense alliance would be â€œforced to take appropriate measures.â€ Like Biden, he refused to provide specifics. Doocy has clashed frequently with White House press secretary Jen Psaki. Biden referred to the journalist as a â€œstupid son of a bitchâ€ on a hot mic at the White House earlier this year. But the president later called Doocy to apologize. â€œItâ€™s nothing personal, pal,â€ Biden told him, according to the reporter.

Title: Volodymyr Zelenskyy Open To Ukraine Adopting Neutral Stance To Secure Russian Peace Deal
Text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said Sunday he is open to the country adopting a neutral stance as part of any peace deal with Russia to end the ongoing invasion. The comments were part of a sweeping, 90-minute interview Zelenskyy gave to several Russian journalists on Sunday, the first time heâ€™s spoken at length to Russian journalists in their own language since the war began. However, the Kremlin warned Russian media outlets not to publish the interview as part of a broader effort to censor what information Russians are able to receive about the ongoing invasion of Ukraine. Details from the call were published by Russian journalists living outside Russia. â€œSecurity guarantees and neutrality, non-nuclear status of our state. We are ready to go for it,â€ Zelenskyy said, per a translation from Reuters. â€œThis is the most important point.â€ Ukrainians would have to vote on the compromise, which would bar the country from joining NATO, a long-sought goal that Zelenskyy admitted was unlikely to happen. A vote on an official neutrality stance could only take place during a ceasefire, he said, as a â€œreferendum is impossible when there is the presence of troops.â€ A new round of peace talks are set to begin this week in Turkey. Russian President Vladimir Putin appears to have shifted tack as his invasion of Ukraine drags on far longer than anticipated, stymied by a fierce Ukrainian resistance. Ukrainian military officials have said they worry the Kremlin may now be focused on dividing Ukraine into occupied and unoccupied territories. Zelenskyy said Putinâ€™s attempt to revert to an era of the past had instead driven the countries further apart. He pointed to the ongoing barrage in Mariupol, which he said had left the city â€œlittered with corpses.â€ â€œA humanitarian catastrophe inside the city is unequivocal, because it is impossible to go there with food, medicine and water,â€ he said of Mariupol. â€œThis is not simply a war, this is much worse,â€ Zelenskyy added. â€œA global, historical, cultural split has happened over this month.â€ Zelenskyyâ€™s comments came more than a month after the invasion began and just days after he called for worldwide demonstrations to show support for Ukraine. â€œIt breaks my heart, hearts of all Ukrainians and every free person on the planet. Thatâ€™s why I ask you to stand against the war,â€ Zelenskyy said in a message posted to social media. â€œâ€¦Come from your offices, your homes, your schools and universities, come in the name of peace, come with Ukrainian symbols to support Ukraine, to support freedom, to support life.â€

Title: Joe Biden: 'No Apologies' For Saying Putin 'Cannot Remain In Power'
Text: WASHINGTON â€• President Joe Biden on Monday stood by his belief that Vladimir Putin should not be president of Russia, telling reporters that he made â€œno apologiesâ€ for his unscripted remarks. â€œIâ€™m not walking anything back,â€ the president said.. â€œI was expressing moral outrage, and I make no apologies,â€ he added. Speaking in Poland at the end of his four-day trip to Europe on Sunday, Biden said of Putin, â€œFor Godâ€™s sake, this man cannot remain in power.â€ The line came at the end of a 27-minute speech and was ad-libbed by a president famous for doing so. Bidenâ€™s prepared remarks in the State Dining Room, his first public appearance since the speech in Warsaw Saturday, were about his budget proposal he is sending lawmakers for the fiscal year that starts in October, but most of the questions from the two dozen reporters assembled before him were about his ad-libbed comment. White House officials on Saturday almost immediately afterward sent out a clarification that the sentence did not reflect a change in U.S. policy, and that Biden was not advocating â€œregime changeâ€ in Russia: â€œThe presidentâ€™s point was that Putin cannot be allowed to exercise power over his neighbors or the region. He was not discussing Putinâ€™s power in Russia, or regime change.â€ Biden, though, on Monday insisted that and similar explanations did not constitute a â€œwalk back,â€ and that he was reacting as anyone would after meeting with the victims of Putinâ€™s assault on civilians, including children, in Ukraine. â€œThis is just stating a simple fact that this kind of behavior is totally unacceptable. Totally unacceptable,â€ he said. â€œI wasnâ€™t articulating a policy change,â€ he added. â€œI think that he continues on this course that he is on, he is going to become a pariah worldwide, and who knows what he becomes at home, in terms of support.â€ Biden said he had no interest in escalating a conflict with a nuclear armed power, but was expressing a view shared by many. â€œPeople like this shouldnâ€™t be ruling countries, but they do,â€ he said. He also said he was not at all worried that what he said would escalate the conflict or weaken NATO. â€œNATO has never, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever been as strong as it is today,â€ he said. â€œNever.â€

Title: Reports: Ukrainian Peace Negotiators Showed Signs Of Poisoning After Meeting Russians
Text: Three Ukrainian peace negotiators showed signs of poisoning after meeting their Russian counterparts earlier this month, including Russian oligarch Roman Abramovich, who has been enlisted to facilitate discussions. Sources told The Wall Street Journal that members of the group developed red eyes, constant and painful tearing, and peeling skin on their faces and hands soon after their March 3 meeting. The report was corroborated by the investigative journalism website Bellingcat, which added that the symptoms subsided over the next week and their lives are not in danger. Chemical weapons experts told Bellingcat that, based on the likely toxin and dosage used, the act was intended to intimidate the victims instead of cause permanent harm. A source with direct knowledge of the matter told The Guardian that Abramovich lost his sight â€œfor several hoursâ€ and required treatment in Turkey. A source with direct knowledge has just confirmed to me the WSJ/Bellingcat reports that Abramovich suffered symptoms of poisoning. "Roman lost his sight for several hours" and was treated in Turkey, the source said. Abramovichâ€™s camp told the Journal itâ€™s unclear who may have targeted the group. BBC also confirmed the reports, and noted that Abramovich traveled between Moscow and Kyiv for â€œseveral rounds of talksâ€ at the start of the month. Ukrainian negotiators were unwilling to confirm the incident. Rustem Umerov, one member of the Ukrainian team, told Reuters that people should be wary of â€œunverified information.â€ Another negotiator, Mykhailo Podolyak, said â€œthere is a lot of speculation, various conspiracy theories.â€ Peace talks between Russia and Ukraine are scheduled to resume in Turkey this week.

Title: Oscars Hold Moment Of Silence For Ukraine, Urge Global Community To 'Do More'
Text: Midway through the 2022 Oscars telecast on Sunday night, there was a moment of silence for the people of Ukraine amid Russiaâ€™s unprovoked invasion. Following a performance by Reba McEntire that was introduced by Ukraine-born actor Mila Kunis, who mentioned feeling â€œguttedâ€ by recent global events, a message appeared on screen. â€œWeâ€™d like to have a moment of silence to show our support for the people of Ukraine currently facing invasion, conflict and prejudice within their own borders,â€ the screen read. â€œWhile film is an important avenue for us to express our humanity in times of conflict, the reality is millions of families in Ukraine need food, medical care, clean water, and emergency services. Resources are scarce, and we â€” collectively as a global community â€” can do more.â€ The 30-second clip ended with a call to all those watching around the world: â€œWe ask you to support Ukraine in any way you are able. #StandWithUkraine.â€ #Oscars holds moment of silence in support of Ukraine.  Ahead of the 94th annual ceremony, there were rumors that Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy would make a surprise virtual appearance during the show to urge celebrities and artists to speak up in solidarity with his country. Zelenskyyâ€™s aides reportedly lobbied the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to show some form of support, according to The New York Times, with Kunis helping to coordinate the Ukrainian governmentâ€™s outreach. Zelenskyy has long held ties to the entertainment industry. Before he was elected Ukraineâ€™s president, he worked as an actor and comedian, starring for years in the satirical comedy series â€œServant of the People,â€ which is now available to stream on Netflix. He also appeared as a contestant in the Ukrainian version of â€œDancing with the Starsâ€ and voiced the role of Paddington Bear in the 2014 film, among other past credits. Amy Schumer, who is co-hosting the ceremony with Wanda Sykes and Regina Hall, was the first to publicly mention the idea of Zelenskyy appearing at the event, but the academy had stayed mum on whether heâ€™d been invited. â€œI wanted to find a way to have Zelenskyy satellite in or make a tape or something, just because there are so many eyes on the Oscars,â€ Schumer said on â€œThe Drew Barrymore Showâ€ earlier this month. â€œI think itâ€™s a great opportunity to at least comment on a couple of things. I have some jokes that kind of highlight the sort of current condition.â€ Amid the speculation that producers nixed Schumerâ€™s idea, Sean Penn, one of Hollywoodâ€™s most vocal Ukraine supporters, threatened to smelt his own Oscar trophy in protest. â€œIf it turns out to be what is happening, I would encourage everyone involved â€” though it may be their moment, and I understand that, to celebrate their films â€” it is so much more importantly their moment to shine, and to protest and to boycott that Academy Awards,â€ Penn, who was on the ground during the early days of Ukraineâ€™s invasion, told CNNâ€™s Jim Acosta in an interview this week. The entertainment industry has come out in full force to show support for Ukraine. A slew of stars, including Jamie Lee Curtis and Jason Momoa, sported blue ribbons on the red carpet provided by the United Nations refugee agency. In recent months, many celebrities have publicly condemned Russiaâ€™s actions and raised funds for refugees fleeing the country. Perhaps most notably, Kunis, who was born in Ukraine before moving to the United States as a child, and her husband, Ashton Kutcher, raised nearly $35 million through a GoFundMe campaign for refugee and humanitarian aid efforts. The couple spoke with Zelenskyy over a video call earlier this month with the president thanking them directly for their efforts to secure aid in the war-torn nation.

Title: Ukraine Ambassador On Putin's Strategy: â€˜We Can Always Count On Russia Lyingâ€™
Text: The Ukrainian ambassador to the United States said Sunday that Ukraine is ready to negotiate a peace agreement with Russia, but that the country will stand its ground when it comes to giving up territory to Vladimir Putin. When Oksana Markarova appeared on CNNâ€™s â€œState of the Union,â€ host Dana Bash said Russian military officials seemed to be signaling a potential change in strategy. What was once an invasion meant to seize the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv has instead shifted to focus on Crimea and the separatist-controlled Donetsk and Luhansk regions of the Donbas, according to Moscow. â€œFirst, we can always count on Russia lying,â€ Markarova said. â€œThey lied before the war that they will not start the war. They lied in 2014 that they did not attack us when they illegally occupied Crimea and Donetsk and Luhansk. And they are lying during the past 33 days about not attacking civilians, about not besieging Mariupol and killing people there, about not kidnapping people and taking them into Russia.â€ â€œI think the signals that we hear from Russia merely comes from the fact that they were not able to do anything that they have planned to achieve â€” either blitzkrieg, taking over Kyiv,â€ she added. â€œWe can always count on Russia lying.â€Ukrainian ambassador to the US @OMarkarova tells @DanaBashCNN that Ukraine is ready to negotiate a peace agreement with Russia, but the country is not willing to give up territory and leave it under Russian occupation. #CNNSOTU  Bash asked the ambassador if there were any circumstances under which Ukraine would give up regions like Crimea or the Donbas in order to reach a peace agreement with Russia â€” a possibility that President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has so far rejected. Chuck Todd, the host of NBCâ€™s â€œMeet the Press,â€ asked Markarova similar questions on Sunday as well. â€œI donâ€™t even think we should be asking Ukraine what we are ready to give up. We are fighting for our country,â€ Markarova told CNN. â€œThe territorial integrity and sovereignty of any country is enshrined not only in the statehood of [the United Nations], but should be enshrined in every heart and mind of anyone who believes in democracy.â€ The ambassador went on to give some historical context for the countryâ€™s resistance to giving up land. â€œSo, after this brutal aggression, we, of course, are ready to negotiate. And we are negotiating the humanitarian corridors. And we are ready to negotiate a peace agreement, but the peace agreement should include them leaving our territory, all of it,â€ she said. â€œAnd no, we are not ready to give up on some of our people or some of our territories and leave it under occupation. Because occupation, as we see now, as we saw in 1932 during the Holodomor, as we saw in previous times when Russia occupied us â€” occupation for Ukrainians mean extermination of us.â€

Title: Trump Repeats Praise Of 'Smart' Putin But Calls Ukraine Invasion A 'Big Mistake'
Text: Former President Donald Trump doubled down on his past praise of Vladimir Putin on Saturday, calling the Russian president â€œsmartâ€ but describing his invasion of Ukraine as â€œa big mistake.â€ â€œThey ask me if Putin was smart. Yes, Putin was smart,â€ Trump said at a rally in Commerce, Georgia, before adding that he was surprised by Putinâ€™s decision to start a war. â€œI actually thought he was going to be negotiating. I said, thatâ€™s a hell of a way to negotiate â€• put 200,000 soldiers on the border,â€ he said. â€œI think he made a big mistake, what heâ€™s done to so many people. Boy, that was a big mistake. But it looked like a great negotiation, that didnâ€™t work out too well for him.â€ Trump is back to saying Putin is smart. He says he thinks Putin made a mistake but then describes it as a â€œgreat negotiation that didnâ€™t go so well for himâ€  Though Trump called Russiaâ€™s invasion a mistake, he has not condemned Putin as a leader. Earlier this month, Trump called Putin a â€œgeniusâ€ for invading parts of Ukraine after declaring those regions to be independent. In a subsequent interview with Fox News, Trump declined to call Putin â€œevilâ€ when confronted about those remarks. An estimated 2,570 civilians have been recorded as killed or wounded since the start of Russiaâ€™s invasion on Feb. 24, according to a recent tally by the United Nations, which said the actual count is likely considerably higher. The U.N.â€™s tally includes more than 80 dead children. NATO this week also estimated that 7,000 to 15,000 Russian soldiers have died from fighting. Trump on Saturday also called Chinese leader Xi Jinping â€œsmart.â€ â€œHe runs 1.5 billion people with an iron fist. Yeah, I think heâ€™s pretty smart. And they have a chain over there. If youâ€™re a dummy, you get left here,â€ he said, gesturing low. â€œItâ€™s like a pyramid. The smartest one gets to the top. That didnâ€™t work so well recently in our country.â€ Trump, who repeated his false claims of â€œmassive voterâ€ fraud during the 2020 election, also predicted that a Chinese invasion of Taiwan will â€œbe next.â€ â€œI would say that thatâ€™s a very good possibility that he will invade Taiwan, because he doesnâ€™t respect the United States of America any longer and he had a lot of respect for us a year and a half ago,â€ he said.

Title: Trump Wouldn't Be 'Capable' Of Ukraine Peace Talks With Moscow, Says John Bolton
Text: Former president Donald Trump would not be â€œcapableâ€ of holding Ukraine peace talks in Moscow to stop the invasion, according to his own former national security adviser. â€œHeâ€™s not capable of it,â€ John Bolton told The Palm Beach Post in a story Saturday when asked about Trumpâ€™s ability to successfully conduct a â€œpeace-negotiating tripâ€ to Moscow. â€œThis would require thinking through a policy and considering the pluses and minuses, the risks and costs involved. Thatâ€™s just not what he does,â€ Bolton added. Bolton spoke to the newspaper as it examined Trumpâ€™s boasts that the Russian invasion of Ukraine would not have happened on his watch â€” in part because of his claimed excellent relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin. Early on, Trump called Putinâ€™s Ukraine invasion â€œgenius.â€ If the invasion had occurred while he was president, he could have ended it, Trump has also claimed. The former president said last week he would use U.S. nuclear submarines to threaten Russia, which many observers viewed as dangerously provocative, especially since Putin has already indicated heâ€™s ready to use nuclear weapons. Bolton had said earlier that Trump in fact helped set the stage for the invasion. His repeated flattery of Putin and his weakening of Americaâ€™s relationship with Europe emboldened the Russian leader, while Trumpâ€™s â€œcontemptâ€ for Ukraine and his baseless claims that its government was corrupt weakened that nationâ€™s standing. â€œI think all contributed to a precarious status for Ukraine, which would have continued in a second term,â€ for Trump, Bolton told The Palm Beach Post. In 2019, Trump froze military aid to Ukraine authorized by Congress that he then tried to use as an enticement to convince Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to launch an investigation into Trumpâ€™s rival Joe Biden and his son Hunter. The action led to Trumpâ€™s first impeachment. The aid stall was far more serious for Ukraine than many realized at the time, according to Bolton. â€œThe urgency of the particular $250 million was that it was appropriated money that under the federal governmentâ€™s bizarre budget procedures would have expired on Sept. 30, 2019,â€ Bolton recounted to the newspaper. He also said that Ukraine wasnâ€™t the only nation that faced increased security risks in the Trump administration. Bolton believed Trumpâ€™s objective was to â€œwithdraw the U.S. from NATO or substantially limitâ€ Washingtonâ€™s support for the defense alliance. Thatâ€™s what Putin was â€œwaiting forâ€ in a second Trump term, Bolton told The Washington Post early this month. Check out the full Palm Beach Post story here.

Title: If Russia Uses Chemical Weapons In Ukraine, NATO Will Take Action, Warns Official
Text: If Russia employs chemical or nuclear weapons in its military assault in Ukraine, NATO would be â€œforced to take appropriate measures,â€ NATOâ€™s Deputy General Secretary Mircea GeoanÄƒ told The Associated Press in an interview. He did not detail what action the defense alliance would take, but warned: â€œI can guarantee that NATO is ready to respond proportionately.â€ NATO is a â€œdefensive alliance, but also itâ€™s a nuclear alliance,â€ he explained. If Russia uses â€œchemical weapons or other kinds of higher-end systems against Ukraine, this will be changing fundamentally the nature of the war that Mr. Putin has waged against Ukraine.â€ The fear of Russiaâ€™s use of far more horrifying weapons has increased as Vladimir Putin fumes over an operation he thought would be successfully completed quickly. â€œMr. Putin probably believed his own post-imperial fantasies, thinking that Ukrainians will welcome them with open arms,â€ GeoanÄƒ said. â€œIn fact, they got very fierce resistance. We are convinced that today, even with reinforcements that are still coming into Ukraine, Russia does not possess the forces and the capacity to occupy the whole of Ukraine,â€ he added. Until there is some resolution, â€œwe hope that Mr. Putin will not go even further down the road of war crimes, and even more devastation against a sovereign nation,â€ said GeoanÄƒ.

Title: WNBA Legend Lisa Leslie: We Were Told Not To Make 'Big Fuss' Over Brittney Griner
Text: Basketball legend Lisa Leslie said she and others in the womenâ€™s basketball world â€œwere toldâ€ not to be too vocal about the arrest of Brittney Griner in Russia, for fear of turning her into a â€œpolitical pawn.â€ Leslie, the former Los Angeles Sparks center who was known as the face of the WNBA, spoke on the â€œI Am Athleteâ€ podcast about the tense situation. â€œWhat we were told was to not make a big fuss about it so that they could not use her as a pawn, so to speak, in this situation and war,â€ Leslie said in a clip from the podcast, which is set to air in full on Monday. Griner, who plays for the Phoenix Mercury, was arrested in mid-February by Russian authorities who claimed she was carrying vape cartridges containing hashish oil in her luggage at an airport. She had been in Russia playing for a team there, a common practice for WNBA players due to the higher pay. But Grinerâ€™s detention did not make the news in the United States until March, after Russian customs officials and news outlets publicized the arrest. The fact that Grinerâ€™s initial arrest seemingly went unnoticed â€• and the relative quiet of the U.S. media and the WNBA even after the news broke â€• has drawn criticism, notably a New York Magazine story asking, â€œWhy Isnâ€™t Brittney Griner the Biggest Sports Story in the Country?â€ Russia announced the arrest about a week and a half into Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, prompting speculation that officials hoped to use Griner for leverage with the U.S. Leslieâ€™s comments suggested that people closer to the situation shared that concern, though she didnâ€™t say exactly where the instruction to not make a â€œfussâ€ came from. â€œI wonâ€™t say who said that, but itâ€™s kind of whatâ€™s been spreading throughout the womenâ€™s basketball world,â€ she said. She added that those who care about Griner struggled with whether keeping quiet was actually the right thing to do. â€œItâ€™s heartbreaking, for all of us,â€ she said. Griner remains incarcerated in Russia. An official from the U.S. Embassy who was allowed to see her said she was in â€œgood condition,â€ the U.S. State Department said earlier this week. The WNBA did not immediately respond to a request for comment from HuffPost about Leslieâ€™s comments. The organization said in a statement earlier this month that it was working â€œdiligentlyâ€ to get Griner home.

Title: Ingraham Guest Says â€˜No Reason Whatsoeverâ€™ For Ukrainian Refugees To Come To U.S.
Text: Fox Newsâ€™ Laura Ingraham and a guest pushed back on Friday against President Joe Bidenâ€™s pledge to accept 100,000 refugees fleeing Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. â€œObviously, our hearts break for the people in Ukraine. It is absolutely horrific what has happened to them,â€ said Ingraham, before asking guest Todd Bensman: â€œBut is bringing them all the way to the United States in their best interest? And what about the U.S. taxpayers?â€ Bensman, a senior national security fellow at the Center for Immigration Studies â€• a far-right anti-immigrant group thatâ€™s known for its ties to white nationalists â€• suggested the refugees would be better off staying in Europe where they have been offered three-year residencies with associated health care, rights to work and housing. â€œSo thereâ€™s really no reason whatsoever for Ukrainians to be coming to our border or for us to be bringing in huge swells, numbers of Ukrainians here,â€ he argued. â€œTheyâ€™re doing great for a group of war refugees.â€ â€œThe issue is that they are not asylum-seekers,â€ Bensman added. â€œThey have asylum, right in their own neighborhood, so itâ€™s a little bit disingenuous.â€ â€œThen that makes more sense. OK,â€ Ingraham agreed. More than 3.5 million refugees have now fled Russiaâ€™s invasion. More than half of Ukraineâ€™s 7.5 million children have been displaced by the conflict. The Biden White House, announcing its pledge on Thursday, acknowledged in a fact sheet that it expected â€œmany Ukrainians will choose to remain in Europe close to family and their homes in Ukraine.â€ But its raft of measures aimed to â€œhelp relieve some of the pressure on the European host countries that are currently shouldering so much of the responsibility,â€ reported CNN, citing a senior official.

Title: Former Top NATO Commander Warns: â€˜Itâ€™s Going To Get Worseâ€™ For Ukraine
Text: Retired U.S. Air Force Gen. Philip Breedlove, who served as NATOâ€™s supreme allied commander in Europe until 2016, warned on Friday why things are â€œgoing to get worse and worseâ€ for Ukrainians during Russiaâ€™s invasion. Breedlove, speaking to CNN, explained how Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s troops had â€œbeen unable to meet Ukrainian forces on these big force-on-force battlesâ€ with Ukrainians fighting a â€œwonderful, skirmishing rear-attack, ambush kind of fight that frustrates the military advance of Russia.â€ Putinâ€™s frustration at his military failing to accomplish its goals was making him â€œmore and more dangerous every day,â€ said Breedlove, as Moscow appeared to turn its focus away from seizing the capital Kyiv. â€œAnd when they canâ€™t fight Ukrainian troops, they are going to fight and kill Ukrainian civilians as you have seen,â€ he continued, having earlier described indiscriminate attacks by Russia on people sheltering inside a theater in Mariupol and multiple humanitarian aid stations as war crimes. â€œThe risk is going up every day because of the frustration of Putin and his army,â€ he added. Text: Andriy Yermak, chief of staff to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, issued a blistering takedown of Russian state TV on Friday. They certainly wouldnâ€™t expect me to give them a gift like that.â€ The former diplomatâ€™s memoir, â€œLessons From The Edge,â€ details her service in Ukraine, which ended in 2019 following a smear campaign from Donald Trump allies who feared sheâ€™d scupper their attempts at digging up dirt on now-President Joe Biden.

Title: Vladimir Putin Claims Russia Is Being Canceled Like J.K. Rowling
Text: Russian President Vladimir Putin on Friday used a televised address to claim his country was being victimized by â€œcancel cultureâ€ after its invasion of Ukraine. Title: 'Depressed' Ukrainian-Born Russian General Walked Out On U.S. Military Meeting: Report
Text: In a rare burst of emotion, a â€œdepressedâ€ Ukrainian-born Russian major general called the military operation in his home country â€œtragicâ€ and suddenly walked out of a meeting with U.S. officials, CNN reported Thursday. The Americans indicated the emotional moment was likely a sign of a broader upheaval and poor morale in Russia over the military operation in Ukraine. Maj. Gen. Yevgeny Ilyin, deputy chief of the main directorate of international cooperation, became upset in a rare meeting late last month with Americans at the Russian ministry of defense in Moscow, CNN reported. A U.S. defense attachÃ© inquired about Ilyinâ€™s Ukrainian family roots just as the meeting was breaking up, according to a U.S. summary of the meeting obtained by CNN. The typically â€œstoicâ€ Ilyin became â€œflushed and agitated,â€ according to the U.S. account of the meeting. He said he was born in Dnipropetrovsk and then moved with his family to Donetsk, where he went to school. Both cities are in Ukraine. He then called the situation in Ukraine â€œtragic and I am very depressed over itâ€ â€” then exited the room without shaking anyoneâ€™s hand, according to the account, CNN reported. What specifically Ilyin was reacting to, as well as the circumstances of the meeting and other details, could not immediately be determined, according to CNN. â€œAt the very least,â€ noted the American account, â€œit is clear that morale problems among Russian forces are not limited to front-line troops,â€ the summary concluded. CNN Exclusive: Inside a rare U.S. meeting with a Russian General in Moscow @barbarastarrcnn reports@PamelaBrownCNN  Russian President Vladimir Putin, meanwhile, is reportedly furious and humiliated that Russia wasnâ€™t able to conquer Ukraine in just days, as he expected. Amid his fury, top spies have been placed under house arrest and at least one top government official, Putin aide Anatoly Chubais, has reportedly fled Russia over his opposition to the invasion of Ukraine.

Title: Tucker Carlson Surprises No One By Parroting New Russian Conspiracy Theory
Text: Fox News host Tucker Carlson on Thursday parroted Russian propaganda linking Hunter Biden to Ukrainian biolabs that was disseminated by the Kremlin to justify its invasion of Ukraine. Earlier on Thursday, Russiaâ€™s Defense Ministry released a colorful diagram that claims to prove that President Joe Bidenâ€™s son was involved in funding a secret U.S. bioweapons plot in Ukraine. Several commentators predicted the claim would end up on Fox News, where Hunter Biden theories are ever-popular. Julia Davis, a columnist for The Daily Beast who monitors Russian media, suggested it was crafted with hopes of getting a Fox News feature. If you thought Russian propaganda was ever â€œsophisticated,â€ I hate to break it to you: it was always quite stupid. Still is. Here is their latest gem: Hunter Biden funded bio-labs in Ukraine. Handcrafted for Fox News.  Hours later, it got its shoutout. Citing a report in the right-wing website National Pulse, Carlson said, â€Apparently a private equity firm run by Hunter Biden funded some of the research into pathogens in these biolabs.â€ â€œWhat are the outlines of that story? Weâ€™re not sure,â€ he continued. â€œWe know itâ€™s legitimate to ask what it means, why wouldnâ€™t it be? Youâ€™re not a Russian agent repeating discredited Putin talking points if you ask. Youâ€™re a good citizen.â€ Tucker Carlson cites reporting by The National Pulse saying that a private equity firm run by Hunter Biden funded some of the research in Ukrainian biolabs.  Russiaâ€™s baseless claims about American biological warfare labs in Ukraine have taken root in U.S. right-wing networks in recent weeks. Despite repeated debunking from U.S. officials, Carlson has devoted considerable airtime to promoting the conspiracy theory, appearing to side with the Kremlin over the U.S. government. The Fox News host has repeatedly pushed pro-Russia and anti-Ukraine talking points as Russian President Vladimir Putin continues his war on the neighboring nation. Multiple excerpts from Carlsonâ€™s show have been translated to serve as propaganda on Russian state-sponsored TV. Earlier this month, Mother Jones detailed a leaked memo in which the Kremlin asked state-controlled media to highlight Carlson â€œas much as possibleâ€ due to his criticism of the U.S. and its NATO allies and defense of Russia.

Title: Why Europe Cannot Afford To Cut Off Russian Energy For Now
Text: While the West is united in punishing Russian President Vladimir Putin for invading Ukraine, Europeâ€™s reliance on Russian energy is making that difficult. President Joe Biden joined European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen on Friday to announce a new plan under which the U.S. and other countries will increase shipments of liquified natural gas to Europe by at least 15 billion cubic meters in 2022, with further increases in years to come. â€œWe want as Europeans to diversify away from Russia towards suppliers that we trust, that are friends and that are reliable,â€ von der Leyen said during a joint news conference in Brussels. However, Europe remains reliant on Russian energy and canâ€™t cut it off overnight. Last year, Russia provided 8% of all U.S. petroleum imports, including 3% of crude oil imports, according to the U.S. Energy Information Administration. The U.S. has not imported any natural gas from Russia since 2019, according to Forbes. The U.S. banned imports of Russian oil and gas earlier this month. â€œThe United States produces far more oil domestically than all of Europe,â€ Biden said when he announced the ban, according to NBC News. â€œWe can take this step when others cannot.â€ The European Union relies on Russia for 40% of its gas, 27% of its oil imports and 46% of coal imports, according to Reuters. â€œWe are much more dependent in Europe in comparison to the situation in the United States,â€ Charles Michel, president of the European Council, told CNNâ€™s Christiane Amanpour on Wednesday. â€œItâ€™s why we must be intelligent. The goal is to target Russia, the goal is to be painful against Russia. The goal is not to be painful for ourselves.â€ Exclusive: @eucopresident Charles Michel says that on sanctions, the EU's situation differs from the US.Europe is much more dependent on Russian gas, "that's why we must be intelligent... The goal is to be painful against Russia. The goal is not to be painful for ourselves."  Russiaâ€™s energy relationship with Europe traces back to the Cold War, explained Pierre NoÃ«l, global research scholar at the Center on Global Energy Policy at Columbia Universityâ€™s School of International and Public Affairs. Natural gas from the Soviet Union helped Western Europe move away from oil products after the oil shocks of the 1970s. In 1981, then-U.S. President Ronald Reagan imposed sanctions effectively banning American companies from participating in development of a gas pipeline from Siberia to Germany. But Reagan lifted the sanctions a year later following fierce opposition from the gas and oil industry, according to The New York Times. Years later, in the early 2000s, some European countries were growing increasingly wary of dependence on Russian energy as Putin first came to power and Europeâ€™s political relationship with the country changed. â€œHowever, Russia was always a very reliable supplier and adapted its commercial terms to the changing European market, ensuring the competitiveness of its gas,â€ NoÃ«l said. Besides, some European powers like Germany and France wanted to maintain a relationship with Russia, and deemed energy an area where cooperation had proven successful, NoÃ«l added. E.U. countries are worried that further pressure on Russia could cause vast damage to the global economy. Germany â€” Europeâ€™s biggest economy and the worldâ€™s fourth-largest â€” relies on Russia for more than half of its gas and a third of its oil, according to the London School of Economics. Stopping Russian energy supplies could prove risky. â€œEconomic damage would be considerable,â€ Christian Egenhofer, an associate senior research fellow at the think tank Center for European Policy Studies, told HuffPost. â€œShould we weaken our economies is one question. The other is whether we should keep more sanctions ready, for in case Russia uses chemical weapons or more brutality towards civilian targets.â€ In the meantime, it is unclear how much financial pressure the E.U. is willing to tolerate to punish Russia. â€œI think itâ€™s important for us at the European Union level to protect our economic strength, our economic power,â€ the E.U.â€™s Michel told CNN. â€œThis is the key condition in order to support Ukraine and to take painful measures against Russia.â€ Worldwide prices of gas and oil reached record highs after Russia invaded Ukraine. Soaring costs also may affect other industries, warned Anne-Sophie Corbeau, global research scholar at the Center on Global Energy Policy at Columbia Universityâ€™s School of International and Public Affairs. â€œHigh gas prices also mean high power prices,â€ Corbeau told HuffPost. â€œThat could have a serious impact on our industries. That can also have a disastrous impact on fertilizer production and therefore food production, which can compound a potential food crisis.â€ Biden has accused Putin of using his countryâ€™s energy supplies to â€œcoerce and manipulate his neighborsâ€ and â€œdrive his war machine.â€ "We're coming together to reduce Europe's dependence on Russian energy"US President Joe Biden outlines major deal between US and EU on liquified natural gas which will attempt to reduce Europe's reliance on Russian energy  Putin has already shown he is willing to exploit this reliance by announcing Wednesday that payments for Russian gas will have to be made in rubles for â€œunfriendly countries.â€ That could prove even more complicated for Europeans, who must balance their dependence on Russia with their condemnation of a war that has forced over 3.7 million Ukrainians to flee their country. â€œI suppose people will first look at their contracts and demand that the contracts be respected,â€ NoÃ«l said of Russiaâ€™s European customers. â€œHowever, there is no appetite in Europe for a sharp aggravation of the energy crisis, and therefore governments would likely ask European companies to comply, forcing them to procure the Russian currency.â€

Title: Ukraine Claims It Destroyed A Russian Warship That Was Restocking Troops
Text: Ukraineâ€™s navy said it sank a large Russian landing ship near the port city of Berdyansk in southern Ukraine on Thursday, preventing attempts by Russian forces to resupply its troops at the Russian-seized city just west of Mariupol. Photos and video posted on social media show the vessel, called the Orsk, burning in the port which was seized by Russian troops shortly after the start of Russiaâ€™s invasion last month. As the ship burns, at least two other ships are seen leaving the port with what appeared to be smaller fires burning on them. â€œThe destroyed ship in Berdyansk could carry up to 20 tanks, 45 armored personnel carriers and 400 paratroopers,â€ the Ukrainian deputy defense minister, Hanna Malyar, said in a statement on Thursday, according to The New York Times. â€œThis is a huge target that was hit by our military.â€ Ukrainian officials said two additional ships were damaged by Ukrainian forces and a 3,000-ton fuel tank was also destroyed, igniting a fire that spread to nearby ammunition supplies, according to The Associated Press. Berdyansk, which overlooks the Sea of Azov, is roughly 45 miles west of Ukraineâ€™s main southeast port city of Mariupol. That city has sustained widespread destruction from the war but continues to resist total Russian control. On Thursday, Ukraine accused Russia of illegally deporting about 15,000 civilians from Mariupol to Russia since Russian forces began seizing parts of the city.

Title: Volodymyr Zelenskyy Calls For Worldwide Demonstrations As Russian Invasion Enters Second Month
Text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy urged the world to remain steadfast in its support on Thursday, one month after Russia began its invasion of Ukraine. â€œIt breaks my heart, hearts of all Ukrainians and every free person on the planet. Thatâ€™s why I ask you to stand against the war,â€ Zelenskyy said in a video message posted to social media. â€œâ€¦Come from your offices, your homes, your schools and universities, come in the name of peace, come with Ukrainian symbols to support Ukraine, to support freedom, to support life.â€ .@ZelenskyyUa: The war of #Russia is not only the war against #Ukraine.ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡ºstarted the war against freedom as it is. Thatâ€™s why I ask you to stand against the war! Starting from March 24 - exactly one month after the Russian invasionAll as one together who want to stop the war!  The war, which began on Feb. 24 when Russian troops invaded Ukraine, has stretched far longer than Putin or military analysts anticipated, with a fierce Ukrainian resistance holding off the Russian military in Kyiv and other cities. Earlier this week, NATO said that as many as 15,000 Russians had been killed in the conflict and up to 25,000 more injured. Ukraine has claimed that figure includes six Russian generals; the Kremlin has acknowledged just one of those generalsâ€™ deaths. At the same time, Russian President Vladimir Putin has upped his militaryâ€™s assault on civilian targets, bombing Ukrainian cities while peace talks make little ground. The U.S. has said those attacks amount to war crimes, and pointed to the shelling of a maternity hospital in Mariupol. Figures show at least 2,500 Ukrainian civilians have been killed in the war, although the actual number of fatalities is likely far higher. Zelenskyy has become a national hero through his leadership during the invasion, wielding social media to rally Ukrainians and appeal for aid and military support from Europe, Asia and the United States. But fears have grown that Putin, angered at the stalled effort, could turn to the countryâ€™s vast arsenal of chemical, biological or nuclear weapons in order to shift the tide of battle. President Joe Biden is in Europe this week for a summit with NATO allies and the European Union to hash out new sanctions against Russia and discuss further military aid. According to The New York Times, the White House has also quietly assembled a team of national security officials to sketch out how it will respond if Putin turns towards weapons of mass destruction. In his video address Thursday, Zelenskyy urged people all over the world to recognize the Kremlinâ€™s assault against Ukraine as not just a war against his people, but a â€œwar against freedom as it is.â€ â€œMake yourselves visible and heard,â€ he said. â€œSay that people matter, freedom matters, peace matters, Ukraine matters. All as one, together, who want to stop the war.â€

Title: Retired Major General Names The Vladimir Putin Trait Thatâ€™s Breaking Russiaâ€™s Military
Text: Retired U.S. Army Maj. Gen. James Marks put the blame for Russiaâ€™s faltering invasion of Ukraine firmly on Russian President Vladimir Putin and his excessive pride. Marks, now a military analyst for CNN, said Wednesday that Putin likely thought the invasion would be a 48-hour â€œcakewalkâ€ with cities across Ukraine falling quickly to his troops. The war is now in its fourth week, with the United Nations estimating that some 7,000 to 15,000 Russian troops have been killed. â€œI mean, thatâ€™s hubris,â€ Marks told anchor Pamela Brown. â€œThatâ€™s a misunderstanding, a strategic miscalculation thatâ€™s incredibly huge. And Putin is in the intel business and he totally blew it. I mean, thatâ€™s phenomenal.â€ Russian forces were ill-prepared for the assault on their neighboring country as a direct result of Putinâ€™s arrogance, Marks continued. â€œThey thought they would â€¦ get into Kyiv and theyâ€™d immediately be welcomed and theyâ€™d have an opportunity to be replenished in (a) short amount of time. That has been totally exposed,â€ he explained. An â€œincredible lack of leadershipâ€ meant supplies couldnâ€™t get to the front lines and Russian soldiers didnâ€™t know what to do or why they were doing it, he said. â€œI mean, itâ€™s a total collapse of the Russian military,â€ Marks added.
