Title: Bayonne, New Jersey, Covers Vladimir Putin's Name On 9/11 Memorial
Text: A New Jersey city has erased Vladimir Putinâ€™s name from a 9/11 memorial that the Russian government gave to the U.S. back in 2005. On Monday, officials in Bayonne, New Jersey, added an acrylic board to cover the Russian presidentâ€™s name on the memorial, which is formally called, â€œTo the Struggle Against World Terrorism,â€ but is also known as the â€œTeardrop Memorialâ€ and â€œTear of Grief.â€ The sculpture was a gift from Russia, and Putin visited Bayonne back in 2005 for the groundbreaking on the memorial. However, after Putin sent troops to invade Ukraine, city officials decided erasing his name from the dedication plaque was a prudent move. â€œItâ€™s definitely satisfaction, but I donâ€™t want to take away from the monument,â€ Tom Cotter, the cityâ€™s Department of Public Works director, told NBC New York. â€œItâ€™s unfortunate Putinâ€™s nameâ€™s on the monument, but I donâ€™t want this to be a Putin thing. I still want this to be a 9/11 monument.â€ Cotter said having Putinâ€™s name on a memorial protesting terrorism isnâ€™t exactly appropriate given current events. â€œBasically whatâ€™s happening in Ukraine right now is like a form of terrorism, the invasion of that country,â€ Cotter said. Bayonne Mayor Jimmy Davis took credit for the action, saying he made the decision so â€œwe donâ€™t deface this honoring of the victims and families of 9/11/01, and we show our support with the people of Ukraine,â€ according to NJ1015.com. Davis also said covering Putinâ€™s name is a statement against the president alone and not the Russian people. â€œWe remain grateful to the Russian people for the memorial. They did not start the war. Mr. Putin did. The memorial will stay in place on our waterfront. It is not going anywhere,â€ Davis said in a statement. Davis doesnâ€™t seem to be worried about how Putin might react to being removed from the cityâ€™s memorial, mainly because he doesnâ€™t have good memories of the Russian leader. â€œIn my opinion, heâ€™s probably the coldest human being Iâ€™ve ever met,â€ Davis, who was a police captain at the time of Putinâ€™s visit, told NBC New York.

Title: Biden To Travel To Europe For NATO Summit On Russiaâ€™s War On Ukraine
Text: President Joe Biden will travel to Belgium next week to meet with NATO allies and European Union leaders as Russia continues its deadly war on Ukraine. The president is scheduled to go to Brussels on March 24 for a NATO summit in which leaders will â€œdiscuss ongoing deterrence and defense efforts in response to Russiaâ€™s unprovoked and unjustified attack on Ukraine,â€ White House press secretary Jen Psaki said Tuesday. Psaki said Biden will also â€œreaffirm our ironclad commitment to our NATO allies.â€ While there, the president is expected to join a European Council summit, where Psaki said he will â€œdiscuss our shared concerns about Ukraine,â€ including efforts to impose economic sanctions on Russia, provide humanitarian aid to civilians impacted by the violence, and address other challenges related to the invasion. Biden will travel to Brussels next week to participate in a NATO summit on the situation in Ukraine, Psaki says  The White House said it is still finalizing details of the trip and could not confirm whether Biden would also travel to Poland or meet with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, who has been pleading for Western leaders to do more to aid the country under attack. Zelenskyy will deliver a virtual address to Congress on Wednesday. â€œHis goal is to meet in person, face-to-face with his European counterparts and talk about and assess where we are at this point in the conflict in the invasion of Ukraine by Russia,â€ Psaki said. â€œWeâ€™ve been incredibly aligned to date â€• that doesnâ€™t happen by accident. The president is a big believer in face-to-face diplomacy, so itâ€™s an opportunity to do exactly that.â€ The trip to Europe would be Bidenâ€™s first since October, and follows Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ visits to Poland and Romania last week. The announcement came on the same day Russia announced sanctions on Biden and other top U.S. officials, in a move aimed at restricting travel to Russia. The move is in response to sanctions that prevent Russian officials from entering the U.S. â€œIt wonâ€™t surprise any of you that none of us are planning tourist trips to Russia,â€ Psaki told reporters. â€œNone of us have bank accounts that we wonâ€™t be able to access, so we will forge ahead.â€

Title: 2 Journalists Working For Fox News Are Killed In Ukraine
Text: A cameraman for Fox News was killed in Ukraine while reporting on the Russian invasion, the network said Tuesday. Pierre Zakrzewski was killed in Horenka, a city outside of the countryâ€™s capital, Kyiv. He was killed in the same attack that wounded Fox News Ukraine correspondent Benjamin Hall. Ukrainian journalist Oleksandra Kuvshynova, who was working as a freelancer for Fox News, was also killed in the attack, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists. â€œPierre was a war zone photographer who covered nearly every international story for FOX News from Iraq to Afghanistan to Syria during his long tenure with us,â€ the network said in a statement. â€œHis passion and talent as a journalist were unmatched.â€ Fox News host John Roberts announced Zakrzewskiâ€™s death on Twitter and said the cameraman was â€œan absolute treasure.â€ Last year, as the U.S. withdrew its forces from Afghanistan, Zakrzewski helped Afghan freelance associates and their families with leaving the country, Fox News said in its statement. â€œIn December at our annual employee Spotlight Awards, Pierre was given the â€˜Unsung Heroâ€™ award in recognition of his invaluable work.â€ Before the attack that killed Zakrzewski and injured Hall, Hall pushed back against Fox News personality Greg Gutfeld for saying the media is trying to rouse up an â€œemotional responseâ€ with its coverage of Ukraine. â€œSpeaking as someone on the ground, I want to say that this is not the media trying to drum up some emotional response,â€ Hall told Gutfield. â€œThis is absolutely whatâ€™s happening.â€ More details of the attack on the journalists are not yet known.

Title: Volodymyr Zelenskyy Has A Message For Russian Soldiers: 'Surrender'
Text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addressed Russian soldiers shelling Ukrainian cities, urging them to surrender in a video message posted on Telegram early Tuesday. â€œOn behalf of the Ukrainian people, I give you a chance, a chance to survive,â€ Zelenskyy said, according to the translation provided with the video. â€œIf you surrender to our forces, we will treat you the way people are supposed to be treated, as people, decently. In a way you were not treated in your army. And in a way your army does not treat ours.â€ In a new address overnight, Zelensky spoke directly to Russian soldiers, in Russian: â€œYou will not take anything from Ukraine. You will take lives... But your lives will also be taken. But why should you die? What for? I know that you want to survive.â€  Zelenskyy said his countryâ€™s fighters continue to resist the invasion and have inflicted major damage on the Russian military. â€œYouâ€™ve already understood everything,â€ Zelenskyy said. â€œYou will not take anything from Ukraine. You will take lives. There are a lot of you. But your life will also be taken. But why should you die? What for? I know you want to survive.â€ He added that Russian forces will face a further reckoning, for committing war crimes. â€œResponsibility for war crimes of the Russian military is inevitable,â€ Zelenskyy warned. â€œResponsibility for a deliberate humanitarian catastrophe in Ukrainian cities is inevitable.â€ The United Nations continues calling for an end to the war, citing the human cost and the devastating impact on the global economy, especially on developing nations, due to rising prices of food and energy. â€œAll of this is hitting the poorest the hardest and planting the seeds for political instability and unrest around the globe,â€ U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres told reporters Monday. Zelenskyy also pleaded with ordinary Russians to continue to resist Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s misinformation campaign. State-run media in Russia have been using the term â€œspecial military operationâ€ instead of â€œwarâ€ to describe the fighting and falsely say Ukraine is led by neo-Nazis, according to the BBC. Zelenskyy made a special mention of Marina Ovsyannikov, the news editor who stormed the set of the Channel One newscast with a poster reading, â€œStop the war. Donâ€™t believe the propaganda. They are lying to you,â€ in Russian. â€œAs long as your country has not completely closed itself off from the whole world, turning into a very large North Korea, you must fight,â€ Zelenskyy said. â€œYou must not lose your chance.â€ The prime ministers of three European Union and NATO member countries â€” Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia â€” are traveling to Kyiv on Tuesday as Russian soldiers edge closer to the capital. â€œEurope must guarantee Ukraineâ€™s independence and ensure that it is ready to help in Ukraineâ€™s reconstruction,â€ Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki tweeted. Together with Deputy PM JarosÅ‚aw KaczyÅ„ski, PM @P_Fiala and PM @JJansaSDS we are going to Kiev to meet President @ZelenskyyUa and PM @Denys_Shmyhal. Europe must guarantee Ukraine's independence and ensure that it is ready to help in Ukraine's reconstruction. U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) said Zelenskyy will give a virtual speech to Congress on Wednesday. Last week, Congress passed a spending bill with bipartisan support, including $13.6 billion for military and humanitarian support to Ukraine and regional allies.

Title: Greg Gutfeld Addresses His 'Little Kerfuffle' With Colleague Benjamin Hall
Text: On Tuesday, Fox News host Greg Gutfeld addressed his dispute last week with Benjamin Hall, a correspondent for the network who was injured on Monday while reporting on the ground in Ukraine. Gutfeld did not apologize for his remarks about his colleague, but claimed he had spoken to Hall over the phone last week about their â€œlittle kerfuffle.â€ He referenced the incident after co-host Geraldo Rivera offered his heartfelt condolences and prayers for Hall â€• who Rivera said had been â€œgrievously injuredâ€ â€• along with two other Fox News colleagues who died in an attack Monday in Ukraine. â€œI want to talk about Ben, but first, the fact that Joe [Biden] is announcing that heâ€™s going to Europe â€• next week â€• no!â€ Gutfeld said, launching into a spiel criticizing the presidentâ€™s handling of the Ukraine crisis. â€œAs for Ben, I spoke to him last week at length after we had our little kerfuffle,â€ Gutfeld continued. â€œAnd the thing that pisses me off most about him is that heâ€™s handsome and heâ€™s funny.â€ Here is Greg Gutfeld talking about Benjamin Hall today. Mentions that they spoke last week after their "little kerfuffle" and ends by calling Hall "a lovely guy."  Last Tuesday, Gutfeld suggested the media was trying to inspire an â€œemotional responseâ€ to the war in Ukraine because â€œthat makes a profit for news companies.â€ From Kyiv, Hall pushed back. â€œSpeaking as someone on the ground, I want to say that this is not the media trying to drum up some emotional response,â€ he said. â€œThis is absolutely whatâ€™s happening.â€ Gutfeld later called Hallâ€™s comments a â€œcheap attackâ€ and doubled down on his assertions about a one-sided narrative in the coverage of Ukraine. On Monday, Fox News announced that Hall had been hospitalized while reporting outside Kyiv. The network said Tuesday that its cameraman, Pierre Zakrzewski, was killed in the same attack, as was Ukrainian journalist Oleksandra Kuvshynova, who was working as a consultant for Fox News. On Tuesday, Gutfeld said that he and Hall had â€œjoked aboutâ€ their on-air debate last week and that Hall had said, â€œâ€˜Greg, you canâ€™t do my job, and I canâ€™t do yours.â€™â€ â€œAnd I said, â€˜duh,â€™â€ Gutfeld continued. â€œMy job is way easier. Iâ€™m not in any danger. I do get death threats, but theyâ€™re usually from Dana,â€ he said, joking about his colleague Dana Perino. â€œBut ... We can afford to pontificate because weâ€™re here, thousands of miles away.â€

Title: Retired Lt. General: Russia May Face Trouble In Ukraine â€˜Within The Next 10 Daysâ€™
Text: A former U.S. Army general predicted Monday that the Russian military could soon run out of the manpower and weaponry needed to continue its invasion of Ukraine. Retired Lt. Gen. Ben Hodges, the former commander of U.S. Army forces in Europe, said recent moves by Russia to extend its campaign to western Ukraine and reports that the country had asked China for military supplies may mean the Kremlin is running out of steam. â€œRussiaâ€™s decision to transition to a war of attrition, where theyâ€™re smashing cities, putting civilians on the road for fear of being murdered, they need three things to do this, and they donâ€™t have those three things,â€ Hodges said on MSNBCâ€™s â€œMeet the Press.â€ â€œThey donâ€™t have the time, they donâ€™t have the manpower and I donâ€™t think they have the ammunition.â€ WATCH: Russia needs three things for a war of attrition that they don't have: "the time ... the manpower and ... the ammunition," says @general_ben. "Within the next 10 days Russia is going to culminate, which means they will not be able to continue the attack any further."  Hodgesâ€™ comments were buoyed by evidence that Russia was running low on weaponry as Ukraine continued to mount a fiercer-than-expected resistance, notably around the capital of Kyiv. He said that if the West continued to support Ukrainians, it could be less than two weeks before the Russian military reached what he referred to as its culmination point. â€œAssuming that we, the West, not only continue but accelerate the delivery of the capabilities the Ukrainians need, I think within the next 10 days that Russia is going to culminate, which means they will not be able to continue the attack any further,â€ Hodges said. â€œSo, itâ€™s kind of a race, actually, if we give the Ukrainians enough so they can outlast Russia.â€ Russian forces will culminate within the next ten days if we maintain pressure on them...they have manpower problems and ammo shortages. Accelerate/expand support to UKR to destroy Russian arty, rockets, and cruise missiles. Now is the time to keep our foot on the gas. Hodges added that there was a big caveat to his prediction, a nod to Putinâ€™s unpredictability during the invasion. â€œIâ€™ve been wrong a lot,â€ he said. â€œI donâ€™t have a crystal ball here.â€

Title: Volodymyr Zelenskyy To Deliver Virtual Address To Congress
Text: WASHINGTON â€• Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will give a virtual address to Congress on Wednesday, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) announced. â€œThe Congress remains unwavering in our commitment to supporting Ukraine as they face Putinâ€™s cruel and diabolical aggression, and to passing legislation to cripple and isolate the Russian economy as well as deliver humanitarian, security and economic assistance to Ukraine,â€ the two Democrats wrote in a letter to all lawmakers on Monday. â€œWe look forward to the privilege of welcoming President Zelenskyyâ€™s address to the House and Senate and to convey our support to the people of Ukraine as they bravely defend democracy.â€ All members of Congress are invited to hear from the foreign leader, who has refused to leave Kyiv, the capital city of Ukraine, as Russian forces continue their bloody advance into the country. Zelenskyy previously addressed all members of the U.S. Senate during a private video call earlier this month. Itâ€™s unclear whether this weekâ€™s address will be made public. Congress last week approved nearly $14 billion in humanitarian and military assistance to Ukraine as it struggles to repel a Russian invasion. President Joe Biden over the weekend also approved an additional $200 million in weapons for Ukraine, bringing the total security aid provided to the country since January to $1.2 billion. But the Biden administration has so far resisted one of Zelenskyyâ€™s top requests: the imposition of a no-fly zone over Ukraine in an effort to protect civilians from Russian airstrikes. White House officials have argued that such a move could put U.S. planes and pilots at risk of engagement with Russian troops, heightening the risk of a broader nuclear war. Sen. Angus King (I-Maine), a member of the Senate Intelligence Committee, also noted in an interview with CNN over the weekend that a no-fly zone may not prove as effective due to reliance by Russian troops on artillery, rather than simply fighter jets. .@SenAngusKing of Intel Cmte notes to me and @DanaBashCNN: â€œthe destruction in Ukraine is almost entirely the result of missiles and artillery (not bombs from aircraft) which a no-fly zone would not stop. In other words, high escalation risk for little actual benefit.â€

Title: Fox News Reporter Hospitalized With Injuries In Ukraine
Text: A Ukraine correspondent for Fox News has been hospitalized with injuries he sustained while reporting on the Russian invasion, the network said Monday. â€œEarlier today, our corespondent Benjamin Hall was injured while reporting outside of Kyiv in Ukraine,â€ network CEO Suzanne Scott said in a memo to staff. â€œWe have a minimal level of details right now, but Ben is hospitalized and our teams on the ground are working quickly to gather additional information as the situation quickly unfolds.â€ Fox News also shared the message on air. Hall recently pushed back against Fox News personality Greg Gutfeld for saying the media is trying to rouse up an â€œemotional responseâ€ with its coverage of Ukraine. After Greg Gutfeld said the media is airing emotionally manipulating viewers on Ukraine to push a narrative, Fox News correspondent Benjamin Hall pushes back:"Speaking as someone on the ground, I want to say that this is not the media trying to drum up some emotional response."  Moments after Gutfeld made those remarks, the network cut to Hall in Kyiv. â€œSpeaking as someone on the ground, I want to say that this is not the media trying to drum up some emotional response. This is absolutely whatâ€™s happening,â€ he said, saying heâ€™s seen people trapped by Russian forces in Ukraineâ€™s Mariupol resort to drinking water from puddles. The United Nations says at least 596 civilians have died as a result of Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s invasion. â€œThis is a stark reminder for all journalists who are putting their lives on the line every day to deliver the news from a war zone,â€ Scott added in Mondayâ€™s memo. News of Hallâ€™s injuries come a day after police in Ukraine confirmed that award-winning American journalist and filmmaker Brent Renaud was killed by Russian forces outside of Kyiv.

Title: Dick Durbin Slams Tucker Carlson As 'Apologist For Putin' In Senate Floor Speech
Text: In a speech on the Senate floor Monday, Majority Whip Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) said Fox News host Tucker Carlson â€œshould be ashamed of himselfâ€ for acting as an apologist for Russian President Vladimir Putin. Amid Putinâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, parts of Carlsonâ€™s on-air spiels have been translated to serve as pro-Russia propaganda on Russian state-sponsored TV. The Fox News host has blamed the U.S. for Russiaâ€™s war and repeated pro-Russia talking points, evidently nabbing the attention of the Kremlin, which reportedly directed state media to use clips of his broadcasts â€œas much as possibleâ€ earlier this month. â€œWhen I hear apologists for Putin in America, I wonder who they are and what theyâ€™re made of,â€ Durbin said during a speech condemning Russian atrocities in Ukraine. â€œTucker Carlson is one that even the Russians are recommending that their friends in the media listen to. Making excuses on Fox for Vladimir Putin. There are no excuses. Not acceptable,â€ the senator said. â€œMr. Carlson should be ashamed of himself.â€ "Tucker Carlson ... making excuses on Fox for Vladimir Putin. There are no excuses, none acceptable on the subject. Mr. Carlson should be ashamed of himself." â€” Sen. @DickDurbin  According to a Mother Jones report published over the weekend, a Russian government agency asked media and commentators in a March 3 memo to use clips of Carlsonâ€™s broadcasts because he â€œsharply criticizesâ€ the actions of the U.S. and NATO and their â€œnegative role in unleashing the conflict in Ukraine.â€ On Thursday, ABCâ€™s chief Washington correspondent, Jonathan Karl, reported that Carlsonâ€™s commentary justifying Russiaâ€™s attack on Ukraine has at times been an almost â€œword-for-wordâ€ recitation of Putinâ€™s remarks. Carlson has promoted these types of views for years. In 2019, he asked, â€œWhy do I care what is going on in the conflict between Ukraine and Russia? ... Why shouldnâ€™t I root for Russia? Which I am.â€ Following backlash, he claimed he was joking. As Russian aggression intensified in the lead-up to the invasion, Carlson defended Putin and criticized Ukraine, arguing that Ukraine was not a democracy. After Putin began his brutal attacks on the neighboring nation and its civilians, Carlson admitted that it had taken him â€œby surpriseâ€ and that some of his analysis was wrong. He has since amplified a baseless Russian conspiracy theory about secret U.S.-backed biological warfare labs in Ukraine. Carlson and his Fox News colleague Laura Ingraham were also featured in a speech by Durbin on the Senate floor last year. On that occasion, Durbin slammed them for spreading anti-vaccine misinformation amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

Title: Demonstrators In Russia Resort To Blank-Sign Protests â€” And Still Get Arrested
Text: Protesters in Russia are being detained just for protesting with blank posters, according to videos being shared on social media. The Kremlin has been cracking down on anti-war demonstrations since Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered his troops to invade Ukraine almost three weeks ago. The controversial move has caused widespread devastation in Ukraine, and isolated Russia as the international community condemns Putinâ€™s aggression with severe sanctions. However, Moscow has been shutting down independent media outlets and reducing access to social media platforms for Russian citizens to prevent the reality of the Ukrainian invasion reaching the general public. People in Russia have not even been able to call the invasion what it is, or a war. Now the Russian authorities have gone one step further and appear to be removing demonstrators with blank signs from the streets, as seen in this video: Police in Nizhny Novgorod arrested a demonstrator today for protesting with a blank sign. Welcome to Russia in 2022.  According to independent Russian human rights project, Ovd Info, approximately 14,911 people in Russia have been detained since Putin launched his invasion in Ukraine on Feb. 24. Similar videos have also been shared on Twitter. In one, a woman holds up a sign which just says, â€œtwo wordsâ€ in Russian. The activist asks the cameraman, â€œAm I going to get arrested for this or not?â€ Within a matter of seconds, she is removed by a group of police officers dressed in protective gear with helmets and visors. Then another woman approaches the camera, and starts to explain why she supports the war against Ukraine â€“ but before she can say anything, police grab her by the arm and pull her away from the screen too. One of the most extraordinary videos Iâ€™ve ever seen. The first woman is holding up a sign that says â€˜two wordsâ€™.  Another social media video appears to show Russian citizens deflecting questions about whether they agree with the war. What do the Russians say about the attack against Ukraine? Full video with English subtitles here: subtitles  Speaking out against the war could lead to hefty fines or imprisonment for up to 15 years. This dramatic legislation came into place during the first week of the invasion, after the Russian Duma cracked down on the spread of any so-called â€œfalse informationâ€ related to the invasion. As a result, open acts of defiance â€” such as the one seen below â€” are rare and usually come with significant consequences. A Russian pilot tells passengers that he believes â€œthe war in Ukraine is a crime,â€ adding â€œI think each sensible citizens will agree with me and will do everything to make it stop.â€ Rare to see public opposition to the war given the consequences such a statement will have

Title: Leaked Kremlin Memo Told Russian Media To Feature Lots Of Tucker Carlson: Report
Text: The Kremlin asked state-controlled Russian media to highlight Fox News host Tucker Carlsonâ€™s broadcasts â€œas much as possibleâ€ due to his criticisms of the U.S. and its NATO allies in his coverage of the Ukraine crisis, Mother Jones reported. A leaked 12-page memo from a Russian government agency to media on March 3 said â€œit is essential to use as much as possible fragments of broadcastsâ€ by Carlson, according to a translation by Mother Jones, which said it obtained the note from a contributor to a national Russian media outlet. Carlson â€œsharply criticizesâ€ the actions of the U.S. and NATO and their â€œnegative role in unleashing the conflict in Ukraine,â€ the memo said, per the news site. Carlson is also critical of the â€œdefiantly provocative behavior from the leadership of the Western countries and NATO towards the Russian Federation and towards President Putin, personally,â€ it reportedly continued. The document was titled â€œFor Media and Commentatorsâ€ and sent from Russiaâ€™s Department of Information and Telecommunications Support, according to Mother Jones. The outlet said Carlson was the only Western journalist referenced in the memo. Retired Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, the former director for European and Russian affairs at the National Security Council whose testimony figured prominently in former President Donald Trumpâ€™s first impeachment, weighed in on the report, tweeting at Carlson to â€œLive your life in such a way that the Russian government and state TV apparatus doesnâ€™t think youâ€™re an ally.â€ Carlson has evidently landed in the Kremlinâ€™s good books after consistently amplifying Russian propaganda on his show. On Thursday, ABCâ€™s chief Washington correspondent Jonathan Karl reported that Carlsonâ€™s rhetoric was â€œalmost a plagiarismâ€ of Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s. In the days before Russia invaded Ukraine, Carlson defended Putin and questioned why he was expected to dislike him. â€œHas Putin ever called me a racist? Has he threatened to get me fired for disagreeing with him?â€ he asked. Since the invasion, Carlson has blamed the U.S. for Russiaâ€™s attack and parroted baseless Russian conspiracy theories about secret American biological warfare labs in Ukraine. He also complained that he was falsely accused of rooting for Russia. (He has openly admitted to doing so in the past.) â€œWhy do I care what is going on in the conflict between Ukraine and Russia?â€ Carlson said in 2019. â€œAnd Iâ€™m serious. Why do I care? Why shouldnâ€™t I root for Russia? Which I am.â€ He later claimed he was joking. Multiple excerpts from his show have been translated to serve as propaganda on Russian state-sponsored TV, including one in which he argued that Ukraine is not a democracy but â€œa client state of the Biden administration.â€

Title: Cut Off From Donors, Russiaâ€™s â€˜Free Press In-Exileâ€™ Launches Global Crowdfunding Campaign
Text: A crowdfunded news outlet that bills itself as Russiaâ€™s â€œfree press in-exileâ€ has seen its funding completely severed by the descent of Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s new iron curtain, cutting Russians off from one of their few remaining independent sources of information. The Latvia-based outlet, Meduza, has published stories in both English and Russian since 2014, relying on a combination of advertising revenue and donations from readers. That changed drastically in 2021, when the Kremlin branded the news website a â€œforeign agentâ€ and ad revenue evaporated. Some 30,000 Russian donors stepped in to make up the difference, according to the outlet. But now that sending money into and out of Russia is virtually impossible, Meduza is once again facing an existential crisis. Meduzaâ€™s editorial staff in Russia fled the country at the start of the war â€• some on foot, in the middle of the night â€• and are now scattered across Asia and Europe. Though Meduzaâ€™s website has been blocked in Russia, the outlet says millions of Russians continue to read via the outletâ€™s app and encrypted messaging apps, like Telegram. (Meduza has produced a number of joint investigations in the past via a partnership with BuzzFeed, HuffPostâ€™s parent company.) Now Meduza is getting a signal boost from news outlets around the world in a bid for new members. â€œWe ask you to take the place of our dedicated supporters from Russia,â€ the Meduza staff wrote in a crowdfunding appeal. â€œWe have a duty to tell the truth. We have millions of readers in Russia who need us. Without independent journalism, it will be impossible to stop this monstrous war.â€ One of the outlets pitching in is Krautreporter, a crowdfunded German news cooperative that offered to help lead the crowdfunding effort after reading about Meduzaâ€™s plight on social media. â€œThis is one of the few shots that Russians have at getting independent reporting and good information,â€ Krautreporter publisher Leon Fryszer told HuffPost, emphasizing the two outlets share no formal, professional relationship. â€œI think there needs to be a counter-force to what the Kremlin is doing now, and Meduza has a good chance at being that.â€ â€œItâ€™s something very practical that we can do for Russians in a situation where sometimes it feels like youâ€™re paralyzed because you canâ€™t do a lot,â€ he added. Despite the setbacks, the staff of Meduza is still hard at work. In the past theyâ€™ve exposed everything from the presence of Russian mercenaries in Venezuela to the machinations of Russiaâ€™s propaganda apparatus; these days itâ€™s mostly 24/7 war coverage. â€œMeduza is very popular and thatâ€™s a huge responsibility because a lot of people rely on us for factual information that nobody else will have either the experience, the resources or the will to report,â€ investigative reporter Alexey Kovalev told the Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism at Oxford. â€œWe are immensely proud of this. Itâ€™s an incredibly physically and mentally taxing job. But it still energizes me to know that for so many people now we are the only lifeline, the only window to the world.â€ BuzzFeed News reporter Stephanie Baer contributed reporting.

Title: Russia Facing â€˜Outright Defeatâ€™ And â€˜Suddenâ€™ Collapse In Ukraine, Author Says
Text: Author and political scientist Francis Fukuyama said the Russian military is now facing the possibility of â€œoutright defeatâ€ in Ukraine. And heâ€™s warning Russian President Vladimir Putin that the end could be swift â€• for both his military and his more than two-decade rule. â€œThe collapse of their position could be sudden and catastrophic, rather than happening slowly through a war of attrition,â€ Fukuyama wrote for the American Purpose website. â€œThe army in the field will reach a point where it can neither be supplied nor withdrawn, and morale will vaporize.â€ Fukuyama, author of 1992â€²s â€œThe End of History and the Last Man,â€ blamed incompetent planning by Moscow, which anticipated that its forces would be welcomed in Ukraine. â€œRussian soldiers were evidently carrying dress uniforms for their victory parade in Kyiv rather than extra ammo and rations,â€ wrote Fukuyama, who holds several positions at Stanford, including Olivier Nomellini Senior Fellow at the universityâ€™s Freeman Spogli Institute for International Studies. Now, those soldiers are stuck outside of cities, facing both supply issues and constant attacks from Ukrainian forces. If theyâ€™re defeated, he predicted, that would also spell the end of Putin. â€œPutin will not survive the defeat of his army,â€ Fukuyama wrote. â€œHe gets support because he is perceived to be a strongman; what does he have to offer once he demonstrates incompetence and is stripped of his coercive power? Read Fukuyamaâ€™s full analysis here. H/T Raw Story

Title: Rebel Wilson Gives Vladimir Putin The Finger At BAFTAs
Text: BAFTAs host Rebel Wilson took aim at Russian President Vladimir Putin Sunday for directing an unprovoked invasion of Ukraine. And she did it with just one finger â€• the middle one. (Watch the video below.) The â€œPitch Perfectâ€ actor introduced a musical performance by â€œCODAâ€ star Emilia Jones by explaining that American and British sign-language interpreters would be onstage. â€œLuckily, though, in all sign languages, this is the gesture for Putin,â€ she said, flipping a bird that got digitally blurred in the broadcast. Here's a lesson in sign language from @RebelWilson #EEBAFTAs  Wilson, the Australian star of â€œIsnâ€™t It Romantic,â€ had a few other zingers of note. Addressing her weight loss, she quipped, per the New York Post: â€œClearly it was to get the attention of Robert Pattinson. ... I didnâ€™t lose weight just to get a guy, I did it to get more acting roles. Now I can play the non-funny love interest in an Adam Sandler film.â€ She added that he had gone through a transition. â€œI hope J.K. Rowling approves,â€ she sniped in a dig at the â€œHarry Potterâ€ authorâ€™s controversial beliefs about transgender people.

Title: Putin's War Could Worsen The Impact Of COVID-19 In Ukraine
Text: The escalation of Russiaâ€™s military offensive in Ukraine, including attacks on health care facilities, could prolong the pandemic, U.N. agencies warned Sunday. â€œAmidst the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, which has already put health systems and health care workers under enormous strain, such attacks have the potential to be even more devastating for the civilian population,â€ reads a joint statement issued by the World Health Organization, UNICEF, and the United Nations Population Fund. The statement cited 31 attacks that destroyed or damaged health care facilities since the beginning of the Russian invasion, curtailing Ukrainiansâ€™ access to services, including vaccinations against COVID-19. â€œHumanitarian partners and health care workers must be able to safely maintain and strengthen essential health service delivery, including immunization against COVID-19 and polio, and the supply of life-saving medicines for civilians across Ukraine as well as to refugees crossing into neighbouring countries,â€ the statement says. Vaccination rates in Ukraine were low, even before the invasion. Only about 35.7% of the population had received two COVID-19 vaccine doses as of Feb. 23, according to Reuters. Daily cases peaked at 41,694 on Feb. 10 and have been decreasing since, although the war has impacted access to testing. Ukraine has reported 106,985 COVID-19-related deaths during the pandemic. Ukrainian health care workers have been told to take note of patientsâ€™ symptoms, instead of seeking COVID tests, Dr. Oleksandr Matskov, deputy director of the General Public Health Center of Ukraine, told The New York Times. The war has upended life across the country and has eclipsed COVID concerns for many everyday Ukrainians. â€œPeople are not frightened about COVID anymore,â€ Dr. Marta Saiko, head of the therapy department at the Clinical Municipal Emergency Hospital in Lviv, told The New York Times. â€œPeople are frightened of the war.â€ Over 2.8 million people have fled Ukraine since the Russian invasion, according to U.N. data last updated on Sunday. Most have sought refuge in Poland, where border staff have not been requesting vaccination certificates or COVID-19 tests, according to Euronews. Typically, travelers from outside the E.U. are required to show a negative COVID-19 test result and proof of vaccination or recovery certificate to avoid quarantine, according to the Polish governmentâ€™s website. Jean-Claude Cordeau, head of the Urban Search and Rescue mission in the Polish village of Medyka, looks after refugees making the crossing from Ukraine, including small children arriving with hypothermia. â€œCOVID at this border crossing here in Medyka is obviously not a priority,â€ Cordeau told Euronews. â€œNot a priority for us, and not a priority for refugees that are arriving.â€ Still, WHOâ€™s Dr. Maria Van Kerkhove warned the pandemic is not over and said the chaos in Ukraine is a breeding ground for infectious diseases. â€œCertainly, this pandemic is not taking a break, despite the fact that we have this war, despite the fact that we have challenges and many countries are facing challenges right now,â€ Van Kerkhove said during a WHO press briefing on Wednesday. The BA.2 variant, also known as â€œstealth omicron,â€ has driven Chinaâ€™s biggest COVID-19 outbreak since the beginning of the pandemic in early 2020. Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla said Sunday an additional booster shot is necessary to prevent future infections. Pfizer CEO @AlbertBourla tells @margbrennan his company is working â€œvery diligentlyâ€ to make a covid vaccine that will protect against variants & will protect â€œfor at least a year.â€

Title: Russia Restricts Instagram For Millions Of Citizens
Text: Russia has banned millions of citizens from using Instagram after the social media platformâ€™s parent company decided it would allow posts referring to violence against Russian soldiers in Ukraine. Facebook and Instagram â€” which are both owned by Meta â€” have altered their guidelines to allow users in certain countries to post content thatâ€™s typically forbidden, such as hate speech and calls for the death of Russian soldiers or politicians, according to The Verge. Russia banned Facebook last week, claiming it allowed â€œdiscrimination against Russian media,â€ The Verge reported. Instagram CEO Adam Mosseri tweeted last week that Russiaâ€™s decision to ban the social media platform would â€œcut 80 million in Russia off from one anotherâ€ and â€œthe rest of the world.â€ On Monday, Instagram will be blocked in Russia. This decision will cut 80 million in Russia off from one another, and from the rest of the world as ~80% of people in Russia follow an Instagram account outside their country. This is wrong. The Russian parliament has also blocked access to Twitter for its citizens. A slew of corporations have pulled their services from Russia. Social media app TikTok banned all livestreaming and content creation in Russia due to President Vladimir Putinâ€™s new law that criminalizes anything he deems to be â€œfake newsâ€ as Russia continues its violent invasion of Ukraine. â€œIn light of Russiaâ€™s new â€˜fake newsâ€™ law, we have no choice but to suspend live-streaming and new content to our video service while we review the safety implications of this law,â€ TikTok said last week in a statement.

Title: Rep. Adam Kinzinger Declines To 'Ever' Appear On Tucker Carlson's 'Propaganda' Show
Text: Rep. Adam Kinzinger (R-Ill.) on Monday provided a lengthy rationale for declining to ever appear on Tucker Carlsonâ€™s Fox News program, describing it as being â€œfull of Russian propaganda and not news.â€ â€œTucker Carlson invited me on his show tonight, but thatâ€™s not going to happenâ€¦ ever,â€ the lawmaker tweeted alongside a video statement. â€œWhile he echoes Putinâ€™s lies, Iâ€™ll remain focused on supporting the Ukrainian people.â€ Carlson often attacks Kinzinger, one of a handful of Republicans in Congress who have been repeatedly and publicly critical of former President Donald Trump. Kinzinger has also gone after Carlson in the past for spreading disinformation and sentiments supportive of Russian President Vladimir Putin. â€œHis insistence that the West was provoking war with Putin, his spreading lies about bio labs, and his continued spewing of conspiracy theories are nothing but complete evil,â€ Kinzinger said in his video statement. â€œHis show is full of Russian propaganda and not news, and I will not validate his show by making an appearance. I do not want to be associated with it in any way.â€ He predicted what would happen if he appeared on the program, noting that Carlsonâ€™s playbook for â€œhostileâ€ interviews is to interrupt the guests and then laugh â€œwhen heâ€™s been caught in a lie.â€ Carlson has openly admitted that he lies on his show. â€œWe know the interview would be promoted to get more viewers, to make more money, to further empower his garbage,â€ Kinzinger added. Tucker Carlson invited me on his show tonight, but thatâ€™s not going to happenâ€¦ever. While he echoes Putinâ€™s lies, Iâ€™ll remain focused on supporting the Ukrainian people. My video statement:  Pointing to the dire situation in Ukraine as Putin wages war, Kinzinger said it was time for â€œserious conversation and decisive action.â€ â€œNot a self-serving showboat clamoring for more clicks tonight.â€ Kinzinger encouraged viewers to join him in supporting Ukraine by donating to a humanitarian aid fund for Ukrainian refugees on his website. â€œTucker has made it clear he stands with Putin and his war against freedom,â€ Kinzinger added. â€œI stand with Ukraine, democracy, and the men and women willing to fight and die for their country.â€ He concluded by offering his and his wifeâ€™s prayers for Benjamin Hall, a Fox News correspondent who was injured while reporting in Ukraine. â€œThe job they do is dangerous and appreciated,â€ he said. Last week, Carlson taunted the congressman to appear on his show after Kinzinger slammed him for hosting a UFC fighter who said that the Biden administration â€œshouldnâ€™t be giving our tax dollarsâ€ to Ukraine. Carlson has faced furious backlash in recent weeks for peddling Russian conspiracy theories and promoting pro-Russia and anti-Ukraine talking points. His commentary are so aligned with Russian propaganda that the countryâ€™s state-controlled television channels have aired excerpts of his broadcasts with subtitles, and the Kremlin reportedly asked state media to highlight Carlsonâ€™s programs.

Title: U.S. Filmmaker Brent Renaud Killed By Russian Forces In Ukraine: Police
Text: An award-winning American journalist and filmmaker was killed by Russian forces outside Kyiv on Sunday, the head of the regionâ€™s police force said. Brent Renaud, a 51-year-old Peabody Award recipient, was fatally shot in Irpin, northwest of Ukraineâ€™s capital. A second journalist was injured along with him, said Andriy Nebytov, the head of Kyivâ€™s regional police force, in a message posted on Facebook. (Warning: The message includes disturbing photos of a body, believed to be that of the filmmaker.) Nebytov also shared a photo of Renaudâ€™s passport and media credentials issued by The New York Times. â€œOf course, the profession of journalism carries risks. Nonetheless, U.S. citizen Brent Renaud paid with his life trying to highlight the deceit, cruelty and ruthlessness of the aggressor,â€ Nebytovâ€™s post read. Renaud was not on assignment for the Times in Ukraine at the time of his death. A Times press badge he was wearing had been issued for an assignment â€œmany years ago,â€ a spokesperson for the news outlet said Sunday. â€œWe are deeply saddened to hear of Brent Renaudâ€™s death. Brent was a talented filmmaker who had contributed to The New York Times over the years,â€ the Times said in a statement. PBS NewsHour reporter Jane Ferguson said on Twitter that she was at the roadside scene where Renaudâ€™s body lay under a blanket and that there was nothing Ukrainian medics could do for him. She quoted an outraged Ukrainian police officer as saying: â€œTell America, tell the world, what they did to a journalist.â€ Danylo Shapovalov, a surgeon volunteering for the Ukrainian territorial defense, told AFP that the journalists were riding in a car when they were shot at. â€œThere were two journalists and one of ours (a Ukrainian),â€ he told the news outlet. â€œOur guy and the journalist are wounded, I provided them first aid, the other one received a wound in the neck, he died immediately.â€ White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan, speaking on CBS Newsâ€™ â€œFace the Nation,â€ called news of a U.S. journalistâ€™s death â€œobviously shocking and horrifyingâ€ and said itâ€™s just the latest example of â€œbrazen aggressionâ€ by Russian forces. â€œI will be consulting with my colleagues, weâ€™ll be consulting with the Ukrainians to determine how this happened and then to measure and execute appropriate consequences as a result of it,â€ he said.

Title: Russia Reportedly Asked China For Military Supplies, Other Aid, U.S. Officials Say
Text: Russia has asked China for military equipment and economic support following the Kremlinâ€™s protracted invasion of Ukraine, several media outlets reported Sunday. The request comes as Russian President Vladimir Putin expanded his assault on Ukraine to the countryâ€™s west, killing 35 people in an attack on a military base not far from its border with Poland. But Russia has faced fiercer than expected resistance, particularly around Kyiv, and there is evidence the country is running low on weaponry, the Financial Times reported. Itâ€™s unclear how China responded, and U.S. officials only spoke to the outlets on condition of anonymity to preserve Russian intelligence gathering efforts. Liu Pengyu, a spokesperson for the Chinese embassy in Washington D.C., said heâ€™d â€œnever heardâ€ of the Russian request for support. â€œThe current situation in Ukraine is indeed disconcerting,â€ Pengyu said in a statement to The New York Times. â€œThe high priority now is to prevent the tense situation from escalating or even getting out of control.â€ Russia and China are close political allies and Beijing has refused to condemn Putinâ€™s invasion, instead saying it hoped for a negotiated end to the conflict. The Biden administration has increased diplomatic pressure on China in recent weeks, exchanging barbs about the Kremlinâ€™s disinformation campaign. Beijing has said it blames the U.S. and the United Nations for the invasion. Jake Sullivan, the White House national security adviser, is set to travel to Rome on Monday to meet with a senior Chinese official and deliver warnings about any support Beijing may offer to Russia. â€œWe have communicated to Beijing that we will not stand by and allow any country to compensate Russia for its losses from the economic sanctions,â€ Sullivan said on CNNâ€™s â€œState of the Unionâ€ on Sunday. â€œWe will not allow that to go forward and allow there to be a lifeline to Russia from these economic sanctions from any country, anywhere in the world.â€ The Times notes that China has traditionally bought its military equipment from Russia, but Beijing has advanced missile and drone programs that could aid Putinâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. The paper, citing independent analysts, also added that there is evidence Russia may be running low on missile supplies. The request comes amid a raft of harsh economic sanctions against Russia and the swift departure of many Western businesses from the country. The ruble collapsed in the days after the invasion began and the Kremlin has taken steps to limit foreign currency withdrawals and threatened to seize the assets of companies that leave.

Title: Ukraine Unveils New Stamp Based Off 'Russian Warship, Go F**ck Yourself' Audio
Text: Ukrainian border guardsâ€™ defiant stand against a Russian warship became a rallying cry throughout the war-torn country, and now itâ€™s set to be an official postage stamp. â€œRussian warship, go fuck yourself!â€ shouted a Ukrainian border guard alongside a dozen other soldiers stationed on Snake Island in the Black Sea at the start of Russiaâ€™s invasion last month. Audio of the incident quickly went viral and became a symbol of Ukrainian resistance against the Russians. Though the border guards were first thought to have been killed, they are now reported to have been captured and are alive. Ukrposhta, the countryâ€™s postal service, announced a new stamp commemorating the event on Saturday. The stamp, created by artist Boris Groh, shows a Ukrainian border guard on an island facing a warship in the distance. He holds a rifle in one hand. His other hand gives the warship a confident middle finger. â€œWith this stamp, you can send letters and postcards even abroad,â€ Ukrposhta wrote in a Facebook update. â€œAnd most importantly, they will have a sewn-in message that you already know well: â€˜Russian warship, go fuck yourself!â€™â€ Groh was among 20 artists whose stamp design made it to a final voting round. Grohâ€™s stamp won 1,700 out of the total 8,000 votes, according to Business Insider. Russia has entered its third week of invading its sovereign neighbor, but continues to meet fierce resistance from Ukrainian forces. Several reports have described Russian forces targeting civilians in cities across Ukraine.

Title: Russia Accuses Ukraine, U.S. Of Biological Weapon Operations In Heated U.N. Face-Off
Text: In a heated U.N. Security Council meeting Friday, Russia accused the United States of supervising and funding Ukrainian biological weapon operations, a statement that was angrily denied by the Ukrainian and American ambassadors. Some observers fear the accusations are a bid by Russia to justify rolling out its own biological warfare against the Ukrainians. U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said last month that Russia would â€œfabricate allegations about chemical or biological weapons to justify its own violent attacks against the Ukrainian people.â€ Russia presented no evidence for its claims, and United Nations officials say there is nothing to support allegations of the existence of biological weapon operations in Ukraine. China, however, has amplified the unsupported claims. But Russiaâ€™s U.N. representative, Vasily Nebenzya, insisted Friday that at least 30 Ukrainian labs were discovered near the Russian border that are working on weaponizing diseases, including anthrax, cholera and â€œthe plague.â€ The research, which he claimed threatens Europe, involves research using diseases carried by birds, lice and fleas, The Washington Post reported. The U.S. ambassador to the U.N., Linda Thomas-Greenfield, vehemently denied all such claims. She accused Russia of calling for the Security Council meeting â€œfor the sole purpose of lying and spreading disinformation.â€ Russia is â€œattempting to use the Security Council to legitimize disinformation and deceive people to justify President [Vladimir] Putinâ€™s war ... against Ukraine and the Ukrainian people,â€ she said. â€œUkraine does not have a biological weapons program, and there are no Ukrainian biological weapons laboratories supported by the United States â€” not near Russiaâ€™s borders, not anywhere,â€ Thomas-Greenfield added. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said in a Facebook post that itâ€™s Russia, not Ukraine, which is capable of planning such an atrocity. â€œNo chemical or any other weapons of mass destruction were developed on my land,â€ he said. â€œThe whole world knows that.â€ Russia accuses â€œthat we are allegedly developing biological weapons, allegedly we are preparing a chemical attack. This makes me really worried,â€ he added, noting that he has two children. Ukraine does have a network of biological labs supported by the U.S. But theyâ€™re part of a biological threat reduction program intended to mitigate deadly outbreaks, whether natural or manufactured. Early efforts date to the 1990s to dismantle the former Soviet Unionâ€™s program for weapons of mass destruction, The Associated Press reported.

Title: Russia Trots Out New Melitopol 'Mayor' In Ukraine After Elected One Vanished
Text: A newly installed â€œmayorâ€ of the Ukrainian southern port city of Melitopol seized by Russia has introduced herself in a disturbing televised local statement after Russian troops reportedly kidnapped the actual mayor. Elected Melitopol Mayor Ivan Fedorov was seen on video Friday with a hood over his head, being led away from a government building by armed men. The Russian-backed Luhansk regional prosecutor claimed that Fedorov had committed terrorism offenses and was under investigation. Newly installed unelected mayor Galina Danilchenko said in her televised statement that her â€œmain task is to take all necessary steps to get the city back to normal,â€ CNN reported. â€œI ask you to keep your wits about you and not to give in to these provocations,â€ she added. Danilchenko also ironically suggested organizing a â€œPeopleâ€™s Choice Committeeâ€ to â€œsolve all the critical issues for ... the Melitopol region.â€ Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy on Friday lashed the kidnapping of Melitopolâ€™s legitimate mayor, comparing it to the actions of â€œISIS terrorists.â€ He called it a â€œcrime against democracy.â€ The mayor of #Melitopol Ivan Fedorov was kidnapped, said Anton GerashchenkoAccording to him, Fyodorov refused to cooperate with the Russian military occupying the city. He was detained at the city crisis center, where he was in charge of the city's life support.  Russia has â€œtransitioned into a new stage of terror, in which they try to physically liquidate representatives of Ukraineâ€™s lawful local authorities,â€ Zelenskyy said in a video address. He called it â€œsimple terrorism.â€ Federovâ€™s disappearance sparked a protest Saturday by some 2,000 city residents outside its city hall occupied by Russian forces, The Washington Post reported. â€œBring back the mayor! Bring back the mayor!â€ they chanted. â€œFreedom to the mayor!â€ In Melitopol, defiant residents gathered near occupied district administration demanding that Russians release the kidnapped Melitopol mayor Ivan Fedorov - video by Odessa reg governor Maksym Marchenko

Title: Meta Grants Exemption To Hate Speech Rules, Allowing Calls For Violence Against Putin
Text: Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, will temporarily allow users in some countries to post hateful comments against Russian attackers in Ukraine, Russian President Vladimir Putin, and Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko, according to leaked emails first reported by Reuters on Thursday. The tech giant will allow posts containing death threats against Putin and Lukashenko unless they reference other individuals or are deemed to be credible threats of actual violence with specifics like place and time. Lukashenko, a Putin ally, has allowed Russian troops to use Belarus to stage attacks on Ukraine. â€œIn light of the ongoing invasion of Ukraine, we made a temporary exception for those affected by war, to express sentiments toward invading armed forces such as â€˜death to the Russian invaders,â€™â€ Meta spokesperson Drew Pusateri told HuffPost in an email Friday. The declaration is a reversal of Metaâ€™s standing hate speech rules, under which the company typically removes posts that encourage violence. â€œThese are temporary measures designed to preserve voice and expression for people who are facing invasion,â€ Pusateri said. â€œAs always, we are prohibiting calls for violence against Russians outside of the narrow context of the current invasion.â€ The policy change applies to users in 12 countries, including Ukraine, Russia, and Poland, according to an email seen by Reuters. The Russian Embassy in the U.S. accused Meta of sowing division between countries. â€œWe demand that ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ authorities stop the extremist activities of @Meta, take measures to bring the perpetrators to justice,â€ the embassy tweeted Thursday. â€œUsers of #Facebook & #Instagram did not give the owners of these platforms the right to determine the criteria of truth and pit nations against each other.â€ â˜ï¸We demand that ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ authorities stop the extremist activities of @Meta, take measures to bring the perpetrators to justice. Users of #Facebook & #Instagram did not give the owners of these platforms the right to determine the criteria of truth and pit nations against each other.  Facebook and Twitter removed posts by the Russian Embassy in the U.K. on Thursday that questioned reports of Russiaâ€™s attack on a maternity hospital in Mariupol that killed three people, according to Reuters. Meanwhile, the Kremlin continues to crack down on news outlets and social media in Russia, shutting off Facebook and restricting access to Twitter and legitimate news websites like the BBC, according to The Financial Times. The U.N. says more than 2.5 million people have fled Ukraine since Russiaâ€™s invasion.

Title: Stephen Colbert Taunts Putin By Bringing Up Russia's Most Humbling Moment Yet
Text: Stephen Colbert mocked Russian President Vladimir Putin as Russian forces continue to struggle in Ukraine, where they control just 10 percent of the country despite two weeks of relentless assaults. â€œHey Putin,â€ the â€œLate Showâ€ host called out. â€œHow do you like them turnips?â€ Colbert said Ukraineâ€™s military had shot down 48 Russian planes and 80 helicopters, taken out hundreds of tanks and sunk two naval vessels. â€œAnd get this,â€ he said. â€œThe Ukrainians didnâ€™t sink just any ship, because the Russian warship that was told to go fuck itself at Snake Island has been destroyed.â€ Colbertâ€™s audience cheered. â€œIt may not have been exactly what the Ukrainians wanted,â€ he said. â€œbut it did go down on itself.â€ See more in his Thursday night monologue:

Title: Trump Ignores Sean Hannity's Prompt To Call Putin 'Evil'
Text: Fox Newsâ€™ Sean Hannity gave Donald Trump multiple opportunities to condemn Russian President Vladimir Putin on Thursday, and the former president repeatedly declined to do so. Trump has faced widespread backlash for calling Putinâ€™s tactics a work of â€œgeniusâ€ last month as the authoritarian leader prepared to invade Ukraine. His rhetoric met resistance from some high-ranking Republicans, including House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, who said on Wednesday that Putin was not a genius but an evil dictator. Hannity gave Trump an opportunity on Thursday to walk his comments back, two weeks after Putin launched a brutal war that has killed hundreds of civilians. â€œYou came under some fire when you said that Vladimir Putin is very smart,â€ Hannity said during an interview with Trump. â€œI think I know you a little bit better than most people in the media, and I think you also recognize heâ€™s evil, do you not?â€ Trump declined to say and instead tried to argue about the semantics of his praise for the dictator. â€œWell, I was referring to the fact that he said this is an independent nation, talking about Ukraine, and I said that ... this was before there was any attack. Heâ€™s calling it an independent nation,â€ Trump said, adding that â€œthis doesnâ€™t seem to be the same Putin that I was dealing with.â€ â€œBut I will tell you, he wouldnâ€™t have changed if I were dealing with him. He wouldnâ€™t have changed,â€ he added. Trump declines to call Putin "evil" when Hannity prompts him to  Trump then criticized President Joe Bidenâ€™s nuclear posture during the crisis in Eastern Europe and described how he would have handled it if he were in charge. Biden has declined to match Putinâ€™s heightened nuclear alert status, avoiding an escalation of warnings between the two superpowers. â€œLook, Biden, every time he gets up he says they are a nuclear nation. He should say we are a nuclear nation,â€ Trump said. â€œAnd, you know, I rebuilt our whole nuclear arsenal, stronger, bigger, better than ever before,â€ he added. â€œHe should say, â€˜We are a nuclear nation and we donâ€™t want war ... and we donâ€™t want to wipe out Russia.â€™â€ He condemned the violence as â€œa crime against humanityâ€ and said it â€œhas to endâ€ now, though he also noted that if it comes to an end as things stand, itâ€™s â€œgoing to look like a big lossâ€ for Putin. Hannity later circled back to the backlash against Trump for his praise of Putin, giving him another chance to retract those comments. â€³Youâ€™ve often quoted to me Sun Tzu, â€˜The Art of War.â€™ Keep your friends close and your enemies closer. Is that how you viewed Vladimir?â€ the Fox News host said. â€œDid you view Vladimir Putin and people like President Xi and Kim Jong Un and the Iranian mullahs as enemies that you needed to keep close?â€ Again, Trump offered no condemnation for the authoritarian leader. â€œI got along with these people. I got along with them well. That doesnâ€™t mean they are good people. It doesnâ€™t mean anything other than the fact that I understood them and perhaps they understood me,â€ Trump said. â€œBecause they knew thereâ€™d be a big penalty.â€ LOL -- Hannity is trying so hard to get Trump to denounce authoritarians like Putin and he just refuses to do it  Hannity had already tried to explain away Trumpâ€™s praise for Putin on Ukraine, arguing on Feb. 24 that it was â€œtaken out of context.â€ Donald Trump Jr. also chimed in on the subject this week, suggesting his dadâ€™s cozying up to dictators was a ploy to â€œplay these guys.â€ As president, Trump routinely alienated U.S. allies, including Canada and Germany, while praising autocratic leaders like Putin, North Koreaâ€™s Kim Jong Un, Chinese President Xi Jinping and Turkish President Recep Tayyip ErdoÄŸan.

Title: 2 Ukrainians Calmly Defuse Unexploded Russian Bomb In Heart-Pounding Video
Text: Faced with a live Russian bomb in the northern city of Chernihiv, two Ukrainians used a bottle of water to calmly defuse it. One man poured water over the tip of the unexploded projectile as the other carefully removed its detonator in footage the State Emergency Service of Ukraine shared online Wednesday. The bomb came from a downed Russian fighter jet, according to the Ukrainian government report. CNNâ€™s Anderson Cooper called the clip â€œa moment of remarkable cool under pressure,â€ praising the pair for their â€œutter calm in a storm thatâ€™s only expected to grow.â€ Watch the video here: The video went viral on social media as Ukrainians continued to flee their country amid the military invasion ordered by Russian President Vladimir Putin. Some 2.5 million people have now fled. Ukrainian officials are seeking to create new humanitarian corridors in areas under Russian attack, such as Chernihiv.

Title: Mila Kunis, Who Is Ukrainian, Reveals Why She Used To Say She Was Russian
Text: Mila Kunis has opened up about how recent events in Ukraine have affected her. The â€œBad Momsâ€ star was born in Chernivtsi but moved to the United States with her family in 1991 around the age of 8. Kunis told Maria Shriver in a candid interview uploaded to YouTube Friday that because of this, she â€œvery muchâ€ has â€œalways felt like an American.â€ â€œPeople were like, â€˜Oh, youâ€™re so Eastern European.â€™ I was like, â€˜Iâ€™m so LA! What do you mean?â€™ Like, my whole life I was like, â€˜I am LA through and through,â€™â€ Kunis said. Kunis said that because she identified so strongly as an American that being Ukrainian felt â€œirrelevantâ€ to her for a majority of her life â€” although she still has close friends in Ukraine and visited the country often with her family and her husband, Ashton Kutcher. Nonetheless, she admitted that whenever people would ask her where she was from, sheâ€™d say she was Russian for â€œa multitude of reasons.â€ â€œOne of them being when I came to the States and I would tell people Iâ€™m from Ukraine, the first question Iâ€™d get was, â€˜Where is Ukraine?â€™â€ Kunis said. â€œAnd then Iâ€™d have to explain Ukraine and where it is on the map, and i was like â€˜Ugh, thatâ€™s exhausting.â€™â€ So, she soon figured out a shorthand. â€œBut if I was like, â€˜Iâ€™m from Russia,â€™ people were like, â€˜Oh, we know that country.â€™ So I was like, great, Iâ€™ll just tell people from Russia,â€ Kunis said. But all of that changed for the â€œFour Good Daysâ€ star when Russia invaded Ukraine late last month. â€œThis happens and I canâ€™t express or explain what came over me, but all of a sudden I was like, â€˜Oh my God, I feel like a part of my heart just got ripped out,â€™â€ she said. â€œIt was the weirdest feeling.â€ She now says that she wonâ€™t tell people sheâ€™s from Russia anymore. â€œHell no, Iâ€™m from Ukraine!â€ she told Shriver. She also noted that the way Ukrainians are handling the conflict has given her a renewed sense of â€œpride.â€ She said that she was recently speaking to one of her Ukrainian friends about how his family is handling the conflict. â€œThey refuse to evacuate,â€ Kunis said of her friendâ€™s family. â€œAnd they all go to work everyday. So theyâ€™re in their bomb shelter at night, they wake up in the morning, they take whatever they have to protect themselves in the city, and they go to their office to continue working. It is a different breed of people,â€ Kunis said. Ukrainiansâ€™ resilience in the face of devastating circumstances is an aspect of the conflict that has caught many peopleâ€™s attention. Videos of a pianist playing Louis Armstrongâ€™s â€œWhat A Wonderful Worldâ€ outside of a train station in Lviv and a girl singing â€œLet It Goâ€ in a bunker have gone viral on social media. There are many heroic stories about Ukrainians having to travel hundreds of miles to escape violence. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy declined an offer from the U.S. to evacuate him and has reportedly dodged multiple assassination attempts. â€œThe fight is here; I need ammunition, not a ride,â€ Zelenskyy said in February, soon after the Russian invasion. Kunis told Shriver sheâ€™s now trying to instill Ukrainian pride in her children, daughter Wyatt, 7, and son Dimitri, 5, both of whom she shares with Kutcher, who was raised in Iowa. â€œI turned to my kids and I was like, â€˜You are half Ukrainian, half American!â€™ Like, I literally was like, â€˜Look, you!â€™ And my kids were like, â€˜Yeah mom, I get it.â€™ And I was like, â€˜No! You are Ukrainian and American.â€™ I was like, â€˜You are half Iowa, half Ukraine.â€™ And theyâ€™re like, â€˜OK, I get it.â€™â€

Title: GOP Backing Ukraine Now â€” 2 Years After OK'ing An Extortion Scheme Against It
Text: WASHINGTON â€“ Congressional Republicans today are lining up to support military aid to Ukraine just two years after backing then-President Donald Trumpâ€™s extortion scheme against that country, apparently in acknowledgment that their earlier choices could come back to haunt them in this autumnâ€™s midterms. â€œI have zero problems with this phone call. Thereâ€™s no quid pro quo here,â€ South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham said on Sept. 29, 2019, defending Trumpâ€™s attempt to coerce Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy into smearing Joe Biden, the 2020 Democratic challenger Trump most feared, by withholding military aid to Ukraine. â€œThis type of diplomacy is hard to watch but nonetheless has existed and hardly rises to an impeachable offense,â€ said South Dakota Sen. Mike Rounds on Nov. 7, 2019. In recent days, those same Republicans and many others have come around to urge Trumpâ€™s successor, Democrat Joe Biden, to provide more military assistance to Ukraine in the face of Russian dictator Vladimir Putinâ€™s invasion. â€œVladimir Putin is a cold, calculating killer. We must continue to support the people of Ukraine as they defend their country,â€ Rounds wrote on Twitter on Feb. 25. â€œI have never seen a leader rise to the occasion more than President @ZelenskyyUa has done,â€ Graham added a day later. â€œYou can see by the mad scramble to support Zelenskyy and Ukraine that they are afraid of the consequences of their past miscreance,â€ said Norm Ornstein, a scholar at the right-leaning American Enterprise Institute. Back in 2019, Trump, his personal lawyer and allies in his administration pushed for Zelenskyy, a former comedian and political novice, to announce an investigation into Biden and to search for evidence that Ukraine had worked to elect Democrat Hillary Clinton in 2016, proof of which supposedly existed on a computer hidden somewhere in that country. That false story, according to U.S. officials, was concocted by Russian intelligence in an attempt to deflect attention from their own successful work to put Trump into the White House in that election, Trump, nevertheless, demanded Ukraine act on the Russian conspiracy theory and held up $391 million in congressionally approved military aid to Ukraine. In a now-infamous phone call with Zelenskyy, Trump asked him for â€œa favor,â€ which led to a whistleblower complaint that sparked Trumpâ€™s first impeachment. Among 197 Republicans in the House and 53 in the Senate, only one â€” Utah Sen. Mitt Romney â€” voted that Trump had abused his power and should be removed from office because of it. Some argued that while Trumpâ€™s call with Zelenskyy might have been improper, it did not rise to the level of an impeachable offense. Others, like Maineâ€™s Susan Collins, said that the House impeachment vote by itself would be enough to chasten Trump and dissuade him from such behavior in the future. â€œThe president has been impeached. Thatâ€™s a pretty big lesson,â€ she said. Trump, though, was not at all chastened. In fact, the morning after the Senate voted not to remove him from office, he held a raucous celebration in the White House itself. â€œIt was evil, it was corrupt, it was dirty cops, it was leakers and liars,â€ he said as dozens of GOP lawmakers whooped and cheered in the East Room. Two years later, Trump is out of office, having lost his reelection and failed in his attempt to overthrow the republic to remain in power. Five thousand miles to the east, Zelenskyy has become a global hero for his leadership against Putinâ€™s aggression. â€œItâ€™s dangerous to judge anything in the moment, but Trumpâ€™s fawning comments about Putin, disdain for NATO and strong-arming of Zelenskyy may be a heavy burden for Republicans moving forward,â€ said David Axelrod, the Democratic consultant behind former President Barack Obamaâ€™s 2008 victory. â€œYou can see by the mad scramble to support Zelenskyy and Ukraine that they are afraid of the consequences of their past miscreance.â€ Itâ€™s unclear exactly how much Republicansâ€™ support for Trump â€” and indirectly, for Putin â€” in late 2019 and early 2020 will matter in November 2022 as the GOP tries to take control of both chambers of Congress. Neil Newhouse, a prominent Republican pollster, estimates the potential effect at â€œnada.â€ â€œThere is very little chance that legislatorsâ€™ votes against Trumpâ€™s impeachment regarding Ukraine will impact a single vote in the â€™22 election,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s ancient history to most voters and of little relevance to the current conflict.â€ â€œVoters vote on the issues that are affecting their lives today, and never on what happened in the previous administration,â€ added Rick Tyler, a GOP consultant who worked on Texas Sen. Ted Cruzâ€™s 2016 presidential campaign. Amanda Carpenter, a former Cruz aide in his Senate office, said tying candidates to Trumpâ€™s pro-Putin, anti-Ukraine scheme could work but would require considerable effort from Democrats. â€œAre Democrats going to make that a top campaign issue? I donâ€™t see them making the impeachment vote a priority,â€ she said. â€œThis is a moment where we need unity on supporting Ukraine and things are too volatile now to predict how it will play in 2022.â€ She added that some Republicansâ€™ vocal criticism of Ukraine and Zelenskyy today, such as recent remarks by North Carolina congressman Madison Cawthorn, could prove damaging in specific instances. â€œStuff like this on an individual level, that is so clearly out of step with mainstream opinion, could be an issue in certain races,â€ she said. AEIâ€™s Ornstein agreed. â€œMy guess is that the issue will be muddied enough, and the tribal impulse strong enough that it wonâ€™t matter for House members. The Senate could be a little different. It might be that this is an issue that could have an impact at the margins on Ron Johnson, for example,â€ he said of the Wisconsin Republican seeking reelection. South Dakota Sen. John Thune, for one, hopes Congress and the country can unite on helping Ukraine now and not try to â€œrelitigateâ€ things like Trumpâ€™s Ukraine impeachment. â€œWe canâ€™t live in the past,â€ said Thune, the No. 2 Republican in the chamber. â€œThe past is the past. I think we are where we are.â€ Igor Bobic contributed reporting.

Title: A Ukrainian Man Learned Of His Family's Deaths From Viral Photos On Twitter
Text: A Ukrainian man was waiting anxiously to hear from his family members, who were evacuating their town near Kyiv, when he saw their bodies in a photo on Twitter, he told The New York Times in an interview. Images circulated around the world show four people lying bloodied and motionless on the pavement in Irpin, Ukraine, after they were fired on by Russian troops. Three of them were Serhiy Perebyinisâ€™ loved ones: his wife, Tatiana, his 18-year-old son, Mykyta, and 9-year-old daughter, Alisa. The fourth was Anatoly Berezhnyi, a 26-year-old church volunteer who was helping the family, according to the Times. â€œI recognized the luggage and that is how I knew,â€ Perebyinis told the newspaper. Times photographer Lynsey Addario captured a widely viewed image of the four civilians that appeared on the paperâ€™s front page. Perebyinis, a computer programmer, was not with his family because he was caring for his mother in Donetsk in eastern Ukraine, he told The Washington Post. He said his two dogs had also died. â€œI lost everyone and lost the meaning of life,â€ he told the Post, calling what happened to his family a â€œwar crime.â€ Tatiana Perebyinis was the chief accountant for a software company headquartered in London, SE Ranking. The company said Monday it was devastated to learn of her death. â€œThere are no words to describe our grief or to mend our pain,â€ the company said, adding that it was crucial to them that the family did not become â€œstatistics.â€ â€œHer family became the victim of the unprovoked fire on civilians, which under any law is a crime against humanity,â€ the statement read. On Sunday, as residents of Irpin were trying to flee the area, Russian forces fired mortar shells on the city, including a bridge being used by evacuees, killing at least eight people, including Perebyinisâ€™ family. Video from the moment of the strike shows a Ukrainian soldier standing outside a building before a sudden blast. As the debris and dust clear, soldiers can be seen running to a number of bodies on the ground. Someone is heard screaming for a medic, and a dog can be heard barking and howling. Ukraine has accused Russia of indiscriminately shelling heavily populated areas and violating agreements on humanitarian corridors to evacuate civilians. On Wednesday, at least three people, including a child, were killed after a Russian airstrike on a hospital in the city of Mariupol, the city council said. At least 549 civilians have been reported killed in the Russian invasion, though the real figure is likely higher, according to the United Nations. Perebyinis told the Times he felt it was important that his family membersâ€™ deaths were recorded on camera. â€œThe whole world should know what is happening here,â€ he said. Read his story in The New York Times.

Russia is increasingly â€œcut offâ€ from the rest of the world as sanctions bite and companies suspend operations following Putinâ€™s invasion of neighboring Ukraine, noted McFaul. â€œOver time that feeling like, â€˜Weâ€™re a pariah stateâ€™ will begin to haunt him,â€ McFaul continued. â€œAnd I think thereâ€™ll be growing opposition both within the elite and within society.â€ In particular, McFaul said he was keeping a close eye on defections from people within Putinâ€™s inner circle. If they start leaving â€œthat then opens the door for other elites to say, â€˜OK, maybe itâ€™s time for us to quit this war,â€™â€ he added. Title: Trump Responds To Question About Ukraine Crisis By Ranting About Windmills
Text: Former President Donald Trump somehow turned a question about the Ukraine crisis into an opportunity to bemoan windmills during an appearance on the â€œFull Sendâ€ podcast hosted by YouTubers. â€œWhat do you see happening next, then? Cause it seems like the tensions are high. How does this all end? Is this going to be a long-term thing? How do you see it unfolding?â€ Nelk Boys founder Kyle Forgeard asked the former president during a sit-down discussion about Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. â€œWell, and I said this a long time ago, if this happens, we are playing right into their hands. Green energy. The windmills donâ€™t work. Theyâ€™re too expensive. They kill all the birds. They ruin your landscapes,â€ Trump answered. â€œAnd yet the environmentalists love the windmills. And Iâ€™ve been preaching this for years. The windmills â€• and I had them way down â€• but the windmills are the most expensive energy you can have. And they donâ€™t work.â€ Trump has a long-documented hatred of wind turbines, ever since a protracted and failed legal fight to stop Scottish officials from building what he called a â€œreally ugly wind farmâ€ in view of his Aberdeen golf resort. He routinely spouts bizarre lies about windmills, including the widely-mocked claim that the noise they make causes cancer. OMG Iâ€™m dying!!! On a UFC podcast today, Trump is asked how he sees the war in Ukraine playing out and he launches into a riff about windmills!  He continued to discuss windmills for some time before telling an anecdote about giving a â€œwhite flagâ€ as a gift to former German Chancellor Angela Merkel over discussions about Nord Stream 2, a controversial natural gas pipeline between Russia and Germany. Both the U.S. and U.K. are banning oil imports from Russia to punish the Kremlin for its war on Ukraine, causing a spike in already-high gas prices for Americans. It seems Trump was citing a theory in right-wing circles that the crisis in Ukraine was a ploy to push alternative energy, as rising gas prices could force the adaption of cleaner energy such as wind turbines. Last month, for example, Fox Newsâ€™ Tucker Carlson suggested that the Biden administration was provoking conflict with Russia to make a play against fossil fuels and push for renewable energy. The â€œFull Sendâ€ podcast is produced by Nelk Boys, a group of popular Canadian and American YouTube creators known for their pranks and frat-style parties.
