Title: Fox News Reporter In Ukraine Rebuts Colleague Greg Gutfeld's Ugly Take On War Coverage
Text: A Fox News correspondent in Kyiv took issue Tuesday with suggestions made on air by colleague Greg Gutfeld that the media have been pushing a lopsided narrative on Ukraine to evoke an â€œemotional responseâ€ for profit. â€œSpeaking as someone on the ground, I want to say that this is not the media trying to drum up some emotional response,â€ reporter Benjamin Hall said, evidently having heard Gutfeldâ€™s comments on â€œThe Fiveâ€ shortly before he dialed in. â€œThis is absolutely whatâ€™s happening. From the cities of Kharkiv to Mariupol to Chernigov, they are being absolutely flattened. And from all corners of this country, people are fleeing for safety.â€ â€œIn the city of Mariupol, people are drinking water from puddles because the Russian forces havenâ€™t allowed them to get out. When they have tried to get out, they are shelled.â€ â€œAnd donâ€™t take it from my word, take it from the words of some of those who are trying to flee,â€ he added, cutting to footage of tearful civilians trying to escape. After Greg Gutfeld said the media is airing emotionally manipulating viewers on Ukraine to push a narrative, Fox News correspondent Benjamin Hall pushes back:"Speaking as someone on the ground, I want to say that this is not the media trying to drum up some emotional response."  During a discussion about Russiaâ€™s targeting of Ukrainian civilians, Gutfeld questioned the news coverage of the conflict, suggesting it was being manipulated to try to create a reaction. â€œI can feel the galvanizing force of these stories that kind of have sped up and are accumulating to create a narrative,â€ the Fox News host said. â€œAnd they only go in one direction. And I understand why they only go in one direction, because itâ€™s the invaded who experience the atrocity, right? And thatâ€™s all weâ€™re going to see.â€ â€œHowever, I canâ€™t help but feel that this is a lot like other stories that weâ€™ve gone through in the Digital Age in which an image is taken and then played over and over and over again to create some kind of emotional response out of you, because that makes a profit for news companies, right?â€ he added. Here are Greg Gutfeld's comments that preceded Benjamin Hall's rebuke live from Ukraine:"This is a lot like other stories...in which an image is taken and then played over and over and over again to create some kind of emotional response out of you, because that makes a profit"  He then drew a link between coverage of Ukraine and media reporting on police brutality in 2020, which he implied was overblown and led to â€œa year of riots.â€ â€œJust because the news is pushing these videos at you doesnâ€™t mean you gotta do something,â€ he said. He later responded to his colleagueâ€™s comments from the war zone, calling it a â€œcheap attack.â€ â€œShould I address Benjamin Hallâ€™s cheap attack on me or be a good co-worker and let it slide?â€ he asked his colleague Dana Perino. â€œI will be the better man here,â€ he continued. â€œAs I said before, when this started, we want the quickest end possible. My concern has always been, when a narrative creates a story that bolsters one side, that is out of its element, will you create more suffering?â€ More than 2 million refugees have fled Ukraine since Russia invaded it two weeks ago, according to the United Nations. Hundreds of civilians have been killed in bombings as Russian ground and air forces push in on Ukrainian towns and cities. Ukrainian citizens and leaders have begged the world for military and humanitarian aid as the crisis unfolds.

I think he was afraid of him. I think the man intimidated him,â€ Grisham said on Tuesdayâ€™s broadcast of â€œThe View.â€ â€œI also think he admired him greatly. I think he wanted to be able to kill whoever spoke out against him,â€ she continued, adding Trump â€œloved the dictatorsâ€ and â€œthe people who could kill anyone, including the press.â€ Grisham, now working to prevent Trump from taking office again in 2024, also suggested how her former boss would have responded had America been invaded as Ukraine has been by Russia. â€œDonald Trump would be 57 feet below ground hiding,â€ she said, praising Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy for being â€œout there fighting for his country, and I just think thatâ€™s great.â€ And were he still president, Trump would have had a â€œcompletely hands-off approachâ€ to Putinâ€™s military aggression, she said. Title: Why McDonald's Closing All Restaurants In Russia Is 'Hugely Symbolic'
Text: McDonaldâ€™s, an icon of post-Soviet Russia, has said it will temporarily close all its 847 restaurants in the country in a move commentators described as â€œhugely symbolic.â€ The fast-food chain, the latest Western company to shutter operations in the country after its troops invaded Ukraine, said it would go on paying salaries to its 62,000 employees in Russia. In an open letter to employees, McDonaldâ€™s president and CEO Chris Kempckinski said: â€œOur values mean we cannot ignore the needless human suffering unfolding in Ukraine.â€ Because of its large size and global reach, the chain is often copied by other companies if it takes a stance on an issue or makes a major operational change. The Big Mac became available in Russia on Jan. 31, 1990, when the opening of the first McDonaldâ€™s in the final months of the Soviet Union drew international attention. That day over 30,000 people queued around the block for a first taste of U.S. fast food, representing the thawing of Cold War tensions and an increasing appetite among young people for a slice of Americana. The BBCâ€™s Moscow correspondent, Steve Rosenberg, was among many to comment on the significance of the decision. He wrote on Twitter: â€œIn 1990 I was in the queue when McDonaldâ€™s opened its 1st restaurant in Moscow: when iron curtains were crumbling & Russia was embracing the West. Today McDonaldâ€™s announced it is temporarily closing its 850 restaurants in Russia. Hugely symbolic.â€ In 1990 I was in the queue when McDonald's opened its 1st restaurant in Moscow: when iron curtains were crumbling & Russia was embracing the West. Today McDonald's announced it is temporarily closing its 850 restaurants in Russia. Hugely symbolic. McDonalds shutters in Russia...Oh, the deliciousness of the milkshake, my first taste of America at the Moscow McDonald's in the early 1990s. While mom waited at the US embassy to submit our refugee papers, grandma & I stood in the snaking McD line MAJOR: McDonald's says it will temporarily close restaurants and pause operations in RussiaThis is huge deal, given the historic resonance of McDonaldâ€™s arrival in Russia.  Some cited the â€œMcDonaldâ€™s peace theoryâ€ â€“ the idea first expounded by New York Times columnist Thomas Friedman that no two countries with a McDonaldâ€™s will ever go to war. McDonaldâ€™s leaving Russia. End of an era. I guess McDonaldâ€™s peace theory holds again Pressure has been mounting on McDonaldâ€™s and other Western companies that had remained in Russia to pull out. Following the McDonaldâ€™s announcement, other iconic U.S. brands â€“ Coca-Cola and Pepsi â€“ said they would pause operations in the country. PepsiCo, the soft-drink and snack maker, will suspend all advertising in Russia and stop the sale of its drinks brands, and rival Coca-Cola said it will suspend its business there. Coffee chain Starbucks also said Tuesday it is suspending all business activity in Russia, including shipment of its products and cafes run by a licensee. Earlier, Shell stopped buying oil from Russia and said it would cut links to the country entirely while the United States stepped up its campaign to punish Moscow by banning Russian oil and energy imports. Britain too said it would ban imports of Russian oil but only by gradually phasing them out during 2022 to give businesses time to find alternative sources of supply. Consumer goods conglomerate Unilever is among the corporations to cease operations. On Tuesday, it said it has suspended all imports and exports of its products into and out of Russia, and that it will not invest any further capital into the country.

Title: Zelenskyy Speaks Out After Leaked UN Email Instructs Staff Not To Say 'War'
Text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addressed a leaked U.N. email instructing staff not to characterize Russiaâ€™s attack on Ukraine as a â€œwarâ€ or â€œinvasion,â€ but instead as a â€œconflictâ€ or â€œmilitary offensive.â€ â€œI know this outraged many, and not only in Ukraine,â€ Zelensky said on a video posted on Telegram on Tuesday, according to CNN. The U.N. email, with the subject line â€œUkraine crisis communication guidelines,â€ was intended for internal use by staff. It also reminded workers to be careful about personal use of social media. â€œWe, as international civil servants, have a responsibility to be impartial,â€ the email read. Zelenskyy said his representatives contacted the U.N. following the disclosure, first reported in the Irish Times on Tuesday. â€œWe made everything clear and quickly received assurances: there will be no lies in the U.N. structures,â€ Zelenskyy said. â€œThere will be no playing along with the aggressor. The word â€˜warâ€™ will be heard on this site. Because that is the truth. We will not allow anyone in the world to ignore the suffering and murder of our people, our children.â€ Earlier, Ukrainian Minister of Foreign Affairs Dmytro Kuleba accused the U.N. of censorship. â€œItâ€™s hard to believe that the UN could essentially impose the same kind of censorship as the Kremlin imposes inside Russia now by banning the use of words â€˜warâ€™ and â€˜invasionâ€™ among UN staff,â€ Kuleba tweeted on Tuesday. â€œI urge the UN to swiftly refute such reports if they are false. UN reputation at stake.â€ Itâ€™s hard to believe that the UN could essentially impose the same kind of censorship as the Kremlin imposes inside Russia now by banning the use of words â€˜warâ€™ and â€˜invasionâ€™ among UN staff. I urge the UN to swiftly refute such reports if they are false. UN reputation at stake. In a since-deleted tweet posted on Tuesday, the official U.N. spokesperson account said the staff email was â€œfake.â€ A subsequent tweet omitted that assertion. It is simply not the case that staff have been instructed not to use words like â€œwarâ€ and â€œinvasionâ€ to describe the situation. In fact, on Monday, the head of political affairs @DicarloRosemary tweeted this: StÃ©phane Dujarric, spokesperson for the U.N. secretary-general, did not deny the email was sent to staff, but told the Irish Times â€œit can not be considered official policy.â€ Dujarric on Tuesday told reporters at the U.N. daily press briefing that there were no banned words for staff on the subject of Ukraine. â€œI just wanted to correct the mistaken impression that U.N. staff were told to avoid using certain words to describe the situation in Ukraine,â€ Dujarric said. â€œItâ€™s simply not the case that there was some sort of global instructions to all U.N. staff not to use words like â€˜warâ€™ or â€˜invasionâ€™ to describe the situation.â€ From today's noon briefing: the @UN does not have a list of banned words when it comes to describing the war in Ukraine.  Two million Ukrainians have fled their country since the Russian invasion began, according to the U.N.

Title: Russia's War Has Given Biden A Chance To Ditch Trump's Failed Venezuela Policy
Text: Amid climbing gas prices that are likely to increase in the coming days, the Biden administration pushed to reengage one of the United Statesâ€™ staunchest geopolitical foes this week: the Venezuelan government of President NicolÃ¡s Maduro, an authoritarian leader the United States has targeted with increasing rounds of sanctions for the last half-decade. The White House confirmed on Monday that Biden had sent a group of U.S. officials to Caracas for renewed talks last weekend. White House press secretary Jen Psaki told reporters that the â€œongoingâ€ discussions included dialogue about â€œenergy securityâ€ â€” a suggestion that the U.S. had discussed potentially easing the de facto embargo it placed on Venezuelaâ€™s oil industry in 2019. The attempt to reengage Maduro is the latest sign that the U.S. is reassessing its foreign policy in response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine to mitigate the effects of isolating Russian President Vladimir Putin â€” including potential fuel shortages that have pushed domestic gas prices to record highs. U.S. overtures to Venezuela sparked bipartisan criticism, particularly from hawkish foreign policy voices that have egged on an aggressive approach to Maduro. Sens. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) and Bob Menendez (D-N.J.) criticized the White House on Monday for placating a human rights abuser who has overseen disputed elections and dismantled Venezuelan democracy in exchange for domestic political relief that may not materialize. But many others have welcomed the potential shift, and not just because Venezuelan oil may help reduce gas prices that reached $4.17 per gallon across the United States on Tuesday even before Biden announced a new ban on Russian oil imports. The United Statesâ€™ approach to Venezuela, which has spent the last five years mired in economic, political and migration crises, has been disastrous: It has failed to mitigate the humanitarian damage of those crises, and perhaps even helped make it worse. Now, Russiaâ€™s military aggression in Ukraine may have provided just enough space for a much-needed reset to finally begin. â€œThe puzzle weâ€™ve all had for the past several months is: Why doesnâ€™t the Biden administration do something to change course from the Trump policy?â€ said David Smilde, a University of Tulane professor and Venezuela expert at the Washington Office on Latin America. â€œIt took the conflict in Ukraine to provide the straw that broke the camelâ€™s back, to get Biden to change things around a bit.â€ The U.S. and Venezuela have sparred for two decades, ever since socialist President Hugo ChÃ¡vez won his first election in 1999. Maduro, who assumed the presidency upon ChÃ¡vezâ€™s 2013 death, has been a thorn in the side of Bidenâ€™s two immediate predecessors. In 2015, President Barack Obama sanctioned seven Venezuelan government officials amid concerns that Maduroâ€™s government had engaged in widespread corruption, as well as crackdowns on political opponents. President Donald Trump followed with new sanctions in both 2017 and 2018, when Maduro emerged victorious from elections that his opponents, the United States and many international organizations alleged were rife with fraud. In 2019, the U.S. (along with dozens of other countries) recognized Venezuelan opposition leader Juan GuaidÃ³ as the countryâ€™s legitimate leader and launched a â€œmaximum pressureâ€ campaign meant to dislodge Maduro from power. Trumpâ€™s approach to Venezuela, while popular in some quarters, was quickly exposed as nakedly political and broadly impractical. He empowered hard-line appointees whose saber-rattling toward Maduro included repeated refusals to take implausible military actions off the table. This was primarily meant to shore up support among Venezuelan voters in South Florida, the fastest-growing Latino population in the swing state, and among large populations of Cuban American voters who see Maduro as an extension of Cubaâ€™s Communist government. From that standpoint, Trumpâ€™s approach was successful: It helped him gain massive ground among Latino voters in the Miami area and easily win Florida in the 2020 election. But by nearly every other measure, the maximum pressure campaign toward Venezuela has been an abject, and sometimes tragicomic, failure. The U.S. pressure campaign further brutalized Venezuelaâ€™s economy, which had already experienced hyperinflation and severe energy, food and medicine shortages. But it largely failed to hit Maduro and top government officials. Meanwhile, the Trump administrationâ€™s weaponization of humanitarian assistance for political purposes, along with its decision to undermine negotiations between Maduro and the Venezuelan opposition, cratered any hope of real progress and did almost nothing to alleviate a humanitarian crisis that had driven millions of Venezuelans into extreme poverty or out of the country. â€œThe maximum pressure campaign toward Venezuela has been an abject, and sometimes tragicomic, failure.â€ By the time Trump left office, GuaidÃ³ was largely impotent at home and losing support abroad, and his opposition movement deeply splintered. Maduro, by contrast, was by most accounts stronger and more stable than he was when the campaign kicked off, free to continue to crack down on political opponents, dissenters and human rights. Ties between Caracas and Moscow had also deepened: As the U.S. ramped up pressure on Caracas, Russia expanded its oil holdings in Venezuela and helped Maduro and his government evade American sanctions. The policy was, in sum, the exact catastrophe many experts had warned it would become. â€œSanctions without a more comprehensive strategy are an absolute waste of time,â€ said Brian Fonseca, a foreign affairs professor at Florida International University and former analyst at the United States Southern Command. â€œSanctions are an instrument meant to encourage discussion, but thereâ€™s got to be discussion.â€ Still, Biden maintained the broad tenets of the maximum pressure strategy upon taking office in 2021. He continued to recognize GuaidÃ³ as Venezuelaâ€™s legitimate leader and left the aggressive sanctions regime in place. Despite growing calls for change from foreign policy officials, members of Congress and some members of the Venezuelan opposition, a strategic shift seemed unlikely to materialize before the 2022 elections, especially as Democrats fretted about further erosion of support among South Florida voters. But then, the Russian invasion of Ukraine shifted American priorities both domestically and internationally. Abroad, Bidenâ€™s efforts to thwart Putin have taken foreign policy precedence over hard-line tactics toward countries like Venezuela. At home, political concerns over modest engagement with Maduro have taken a backseat to a much bigger worry: that rising gas prices, which Biden desperately attempted to characterize as â€œRussiaâ€™s faultâ€ on Tuesday, might crater Democrats in upcoming midterm elections that already seem likely to generate sizable Democratic losses. Engagement with Maduro still makes for a touchy political subject in Florida, but Latino voters there may be open to a course change as well. A majority of Venezuelan American voters in Florida said that foreign policy is somewhat or very important to their voting decisions in a recent poll conducted by the Latino Public Opinion Forum at Florida International University. Roughly 45% said they disapprove of Bidenâ€™s continuation of Trumpâ€™s maximum pressure approach to Maduro, compared to just 37% who support it, and nearly two-thirds said the sanctions had either fallen short of their expectations or â€œfailed completelyâ€ to meet their expectations of change in Venezuela. Roughly 60% of Venezuelan American voters â€” and an even larger share of Cuban American voters â€” said they could support an easing of oil sanctions if Maduro didnâ€™t manage new oil revenues and they were directed toward the countryâ€™s humanitarian crisis, the poll found. â€œThe findings suggested that the diaspora would be open to lifting things like oil sanctions,â€ Fonseca said. â€œWhen you look at priorities, they donâ€™t think the sanctions are having an effect, and they see the humanitarian crisis as more important than beating the [Maduro] government.â€ That atmosphere has provided a natural backdrop for a shift in relations. Venezuela likely canâ€™t produce enough oil to fully offset Russian imports. But, like much of the oil the U.S. buys from Russia, Venezuelan oil is of the heavy crude variety, making it a natural replacement at U.S. refineries along the Gulf and East coasts that were specifically built to turn heavy crude into gasoline. It will likely take months for Venezuela to ramp up its oil production to previous capacities if sanctions are eased, but even an immediate injection could help dampen price spikes in the U.S. over the coming months. From a foreign policy standpoint, engaging Maduro now could have multiple benefits as the U.S. and Europe seek new ways to counter Putinâ€™s aggression. U.S. sanctions on Venezuela increased U.S. dependence on Russia: American imports of Russian oil have doubled since the U.S. placed sanctions on Venezuelan oil in 2019. Easing the sanctions on Venezuela now could both weaken Russiaâ€™s oil industry and its overall ties with its strongest ally in the Americas. That could limit Russiaâ€™s power in the Western Hemisphere, a region the U.S. still paternalistically views as its own backyard. But it may also make it easier for Biden to place new and alternative sanctions on Putin and Rosneft â€” Russiaâ€™s largest oil company, a subsidiary of which the U.S. has already sanctioned in Venezuela â€” if he chooses to, Fonseca said, providing the U.S. with another potential way to combat Putinâ€™s advances in Europe. Eased sanctions could also lead to renewed diplomatic negotiations with Maduro and advances toward a resolution to Venezuelaâ€™s democratic, economic and humanitarian crises. The U.S. and Venezuela appear to have made little progress during the initial round of discussions. But on Monday, Maduro signaled his openness to more talks with the U.S. â€” and pledged to restart negotiations with the Venezuelan opposition. Previous rounds of talks stalled in October when Maduro abruptly backed out. â€œEasing the sanctions on Venezuela now could both weaken Russiaâ€™s oil industry and its overall ties with its strongest ally in the Americas.â€ The path forward is difficult and full of caveats. The U.S. and the Venezuelan opposition still want a pledge for new rounds of â€œfree and fair elections,â€ while Maduro wants the U.S. to lift sanctions completely. Maduro, Smilde said, has used past negotiations as a stall tactic to maintain or consolidate his domestic power, and the Venezuelan opposition has already expressed concerns that heâ€™s preparing to do so again. But some progress does seem possible: On Tuesday night, Venezuela released two of the six former Citgo executives it had detained in October after the U.S. secured the extradition of a key Maduro ally in Colombia. Five of the six detainees, who had been serving house arrest sentences, are American citizens; the other is a U.S. permanent resident. The release of two prisoners may not yet mark a return to the pre-October status quo, but itâ€™s at least a suggestion that further talks could achieve more if the U.S. presses Maduro for substantive democratic and human rights reforms. As part of the ongoing talks, the U.S. â€œneeds to require a commitment that actual progress is made,â€ Smilde said. â€œThey need to get some actual commitments from Maduro, and work on actual democratic issues.â€ â€œThereâ€™s a lot of space for improvement this year in terms of electoral institutions and electoral democracy, so itâ€™d be great if they focus on that and not just on U.S. citizens that are prisoners in Venezuela,â€ Smilde added. â€œThe ironing out or forging of some actual commitments on human rights is something that could make this go in the right direction.â€ The alternative is continuing a strategy that has paid little dividend. On Monday, Sen. Rick Scott (R-Fla.) opined that the only thing Biden should negotiate with Maduro is â€œthe time of his resignation,â€ the sort of empty rhetoric U.S. officials have aimed south for three years with no real plan to back it up. â€œThe bottom line,â€ Fonseca said, â€œis that our policy has done little to move the needle. And so this may be an opportunity for us to rethink and recalibrate our policy towards Venezuela.â€

Title: In Trumpâ€™s Putin Rehab Tour, One Sticking Point: A Big Jump In Russian Oil On His Watch
Text: WASHINGTON â€” As former President Donald Trump works to rehabilitate his image on Ukraine by hammering his successor on Russian oil imports, he is hamstrung by his own record on the issue: an increase of 39% of petroleum products from that country over his four years. â€œWe should not be buying Russian energy,â€ Trump said recently at the Conservative Political Action Conference in Florida, part of an extended effort to rewrite his Vladimir Putin-friendly presidency into something more attuned to the current sentiment about the Russian dictator. â€œNo president was ever as tough on Russia as I was.â€ Trump, though, has not explained why Russian oil imports increased from 142.0 million barrels in 2017, his first year in office, to 197.7 million barrels in 2020 â€” an increase of 39%. In contrast, Russian oil went from 205.5 million barrels in 2009, predecessor Barack Obamaâ€™s first year, to 161.3 million barrels in 2016, his eighth and final year in office â€” a decrease of 22%. Trumpâ€™s staff did not respond to HuffPost queries about the matter. In reality, the imports of crude oil and other petroleum products from Russia into the United States have never accounted for more than a small percentage of this countryâ€™s demand. Moreover, purchase decisions are made by individual traders and refinery operators seeking the cheapest source at any given moment, not by the federal government. The decrease in Russian oil during Obamaâ€™s administration coincided with an increase of cheaper U.S. oil thanks to a boom in fracking in shale deposits, according to oil industry analysts. This continued two years into Trumpâ€™s years before Russian imports started increasing again as OPEC producers sought to build markets in India and other developing nations, making Russian oil somewhat less expensive in comparison. Still, the comments by Trump and other Republicans suggest that the U.S. should have actively cut off Russia from the American market some time ago. That did not happen until this week, when President Joe Biden signed an executive order banning such imports on Monday. Trumpâ€™s recent criticism of Russiaâ€™s invasion marks a radical departure from his decades of praise for the country and its longtime ruler. In a 2007 letter to Putin, Trump told him he was â€œa big fanâ€ of his. Five years later â€” after Putin had already invaded Chechnya and Georgia â€• Trump posted on Twitter: â€œDo you think Putin will be going to The Miss Universe Pageant in November in Moscow â€• if so, will be become my new best friend?â€ For many years â€” including during his run for president in 2015 and 2016 â€” Trump sought a deal to build a condo tower in Moscow. Also in 2016, when asked why he supported a â€œkillerâ€ like Putin, Trump responded that the United States had also killed people. That same year, he openly asked for Russian help in the November election, and then used that help on a daily basis during the campaignâ€™s final month. Once in office, Trump continued to praise Putin, as well as other authoritarian rulers around the globe, saying he was proud to get along with them. According to his onetime national security adviser John Bolton, Trump tried continually to end sanctions on Russia and prominent Russians, but met resistance from Bolton and others in his administration. â€œPutin saw Trump doing a lot of his work for him,â€ Bolton told Julie Masonâ€™s XM radio show Wednesday morning. â€œHe thought maybe in a second term, Trump would make good on his desire to get out of NATO and that would ease Putinâ€™s path just a bit more.â€ Fiona Hill, a Russia expert on the National Security Council during Trumpâ€™s years, said while it was true that the U.S. government imposed new sanctions and took other steps against Russia during his term, it was done in spite of Trump, not because of him. â€œThe tough steps were taken by his administration, true, and he didnâ€™t block,â€ she said. â€œBut thatâ€™s about it.â€ In 2019, Trump tried to persuade the other large, industrialized democracies in the G-7 to readmit Russia, which had been expelled because of its invasion and annexation of Ukraineâ€™s Crimean peninsula. He defended that annexation because Russia had subsequently built a base there for its â€œlarge and powerful submarines.â€ Also that year, Trump tried to extort Ukraineâ€™s new president into announcing an investigation into Joe Biden, then the Democrat he feared most as a 2020 challenger. He held $391 million in congressionally approved military aid hostage â€” thereby helping Putinâ€™s continued efforts to weaken Ukraine. That president, Volodomyr Zelenskyy, is now hailed around the world for his leadership as his country fights Putinâ€™s current invasion. Trumpâ€™s praise for Putin continued even as the Russian dictator began that second invasion of Ukraine last month. â€œI said, this is genius. Putin declares a big portion of the Ukraine â€” of Ukraine â€” Putin declares it as independent,â€ he told radio hosts Clay Travis and Buck Sexton. â€œOh, thatâ€™s wonderful. So Putin is now saying itâ€™s independent â€” a large section of Ukraine. I said, how smart is that? And heâ€™s going to go in and be a peacekeeper. Thatâ€™s the strongest peace force. We could use that on our southern border.â€ Days later, at CPAC, Trump still did not criticize Putin by name, but had stopped praising the invasion. â€œThis is an assault on humanity. So sad,â€ he said instead. After Trumpâ€™s Ukraine extortion scheme became public thanks to a whistleblower, he was eventually impeached for it in early 2020, but was allowed to remain in office by Senate Republicans. He was impeached a second time in his final days in office for trying to overthrow the republic by inciting a riot to block the certification of his election loss.

Title: Rep. Kevin McCarthy Rejects Trump Comments: Nothing 'Savvy Or Genius' About Putin
Text: House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) on Wednesday rejected former President Donald Trumpâ€™s characterization of Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s ongoing invasion of Ukraine as â€œsavvy.â€ â€œI do not think anythingâ€™s savvy or genius about Putin,â€ McCarthy told reporters at his weekly news conference when asked about Trumpâ€™s remarks. â€œI think Putin is evil. Heâ€™s a dictator. And I think heâ€™s murdering people right now.â€ During an interview on a right-wing talk radio program last month, Trump lauded Putinâ€™s strategy for invading the country. â€œI said, â€˜This is genius,â€™â€ Trump said as he recalled watching the news after Putin declared two sections of Ukraine to be independent and ordered troops to storm the regions for alleged â€œpeacekeepingâ€ purposes. â€œSo, Putin is now saying, â€˜Itâ€™s independent, a large section of Ukraine.â€™ I said, â€˜How smart is that?â€™ And heâ€™s going to go in and be a peacekeeper. Thatâ€™s the strongest peace force,â€ Trump said. â€œWe could use that on our southern border,â€ he added. â€œThatâ€™s the strongest peace force Iâ€™ve ever seen. There were more army tanks than Iâ€™ve ever seen. Theyâ€™re going to keep peace all right. No, but think of it. Hereâ€™s a guy whoâ€™s very savvy.â€ CNN's @mkraju asks House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy about Trump's lavish praise of Putin:"I do not think anything's savvy or genius about Putin," McCarthy says in a rare break from Trump.  McCarthy also said he agreed with former Vice President Mike Penceâ€™s comment last week that there is no room in the Republican Party for â€œapologists for Putin.â€ Trump has since described the invasion of Ukraine as â€œa Holocaustâ€ and â€œa horrible thing thatâ€™s happening,â€ urging Russia to stop killing Ukrainians. However, he has not walked back his praise of Putin. Trump has also repeatedly claimed that conflict would not have happened if he was still president. Some of his allies on the far-right have behaved similarly. When Russian aggression against Ukraine had not yet escalated into a full-scale invasion, Fox News host Tucker Carlson defended Putin, parroting Kremlin talking points in an infamous rant on Feb. 22 with such efficacy that Russian TV later aired segments of his broadcast. He has since shifted his tone, admitted he was mistaken, and has instead sought to blame President Joe Biden for the war.

Title: Ukrainian Athlete Pulls Out Of Paralympics Race After Her Father Is Captured By Russians
Text: A Ukrainian biathlete has forfeited a chance to compete in an event at the 2022 Paralympic Winter Games after receiving tragic news from home. Anastasiia Laletina, 19, pulled out of her biathlon middle-distance sitting race on Tuesday morning after she learned that her father â€” a soldier in the Ukrainian army â€” was taken prisoner by Russian invaders, the Agence France-Presse reported. â€œThey beat him,â€ team spokesperson Nataliia Harach told the news agency. â€œShe was very upset and couldnâ€™t take part in the race.â€ Harach said Laletina was resting and receiving support from the teamâ€™s doctor. She also said that a Ukrainian team coachâ€™s home in Kharkiv was recently bombed. The Ukraine Federation of Sports for Persons with Locomotor Disabilities did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The Ukrainian team is doing exceptionally well at the winter games in Beijing, despite the emotional toll of the harrowing circumstances in their country. It has racked up six gold medals so far, and is second to China, which leads the pack with eight, according to The Guardian. Russia was banned from the games after the nation invaded Ukraine on Feb. 24, shortly after the Winter Olympics wrapped up in Beijing. Russian para-athletes were sent home from Beijing on Friday â€” the day of the opening ceremony for the Paralympic Games â€” while the Ukrainian team had to escape war zones to participate, per The Associated Press. â€œItâ€™s a miracle that we have made it to the Paralympics,â€ Ukrainian delegation head Valerii Sushkevych told the AP. The Ukrainian athletes are under intense stress due to the invasion of their home country, Sushkevych told The New York Times. He said their eyes are red and puffy and that they cling to their phones, hoping for updates, and only set them down moments before an event starts. Sushkevych said the Paralympics are very popular in Ukraine, and that the competition is typically somewhat of a holiday in the country. â€œ[But] today, no,â€ he told the Times, partially through an interpreter. â€œI ask the athletes in the morning, â€˜Did you sleep?â€™ I ask another, â€˜Did you sleep?â€™ They say, â€˜No, no.â€™ They have dull, sad faces. The mood is very difficult. We are all thinking of home.â€ Still, the Ukrainian athletes have decided that competing in the international event is of utmost importance to them. â€œWe, the Paralympic team, have our battles in Beijing,â€ Sushkevych told the Times. â€œIf we did not come here, it would be like losing position, like capitulation.â€ Paralympic athlete Oksana Shyshkova, who won Ukraineâ€™s fourth gold medal in a cross-country ski event Monday, echoed this sentiment to the Times. â€œWeâ€™re here to represent our country â€¦ to glorify our country, to tell the world that Ukraine exists,â€ she said.

Title: More Than 200 Major Companies Have Pulled Out Of Russia So Far
Text: More than 200 major companies have withdrawn from Russia so far in response to the countryâ€™s unprovoked war on Ukraine, further hobbling an economy already devastated by Western sanctions. A rapidly changing list of the companies compiled by Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, a professor at the Yale School of Management, shows representation across a broad range of industries, from Apple to Exxon, McDonaldâ€™s to Maersk. McDonaldâ€™s decision Tuesday to â€œtemporarilyâ€ close its restaurants and pause operations in Russia is particularly symbolic. The burger chain was among the first Western brands to begin operating in the former Soviet Union in 1990 under Mikhail Gorbachevâ€™s policy of perestroika. At the end of last year, McDonaldâ€™s operated around 850 restaurants in the country, 84% of which were operated directly by the company as opposed to franchisees. The company employs 62,000 people in Russia and serves millions of customers there each day. McDonaldâ€™s said Tuesday it would continue to pay the salaries of its Russian and Ukrainian employees. Sonnenfeldâ€™s list is more than just a tally of companies wary of Moscow, however: It also inventories the companies doing business in Russia that have so far chosen to remain. Among them are big names like Coca-Cola, Kraft Heinz, and Pepsi, all of which are facing increasingly loud calls to take action. While a humanitarian argument can be made for consumer brands like these choosing to remain in operation, Sonnenfeld isnâ€™t convinced. In an article comparing the current economic sanctions to those imposed on South Africa in the 1980s in an effort to dismantle apartheid, Sonnenfeld argued economic pain is kind of the point. â€œReaganâ€™s argument [in 1986] was that sanctions would in fact hurt South African Black people and not solve the problems of Apartheid, while we lose positive influence,â€ he wrote. â€œThose are the same counterarguments echoed today about not hurting Russiaâ€™s population. The purpose of sanctions, however, is to impose pain without the violence of war.â€ â€œVladimir Putin, the most vicious autocrat of this century, rules through tyranny and fear. As he continues to fail, people will lose their fear and he will lose his power,â€ he added.

Title: Saudi Arabia, UAE Leaders Reportedly Decline Calls With Biden Amid Ukraine Crisis
Text: The de facto leaders of Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates declined to arrange calls with President Joe Biden in recent weeks as the U.S. worked to contain a spike in oil prices driven by Russiaâ€™s war on Ukraine, The Wall Street Journal reported Tuesday. Citing U.S. and Middle Eastern officials, the Journal reported that Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and the UAEâ€™s Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed al Nahyan both declined requests to speak to Biden amid dissatisfaction in both countries over U.S. policy in the region. â€œThere was some expectation of a phone call, but it didnâ€™t happen,â€ a U.S. official told the Journal, referring to the planned discussion between the Saudi crown prince and Biden. â€œIt was part of turning on the spigotâ€ of Saudi oil. Biden did, however, speak with the crown princeâ€™s father, King Salman, on Feb. 9, the Journal reported. Officials said relations had grown strained between the U.S. and the two Persian Gulf nations over the Biden administrationâ€™s lack of support for the war in Yemen and its revived negotiations on the Iran nuclear deal. Saudi officials reportedly also seek legal immunity for the Saudi crown prince, who faces multiple lawsuits in the U.S., including over the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi in 2018. The White House has looked to Iran, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela for talks about increasing oil production to offset the effect of the Ukraine crisis on energy markets. Biden on Tuesday announced a ban on Russian oil imports, a major escalation of sanctions that will cause further price hikes for American consumers. Saudi and Emirati officials had earlier this month rejected calls to pump more oil, saying they would stick to a production agreement approved by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC+), an alliance that includes Russia. The Saudi crown prince and the UAEâ€™s Sheikh Mohammed both participated in calls with Russian President Vladimir Putin last week.

Title: Tucker Carlson Somehow Blames U.S. For Russia's War
Text: As he continues to search for a scapegoat in his bungled commentary on the situation between Russia and Ukraine, Fox News host Tucker Carlson is now blaming the U.S. for the war Russian President Vladimir Putin unleashed on his neighbor. â€œKamala Harris encouraged Ukraine to become a member of NATO. Quote, â€˜I appreciate and admire President Zelenskyyâ€™s desire to join NATO,â€™â€ Carlson began, selectively quoting one sentence from the vice presidentâ€™s lengthy remarks at a news conference in Munich, Germany, on Feb. 20. â€œMessage: Up yours, Vladimir Putin, go ahead and invade Ukraine,â€ Carlson continued. â€œAnd, of course, Vladimir Putin did that just days later. So the invasion was no surprise to the Biden administration. They knew that would happen. That was the point of the exercise. â€œWe watched all this happen, we missed it. How? Honestly because it was insane and therefore very hard to take seriously. Why in the world would the United States intentionally seek war with Russia? How could we possibly benefit from that war? We still donâ€™t know the answer to that question.â€ As Russian aggression escalated in February, Biden warned repeatedly and publicly that a Russian invasion of Ukraine was likely imminent and said the U.S. would respond â€œswiftly and decisivelyâ€ to any attack. Itâ€™s not clear how Carlson â€œmissed it.â€ At the time of those warnings, he was still defending Putin and parroting Kremlin talking points. Take a minute to listen. @TuckerCarlson is actually accusing America of starting this war. Not Putin. Not Russia. But America. Itâ€™s our fault. Heâ€™s blaming America for launching this war. Tucker channels todayâ€™s GOP. And todayâ€™s GOP is the new â€œblame Americaâ€ party. The absurd take comes after frantic backtracking on Carlsonâ€™s part in the wake of Russiaâ€™s brutal invasion of Ukraine. Title: Republicans Pushed For Russian Oil Ban, But Are Already Blaming Biden For High Gas Prices
Text: WASHINGTON â€• With Republicans joining Democrats in urging President Joe Biden to ban oil imports from Russia following its invasion of Ukraine, his announcement Tuesday to do just that means Biden can at least expect Republicans to stop attacking him about high gas prices â€• right? He probably shouldnâ€™t hold his breath. Even before Bidenâ€™s announcement from the White House that he was banning all Russian petroleum products from the United States, the GOPâ€™s de facto leader, former President Donald Trump, had put out a statement in all capitals: â€œBREAKING NEWS: HIGHEST GAS PRICES IN HISTORY! DO YOU MISS ME YET?â€ And no sooner had the White House released the language of the executive order than did Ronna McDaniel, who chairs the Republican National Committee, put the blame for higher prices directly on Biden. â€œFamilies know Bidenâ€™s agenda is to blame for the pain at the pump, and no series of lies will change the reality of his failures,â€ McDaniel said in a statement, which expressed no support for Bidenâ€™s action and contained no references to Ukraine or Russiaâ€™s dictator, President Vladimir Putin. â€œThey arenâ€™t holding on to any principles here. Theyâ€™re looking for cudgels,â€ said Amanda Carpenter, a former aide to Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas who broke from the Republican Party because of its support for Trump. She added that Biden should make clear to Americans that Republicans supported his move, and that he should also embrace â€œan all-options above approachâ€ to domestic energy. â€œIf people really want someone to blame, itâ€™s Putin,â€ she said. â€œThat, also, shouldnâ€™t be hard for Biden to explain.â€ In his remarks from the Roosevelt Room of the White House, Biden tried to do exactly that, as he made clear he is aware of the political costs of higher gas prices. â€œPutinâ€™s war is already hurting American families at the gas pump,â€ he said, calling the increases â€œPutinâ€™s price hike.â€ Even before Russiaâ€™s buildup of troops along its border with Ukraine last year, Republicans had already been blaming Biden for the increase in fuel costs, which was a predicted result of the economic rebound from the COVID-19 pandemic. Those increases, which took place over the span of a year, pale in contrast to the sharp leap prices have taken since the start of Russiaâ€™s invasion. Nationally, prices had gone up about $1.50 over the 15-month period beginning when the COVID vaccine became available in late 2020, but they have risen another 75 cents in just the past two weeks. Oil companies, meanwhile, have seen record profits, as demand and prices have increased with the recovering economy. Theyâ€™ve plowed nearly $40 billion into stock buybacks that enrich existing shareholders but do nothing to invest in new energy production. Biden alluded to that in his remarks as well. â€œTo the oil and gas companies and to the finance firms that back them, we understand Putinâ€™s war against the people of Ukraine is causing prices to rise. We get that. Thatâ€™s self-evident,â€ he said. â€œBut itâ€™s no excuse to exercise excessive price increases, or padding profits or any kind of effort to exploit the situation ... Russiaâ€™s aggression is costing us all, and itâ€™s no time for profiteering or price gouging.â€ Biden also countered GOP claims that domestic production has ground to a halt during his presidency, pointing out that the United States is on track to produce more oil and gas next year than ever before â€• even as he argued that the smarter option for the country and the world is to move away from fossil fuels and toward renewables. â€œIt will mean that no one has to worry about price at the gas pump in the future. Thatâ€™ll mean tyrants like Putin wonâ€™t be able to use fossil fuels as weapons against other nations,â€ Biden said. â€œAnd it will make America a world leader in manufacturing and exporting clean energy technologies of the future to countries all around the world. This is the goal we should be racing toward.â€ On Capitol Hill, one Senate Republican acknowledged that his party bears some responsibility now for gas prices, given Republicansâ€™ advocacy for the Russian oil ban. â€œI think that we own some of that,â€ said North Dakotaâ€™s Kevin Cramer. â€œItâ€™s hard for us to escape some of it because weâ€™ve been advocating for this, taking the lead on it. But at the same time, weâ€™ve taken the lead on more policies that can increase domestic production.â€ Cramer, though, appeared to be a rare voice. Far more common among Republicans were views like that of Cruz. On Tuesday afternoon, the Texas senator posted a boast from December by White House chief of staff Ron Klain that gas prices had decreased 25 cents in recent weeks. Cruz added the comment: â€œThis one aged well.â€ Igor Bobic contributed to this report.

Title: Boycott Calls Intensify For Companies Still Open For Business In Russia
Text: Major global companies, including PepsiCo and McDonaldâ€™s, are under growing pressure to quit doing business in Russia as Vladimir Putin continues his countryâ€™s war on Ukraine. Apple halted sales in Russia, Nike and Ikea closed their stores in the country, and Mastercard and Visa suspended their services there. But some large companies, such as PepsiCo, have made no statements condemning the war and have continued business as usual. McDonaldâ€™s had not said whether the food giant would continue business in Russia amid the war â€” until Tuesday afternoon, when the company released a statement saying it will temporarily close all restaurants in Russia and pause all operations in the market. â€œIn Russia, we employ 62,000 people who have poured their hearts and souls into our McDonaldâ€™s brand to serve their communities,â€ the company said. â€œAt the same time, our values mean we cannot ignore the needless human suffering unfolding in Ukraine. â€œYears ago, when confronted with his own difficult decision, [former CEO] Fred Turner explained his approach quite simply: â€˜Do the right thing.â€™ That philosophy is enshrined as one of our five guiding values, and there are countless examples over the years of McDonaldâ€™s Corporation living up to Fredâ€™s simple ideal,â€ the statement continued. â€œToday is also one of those days.â€ In a message shared to employees and franchisees, CEO Chris Kempczinski shared that McDonald's will temporarily close all restaurants and pause all operations in Russia. Click to read the message in its entirety.  McDonaldâ€™s has 847 restaurants in Russia, and says on its website that operations in Ukraine and Russia amount to approximately 9% of worldwide sales and 3% of profit. The company said it will continue paying the salaries of employees in Ukraine and Russia. Russia accounts for over 4% of PepsiCoâ€™s sales, according to The New York Times. New York State Comptroller Thomas DiNapoli warned several companies, including McDonaldâ€™s and PepsiCo, on Friday of â€œsignificant and growing legal, compliance, operational, human rights and personnel, and reputational risks,â€ attached with doing business in Russia, according to Reuters. DiNapoli, who oversees the $258.1 billion New York State Common Retirement Fund, wrote in letters to the companies on Friday that reassessing operations in Russia â€œwould address various investment risks associated with the Russian market and play an important role in condemning Russiaâ€™s role in fundamentally undermining the international order that is vital to a strong and healthy global economy.â€ McDonaldâ€™s said its Ronald McDonald House Charities will continue to fully operate in Russia, and that the RMHC in Ukraine is partnering with local hospitals to deploy medical supplies and helping provide humanitarian aid throughout the country. PepsiCo did not immediately respond to HuffPostâ€™s request for comment. Other Western-based brands, including Coca-Cola, Starbucks and Burger King, also have attracted criticism for continuing to operate in Russia. Actor Sean Penn, who recently returned to the U.S. after filming a documentary on the Russian invasion in Ukraine, called on Monday for Americans to boycott those brands. â€œUntil Coca-Cola, PepsiCo & McDonalds suspend business in Russia, American citizens have a very safe & simple way to stand with Ukraine,â€ Penn tweeted. â€œAny among us can suspend our purchases of their products & ask our friends to consider doing the same.â€ Until Coca-Cola, PepsiCo & McDonalds suspend business in Russia, American citizens have a very safe & simple way to stand with Ukraine. Any among us can suspend our purchases of their products & ask our friends to consider doing the same. Ukrainian Minister of Foreign Affairs Dmytro Kuleba over the weekend called out Shell Oil for buying Russian crude oil. â€œOne question to @Shell: doesnâ€™t Russian oil smell Ukrainian blood for you?â€ Kuleba wrote on Twitter Friday. â€œI call on all conscious people around the globe to demand multinational companies to cut all business ties with Russia.â€ I am told that Shell discretely bought some Russian oil yesterday. One question to @Shell: doesnâ€™t Russian oil smell Ukrainian blood for you? I call on all conscious people around the globe to demand multinational companies to cut all business ties with Russia. Shell announced on Tuesday it would stop buying oil and natural gas from Russia, and said it would close its service stations in the country. â€œWe are acutely aware that our decision last week to purchase a cargo of Russian crude oil to be refined into products like petrol and diesel â€” despite being made with security of supplies at the forefront of our thinking â€” was not the right one and we are sorry,â€ CEO Ben van Beurden said, according to The Associated Press. â€œAs we have already said, we will commit profits from the limited, remaining amounts of Russian oil we will process to a dedicated fund.â€ Sanjana Karanth contributed to this report.

Title: Seth Meyers Has A Field Day With Lindsey Grahamâ€™s Trump-Ukraine Claim

Title: 'Please Help Our Nation': Ukrainian Politician Breaks Down In Plea For U.S. Military Aid
Text: The former chair of the Ukrainian parliamentâ€™s foreign affairs committee broke down weeping in an MSNBC interview on Tuesday, as she begged Western governments to provide â€œmaximum military assistanceâ€ to her homeland amid the ongoing Russian invasion. â€œWe have to stop this new tyranny,â€ Hanna Hopko, who chairs Ukraineâ€™s Democracy in Action Conference, told MSNBCâ€™s Katy Tur in a video call from Warsaw, Poland. Hopko asked for embargoes on commodities like gas and oil from Russia. (President Joe Biden said Tuesday that the U.S. is banning imports of Russian oil.) She also called for a no-fly zone over Ukraine, which Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy recently did as well. National security experts have warned that establishing a no-fly zone could result in a war between nuclear-armed powers. Hopko grew emotional as she described the unfolding humanitarian crisis in Ukraine, including hundreds of thousands of people without water in the city of Mariupol, where a 6-year-old girl reportedly died of dehydration in the ruins of a Russian shelling site Tuesday. â€œI think the world must demonstrate leadership,â€ she said. â€œIt is horrible. I understand, itâ€™s horrible,â€ Tur said. She noted that Western powers have so far rejected calls for a no-fly zone to prevent direct conflict with Russia that could escalate into a larger war. â€œThere are a lot of Americans out there who are saying they want a no-fly zone as well,â€ Tur said. â€œBut again, so far what weâ€™re hearing from officials is they donâ€™t want to start another world war.â€ "This is about humanity." @HopkoHanna talks to @KatyTurNBC about the dire situation in Ukraine as pressure mounts for a no-fly zone.  Breaking down in tears, Hopko said: â€œThere is no explanation. Look, this is not just this one kid.â€ â€œWe cannot just watch how many Ukrainians are dying. Iâ€™m asking Biden, Iâ€™m asking Congress: Please help our nation,â€ she said. â€œI donâ€™t understand why we have to convince everybody this is about humanity.â€ More than 2 million refugees have fled Ukraine to escape the Russian invasion, according to the United Nations, which called it the fastest-growing refugee crisis in Europe since World War II. Countries within the NATO alliance, which does not include Ukraine, have sent weapons to Kyiv and levied unprecedented economic sanctions against Russia. However, allies have ruled out actions that would create direct conflict with the country. A no-fly zone would prohibit Russia from using warplanes to attack Ukraine, meaning NATO would be responsible for shooting down planes that violate the declaration. According to intelligence from the U.K., Russia made minimal ground advances over the weekend, but unleashed a high level of air and artillery strikes on military and civilian sites in Ukrainian cities. The U.N. has recorded 406 civilian deaths in Ukraine, including eight people who were reportedly killed in a town west of Kyiv after Russia shelled a civilian evacuation route.

Text: A Russian gymnast will be investigated after he displayed a national war symbol on his leotard while standing beside a Ukrainian competitor on the podium in Qatar on Saturday. Title: Ukraine Ambassador Gives Russian Diplomats Some Scathing 'Mental Help' Advice
Text: Ukraineâ€™s ambassador to the United Nations gave Russian diplomats some unsolicited mental health advice in response to their latest wild claim. The Russian embassy in London on Monday tweeted that Russia, which attacked Ukraine, is actually attempting to stop a war in Ukraine. Sergiy Kyslytsya, Ukraineâ€™s U.N. ambassador, held up the tweet, read the message and fired back. â€œLet me remind the Russian diplomats that in London, in case of need for mental help, you can dial NHS line 111,â€ he wrote, referring to the emergency number for the National Health Service in the U.K. â€œThank you.â€ Ukrainian Ambassador holds up a tweet from Lavrov and advises Russian diplomats that they can obtain assistance for mental help from the NHS by dialing 111  Russia attacked Ukraine and is currently under investigation for alleged war crimes after multiple reported attacks on civilian targets as well as for creating a massive humanitarian crisis in which 1.5 million people have fled the nation so far. Kyslytsya made headlines soon after the invasion began by delivering a blunt warning to Russian leaders during an emergency U.N. Security Council meeting. â€œThere is no purgatory for war criminals,â€ he told Russian Ambassador Vasily Nebenzya. â€œThey go straight to hell, ambassador.â€ On social media, others took issue with the same post from the Russian embassy in London that provoked the response from Kyslytsya: Say what now? "Officer, I had to kill the victim so that noone else could kill him." I'm starting to think Lavrov doesn't have a clue what's going on and is just winging it until Putin gets couped. Title: Russia Recruiting Syrians To Fight In Ukraine Invasion, Defense Official Says
Text: Russia is recruiting Syrians to fight on its behalf in the Kremlinâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, a senior Pentagon official said Monday. â€œIt is not clear to us whether theyâ€™ve set a quota for that and what that would be or how many theyâ€™ve gotten so far,â€ the unnamed official told reporters in a press briefing, according to Axios. â€œBut we can corroborate reports that the Russians are trying to supplement their fighters with foreign fighters.â€ The Wall Street Journal first reported the development on Sunday, saying Russia was recruiting Syrians with expertise in urban combat as the invasion reportedly stretched longer than Putin expected, stymied by a fierce resistance from Ukrainians seeking to defend their country. The defense official told reporters Monday that the Pentagon found it â€œnoteworthyâ€ that Putin â€œbelieves he needs to rely on foreign fighters to supplement what is a very significant commitment of combat power inside Ukraine as it is.â€ NEWS: Defense Official Says Russians Reportedly Recruiting Syrian Mercenaries . The official said the Kremlin had already committed nearly 100% of the 150,000 troops amassed along the Ukrainian border since the invasion began last month. â€œThey continue to be frustrated by a stiff Ukrainian resistance, as well as their own internal challenges,â€ the defense official said Monday. Pentagon spokesperson John Kirby told The New York Times this week that U.S. analysts donâ€™t have any details about the number of Syrians Russia has recruited or whether they may already be in Ukraine. Britainâ€™s Ministry of Defense said Sunday that Russian forces likely made â€œminimal ground advancesâ€ over the weekend and that it was highly unlikely the Kremlin had achieved its military objectives to date. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy rallied his country in an address from his office in Kyiv on Monday night, saying the country would rebuild itself after it repelled the invading forces. â€œThere will be no trace of the enemy,â€ he said. â€œWe will make our cities destroyed by the invader better than any city in Russia.â€

Title: 'Hero' Ukrainian Boy, 11, Makes It To Slovakia Alone After 700-Mile Journey
Text: A boy from Zaporizhzhia, in southeast Ukraine, has been hailed as a hero by Slovakian authorities who said that he had crossed the border into Slovakia from Ukraine by himself on Friday night, a distance of more than 700 miles. â€œWith one plastic bag, passport and phone number written on his hand, he came completely alone because his parents had to stay in Ukraine,â€ the Slovakian Ministry of Interior said in a Facebook post Saturday, according to a translation. The ministry said the boy was looked after by volunteers. â€œHe gained all of them with his smile, fearlessness and determination, worthy of a true hero,â€ it said. And, thanks to the phone number on his hand, authorities were able to contact his relatives in the capital, Bratislava, who came to collect him. His mother, identified by authorities as Yulia Pisetskaya, said in a video posted on Facebook that she had put her son on a train to Slovakia out of desperation. Zaporizhzhia is home to the nuclear plant that was taken over by Russian forces on Saturday. She said she was unable to leave with her son because she couldnâ€™t leave her mother behind, Britainâ€™s Slovak Embassy wrote in its translation of her video. â€œI am a widow and I have more children,â€ Pisetskaya said, according to the embassy. â€œI want to thank the Slovak customs and volunteers who took care of my son and helped him cross the border. I am grateful you have saved my childâ€™s life. Next to my town is a nuclear power plant that the Russians are shooting at. I couldnâ€™t leave my mother â€• she canâ€™t move on her own.â€ Russian troops attacked the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, Europeâ€™s largest, in the early hours of Friday. They later took control of the facility. The United Nations estimates that more than 1.5 million refugees have fled Ukraine since Russia launched its invasion, with hundreds of thousands pouring into neighboring Poland, Romania, Slovakia and elsewhere.

Title: Ukrainian Actor Pasha Lee Reportedly Killed By Russian Shelling
Text: Pasha Lee, a 33-year-old Ukrainian actor, was reportedly killed on Sunday by Russian shelling of northern Ukraine. According to Ukraineâ€™s Odesa International Film Festival and local reports, Lee was killed in Irpin after joining the Territorial Defense Forces of the Armed Forces of Ukraine to defend the country against the Russian invasion. In an Instagram post tagged to Irpin on Saturday, Lee wrote: â€œFor the last 48 hours there is an opportunity to sit down and take a picture of how we are being bombed, and we are smiling because we will manage and everything will be UKRAINE ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ WE ARE WORKING !!!â€ according to a translation. A post shared by ĞŸĞĞ¨Ğ Ğ›Ğ˜ | ĞĞšĞ¢Ğ•Ğ  | TV HOST (@pashaleeofficial) The actor appeared in films including â€œMeeting Of Classmates,â€ â€œThe Fight Rules,â€ â€œSelfie Partyâ€ and â€œZvychayna Sprava,â€ Deadline reported. He was also a host on the DOM channel and did voice work in â€œThe Lion Kingâ€ and â€œThe Hobbit,â€ according to a Facebook post by Sergiy Tomilenko, president of Ukraineâ€™s National Union of Journalists. At least four civilians were killed in Irpin, just west of Kyiv, on Sunday as Russian forces shelled an area being used as an evacuation route. Russian invaders have been pushing in on the town for days, according to The New York Times.

Title: Westerners, Please Stop With The Memes And Hot Takes On The Ukraine Crisis
Text: You may have heard of â€œmain character syndrome,â€ a term popularized on TikTok and Instagram. Itâ€™s what happens when someoneâ€™s desire for individuality mixes with the desire to romanticize their own life, which leads to them feeling (and acting) like life is a movie starring them. In some ways, this little bit of egoism may be harmless â€” but when you blend main character syndrome with social media and privilege, it can be a recipe for clueless, insensitive and downright strange behavior. Responses to the ongoing crisis in Ukraine have demonstrated this. Itâ€™s no surprise that main character syndrome is so intricately linked with social media â€” after all, whatâ€™s the point of acting like your life is a movie if nobody is around to watch it? It becomes problematic, however, when this desire to center yourself in every discourse, dialogue and disaster takes precedence over everything. Even a major European war. As commentator and YouTuber Natalie Wynn put it: â€œI always hated war, hated Twitter. But somehow I wasnâ€™t prepared for how much I would hate war Twitter.â€ The past few weeks, timelines have been littered with takes and discourses so atrocious that I find myself wondering if social media can possibly get worse â€” and then something else goes viral and I remind myself that yes, it actually can. â€œThis person posts a lot, but thereâ€™s always this feeling that thereâ€™s something left unsaid in their posts: namely, the desire for you to pat them on the back and tell them what a good person they are.â€ Take, for example, clairvoyants using their tarots to predict the death toll, people fetishizing Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy as a â€œheartthrobâ€ as he evades assassination attempts, and â€œ90210â€ star AnnaLynn Mccordâ€™s spoken-word poem in which she somehow positions herself as the would-be savior of Ukraine, if she only had the chance to be Vladimir Putinâ€™s mother. Then there are the particularly egregious Marvel comparisons, such as Twitter threads detailing how Avengers characters would react to the conflict; editing Zelenskyy as Captain America and dubbing him â€œCaptain Ukraineâ€; or â€œfan-castingâ€ Jeremy Renner to play the Ukrainian president in an eventual movie about an event that is continuing (and worsening) each day. There are the numerous jokes about being â€œdraftedâ€ coming from people who, unlike the men in Ukraine being pulled out of cars at the border and forcibly conscripted, are tweeting from the middle of the United States. There is the flood of comments on a fake Putin Instagram page calling him â€œVladdy Daddyâ€ and begging him to â€œPlz wait until the next euphoria ep.â€ We also need to talk about the â€œslactivists.â€ Not to be confused with an actual activist, a slacktivist will take pictures of themselves at an anti-war protest like itâ€™s Coachella, then post screenshots of all the money theyâ€™re donating to help Ukrainian citizens. This person posts a lot, but thereâ€™s always this feeling that thereâ€™s something left unsaid in their posts: namely, the desire for you to pat them on the back and tell them what a good person they are. Sometimes, these â€œactivistsâ€ may take to social media to explain just how hard it is for them to do the bare minimum. They may confess that theyâ€™re suffering from â€œallyship fatigue,â€ or say that as an empath, they know exactly how it feels to be a Ukrainian citizen as they tweet from their idyllic bedroom in the suburbs. The only cure for their angst is sharing memes about how theyâ€™re â€œliving through a historical event,â€ even though their lives havenâ€™t changed at all. That isnâ€™t to say that people outside of Ukraine struggling with their mental health are invalid. Itâ€™s not wrong or insensitive to be triggered by these current affairs â€” the problem lies with those people who try to claim that their experiences are equivalent to those of people who are facing injury, death, bereavement and displacement. Thereâ€™s a multitude of reasons why (mostly white) Westerners centering themselves during the Ukraine crisis is problematic. For one, itâ€™s incredibly dismissive of the pain and day-to-day struggle that Ukrainians are experiencing. By treating themselves as the â€œmain characterâ€ of the Ukraine crisis, these people are diminishing its very real importance and far-reaching implications, equating it to being the next big blockbuster starring them. Itâ€™s concerning, too, that these kinds of posts also have the potential to drown out Ukrainian voices that are also trying to be heard on social media. Even if many of these posts are going viral because theyâ€™re being mocked, that is still a high level of engagement that could have been better utilized elsewhere. And letâ€™s not forget: None of these posts actually help Ukrainians in any way. They might make the poster feel better about themselves, or elevate their self-importance as a part of this â€œhistorical event,â€ but these words and gestures are ultimately hollow â€” especially if they arenâ€™t followed up with any meaningful action. Rather than centering ourselves in marginalized groupsâ€™ crises and yelling into our own echo chambers, we can do three simple things: stop, listen and amplify. Stop sharing posts that spread misinformation, diminish the struggles of Ukrainian people and center yourselves. We need to listen to Ukrainian citizens and reliable, unbiased news sources about ways we can help. And finally, most importantly, we need to amplify the voices of those who are directly involved: sharing their words and their stories rather than constructing our own. For Ukrainians, this is their reality. Do you have a compelling personal story youâ€™d like to see published on HuffPost? Find out what weâ€™re looking for here and send us a pitch.

Title: Ukraine Expert Alexander Vindman Humiliates Marjorie Taylor Greene With Brutal Fact Check
Text: Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.) attempted to blame Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine on Joe Biden Monday, only to be brutally humiliated by an acknowledged expert on the situation: Retired Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman. It started when the controversial lawmaker posted a tweet on Sunday claiming â€œBidenâ€™s poor decision making leading up to [Russian President Vladimir] Putin declaring war on Ukraine.â€ 1. Tragically, people are dying because of Bidenâ€™s poor decision making leading up to Putin declaring war on Ukraine.Bidenâ€™s weakness and failure as a leader not only has put America last but is a danger to the entire world. But Vindman, who as a former national security aide offered key testimony in President Donald Trumpâ€™s 2019 impeachment for dealings with Ukraine, refused to let Greeneâ€™s statement go by without a fact check. â€œNope. Vindmanâ€™s wife, Rachel Vindman, also chimed in, calling Greene â€œcrazy stupidâ€ and asking, â€œwhy do you insist on telling us over and over?â€ We all know you are crazy stupid but why do you insist on telling us over and over? Greene attacked Vindman, saying he wants to â€œdrag Americans into war with Russia with his big tough tweets and his zoom interviews on CNN,â€ but didnâ€™t deny the substance of his arguments. Nor did she deny or object to him accusing her and the GOP of being â€œpro-Putin.â€ This clown wants to drag Americans into war with Russia with his big tough tweets and his zoom interviews on CNN.Go ahead and go fight yourself since youâ€™re from Ukraine.You are clueless about Americans being fed up with sending our sons and daughters to die in foreign lands. Vindman later responded with a heartfelt tweet reminding Greene and others that he proudly served in the U.S. Army after he and his family came to the country as refugees. Children, women, and men are being murdered by the Russian military at the order of putin. Civilians are being murdered and you try and blame our president?? You sound America last. Title: John Bolton Says Putin Isn't Unstable -- He's A 'Cold, Hard, Calculating Man'
Text: John Bolton, a former national security adviser to former President Donald Trump, on Monday dismissed suggestions that Russian President Vladimir Putin is mentally unstable, as Russia continues to attack residential areas in Ukraine. â€œI know there are a lot of theories and speculation going around that Putin has a screw loose,â€ Bolton told the BBC. â€œI donâ€™t think so. I think heâ€™s a cold, hard, calculating man.â€ "There are a lot of theories going around that Putin has a screw loose... I don't think so. I think he's a cold, hard, calculating man"Former US Security Adviser John Bolton says Putin will be "quite irritated at the performance of the Russian military"  Bolton said Putin is likely â€œirritatedâ€ at the performance of the Russian military thus far, and that heâ€™ll try to double down to save face. â€œHe has to try to show military victory,â€ Bolton said. â€œI donâ€™t think thereâ€™s a negotiated way to end this.â€ Bolton also criticized NATOâ€™s decision not to get involved militarily but to supply Ukraine with weapons and intelligence. He argued this will do little to deter Russia. â€œIf Putin wanted a pretext to say that NATO was committing aggression against Russia in this conflict, or that NATO was a party to this conflict, heâ€™s already got it,â€ Bolton said. On Friday, Bolton told The Washington Post that Putin expected Trump to withdraw from NATO if heâ€™d won a second term in office. â€œIn a second Trump term, I think he may well have withdrawn from NATO,â€ Bolton said. â€œAnd I think Putin was waiting for that.â€ Trump appointed Bolton as national security adviser in 2018. He was fired less than a year later.

Title: Blinken Says U.S. Has Seen Credible Reports of Russian Attacks On Ukrainian Civilians
Text: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Sunday the U.S. has seen evidence of Russian attacks on civilians in Ukraine, which could amount to a war crime, as Vladimir Putinâ€™s invading troops continue pounding residential areas. â€œWe have seen very credible reports about the use of certain weapons,â€ Blinken told CNNâ€™s â€œState of the Union,â€ speaking from Moldova. â€œAnd what weâ€™re doing right now is documenting all of this, putting it all together, looking at it, and making sure that, as people and the appropriate organizations and institutions investigate whether war crimes have been or are being committed, that we can support whatever theyâ€™re doing.â€ "We've seen very credible reports of deliberate attacks on civiliansâ€¦"Secretary of State Antony Blinken tells CNN's @jaketapper the US is investigating and documenting reports of Russian attacks on Ukrainian civilians that could constitute war crimes. #CNNSOTU  War crimes include deliberate direct attacks on civilians and the use of weapons that have the ability to cause excess deaths, according to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court. NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg referenced the use of cluster bombs in Ukraine on Friday, according to Reuters. â€œWe have seen the use of cluster bombs and we have seen reports of use of other types of weapons which would be in violation of international law,â€ Stoltenberg said. Cluster munitions disperse when fired, causing destruction over a wide area and posing â€œan immediate threat to civilians,â€ according to Human Rights Watch. Ukraine has brought a case against Russia at the International Court of Justice in The Hague, seeking a court order to stop the war. For that reason, Ukraine has dispatched visual teams to areas shelled by Russia, according to The Washington Post. Russian lawyers snubbed Mondayâ€™s first hearing. The court could decide the case this week. As Western leaders continue to resist Ukraineâ€™s call for imposing a no-fly zone over the country, they are providing more military equipment. Blinken told CBSâ€™ â€œFace the Nationâ€ that the U.S. is in â€œvery active discussionsâ€ with Poland to back-fill any fighter jets provided to Ukraine. â€œAll of us together are continuing to take steps to increase the pressure on Russia through additional sanctions, all of which are very actively under discussion and will be implemented in the in the coming days, as well as taking further steps to give the Ukrainians what they need to defend themselves against the Russian aggression,â€ Blinken said. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Sunday that NATO members have the go-ahead to send fighter jets to Ukraine as the U.S. and allies continue their efforts to help Ukraine defend itself against Russia's invasion.  Blinken also said the U.S. may heighten economic sanctions, possibly including banning Russian oil imports. Oil prices climbed further on the suggestion. â€œWe are now in very active discussions with our European partners about banning the import of Russian oil to our countries, while of course at the same time maintaining a steady global supply of oil,â€ Blinken told NBCâ€™s â€œMeet The Press.â€ â€œThe actions weâ€™ve taken to date have already had a devastating impact on the Russian economy.â€ Sec. of State Blinken reiterates this to Chuck Todd on Meet the Press: "We are now in very active discussions with our European partners about banning the import of Russian oil to our countries, while, of course, at the same time maintaining a steady global supply of oil."

Title: Pope Francis Rails Against Ukraine Invasion: 'War Is Madness. Please Stop.'
Text: Pope Francis issued an emotional plea for an end to Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine during his weekly address at St. Peterâ€™s Square on Sunday. â€œThis is not just a military operation, but a war, which sows death, destruction and misery,â€ said Francis. â€œThe number of victims is increasing, as are the people fleeing, especially mothers and children.â€ Since Russia launched its invasion, some 1.5 million people have fled the country, according to the U.N. refugee agency. In that â€œmartyred country, the need for humanitarian assistance is growing by the hour,â€ the pontiff said. The pope pleaded for diplomatic negotiations to end the violence, and called for common sense to prevail. The church also sent two cardinals to Ukraine to help those in need. â€œThis presence of two cardinals there is the presence not only of the pope but of all the Christian people who want to get closer and say â€˜war is madness,â€™â€ Francis said. The popeâ€™s comments were his strongest to date about the war, which he has condemned from the start. The day after Russia launched the invasion, the pope traveled to the Russian embassy to express his concerns.

Title: More Than 4,000 Russians Arrested Sunday Over Ukraine Invasion Protests, Watchdog Says
Text: Russian authorities arrested more than 4,300 protesters on Sunday who were demonstrating against the ongoing invasion of Ukraine, according to an independent watchdog group. OVD-Info, an organization that tracks the arrest of demonstrators, said thousands of Russians turned out on Sunday to oppose the Kremlinâ€™s military action in Ukraine. At least 4,357 people were arrested in 56 cities across the country, and could face years in jail. Russian President Vladimir Putin recently signed a new law that broadly criminalizes the spreading of information that goes against the Kremlinâ€™s account of the incursion. The law effectively prohibits calling the military action in Ukraine a â€œwarâ€ or an â€œinvasion.â€ Those found violating it, including protesters, can face up to 15 years in prison. Russiaâ€™s interior ministry confirmed that it had arrested thousands of people Sunday, including about 1,700 in Moscow and 750 in St. Petersburg. OVD-Info said more than 13,000 people have been arrested in the country since demonstrations began, including journalists and children. â€œThe screws are being fully tightened â€• essentially we are witnessing military censorship,â€ Maria Kuznetsova, a spokesman for OVD-Info, told Reuters. She added that the protests this weekend were â€œrather bigâ€ and had spread to cities in Siberia â€œwhere we only rarely such such numbers of arrests.â€ In some videos posted to social media, protesters could be heard chanting â€œNo to War!â€ in Moscow and St. Petersburg, statements that would appear to violate Putinâ€™s new legislation. OVD-Info also said there were reports of serious violence at police stations, including detainees who were beaten, kicked and dragged by their hair. Over 4,500 people arrested. Lots and lots of police violence. Searches. Threats. Random phone checks on the streets.OVD-Info reports what was happening during Russiaâ€™s anti-war protests on March 6: The law against â€œfake newsâ€ has already prompted some companies to limit access to Russian users. Just this weekend, TikTok announced it would ban all livestreaming and content creation in Russia while it reviews the implications of the law. Russia also upped its censorship efforts by blocking Facebook and restricting Twitter for tens of millions of people.

Title: TikTok Bans New Videos Made In Russia Over Putin's Anti-'Fake News' Law
