The Russian leader also sought to downplay widespread reports that the Ukrainians have put up a much stronger defense than heâ€™d anticipated, claiming that the â€œspecial military operation in Ukraineâ€ is â€œgoing strictly according to the schedule just as it has been planned.â€ The Russian Defense Ministry on Wednesday announced that nearly 500 of its soldiers have been killed and another 1,600 injured, although Western estimates are significantly higher. Ukraine says its fighters have killed more than 5,000 Russian troops. An American official told The New York Times the figure is more like 2,000. Russia reportedly took control of the Ukrainian port city Kherson this week â€• the first major city to be taken over. But according to the Pentagon, and scattered reports, the Russian military is facing a serious morale problem made worse by food shortages. Some Russian troops are sabotaging their own military vehicles and laying down arms, according to the Pentagon, in order to avoid fighting a war that Russian authorities have baselessly described as a mission to liberate oppressed Ukrainians.

Title: Russian TV Station Proclaims 'No To War,' Plays 'Swan Lake' Before Going Dark
Text: One of Russiaâ€™s last independent news outlets took a stance for peace and made a powerful historical allusion in its last moments. TV Rain, described by The New York Times as a â€œyouthful independent television station,â€ announced Thursday that it would stop operating indefinitely under intense pressure from the Kremlin. Russiaâ€™s telecommunications regulator had already blocked TV Rain earlier in the week, and some of the stationâ€™s employees have fled the country out of fear for their own safety, the Times reported. On Thursday, the outlet delivered its final show, which aired on YouTube. â€œNo to war,â€ Natalia Sindeyeva, one of TV Rainâ€™s founders, said as the stationâ€™s employees walked out of the studio. The station then began playing Tchaikovskyâ€™s â€œSwan Lakeâ€ â€• a reference that many well-versed in Russian history recognized. The staff of the Independent Russian TV station 'Dozhd' (TV Rain) resigned during a live stream with last words: â€œno warâ€ and then played Tchaikovsky's Swan Lake echoing the same from Soviet state TV in August of 1991.  As NPR noted in a piece earlier this year about the significance of â€œSwan Lakeâ€ in Russian political history, Soviet state TV aired the ballet on a loop after the death of Premier Leonid Brezhnev while a new party leader was being selected. It did the same following the deaths of Yuri Andropov and Konstantin Chernenko. Then, in 1991, Soviet TV aired the ballet during the attempt to overthrow President Mikhail Gorbachev â€• a failed coup that helped precipitate the collapse of the Soviet Union. Thatâ€™s it. @tvrain is gone. What were the final images the famed TV station chose to broadcast? There was only ever one option, of course.  There are well-founded fears that reporting any news diverging from the official government line in Russia could result in prison time or worse. Just before TV Rain cut to â€œSwan Lakeâ€ on Thursday, a disclaimer flashed on screen stating the show was the work of a foreign agent. That became a requirement for the station back in August, when Russiaâ€™s justice ministry declared TV Rain a foreign agent â€” a designation editor-in-chief Tikhon Dzyadko vehemently denied â€” in the lead-up to a parliamentary election.

Title: Russia Shells Europe's Largest Nuclear Plant In Ukraine, Sparking Fire
Text: Russian troops shelled Europeâ€™s largest nuclear power plant in Ukraine, prompting worries of an international disaster amid the Kremlinâ€™s ongoing invasion of the country. The shelling took place at Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in Enerhodar, a city about 400 miles from Kyiv. The International Atomic Energy Agency said it had spoken with Ukrainian officials, who said there are no changes in radiation levels at the site, which provides about 25% of Ukraineâ€™s power. Ukraineâ€™s foreign affairs minister, Dmytro Kuleba, confirmed the reports on Thursday evening, saying a fire had broken out. He called for an immediate cease-fire to allow emergency officials to stop the blaze and said Russian troops were firing on the facility â€œfrom all sides.â€ â€œIf it blows up, it will be 10 times largerâ€ than the 1986 nuclear disaster at Chernobyl, Kuleba tweeted. â€œRussians must IMMEDIATELY cease the fire, allow firefighters, establish a security zone!â€ Reuters added later that the fire was in a training building outside the plant, although it could not verify its seriousness. The Ukrainian State Emergency Service said early Friday morning the blaze had been extinguished, and there were no deaths or injuries linked to the shelling. Russian army is firing from all sides upon Zaporizhzhia NPP, the largest nuclear power plant in Europe. Fire has already broke out. If it blows up, it will be 10 times larger than Chornobyl! Russians must IMMEDIATELY cease the fire, allow firefighters, establish a security zone! Nuclear experts said the plantâ€™s reactors are a different type than the ones used at Chernobyl and that emergency safety measures should kick in. The shelling should pose little risk if the containment vessels arenâ€™t damaged and outside power can be restored to the site, although they warned that any military action at a nuclear facility was a danger. â€œWe donâ€™t know the status of the system or the power and until we do, we wonâ€™t know the full extent of the risk,â€ tweeted Jon B. Wolfsthal, a former adviser to then-Vice President Joe Biden. â€œYes, a fire at any nuclear plant is a bad thing but there are a few things to know.â€ Andriy Tuz, a spokesperson for the plant, told a Ukrainian television station that one of the siteâ€™s six nuclear reactors was on fire. That reactor is under renovation and not operating, but has nuclear fuel inside, he said. Open pools where spent nuclear fuel rods have been cooling are also a concern, The New York Times noted. Tuz added that firefighters initially werenâ€™t able to get near the plant because they are being shot at, The Associated Press added. Rafael Mariano Gross, the director-general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, also called for an immediate halt in military action near the plant, saying the body would continue to support Ukraine in hopes of maintaining nuclear safety and security. The @iaeaorg Incident and Emergency Centre is in full 24/7 response mode due to the serious situation at #Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in #Ukraine.

Title: Ukrainian Biathlete Yevhen Malyshev Killed In Combat With Russia
Text: A 19-year-old Ukrainian biathlete was killed in the war with Russia this week, sports organizations said Wednesday. Yevhen Malyshev served in the countryâ€™s military, the International Biathlon Union said. He died in combat against the invading Russian military, according to a joint statement from the Athletes of Ukraine and Global Athlete. In a statement expressing its â€œdeepest condolences,â€ the IBUâ€™s executive board condemned the Russian attacks on Ukraine and the support being provided by Belarus. It announced an indefinite ban on all Russian and Belarusian athletes from international competition on the recommendation of the International Olympic Committee. Malyshev was on Ukraineâ€™s biathlon junior team in 2018 but stopped competing in 2020, according to TMZ Sports. Multiple former athletes have been killed in the invasion, including soccer players Vitalii Sapylo and Dmytro Martynenko.

Title: Can Anyone Persuade Vladimir Putin To Choose Peace In Ukraine?
Text: Peace in Ukraine depends on the international community achieving something it has been unable to do for years: changing Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s mind. After centralizing power over two decades at Russiaâ€™s helm, Putin now singlehandedly makes the key decisions about his countryâ€™s national security policy. Ukraine and Western governments are working on three tracks to make him stop his invasion: They are trying to persuade Putin directly, while simultaneously pressuring Russians who might influence him with unprecedented global financial sanctions that Western nations say will continue until the Ukraine offensive ends. And they are stiffening Ukraineâ€™s resistance to the onslaught to show that an easy, cheap military win is not an option for Putin. But one week into the war, Western officials are extremely pessimistic about the chances of the Russian leader choosing to stop fighting and pursue a diplomatic settlement, saying they know little about Putinâ€™s plans and are alarmed by the indications that they do have. â€œRight now, I frankly do not see how anybody can get through to Putin,â€ said Vaira Vike-Freiberga, a former president of Latvia who met with her Russian counterpart repeatedly. â€œHe is so dead set on rewriting history ... he has invented a parallel universe in which he lives mentally.â€ As Russian forces advance toward the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv, â€œthe man is about to commit mass genocide,â€ she continued. â€œWhat is anybody going to tell him that hasnâ€™t been told already by President [Joe] Biden, [British] Prime Minister [Boris] Johnson, [German] Chancellor [Olaf] Scholz? ... This man is beyond being reached by words and certainly way beyond logic.â€ French President Emmanuel Macron is the most prominent Western leader to maintain a dialogue with Putin. In a Thursday call, the Russian leader told his French counterpart that he will continue his assault and may even demand more concessions from the Ukrainians. â€œThere was nothing that Putin said that reassured us,â€ a top French official later told The Economist. Though Ukraine opened talks with Russia on Monday that have had limited results and its president requested direct negotiations with Putin on Thursday, most foreign policy experts believe the key to a cease-fire is an agreement between Moscow and the major players it views as comparable world powers, like the U.S. or the European Union. Biden last spoke with Putin on Feb. 12 and believes it is inappropriate to hold another call while Putinâ€™s invasion is ongoing, White House press secretary Jen Psaki said this week. Speaking to NBC News for a story published on Thursday, a U.S. official said, â€œthere are no signs Putin is willing toâ€ deescalate at this point. Western officials and analysts say they know what a possible deal would have to achieve: Primarily, it would need to address Putinâ€™s desire for a greater Russian say over security conditions in his neighborhood while committing him to principles respected by most countries like the right to national sovereignty. Yet they do not know when to expect him to take the first step towards that settlement â€” and they worry that if such negotiations do come, Putin may simply lay the groundwork for more conflict in the future. Putin watchers are struggling to make sense of the Russian leaderâ€™s current calculus. The intelligence community lacks human sources close to him, per The Washington Post, particularly because some Russians who were able to provide such information in recent years have left the country. Some observers, however, see reason to be nervous about his state of mind. â€œPutin is not doing well. Heâ€™s shouting at staff. His war is behind schedule. This is a dangerous time,â€ a European official told the Post. Fiona Hill, a Putin biographer who worked on Russia issues at the White House, recently told Politico she sees a new level of â€œvisceral emotionâ€ in the Russian presidentâ€™s public remarks, which worries her because he faces few checks and balances within the Kremlin. In handling Putin now, officials must prepare for him to use anything in his arsenal â€” including nuclear weapons â€” and have a plan to respond, Hill said. On Thursday, Russian foreign minister Sergey Lavrov hinted that Russia might unleash chemical weapons and blame the terrifying escalation on the U.S. and Ukraine. Three possible factors could now push Putin toward the negotiating table. The first depends on timing: how fast Western military support, from anti-tank missiles to air defense systems and ammunition, gets to the Ukrainians. Such aid is largely coming by land through Poland into western Ukraine, but it will then have to be transported to front lines further east. â€œIf that help has arrived in time to be of any effectiveness to slow down the encirclement of Kyiv and of Kharkivâ€ â€” the most important Ukrainian cities currently under attack â€” â€œthen, since Putin has been spinning lies from morning to night, he will easily invent himself a reason why he might stop the aggression,â€ Vike-Frieberga said. The U.S. and other Ukrainian partners could also inflict more economic pain on Russia with two tactics that would be especially alarming to Putin: sanctions on Russiaâ€™s crucial energy industry, which NBC reported the Biden administration is now considering, and specifically targeting Putinâ€™s personal wealth. While Western governments are sanctioning deep-pocketed Russians in the hope that they can turn Putin against the war, those figures have limited influence. â€œHe makes it clear that he, the great leader, allows the oligarchs to become filthy rich but they must respect [his] wishes and desires,â€ Vike-Frieberga said. â€œI personally doubt that he would be influenced by their pain. His own personal pain is a different matter.â€ The Biden administration and foreign friends like the French are repeatedly signaling that itâ€™s not too late to choose peace. Putin could â€œdeescalate,â€ Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin told NBC News in an interview aired Wednesday, and on Thursday, a U.S. defense official told NBC that Washington and Moscow had established a channel of communication. Should the Russian leader decide to negotiate, world leaders and diplomats would face the fresh challenge of designing an effective deal. Putin may be satisfied with ending the current crisis with a relatively modest win rather than capturing all of Ukraine like splintering the country into weak quasi-states, according to Hill, the former White House adviser. But some analysts fear that now that he has shattered the long taboo of waging a large-scale war in the heart of Europe, Putin is initiating a long, ambitious and likely bloody campaign to elevate his global status. â€œHe wants to go into history as a major figure for the greatness of Russiaâ€ who can reverse the toll of the collapse of the Soviet Union and the independence of countries such as Latvia, said Vike-Freiberga. After stepping down as the countryâ€™s president, Vike-Freiberga served as the head of a group of retired world leaders called the Club de Madrid. (She remains a member.) â€œWhen I first met him ... he told me what a sad thing it was that there was a border between our countries nowâ€ and people needed visas to travel between them, Vike-Freiberga said. â€œI told him [Latvians] were very happy to have passports where they could go to Paris and London instead of being taken in cattle cars to Siberia.â€ Many international relations analysts say Putinâ€™s agenda is about far more than Ukraine â€” including his often-stated concerns about the country possibly joining the NATO military alliance â€” and he ultimately seeks an era-defining settlement. â€œPutin has said that only a few great powers â€” Russia, China, India and the United States â€” enjoy absolute sovereignty, free to choose which alliances they join or reject,â€ Georgetown University professor Angela Stent wrote in a January essay. â€œHe is determined to reassert Russiaâ€™s right to limit the sovereign choices of its neighbors and its former [Soviet-era] allies and to force the West to accept these limits.â€ Stent advised Western officials to design a new status quo in Europe that Putin would see as worth standing by. Such a deal would be hard to craft. It would need to reassure European nations that Washington is not negotiating away their right to seek support like military equipment or troop deployments from the NATO military alliance â€” shows of solidarity that Europeans have counted on as Russia has intervened militarily and politically in their region. Meanwhile, it would need to address Russiaâ€™s concerns about key neighbors drawing closer to the West and its increasing global isolation. And American and allied negotiators would have to contend with complex and time-honored Russian diplomatic tactics. In a 2021 paper for the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, former Pentagon and State Department official Michael Albertson assessed how to negotiate with Putin by examining the history of U.S.-Russian arms control talks. Calling Putin â€œa dealmaker, but not necessarily a negotiator,â€ he wrote that Russian mediators often present a long list of grievances, distracting from the issue at hand, and he noted â€œa dramatic reductionâ€ in U.S. officialsâ€™ familiarity with their Russian counterparts in recent years. â€œFrom a Russian perspective, the best negotiating approach is to stick to a hard line at one end of the negotiating spectrum, wait for a centrist U.S. proposal, let time and political pressure build on the U.S. side, and wait for the U.S. position to gradually shift closer to the preferred Russian outcome,â€ Albertson wrote. If Putin outmaneuvers his Western counterparts, the ultimate result could be even deadlier wars in the future. Vike-Freiberga believes the limited international response to his past incursions into Ukraine and Georgia drove Putin to launch his current invasion. â€œAppeasement has only whet his appetite,â€ she said.

Title: Fox Newsâ€™ Ukraine War Coverage Confuses The Hell Out Of â€˜Daily Showâ€™ Correspondent
Text: Desi Lydic ended up dazed and confused after faux-binging on Fox Newsâ€™ questionable coverage of Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. Title: Russia Expert Fiona Hill Reveals How It Could All Go South For Vladimir Putin
Text: Russian affairs expert Fiona Hill said there is one group of people in particular that Russian President Vladimir Putin â€œprobably has to worry aboutâ€ more than anyone else if his invasion of Ukraine doesnâ€™t go as planned. Itâ€™s not Russiaâ€™s obscenely rich oligarchs, who face economic sanctions and seizures of their assets worldwide, the former top analyst on the National Security Council told Stephen Colbert on Wednesdayâ€™s broadcast of â€œThe Late Show.â€ Instead, itâ€™s the â€œvery small circleâ€ â€” such as Russiaâ€™s heads of intelligence, military and security services â€” who cooked up the invasion plan with Putin, said Hill. â€œThese are not the kind of guys who have yachts off Monaco, palaces in Paris or anything like this,â€ Hill explained. â€œThese are people who are very much rooted in Russia itself and I donâ€™t think theyâ€™re too worried about all of these sanctions and everything thatâ€™s cut off, because theyâ€™re not invested in the West. Theyâ€™ve really got that bunker siege mentality â€” fortress Russia.â€ Members of this small circle are who Putin â€œprobably does have to worry aboutâ€ if â€œit looks like Russia is losing,â€ said Hill, an intelligence analyst under former President George W. Bush and Barack Obama who later served on the National Security Council under Donald Trump. Hill was an important witness during Trumpâ€™s first impeachment. â€œI donâ€™t think they care about the world of public opinion,â€ Hill added. â€œBut if thereâ€™s not any movement on the ground, if that great convoy of tanks just basically runs out of gas and is just left there, and if they have to kind of lay waste to Ukraine to basically get a success â€¦ you might then start to get a backlash from those people who are thinking this has not gone as they intended.â€ Watch the interview here:

Title: Bipartisan Support Grows For Banning Russian Oil, But It Could Come At A Cost
Text: WASHINGTON â€” House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) joined the bipartisan chorus of lawmakers calling for the Biden administration to stop Russian oil imports. â€œIâ€™m all for it,â€ Pelosi said at a Thursday press conference. â€œBan the oil coming from Russia.â€ The U.S. and most of the world have harshly sanctioned Russia for its war in Ukraine, crushing Russiaâ€™s currency and potentially collapsing its economy, but made an exception for Russian oil so as to avoid harming consumers with higher gas prices. White House press secretary Jen Psaki said the administration is â€œvery openâ€ to the idea of sanctioning Russian oil and gas, though it is concerned how it would impact energy prices at home and abroad. â€œWeâ€™re considering it, itâ€™s very much on the table, but we need to weigh what all of the impacts will be. Weâ€™re not trying to hurt ourselves, weâ€™re trying to hurt President Putin and the Russian economy,â€ Psaki said Wednesday in an interview on MSNBC. Republicans have unanimously said Biden should stop the oil imports and also undo restrictions on domestic oil production, such as by greenlighting the Keystone pipeline and allowing energy companies to drill in Alaskaâ€™s Arctic National Wildlife Refuge â€” longtime GOP priorities. Democrats such as Sens. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) and Jon Tester (D-Mont.) have also called for sanctions to include Russian energy. â€œIt is simply inexplicable that we and other Western nations continue to spend billions of dollars on energy from Russia,â€ Manchin said this week. â€œThis funding directly supports Putinâ€™s ability to stay in power and execute a war on the people of Ukraine.â€ The war has already pushed up crude oil prices, partly because supply has decreased due to oil traders preemptively shunning Russian crude just because it might be sanctioned later. Itâ€™s all happening at a time when overall price inflation has already surged to the highest level in 40 years. Federal Reserve chair pro tempore Jerome Powell told lawmakers this week that the Fed is keeping a close eye on how Ukraine could affect oil and other commodity prices, but that the warâ€™s effect on the economy would be unpredictable. â€œThe effects are going to be passed through into gas prices, into lower economic activity, and into inflation, headline inflation,â€ Powell told the House Financial Services Committee on Wednesday, adding that he didnâ€™t know how substantial the effects would be. Powell said the Fed would raise interest rates starting this month to stymie inflation by slowing the economy, hopefully without causing a recession. To counteract higher gas prices increase, Biden announced in his State of the Union address this week that the U.S. would tap its strategic petroleum reserve. â€œIâ€™m taking robust action to make sure the pain of our sanctions is targeted at the Russian economy and that we use every tool at our disposal to protect American businesses and consumers,â€ Biden said. Russian crude represented a small but growing fraction of overall U.S. oil imports in the past year, so itâ€™s possible cutting it off would spike gasoline prices and worsen overall inflation. But Manchin said inflation would not result. â€œWeâ€™re producing a million a million barrels less a day than we have shown that we can easily do,â€ Manchin told HuffPost. As they demand the U.S. stop Russian oil and gas imports, Republicans are also ratcheting up attacks against the Biden administration for causing high gas prices across the country. Their strategy is putting Democrats in a box just months from the November midterm elections. Republicans conceded, however, that increased domestic production would not necessarily replace Russian imports in the short term. â€œObviously, trying to build new infrastructure is a challenge,â€ Sen. John Cornyn (R-Texas) told HuffPost. â€œBut I mean, a long journey starts with the first step. And so I think sending a message to the fossil fuel sector that theyâ€™re not persona non grata, and we donâ€™t need them, would be a good start.â€ Climate hawks argued that the Ukraine crisis underscored the need to wean the U.S. off fossil fuels, and that although immediate steps can be taken to stabilize energy supplies, the long-term prioritizing of renewable energy shouldnâ€™t be ditched outright. â€œIt is our dependence on fossil energy that creates the power for these petro-fascists around the world,â€ Sen. Brian Schatz (D-Hawaii) said.

Title: Jill Biden Wore This Sunflower Face Mask To Show Her Support For Ukraine

Title: John Bolton Reveals How Little Donald Trump Actually Knew About Russia
Text: Former President Donald Trumpâ€™s grasp on the geography of Russia wasnâ€™t exactly first class, according to his former national security adviser John Bolton. Trump â€œbarely knew where Ukraine wasâ€ and once asked if Finland was part of Russia, Bolton told Newsmax host Rob Schmitt on Tuesday. Bolton recalled Trumpâ€™s stunning lack of knowledge while countering Schmittâ€™s claim that Russian President Vladimir Putin did not invade Ukraine during Trumpâ€™s presidency because Trump took a â€œvery tough stanceâ€ on the country. John Bolton pushes back on Newsmax host: "[Trump] barely knew where Ukraine was...It's just not accurate to say that Trump's behavior somehow deterred the Russians"  Trump â€œdid notâ€ take a tough stance on Russia, responded Bolton. The Trump White House did sanction Russia, he continued, but â€œin almost every caseâ€ the restrictions were imposed â€œwith Trump complaining about it, saying we were being too hard.â€ â€œIt is just not accurate to say that Trumpâ€™s behavior somehow deterred the Russians,â€ Bolton said. â€œI think the evidence is that Russia didnâ€™t feel that their military was ready.â€ NEWSMAX: â€œTrump was tough on Russia.â€ ğŸ”¥ TRUMP NAT SEC ADVISOR JOHN BOLTON: â€œNO HE WASNâ€™Tâ€¦ he didnâ€™t even know where Ukraine was. He was incompetent. Unfit to be president.â€ Bolton shatters the illusion as Newsmax flashes Opposite Day graphics, trying to rewrite history.  Bolton failed to speak out against Trump during the 17 months he served in his administration, even remaining silent during Trumpâ€™s first impeachment for misconduct in the Ukraine scandal. He penned a critical memoir of his time in the Trump administration, which the Department of Justice attempted to block.

Title: Ukrainian Singer Drops F-Bombs On Vladimir Putin During Live BBC Interview
Text: Ukrainian singer Maria Burmaka cursed out Russian President Vladimir Putin during a live BBC interview on Wednesday. â€œI want to say to Putin â€” youâ€™re a murderer, youâ€™re an aggressor, Ukraine was never against Russia,â€ said the musician. â€œLike our soldiers say, â€˜Fuck you.â€™â€ As â€œBBC Breakfastâ€ anchor Dan Walker apologized for Burmakaâ€™s swearing, she defiantly mouthed the expletive again. Title: The Stunning And Heartbreaking Street Art Painted In Solidarity With Ukraine
Text: Street artists around the world are spraying in solidarity with Ukraine. Many artists have painted poignant pieces highlighting Ukrainiansâ€™ struggles amid the Russian invasion, while others call out Russian President Vladimir Putin over the globally condemned attack. â€œIt was the least I could do apart from sending financial support,â€ the artist known as WOSKerski, who painted the tribute below in London, told HuffPost. A post shared by WOSKerski (@woskerski) â€œAs an artist, I have a voice that can influence people and a moral obligation to act against injustice and support people who need it,â€ WOSKerski said. â€œI am aware that the online support is probably meaningless, but I hope that perhaps it did help someone.â€ Jenks, a street artist in Llanelli, Wales, who acknowledged that Ukrainians likely â€œnever have heard ofâ€ his hometown, said he painted his â€œPray for Ukraineâ€ piece below â€œin the hope that if they saw the image painted thousands of miles away, they would not feel isolated and know people are on their side during this terrible time for them.â€ A post shared by steve (@jenksart1) Artist Seth Globepainter said his artwork was inspired by the â€œincredible resilienceâ€ of the children he met while previously painting in Donbas, Ukraine. He painted the below mural of a girl in Paris, dedicated to a friend Oleg who remains in Kyiv. It â€œsymbolized the courage of the Ukrainians faced with the Russian invasion,â€ Globepainter, whose is real name is Julien Malland, told HuffPost. â€œI do not usually express my views on current events, but I know how important it is for the people living through this dramatic situation to know that we are thinking of them.â€ A post shared by seth_globepainter (@seth_globepainter) Corie Mattie, aka the LA Hope Dealer, collaborated with tattoo artist Juliano Trindade on this piece in Los Angeles depicting doves carrying Putinâ€™s head: A post shared by Corie Mattie (@coriemattie) â€œWhatâ€™s happening in Ukraine isnâ€™t a Ukrainian problem. Itâ€™s a humanity problem,â€ Mattie told HuffPost. â€œThis is a time where we need to come together and stand up for evil, to fight for whatâ€™s right.â€ Meanwhile, the Los Angeles-based artist known as Plastic Jesus produced 5,000 â€œFuck Putinâ€ stickers that are being distributed to fans worldwide: Check out other notable pieces below. Have you seen some similar street art? Or can you help us further identify the artists or locations of the pieces we have in the list? Title: Diplomats Throw Epic Shade The Moment Russian Foreign Minister Opens His Mouth
Text: It wasnâ€™t very diplomatic â€• but it was effective. More than 100 U.S. and European diplomats stood up and marched out of the room on Tuesday when Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov began speaking at a U.N. Human Rights Council meeting in the middle of his countryâ€™s attacks on Ukraine: The moment dozens of diplomats from the European Union and United States walked out of a speech by Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov during the annual U.N. Human Rights Council session, nearly a week since Moscow unleashed its war on Ukraine  Lavrov spoke via prerecorded video, saying flight restrictions against Russian aircraft kept him from attending the event in Geneva in person. He also blamed Ukraine for the war. Canadian Foreign Minister Melanie Joly, one of the leaders of the walkout, later told The Associated Press that Lavrovâ€™s claims were â€œfalse.â€ â€œThatâ€™s why we wanted to show a very strong stance together today,â€ she told the news agency. The walkout was in sharp contrast to the reception given the same day to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, who received a standing ovation when he addressed the parliament of the European Union, also via video. He has applied for Ukraine to join the EU.

Title: Democrats Raise Alarms About Russia Using Cryptocurrency To Dodge Sanctions
Text: WASHINGTON â€” Democrats worry Russia could use cryptocurrencies to ease the impact of economic sanctions imposed to punish Russian President Vladimir Putin for invading Ukraine. A group of lawmakers on Wednesday asked the Biden administration whether they needed additional tools to ensure malign actors arenâ€™t evading U.S. and multilateral sanctions on Russia by using virtual currencies. â€œStrong enforcement of sanctions compliance in the cryptocurrency industry is critical given that digital assets, which allow entities to bypass the traditional financial system, may increasingly be used as a tool for sanctions evasion,â€ Sens. Elizabeth Warren (Mass.), Mark Warner (Va.), Jack Reed (R.I.) and Sherrod Brown (Ohio) said in a letter to Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen. The letter added that â€œthere are growing concerns that Russia may use cryptocurrencies to circumvent the broad new sanctions it faces from the Biden administration and foreign governments in response to its invasion of Ukraine.â€ Sanctions imposed by the U.S. and the rest of the world have severely curtailed Russiaâ€™s ability to do business, crushing the value of Russian currency and shuttering its stock market. But some have speculated that cryptocurrencies â€” speculative assets that purport to be an alternative to government-backed currency â€” could give Russia a way to mitigate the sanctions, since cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin are traded outside of the traditional banking system. Itâ€™s not just Democrats concerned about the possibility of a crypto end-around. â€œI want to find out how itâ€™s been used by the Russians,â€ Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) told HuffPost, after saying earlier this week that cryptocurrency has been â€œrearing its ugly headâ€ in Russia. Other Republicans sounded more skeptical of a crypto sanctions problem, suggesting their effect may be negligible. â€œI donâ€™t think that itâ€™s all that plausible for the Russian government to be able to evade sanctions on a significant scale with crypto right now,â€ Sen. Pat Toomey (R-Pa.), the top Republican on the Senate Banking Committee, said. The topic also came up in a House hearing on Wednesday with Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, where Democrats asked Powell how much of a problem crypto might be for sanctions. â€œIt is past time for all of us to lead on creating a regulatory environment in which we, rather than the worldâ€™s despots, terrorists and money launderers benefit from the emergence of cryptocurrency,â€ Rep. Jim Himes (D-Conn.) said. Powell said he didnâ€™t know whether cryptocurrency offered Russia a sanction workaround, but that it was a possibility Congress should address. â€œIt underscores the need really for congressional action on digital finance, including crypto currencies,â€ Powell told the House Financial Services Committee. â€œWe have this burgeoning industry which has many many parts to it and there isnâ€™t in place the kind of regulatory framework that needs to be there.â€ Sen. Debbie Stabenow (D-Mich.), chair of the Senate Agriculture Committee, which oversees the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, one of the agencies with some regulatory authority over the crypto industry, said Congress should â€œclose loopholesâ€ to protect American consumers from being defrauded. But she said Congress shouldnâ€™t act in an ad hoc way because of the war in Ukraine. â€œWhat we need is a structure for transparency and oversight and accountability,â€ Stabenow told HuffPost. Congress imposed tax reporting requirements on some players in the crypto industry last year to help pay for roads and bridges in a bipartisan infrastructure bill. The industry lobbied hard against the new rules but ultimately lost. Since then, the industry has ramped up its investment in lobbying. â€œThe number of people that came out of the woodwork trying to beat us up for doing that was amazing,â€ Warner said.

Title: Chuck Todd Wondered What Ukrainians Fighting For Their Lives Thought Of Bidenâ€™s SOTU Speech
Text: Just after President Joe Biden wrapped up his State of the Union address late Tuesday, NBC Newsâ€™ Chuck Todd had a pressing question for a correspondent reporting live from Lviv, Ukraine, as the country is under assault by Russia: What did the locals think of Bidenâ€™s speech? Todd said the growing refugee crisis in Ukraine was â€œa very important missed point by the presidentâ€ in his national address, and asked NBC correspondent Tom Llamas how that detail was playing out in Lviv. â€œItâ€™s yet another part of this story that I think a lot of us thought heâ€™d use this time with the American public to speak more about,â€ Todd said. â€œWhat are you seeing in Lviv, Tom?â€ Llamas said he didnâ€™t expect Bidenâ€™s speech to resonate much with the Ukrainian people for several reasons, the most obvious being that theyâ€™re fighting for their lives at the moment and probably didnâ€™t see the speech. â€œThey are preoccupied right now,â€ he said. â€œThey have Russian troops in their country trying to take over their land.â€ Llamas also noted that it was 6 a.m. in Lviv, meaning Bidenâ€™s speech â€• if people even had the ability to watch it or interest in watching it â€• would have begun at 5 a.m. local time. You can watch their exchange here: Llamas went on to say that the things Ukrainian residents would have wanted to hear from Biden are things that heâ€™s said he wonâ€™t do. Namely, he said, they want NATO to enforce a no-fly zone around Ukraine and they want the United States and its allies to put boots on the ground. Biden should have given a more â€œinspirational message,â€ concluded Llamas. â€œHe should have talked more about helping these refugee families.â€

Title: Ukrainian Crowd Blocks Russian Access To Nuclear Power Plant
Text: A crowd of hundreds of Ukrainians on Wednesday blocked the road to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant as Russian troops reportedly took control of the area. The plant, near the city of Enerhodar in the countryâ€™s southeast, is the largest in Ukraine and the whole of Europe. Video shared on Twitter and verified by CNN shows plant workers and civilians congregating en masse on both the road into the facility and a set of railroad tracks nearby. What appear to be garbage trucks are parked farther down the road, behind makeshift bunkers made of sandbags, parked cars and piles of tires. More unbelievable bravery from every day Ukrainian citizens. The road into the town of Energodar which contains Europe's largest nuclear power plant is blocked by vehicles and people.  Anton Gerashchenko, an adviser to Ukraineâ€™s ministry of internal affairs, called on Russia to give the area a wide berth in a post on Facebook. â€œAn accident can happen like [the one] at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant or the Fukushima nuclear power plant,â€ reads Gerashchenkoâ€™s warning, as translated into English by The Telegraph. â€œRussian generals â€“ think again! Radiation does not know nationalities, [it] does not spare anyone!â€ Gerashchenkoâ€™s fears are not unfounded. On Sunday, Russian missiles struck a radioactive waste disposal facility in Kyiv. Ukraineâ€™s State Nuclear Regulatory Inspectorate told the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) that the building thankfully was undamaged and there were no reports of radioactive release. The IAEA called on Russia to allow â€œnecessary services, equipment and componentsâ€ be delivered to Ukraineâ€™s nuclear facilities at all times, and for the staff at such facilities to be given adequate rest so as to not â€œcompromise their safety or put them under undue pressure.â€ Russian forces that invaded the country seized control of the shuttered Chernobyl nuclear facility last Thursday, reportedly holding hostage the staff who maintain and protect the contaminated nuclear facility.

Title: Russian Police Reportedly Arrest, Jail Children Protesting War Against Ukraine
Text: Five Russian children protesting against their countryâ€™s military invasion of Ukraine were reportedly arrested and briefly jailed along with their mothers this week. The kids, ages 7 to 11, were armed with flowers and a sign reading â€œNo Warâ€ when they were taken into custody outside the Embassy of Ukraine in Moscow on Tuesday, NPR first reported. Photos first posted by Alexandra Arkhipova on Facebook show the children behind bars. Arkhipova, a university researcher, said the kids and the two women were detained and brought to a police station. â€œFive children aged 7 to 11 and their mothers Olga Alter and Ekaterina Zavizion were detained today for trying to lay flowers to the Embassy of Ukraine (and also - what a terrible crime - the children made a poster! )â€ Arkhipova wrote in a Facebook post. Putin is at war with children. In Ukraine, where his missiles hit kindergartens and orphanages, and also in Russia. 7 y.o. David and Sofia, 9 y.o. Matvey, 11 y.o. Gosha and Liza spent this night behind bars in Moscow for their â€˜NO TO WARâ€™ posters. This is how scared the man is.  Arkhipova said the women and children were eventually released from the police station and fined. She said they are seeking a human rights lawyer. A video taken by Arkhipova shows a little girl crying, her fingers laced through metal bars. Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba shared images of the kids on Twitter, and said that Russian President Vladimir Putin â€œis at war with children.â€ â€œThis is how scared [Putin] is,â€ Kuleba said. Russia is thought to have detained more than 6,000 anti-war protesters throughout the country as Russian forces continue to inch closer to Ukraineâ€™s capital city, Kyiv. â€œWe understand the vast majority [of arrested Russian demonstrators] are released within hours, many after paying an administrative fine, while some are given prison sentences ranging from seven to 25 days under various laws,â€ the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights said. â€œThere are also reports of unnecessary and excessive use of force by police during and after the arrests.â€

Title: The West's Racist Double Standard For Refugees
Text: With reportedly 2,000 dead in Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s invasion of Ukraine and more than 836,000 people displaced as they flee his brigades, bombs and bullets, somehow, amid all the fear and uncertainty, there is still time for racism. Over the last few days, several reports from the Ukraine-Poland border have indicated that Black people living in Ukraine have had a much tougher time getting to safety. According to CNN, the refugees of color were forced to wait in frigid conditions with no food or water. On Tuesday, Ukraineâ€™s foreign minister said that all people leaving the country should be treated fairly. â€œUkrainians have been prioritized over Africans â€” men and women â€” at every point,â€ Rachel Onyegbule, a Nigerian medical student, told CNN. â€œThereâ€™s no need for us to ask why. We know why.â€ The Russian invasion of Ukraine has put the Western worldâ€™s inability to see Black people as human in the spotlight. While rallying the troops and his people to fight back against Putinâ€™s aggression, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy was successful in appealing to our common humanity. Itâ€™s not something that Black and brown people in conflict have really ever been able to do. Even the ones trying to flee Ukraine. One CNN producer tweeted about his sister who is from Sierra Leone and lives in Ukraine. Her harrowing escape from the country included walking 10 hours in the cold, sleeping outdoors and abandoning belongings. One student from Guinea said he and other Africans were physically prevented from crossing into Ukraine while they watched white people be let through. â€œUnlike with people from the Middle East or countries with predominantly Black or brown populations, for whom war and other devastation are often seen as 'expected,' the Western media very quickly realized the humanity of Ukrainians.â€ Though many may feel as if the unprovoked attack on Ukraine is unprecedented, the horrifying truth is that for many countries and people, war has been a constant for decades. But Palestinians, Iraqis, Afghans and Syriansâ€” though constantly under the threat of death and destruction â€” havenâ€™t been receiving overwhelmingly warm welcomes and worldwide support. At times, itâ€™s been the exact opposite. In 2015, Hungarian camerawoman Petra Laszlo was filmed tripping and kicking Middle Eastern refugees who had fled from war. She was sentenced to three years probation in 2017 but her sentence was overturned the following year. Unlike with people from the Middle East or countries with predominantly Black or brown populations, for whom war and other devastation are often seen as â€œexpectedâ€ (as if their skin color predetermined whether or not theyâ€™d get to live a peaceful existence), the Western media very quickly realized the humanity of Ukrainians. â€œThis isnâ€™t a place, with all due respect, like Iraq or Afghanistan that has seen conflict raging for decades,â€ CBSâ€™s Charlie Agata said. â€œThis is relatively civilized, relatively European.â€ Decoding the dog whistle is not rocket science; the outpouring of support for white Ukrainians while ignoring or even impeding Africansâ€™ escape from the conflict is clearly rooted in white supremacy and the idea that we must do everything to stop war in countries like Ukraine while, in brown and Black countries, thatâ€™s just the way those people are. And in the United States, the racist double standard is so extreme that some Republicans are comparing Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine to alleged problems in other â€œwhiteâ€ countries â€” namely, this one. â€œWe also have neighbors to the north who need freedom and need to be liberated and we need that right here at home as well,â€ Rep. Lauren Boebert (R-Colo.) said at CPAC last week, equating a bloody invasion to wearing a mask at the grocery store in the U.S. and Canada. But still, after some early praise for Putin from former President Donald Trump, who remains the Republican Partyâ€™s standard-bearer, and from Fox Newsâ€™ talking heads, even the GOP had to concede that the Ukrainians were putting up an impressive fight. Much of the world has united behind Ukraine. Members of Congress are wearing yellow and blue â€” the colors of the Ukrainian flag. Social media users have changed their profile pictures to declare their alliance with the Ukrainian people, and pundits are musing openly (and dangerously) about the U.S. getting directly involved. At President Joe Bidenâ€™s State of the Union speech on Tuesday night, his lines about the conflict drew bipartisan support. Republicans, whose sole goal is to oppose anything the Democrats believe in, were on their feet cheering and applauding Ukraine. Can you imagine getting bipartisan support for Afghan refugees or Black Lives Matter? The U.S. is rightly horrified. But the U.S. is also hypocritical. Turning entire nations into The Other is what leads to wars, genocides and other atrocities. This very thing that the U.S. and its allies are doing â€” declaring Ukraine good and therefore deserving of our support while either demonizing or flat-out ignoring similar atrocities in non-Western countries â€” is how wars like the one Russia is waging begin in the first place. The solution here, however, isnâ€™t to turn our backs on Ukraine. But if the U.S. and the rest of the West want to consider themselves the good guys â€” the people who defend democracies and the ordinary people of the world â€” they must, for once, do the same for the people who donâ€™t look like them.

Title: Biden After UN Vote Condemning Invasion Of Ukraine: â€˜Russia Is To Blameâ€™
Text: President Joe Biden said Wednesdayâ€™s United Nations vote to condemn Russia for its invasion of Ukraine showed Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s isolation and â€œdemonstrates the extent of global outrage at Russiaâ€™s horrific assault on a sovereign neighbor.â€ In an emergency session of the U.N. General Assembly, 141 of 193 member states voted for the resolution, a symbolic move that condemns the invasion of Ukraine and reflects the growing global outrage as the war there rages on. The document calls for an immediate end to the invasion and for the protection of civilians and those delivering humanitarian aid. Five countries voted against the resolution â€” Russia, Belarus, Syria, Eritrea and North Korea. â€œAn overwhelming majority of nations around the world condemn Putinâ€™s war,â€ Biden said Wednesday. â€œAn overwhelming majority of nations recognize that Putin is not only attacking Ukraine, he is attacking the very foundations of global peace and security â€” and everything the United Nations stands for.â€ â€œAnd an overwhelming majority of the world recognizes that if we do not stand up to Putinâ€™s Russia, it will only inflict further chaos and aggression on the world.â€ Putin thought the West and NATO wouldnâ€™t respond â€” and he thought he could divide us at home. He was wrong. I spent countless hours unifying our European Allies. We countered Russiaâ€™s lies with truth. And now, the free world is holding him accountable. Linda Thomas-Greenfield, the U.S. ambassador to the U.N., told the body on Wednesday that the resolution was essential because the U.N. was being â€œchallengedâ€ by Putinâ€™s actions. â€œIf it has any purpose, it is to prevent war and to condemn war and to stop war,â€ she said before the vote. â€œThat is our job here today.â€ Biden took direct aim at the Kremlinâ€™s misinformation war behind the invasion, saying the vote shows â€œthe world is rejecting Russiaâ€™s lies.â€ â€œWe can all see what is happening in Ukraine with our own eyes,â€ he said. â€œRussia is responsible for the devastating abuses of human rights and the international humanitarian crisis that we are watching unfold in Ukraine in real time. There is no room for excuses or equivocation.â€ â€œRussia is to blame.â€

Title: Zelenskyy Thanks Prince William, Kate Middleton For Supporting Ukraine
Text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy thanked Britainâ€™s Prince William and his wife, Kate Middleton, on Tuesday after they released a rare political statement supporting Ukraine as it fights off a Russian invasion. In a tweet, the Zelenskyy said he and his wife, Olena, â€œare grateful to the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge ... that at this crucial time, when Ukraine is courageously opposing Russiaâ€™s invasion, they stand by our country and support our brave citizens.â€ Olena and I are grateful to the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge @RoyalFamily that at this crucial time, when Ukraine is courageously opposing Russia's invasion, they stand by our country and support our brave citizens. Good will triumph. His response came after the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge shared a statement on social media Saturday, saying they stood with Ukraine against the Russian forces. In October 2020 we had the privilege to meet President Zelenskyy and the First Lady to learn of their hope and optimism for Ukraineâ€™s future. Today we stand with the President and all of Ukraineâ€™s people as they bravely fight for that future ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ W & C It was an unusually bold statement for the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge to make, as the British royal family is generally forbidden from taking sides on any political issue. A day before the Cambridges posted their statement, Prince Harry and Meghan Markle released a statement of their own also supporting Ukraine. â€œPrince Harry and Meghan, The Duke and Duchess of Sussex and all of us at Archewell stand with the people of Ukraine against this breach of international and humanitarian law and encourage the global community and its leaders to do the same,â€ said the statement, which was posted on the website of the coupleâ€™s nonprofit, Archewell Foundation.

Title: Ukrainian Journalist Confronts Boris Johnson Over No-Fly Zone
Text: Ukrainian journalist Daria Kaleniuk made an impassioned plea to U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson to support the creation of a no-fly zone over Ukraine as Russia continues to invade the country, shelling the city of Kharkiv. â€œUkrainian people are desperately asking for the West to protect our sky,â€ Kaleniuk said during Johnsonâ€™s news conference Tuesday in Warsaw. â€œYouâ€™re not coming to Kyiv, Prime Minister,â€ the journalist added. â€œYouâ€™re not coming to Lviv, because you are afraid, because NATO is not willing to defend, because NATO is afraid of the World War III. But it is already starting, and these are Ukrainian children who are there taking the heat.â€ Johnson said he had to be â€œhonestâ€ about the U.K.â€™s inability to grant the no-fly zone demand. â€œAs I said to Volodymyr Zelenskyy I think a couple of times, unfortunately the implication of that is that the U.K. would be engaged in shooting down Russian planes, it would be engaged in direct combat with Russia,â€ Johnson said. â€œThatâ€™s not something that we can do or that weâ€™ve envisaged. And I think the consequences of that would be truly very, very difficult to control.â€ 'Youâ€™re coming to Poland, you're not coming to Kyiv... because you're afraid'A Ukrainian reporter breaks down as she begs @BorisJohnson for a no-fly-zone over Ukraine - the PM rejects her plea as it would see the UK 'shooting down Russian planes'  Johnson is not the only Western leader resisting a no-fly zone. The White House and U.S. lawmakers on both sides of the aisle, with few exceptions, have cautioned against the move. â€œThis would require a declaration of war by Congress, which is not happening,â€ Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) tweeted Monday. That would require a declaration of war by Congress, which is not happening. Presidents donâ€™t get to go to war with other superpowers without the people having a say. Ukraine Interior Ministry adviser Anton Herashchenko said Tuesday that rocket strikes in Kharkiv, Ukraineâ€™s second-largest city, left 10 people dead and 35 injured, according to CNN.

Title: Tucker Carlson Openly Gaslights Viewers About Pro-Russia Stuff He Said Days Ago
Text: Tucker Carlson is notorious for rewriting history, but he might have broken the record for the speed of this turnaround. The Fox News host whined to his millions of viewers on Monday that people are accusing him of rooting for Russia, days after he defended its president, Vladimir Putin, and leaned into Kremlin talking points ahead of its brutal invasion of Ukraine. He had argued Ukraine was â€œnot a democracyâ€ and delivered a lengthy rant last Tuesday questioning why he should be expected to hate the authoritarian leader. A clip of that monologue later aired on Russian state-sponsored TV with subtitles. But when Rep. Eric Swalwell (D-Calif.) criticized Carlsonâ€™s rhetoric, noting that his comments served as televised material to rally Russians for Putinâ€™s cause, Carlson was not happy. â€œItâ€™s such an awful thing to say,â€ he griped after airing Swalwellâ€™s remarks. â€œWe hesitated to even play it.â€ He added: â€œItâ€™s very common. You hear it every day. The question is: Why are they saying that? It doesnâ€™t make sense.â€ Carlsonâ€™s critics did not have to look far back to offer him an explanation. Tucker Carlson just said "itâ€™s an awful thing" that people are saying he supported Russia and wondered, "Why are they saying it? It doesnâ€™t make sense."Felt like a good time to combine these clips from @Acyn from the past few weeks. Never forget it.  The right-wing personalityâ€™s latest comments come after several days of backpedaling and shifts in tone following Putinâ€™s offensive into Ukraine. Polling has shown that the vast majority of Americans think the invasion was unjustified. His flip-flop was brazen but unsurprising: Heâ€™s openly admitted in the past to lying when â€œcornered.â€

Title: Pat Robertson Resurfaces To Offer Worst Possible Take On Ukraine
Text: Retired televangelist Pat Robertson resurfaced this week to make another in a long line of his doomsday predictions. This time, he returned to his â€œ700 Clubâ€ show to claim that Russian President Vladimir Putin was being compelled by God to not only attack Ukraine, but use the country as a staging ground for a war against Israel to fulfill biblical prophecy: Pat Robertson came out of retirement to claim that Putin "is being compelled by God" to invade Ukraine in preparation for a massive End Times invasion of Israel.  Robertson, who turns 92 this month, is a serial doomsday cheerleader. In the 1970s, he predicted a 1982 ending. In the 1990s, he predicted a 2007 ending. In 2020, he predicted Donald Trump would win reelection â€• â€œwithout questionâ€ â€• and it would lead to the end. (In that case, it wasnâ€™t a war that would end the world, as he is currently predicting, but something a lot more natural, like an asteroid.) â€œItâ€™s sudden destruction. Itâ€™s not going to be some nuclear war,â€ Robertson said, per USA Today. â€œWeâ€™re not going to be allowed to blow this earth up.â€ He also has a long history of hateful, divisive, racist and intolerant comments.

Title: Ukraine's U.S. Ambassador Accuses Russia Of War Crime
Text: Ukraineâ€™s ambassador to the U.S. accused Russia of war crimes for attacking Ukrainians with powerful vacuum bombs during Vladimir Putinâ€™s continued invasion of his neighboring country. â€œThey used the vacuum bomb today, which is actually prohibited by the Geneva Convention,â€ Oksana Markarova told reporters on Capitol Hill on Monday. â€œThe devastation that Russia is trying to inflict on Ukraine is large, but we Ukrainians will resist. We are defending our home, we do not have any other option. We will not get tired, we will not stop, we will not surrender, we will continue defending our home.â€ Vacuum bombs, also known as thermobaric weapons, suck in oxygen to create high-temperature and high-pressure explosions that can cause widespread destruction and death. There hasnâ€™t been independent confirmation that Russia has used vacuum bombs in Ukraine. On Saturday, CNN reporters near the Ukraine-Russia border said they identified a Russian thermobaric rocket launcher. Markarova said Russia is targeting orphanages and schools in Ukrainian cities. â€œWe believe Russia, which is now acting like Nazi Germany during the World War II, essentially killing innocent civilians,â€ Markarova said. â€œItâ€™s horrible, they have to pay the price, they have to be isolated.â€ She said Ukraine is working with the Biden administration and Congress to secure more weapons. Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) who was among the senators meeting with Markarova behind closed doors Monday, told Politico the current crisis calls for unity. â€œThis is the most dangerous moment since the Cuban missile crisis,â€ Murphy said. White House press secretary Jen Psaki said the administration has not confirmed reports of Russia using thermobaric weapons. â€œIf that were true, it would potentially be a war crime,â€ Psaki said. World leaders have expressed alarm over Russiaâ€™s tactics during the invasion. â€œIt is clear that Vladimir Putin is prepared to use barbaric and indiscriminate tactics against innocent civilians to bomb tower blocks, to send missiles into tower blocks, to kill children, as weâ€™re seeing in increasing numbers,â€ U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson said Tuesday from Warsaw. Karim Khan, the chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, pledged an expansive investigation into alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity in Ukraine. Ukranian and Russian delegations held talks Monday on the Belarus border, with no immediate breakthrough. Both parties said they would seek a second round of talks.

Title: Vladimir Putin Is A 'Danger To Life' In Chilling New Street Art
Text: Russian President Vladimir Putin gets the skull and crossbones treatment in street artist Pegasusâ€™ new piece. â€œDanger To Life,â€ blares the creation of Chicago-born Pegasus, whose real name is Chris Turner. The artist painted the street art in protest of Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine in his home city of London over the weekend. Pegasus said he was â€œjust lost for wordsâ€ over the invasion and felt compelled to stand in solidarity with Ukrainians, if only artistically. â€œPutin in my eyes is a ruthless and lethal leader, so a skull and crossbones was the best way for me to express that thought in the form of an image,â€ he told HuffPost. â€œThe world is watching Vladimir Putinâ€™s senseless taste for blood with disgust,â€ he added. â€œPutin has oppressed his people, but he cannot silence us. I am one of millions who stand in solidarity with Ukraine and hope for a peaceful end to this unprovoked and unjustified war.â€ Produced or seen some street art that sends a message? Email your images and information to lee.moran@huffpost.com or direct message via Instagram.

Title: Mayor Paints Very Blunt Message For Putin... Right Outside Russian Embassy
Text: A mayor in Lithuania has a blunt message for Russian President Vladimir Putin, who launched an attack on Ukraine and is facing investigation for possible war crimes, including attacks on civilians. Remigijus Simasius, the mayor of Vilnius, the capital, and a team of volunteers painted â€œPutin, The Hague is waiting for youâ€ in large block letters on a street just outside the Russian embassy, according to Reuters. A handout image provided by the mayorâ€™s office to the news agency shows the stencil in place: The message comes as Chief Prosecutor Karim Khan of the International Criminal Court â€• located in The Hague, in the Netherlands â€• announced an investigation of Putin over potential war crimes. In one instance, Russia is accused of using fearsome thermobaric weapons, aka â€œvacuum bombs.â€ â€œIf that were true, it would potentially be a war crime,â€ White House press secretary Jen Psaki said this week, adding that the U.S. has not yet confirmed use of the weapons. CNN reporters over the weekend said they spotted a thermobaric rocket launcher moving into position near the border. There are also multiple videos online of Russian strikes on civilian targets, and reports of deaths and injuries among civilians.

Title: Ukraine Acknowledges Racist Treatment Of Africans Fleeing Russian Invasion
Text: Days into the massive refugee crisis created by Russiaâ€™s war on Ukraine, the Ukrainian government has publicly acknowledged that African immigrants seeking to flee the violence have faced racist, disparate treatment compared to white Ukrainians. On Tuesday, Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba tweeted that Russiaâ€™s invasion had â€œaffected Ukrainians and non-citizens in many devastating ways.â€ â€œAfricans seeking evacuation are our friends and need to have equal opportunities to return to their home countries safely,â€ the official said, adding that Ukraineâ€™s government â€œspares no effort to solve the problem.â€ There have been numerous reports in recent days of African students and other immigrants facing racist treatment as they seek to flee cities under attack. This includes Black people being kept from boarding buses and trains even as white Ukrainians were able to and being kept waiting hours in the cold at the border with Poland. Earlier Tuesday, the United Nationsâ€™ high commissioner for refugees, Filippo Grandi, also recognized the â€œdifferent treatmentâ€ between Ukrainians and â€œnon-Ukrainians,â€ as he put it. â€œThere should be absolutely no discrimination between Ukrainians and non-Ukrainians, Europeans and non-Europeans,â€ the U.N. official said, adding that the international organization â€œplans to intervene to try to ensure that everybody receives equal treatment.â€ â€œEveryone is fleeing from the same risks,â€ he added. Several African governments have condemned the racism Africans have faced as theyâ€™ve sought to leave the war-torn country. On Monday, the Nigerian government called out â€œunfortunate reportsâ€ of Ukrainian police â€œrefusing to allow Nigerians to board buses and trainsâ€ headed toward Ukraineâ€™s border with Poland. South Africaâ€™s head of public diplomacy echoed similar concerns that South African students and other Africans â€œhave been badly treatedâ€ at Ukraineâ€™s border with Poland. Over 600,000 people have fled Ukraine since Russia attacked last week, the U.N. said. The African Union, which represents the 55 countries of the African continent, said Monday that â€œreports that Africans are singled out for unacceptable dissimilar treatment would be shockingly racist and in breach [of] international law.â€ The nations urged all countries to â€œshow the same empathy and support to all people fleeing war notwithstanding their racial identity.â€

Title: Sean Penn Flees Ukraine On Foot, Says He Walked Miles To Polish Border
Text: Sean Penn said Monday he had escaped Ukraine on foot. The actor and filmmaker, who was in the country making a documentary about Russiaâ€™s invasion, said he and two colleagues had abandoned their car on the side of the road and walked miles to the Polish border. â€œAlmost all the cars in this photo carry women & children only, most without any sign of luggage, and a car their only possession of value,â€ he wrote, sharing an image of a long line of cars. Hundreds of thousands of refugees have fled Ukraine into neighboring countries. At least 280,000 have entered Poland, mostly women and children. Ukrainian men age 18-60 must remain to fight. Myself & two colleagues walked miles to the Polish border after abandoning our car on the side of the road. Almost all the cars in this photo carry women & children only, most without any sign of luggage, and a car their only possession of value.  Penn was praised by the Ukrainian presidentâ€™s office on Thursday for his work, which included meetings with the the deputy prime minister, journalists and military personnel. â€œSean Penn demonstrates the courage that many others, especially western politicians lack,â€ President Volodymyr Zelenskyyâ€™s office wrote on Facebook. â€œThe director specially came to Kiev to record all the events that are currently happening in Ukraine and to tell the world the truth about Russiaâ€™s invasion of our country.â€ Penn was also in Ukraine in late November to work on the project, which is being produced by Vice Studios. He has been involved in multiple international humanitarian and antiwar efforts over the years.

Title: Ukrainian Ambassador Oksana Markarova To Attend Tonight's State Of The Union Speech
Text: Ukraineâ€™s Ambassador to the U.S. Oksana Markarova will be in the audience at tonightâ€™s State of the Union speech, as will Facebook whistleblower Frances Haugen. Text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyyâ€™s powerful speech to the parliament of the European Union stirred emotions in an official translator, who became audibly emotional and almost broke down in tears. Title: Florida Student Who Tracked Elon Muskâ€™s Private Jet Is Now Tracking Russiaâ€™s Elite
Text: A 19-year-old college student who tracked Elon Muskâ€™s private jet has now set up a Twitter account to track the whereabouts of Russiaâ€™s elite, amid Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s attack on Ukraine. The new Twitter account @RUOligarchJets, run by University of Central Florida student Jack Sweeney, tracks when private jets owned by Russiaâ€™s oligarchs take off and land â€” then sends out the locations to over 167,000 followers. Sweeneyâ€™s new tracking efforts come as Ukraine fights for its sovereignty after Russian invaded the European country under Putinâ€™s direct orders. In his tracking, Sweeney found that these Russian-owned jets appeared to be traveling on a daily basis despite harsh financial sanctions and airspace travel restrictions that are being imposed on Russia by President Joe Biden and other allies to Ukraine. Sweeney uses public data provided by the ADS-B Exchange, a website that collects flight data in real time, to track the private Russian jets, just as he does with his other account @ElonJet, which tracks tech billionaire Musk. According to Sweeney, these Russian jets are more extravagant than other private jets heâ€™s previously tracked. â€œThe aircrafts these oligarchs have are absolutely crazy,â€ Sweeney told Bloomberg, emphasizing how Russiaâ€™s richest people were traveling on commercial-sized aircrafts including the Airbus A319 and Boeing 737. â€œTheir planes are huge compared to other jets.â€ Sweeney first made headlines in late January after the tech-focused media site Protocol published a profile about the teen and Muskâ€™s efforts to shut him down. The Twitter account caught the attention of Musk, who asked Sweeney in a direct message, â€œCan you take this down? It is a security risk,â€ according to Business Insider, which obtained a screenshot of the messages. Musk then offered to buy the account from Sweeney for $5,000, adding that the student would also be â€œgenerally helping make it harder for crazy people to track me,â€ Business Insider reported.

Title: After Claiming He Wanted To 'Denazify' Ukraine, Putin Strikes Holocaust Memorial Site
Text: Ukrainian officials reported Tuesday that a Russian missile strike apparently targeting Kyivâ€™s main TV and radio tower had also hit the Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial. Five people died in the bombing. â€œTo the world: what is the point of saying Â«never againÂ» for 80 years, if the world stays silent when a bomb drops on the same site of Babyn Yar? At least 5 killed. History repeatingâ€¦â€ Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy tweeted Tuesday. The attack comes after Russian President Vladimir Putin invoked World War II as a justification for invading Ukraine, saying he wanted to â€œdenazifyâ€ the country. As The Washington Post noted, Putinâ€™s comments were likely meant to help sell the invasion back home, where â€œrhetoric around fighting fascism resonates deeplyâ€ still. Other countries quickly called Putin out for his cynical twisting of history. To start, Zelenskyy himself is Jewish and had family members killed in the Holocaust. Putinâ€™s target may not have been Babyn Yar, but rather the TV tower located close to the memorial. The New York Times reported that videos captured at least two other explosions in the area, in addition to the one that struck the tower itself. But the damaging of Babyn Yar further delegitimizes Putinâ€™s purported motives. Babyn Yar is the site of one of the worst mass murders of Jews during the Holocaust. On Sept. 29-30, 1941, Nazi killing squads executed more than 33,000 people there. Nazis murdered an estimated 100,000 people at Babyn Yar during World War II. In response to the Babyn Yar attack Tuesday, the Auschwitz Memorial in Poland tweeted, â€œItâ€™s hard to expect the Russian army to respect the dead if it is not capable of respecting human lives.â€ Last week, it also said in a statement that people in Ukraine were being killed â€œpurely because of insane pseudo-imperial megalomania.â€ The U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum also tweeted its outrage about Babyn Yar on Tuesday. And previously, it called out Putin for exploiting the Holocaust to invade Ukraine. â€œIn justifying this attack, Vladimir Putin has misrepresented and misappropriated Holocaust history by claiming falsely that democratic Ukraine needs to be â€˜denazified,â€™â€ the museum said in a statement on Feb. 24. â€œEqually groundless and egregious are his claims that Ukrainian authorities are committing â€˜genocideâ€™ as a justification for the invasion of Ukraine.â€ The White House said Zelenskyy and President Joe Biden spoke Tuesday about continued U.S. support for Ukraine. They discussed economic support, sanctions on Russia and the bombing near Babyn Yar.

Title: Even The Dictionary Is Puzzled By GOP Repâ€™s Word Salad About Ukraine
Text: Dictionary.com spelled out exactly what was wrong with Rep. Clay Higginsâ€™ (R-La.) tweet about Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. Namely, it made little sense. â€œYou millennial leftists who never lived one day under nuclear threat can now reflect upon your woke sky,â€ Higgins wrote on Sunday. â€œYou made quite a non-binary fuss to save the world from intercontinental ballistic tweets.â€ You millennial leftists who never lived one day under nuclear threat can now reflect upon your woke sky. Title: BP Plans To Exit Stake In Russian Oil Giant Over Ukraine Invasion
Text: BP announced on Sunday that it would â€œexitâ€ its share in a major, state-owned Russian oil giant over the countryâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, saying the attack merited a â€œfundamental changeâ€ in its business holdings. The British oil company said the share amounts to 19.75% of Russiaâ€™s Rosneft, a stake valued at $14 billion. Itâ€™s unclear how BP will divest itself of the holdings or who could buy them, but the decision reflects a broader shift among companies to abandon Moscow amid the ongoing assault. If BP walks away from the holdings completely it could cost the company up to $25 billion, it said. â€œRussiaâ€™s attack on Ukraine is an act of aggression which is having tragic consequences across the region,â€ Helge Lund, the companyâ€™s chairman said in a statement. â€œBP has operated in Russia for over 30 years, working with brilliant Russian colleagues. However, this military action represents a fundamental change. It has led the BP board to conclude, after a thorough process, that our involvement with Rosneft, a state-owned enterprise, simply cannot continue.â€ BPâ€™s current and former chief executives, Bernard Looney and Bob Dudley, also resigned from the Rosneft board with immediate effect. In response, Rosneft released a statement attacking western media and accusing BP of bowing to public pressure to destroy a â€œ30-year-long cooperation.â€ â€œBP has come under unprecedented pressure from both the regulator and its shareholders,â€ Rosneft said in a statement translated by The Associated Press. â€œBPâ€™s decision was preceded by a Western media campaign full of false reports and conclusions.â€ Russia has drawn widespread fury around the globe for the invasion of Ukraine and faces both economic sanctions and a broader movement to reject anything to do with the Kremlin. Russian planes have been barred from many European nationsâ€™ airspace. Norway said its sovereign wealth fund would divest billions in assets from Russia. And liquor outlets in the U.S. and Canada have begun pulling Russian vodka from store shelves. Western nations have also said they will block Russiaâ€™s access to global financial networks. The BP decision came amid sharp criticism from British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, and shortly after a call between BPâ€™s chief executive and the British business secretary, Kwasi Kwarteng. Kwarteng praised BPâ€™s move on Twitter: I welcome BPâ€™s decision to exit its shareholding in Rosneft oil company.Russiaâ€™s unprovoked invasion of Ukraine must be a wake up call for British businesses with commercial interests in Putinâ€™s Russia.

Title: Trump Takes Credit For NATO â€” And Is Promptly Reminded Of A Few Pesky Facts
Text: When Donald Trump was president, he openly preferred Russian president Vladimir Putin over Americaâ€™s NATO allies, and even suggested leaving the alliance. But that didnâ€™t stop the former president from taking credit for the existence of the group of Western powers on Monday in a statement emailed to reporters: â€œI hope everyone is able to remember that it was me, as President of the United States, that got delinquent NATO members to start paying their dues, which amounted to hundreds of billions of dollars. There would be no NATO if I didnâ€™t act strongly and swiftly. Also, it was me that got Ukraine the very effective anti-tank busters (Javelins) when the previous Administration was sending blankets. Let History so note!â€ Trump bragged. Observers familiar with Trumpâ€™s antipathy toward NATO and his lack of concern for Ukraineâ€™s defense against Russia quickly pointed out the fact-free nature of his statement. Politico reporter Sam Stein (formerly of HuffPost) posted Trumpâ€™s statement on Twitter, with some context. Trump, who discussed pulling the US from NATO takes credit for NATOâ€™s existence in a new statement. Trump, who threatened to withhold weapons funding from Ukraine to get dirt on Biden, takes credit for Ukrainian weapons in same statement.  Others soon followed, including retired Army Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, the former National Security Council aide who reported that Trump was trying to pressure Ukraine to investigate Joe Biden and his son in exchange for U.S. aid. That disclosure helped form the basis of Trumpâ€™s first impeachment. It was trump that undermine U.S. national security & froze military assistance to Ukraine, leaving that lion of a nation, vulnerable to attack. It was Trumpâ€™s attacks on NATO that encouraged Putin to believe NATO was fragile. Others also provided fact checks. July 25, 2019Zelenskyy: â€œ[W]e are almost ready to buy more Javelins from the United States for defense purposes.â€Trump: â€œI want you do us a favor thoughâ€¦â€ This is the guy who withheld military aid to Ukraine, openly talked of dismantling NATO, and cozied up to Putin. Perhaps he should sit this one out. Trump threatened with withdraw if countries didnâ€™t meet minimum obligation of GDP spending on their own defense. Lativaâ€™s FM, and other Baltic state leaders, said the admin overall strengthened NATO and increased spending on defense. None of this here is true. And never forget that when donald trump withheld military aid to Ukraine to extort President Zelenskyy, 99% of republicans in Congress refused to remove trump from office. Trump ordered 12K US forces to leave Germany â€” because it didnâ€™t do what he wanted. Let History so note! One person did find it interesting as a â€œpoliticial litmus testâ€ that Trump now wants to take credit for NATO, considering that the world is rallying for Ukraine and against Russia. All the incongruities cited aside, thereâ€™s one notable thing about this statement. As a political litmus test. Trump has a knack for jumping into a parade and claiming itâ€™s his. Itâ€™s notable that Trump *wants* to take credit for this.

Title: John Oliver Skewers CNN For Running Applebeeâ€™s Ad During Attack On Ukraine
Text: A â€œLast Week Tonightâ€ montage brilliantly demonstrated how a recent Applebeeâ€™s ad may have been the worst-timed commercial in history. John Oliver opened his HBO show on Sunday night with a segment about Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, and the Emmy-winning host couldnâ€™t help but tackle how CNN â€œsomehow managedâ€ to make its coverage of air-raid sirens blaring in Kyiv â€œeven worseâ€ by transitioning from the devastating scene to an â€œaggressively Americanâ€ ad. The Applebeeâ€™s spot, which went viral last week, features a man Oliver refers to as a â€œhuman boot barnâ€ shaking â€œhis nonexistent assâ€ to the tune of Zac Brown Bandâ€™s â€œChicken Fried.â€ The abrupt cutaway from the somber Ukraine footage to the ridiculous ad could have come straight from 2006â€™s â€œIdiocracy.â€ WW3 sponsored by Applebees. Weâ€™re living in an episode of South Park.  Soon after the spot went viral last week, Applebeeâ€™s acknowledged that the ad placement was inappropriate and said â€œit never should have been airedâ€ â€” and Oliver pointed out the significance of the company doing this. â€œYou know if Applebeeâ€™s is apologizing for interrupting the coverage of Russia invading Ukraine, this week got seriously out of hand,â€ he said.
