Title: Ukraine's UN Ambassador Bluntly Tells Putin To  'Kill Himself' Like Hitler
Text: Ukraineâ€™s ambassador to the United Nations had some blunt advice for Vladimir Putin during Mondayâ€™s emergency special session: kill himself in a bunker, like Adolf Hitler. Sergiy Kyslytsyaâ€™s harsh suggestion came during a discussion on the Russian presidentâ€™s decision to order Russian nuclear forces on high alert following intensifying Western sanctions in response to Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. Kyslytsya said Putinâ€™s escalation was basically a death wish. â€œIf [Putin] wants to kill himself, he doesnâ€™t need to use nuclear arsenal,â€ Kyslytsya said. â€œHe has to do what the guy in Berlin did in a bunker in May 1945.â€ â€œIf [Putin] wants to kill himself, he doesnâ€™t need to use nuclear arsenal. He has to do what the guy in Berlin did in a bunker in May 1945.â€â€” Sergiy Kyslytsya, Ukrainian Ambassador to the United Nations  Kyslytsyaâ€™s comments ratcheted up his scorn for Russia. Last week, he bluntly called out Russiaâ€™s U.N. ambassador, Vasily Nebenzya, who was ironically leading a U.N. Security Council discussion of the invasion. â€œThere is no purgatory for war criminals,â€ Kyslytsya told Nebenzya. â€œThey go straight to hell, Ambassador.â€ Kyslytsyaâ€™s latest fiery remarks came as Ukrainian officials began negotiations with Russian counterparts to try to end the warfare.

Title: Sporting World Punishes Russian Aggression With Indefinite Bans, Suspensions
Text: In response to Russiaâ€™s unprovoked war on Ukraine, countries across the world are canceling sporting events and other matchups involving Russian teams and athletes. On Monday, the executive board of the International Olympic Committee recommended barring athletes from Russia and Belarus from international competitions moving forward. For events that cannot feasibly be canceled due to planning or legal reasons, athletes from the countries will participate only as neutral athletes, lacking any national symbols, colors, flags or anthems. The Russian team was already serving a multiyear ban from the Olympics as punishment for the countryâ€™s state-sponsored doping program during the 2014 Sochi Olympics. The IOC said in a statement that the move was needed to â€œprotect the integrity of global sports competitions and for the safety of all the participants.â€ The action follows a surge of teams declining to move forward with planned matches against Russia, across a wide range of sports:

Title: Dee Snider Says Ukrainians Can Use 'We're Not Gonna Take It,' But Not Anti-Maskers
Text: Twisted Sister lead singer Dee Snider has a message for Ukrainians who want to use the bandâ€™s 1984 hit, â€œWeâ€™re Not Gonna Take It,â€ as an anthem as they fight back against Russian forces: Go ahead and take it. Snider first endorsed the use of the anti-authoritarian anthem on Saturday on Twitter, and explained he had very personal reasons for doing so. â€œI absolutely approve of Ukrainians using â€˜Weâ€™re Not Gonna Take Itâ€™ as their battlecry,â€ he wrote. â€œMy grandfather was Ukrainian, before it was swallowed up by the USSR after WW2. Title: Ukrainian Sailor Tries To Sink His Russian Bossâ€™ Yacht Over War Ties
Text: A Ukrainian sailor has reportedly admitted to trying to sink a luxury yacht he worked on that was owned by the head of a Russian state arms exporter in retaliation for Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. The 157-foot Lady Anastasia, which belongs to Rosoboronexport director general Alexander Mikheev, was docked in Majorca, Spain, over the weekend when the sailor, who worked on the boat as a mechanic, opened the engine roomâ€™s valves in an attempt to sink it, the BBC and local news outlets reported. â€œMy boss is a criminal who sells weapons that kill the Ukrainian people,â€ the sailor, identified as 55-year-old Taras Ostapchuk, told officers on Saturday as he turned himself in, according to the Majorca Daily Bulletin. He stood by his actions the following day in court, saying: â€œI donâ€™t regret anything Iâ€™ve done and I would do it again.â€ The man told the court he had worked on the vessel as a mechanic for about 10 years and decided to scuttle it after seeing video of a Russian military cruise missile hitting a building in Kyiv during Russiaâ€™s invasion. A high-rise apartment building near Kyivâ€™s Zhuliany airport was struck by a missile on Saturday. The assault left at least six civilians injured, a rescue worker told The Associated Press. The man said he believed that the missile was produced by Mikheevâ€™s company and so opened the valves, flooding and severely damaging the engine room, according to the Daily Bulletin. Prior to becoming CEO of Rosoboronexport, Mikheev was general director of Russian Helicopters, which is Russiaâ€™s largest rotorcraft manufacturer. The sailor was released by the court and said he planned to return to Ukraine to help the war efforts, the Daily Bulletin reported, citing an interview he gave with local Spanish news outlet Ultima Hora. Lady Anastasia was featured by Yacht Harbour in 2019 as having a listing price of 7 million euros. Itâ€™s listed as having been built in 2001.

Title: NBC Journalist Appears To Wonder Why U.S. Wouldn't Just Attack Russian Convoy
Text: NBC News chief foreign correspondent Richard Engel came under fire Monday after posting a tweet that seemed to lament that the U.S. had not yet attacked Russia for invading Ukraine. Engel noted Monday that a massive Russian convoy was in a position to be destroyed by the U.S. or NATO and said that direct involvement against Russia would risk â€œeverything,â€ meaning a nuclear war. However, in the next sentence, he said, â€œDoes the West watch in silence as it rolls?â€ Perhaps the biggest risk-calculation/moral dilemma of the war so far. A massive Russian convoy is abt 30 miles from Kyiv. The US/NATO could likely destroy it. But that would be direct involvement against Russia and risk, everything. Does the West watch in silence as it rolls? But as Reason.com noted, â€œthe U.S. cannot attack Russia because Congress has yet to declare war on the country. And make no mistake, a direct attack on Russian forces by either the U.S. or NATO would be an act of warâ€ and dramatically increase the risk of nuclear warfare. Many Twitter users were shocked that Engel seemed almost eager to get his war on and also tried to remind him: Be careful what you wish for. This is an NBC News US senior correspondent near-demanding that nuclear powers enter a hot war. It is always incredible to witness how so many American reporters become champions for US militarism, without a shred of concern for the human life they purport to care about. This is NBC's chief foreign policy correspondent, advocating for, uh, nuclear war. How is this journalism? This is utter madness. A major network's chief corresp is asking thisSince USSR got nukes in 1950s, US policy under *every* prez has been not to fight USSR/RUS directly *except* (a) w/in NATO or (b) Western hemisâ€”Cuban Missile Crisis â€œWatch in silenceâ€ = Hungary 1956, Czech 1968, Berlin many times The way you tweet about whether the US and NATO should engage in a full-on war against a nuclear-armed super power is shockingly glib. It's not as simple as "watch in silence as it rolls" or not. The stakes are risking nuclear annihilation. 1) No one is watching in silence, the West has done almost everything Ukraine has asked of it, and 2) you're asking for world war and nuclear standoff. Hopefully no one at US/NATO is taking that even remotely seriously. Richard Engel: So is Biden gonna start WW3 or what here? Nice framing. False binary. Putin couldn't script it better. Very dramatic. A long time ago I wrote something arguing that the Kantian idea of "fiat justicia, ruat caelum" wasn't entirely coherent when it comes to literally world-ending choices because the moral project of improving the world requires that there be a world left to improve Remember that in Richard Engel's book "War Journal" he said that before the invasion of Iraq he knew it "was a land where careers were going to be made" and that being there for war was his "big break" should nato blow up a bunch of russian military personnel? i am very smart. Some people offered advice to Engel in hopes heâ€™d rethink the point he was making in his tweet. i dunno if i was a chief foreign correspondent i would not glibly wonder why one nuclear power isn't carpet bombing another nuclear power's forces if you want a war so badly, go enlist Pro tip: do not tweet questions like this until you've given at least, oh, I don't know, a whole thirty seconds of thought to steps two, three, and four of your decision tree. HuffPost reached out to Engel for comment on the reaction to his tweet, but no one immediately responded.

Title: GOP Sen. Roger Wicker Calls For No-Fly Zone Over Ukraine
Text: Sen. Roger Wicker (R-Miss.) endorsed the idea of creating a no-fly zone over Ukraine amid the Russian invasion of the eastern European country, which grows deadlier by the day as Russian troops lay siege to population centers. â€œClearly, in the absence of a U.N. resolution, which Russia would veto, a strong coalition of like-minded nations should step in and seriously consider this,â€ Wicker told HuffPost on Monday. Ukrainian officials are reportedly urging President Joe Biden and NATO to impose a no-fly zone over parts of the country as large numbers of Russian troops approach the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv, but top White House officials have ruled out the idea. A no-fly zone would require â€œimplementation by the U.S. military â€” it would essentially mean the U.S. military would be shooting down planes, Russian planes,â€ threatening the outbreak of a larger war involving the U.S., White House press secretary Jen Psaki said Monday. â€œThat is definitely escalatory, that would potentially put us in a place where we are in a military conflict with Russia. That is not something [Biden] wants to do,â€ Psaki said in an interview on MSNBC. â€œThose are all the reasons why thatâ€™s not a good idea.â€ Most Republicans also oppose the idea of sending U.S. troops into Ukraine. â€œTheyâ€™re not a NATO country, as much as we want to help them. I donâ€™t think we can get in a situation where weâ€™re almost asking for engagement,â€ Sen. Roy Blunt (R-Mo.) said Monday when asked if he supported imposing a no-fly zone over Ukraine. Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) offered a blunter response. â€œThat would mean World War III,â€ he told HuffPost. But Wicker, who will likely become the next top Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee after Sen. Jim Inhofe (R-Okla.) steps down later this year, argued Russian President Vladimir Putin is â€œthe one escalating this war.â€ â€œTens of thousands of women and children fleeing from Kyiv west have created a humanitarian situation that the international community needs to step in and be involved in,â€ he argued. Earlier on Monday, Wicker issued a statement knocking Biden for taking â€œoptions off the table, including close air support,â€ amid the conflict in Ukraine. That comment drew a response from Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.), who tweeted, â€œLetâ€™s just be clear what that is - the U.S. and Russia at war. Itâ€™s a bad idea and Congress would never authorize it.â€ â€œMilitary equipment for Ukraine, humanitarian support for Ukraine, crippling sanction on Russia, movement of U.S. troops to the eastern flank of NATO - these are all the right moves,â€ Murphy added. â€œBut direct war between the worldâ€™s two nuclear powers should be a non-starter.

Title: Nigerian Government Condemns Racist Treatment Of Africans Fleeing Ukraine
Text: As hundreds of thousands of people escape Ukraine amid Russiaâ€™s attack on its soil, Africans fleeing the violence have reported facing racist, disparate treatment compared to white Ukrainians. On Monday, the Nigerian government called out the â€œunfortunate reportsâ€ of Ukrainian police â€œrefusing to allow Nigerians to board buses and trainsâ€ headed toward Ukraineâ€™s border with Poland. With around 4,000 Nigerians, mostly students, â€œstrandedâ€ in Ukraine, the Nigerian government said, there have been reports of Polish officials refusing Africans entry into Poland. â€œIt is paramount that everyone is treated with dignity and without favour,â€ Nigeriaâ€™s presidential office and residence said in a statement on Twitter. â€œAll who flee a conflict situation have the same right to safe passage under UN Convention and the colour of their passport or their skin should make no difference.â€ South Africaâ€™s head of public diplomacy echoed similar concerns that South African students and other Africans â€œhave been badly treatedâ€ at Ukraineâ€™s border with Poland. The South African foreign office official shared a video of a woman at a Ukrainian border town saying Africans waiting to cross were being â€œpushed,â€ â€œshovedâ€ and â€œdenied access,â€ forced to wait in the cold as Ukrainians got â€œspecial treatment.â€ SA students & other Africans have been badly treated at the #Ukrain/Poland border. ğŸ‡¿ğŸ‡¦ Amb J Mngomezulu has driven from Warsaw (5 hours) to go deal with the matter, receive our nationals & offer further support. ğŸ‡¿ğŸ‡¦ Amb G Tsengiwe in Hungary is also attending to SANs on his side.  One Nigerian man, identified only as Isaac, told BBC News that Africans were being â€œchased backâ€ and hit by police â€œarmed with sticks,â€ and said border officials had told them they were â€œnot tending to Africans.â€ Another Nigerian, Osemen, told the news outlet that only Ukrainians were being permitted to board a train in Lviv to the border with Poland. A group of Congolese students told Canadaâ€™s CTV News that Africans were being â€œput asideâ€ until border guards processed Ukrainians, and were told that â€œUkrainians go first.â€ Responding to the reports of disparate treatment, the Polish embassy in Nigeria said in a statement Saturday that â€œall nationals are given equal treatment and none are discriminated against,â€ adding that Nigerians were â€œamong thoseâ€ whoâ€™d been able to cross into Poland â€œin recent days.â€ The Polish government in Nigeria added that the situation at the border is â€œbecoming increasingly challengingâ€ and that it takes â€œlonger with each passing dayâ€ to get through. Tens of thousands of African students have been studying in Ukraine, according to Reuters. Over 500,000 people have fled the country since Russia attacked last week, the United Nations said. The U.S. civil rights group the NAACP released a statement Monday condemning the mistreatment of Black people seeking to flee Ukraine, saying: â€œAs history has taught us, whenever there is a crisis, Black and brown communities will feel the effects first and be provided with aid last.â€ â€œBlack families, immigrantsâ€¦ are not only facing challenges to evacuate a deadly warzone but are being pushed from trains and beaten by police officers,â€ the NAACP said. â€œThese callous acts are atrocious and reprehensibleâ€¦ Every individual must be treated with dignity and humanity.â€

Title: CNN Correspondent Backs Away From Grenade During Live Report From Kyiv
Text: CNNâ€™s senior international correspondent reacted calmly during a live report from Ukraine on Monday when he noticed he was crouching beside a grenade. Matthew Chance was at the site of a recent battle on the outskirts of Kyiv, speaking on air to a colleague in the U.S. when he stood up and retreated several steps. â€œI didnâ€™t see that, so letâ€™s move away from that,â€ he said, backing farther away before smoothly continuing his report about the Ukrainian resistance against Russian troops there earlier. So @mchancecnn just realized live on CNN that he was right next to a grenade in Kyiv "Oh actually -- I was crouching down right by a grenade. I didn't see that. Let's move away from that."  Chance also showed viewers what he described as the â€œstill smoking,â€ twisted metal wreckage from armored vehicles, debris and ammunition boxes from the Russian offensive. â€œThereâ€™s unexploded grenades ... like pineapple grenades everywhere,â€ he said. â€œA real scene of devastation.â€ He also pointed out the body of a Russian soldier. â€œI toured this area earlier and there were some terrible things that we canâ€™t really show you on camera,â€ he said. â€œIn terms of dead bodies. Russians.â€ "This vehicle is still smoking ... ammunition boxes [are] on the ground ... there's unexploded grenades ... everywhere. A real scene of devastation." @mchancecnn gets a look at the aftermath of a ferocious battle on the outskirts of Kyiv.  Chance has been on the front lines in Kyiv since Russia invaded Ukraine early Thursday morning. Russian troops have met unexpectedly fierce resistance on the ground in multiple cities and towns, including Ukraineâ€™s capital and its second-largest city, Kharkiv.

Title: 2 Danish Journalists Shot In Ukraine: 'We Are Lucky To Be Alive'
Text: Two journalists were shot and wounded in Ukraine on Saturday while reporting on Russiaâ€™s invasion of the country. Freelancers Stefan Weichert and Emil Filtenborg were shot inside a car in Ohtyrka, a town about 55 miles from the city of Kharkiv, where an intense battle is taking place between Russian and local forces. The two experienced war reporters live in Kyiv and had been filing dispatches for The Daily Beast and Danish newspaper Ekstra Bladet, according to the U.S. news site. Weichert said he was hit by a bullet in the shoulder, while his colleague took three bullets to his legs. They were wearing bulletproof vests. â€œMultiple shots were fired and we are lucky to be alive,â€ Weichert tweeted Sunday. â€œWe are at a hospital in Poltava and still need surgery, but we are stable and recovering.â€ He said their car had come under fire while they were traveling near the frontline in Okhtyrka to see a damaged kindergarten. â€œThe car totally damaged, completely broken, smoking and leaking afterwards. But we managed to escape and are now safe. We donâ€™t know what comes next but just want to say thank you for all the support,â€ he wrote. Itâ€™s unclear who the shooters were. â€œThere is still some confusion from our part about what happened. We will tell more when it is possible but will for now focus on our recovery,â€ Weichert wrote. On his Twitter, Filtenborg shared a link to the music video for Elton Johnâ€™s â€œIâ€™m Still Standing,â€ adding, â€œthis is kind if a lie since Iâ€™m shot in both legs, but you get the joke.â€ Denmarkâ€™s foreign minister, Jeppe Kofod, said on Twitter it was â€œan ugly reminder of the dangers journalists in Ukraine face every day to document the horrors of the war,â€ according to a translation.

Title: CBS Journalist Apologizes For Saying Ukraine More 'Civilized' Than Iraq, Afghanistan
Text: CBS News senior foreign correspondent Charlie Dâ€™Agata apologized Saturday for suggesting the war in Ukraine is particularly shocking because the country is â€œrelatively civilizedâ€ and â€œEuropeanâ€ compared to Iraq and Afghanistan. Dâ€™Agataâ€™s characterization was among a flurry of similar commentary in the media that critics have slammed as racist and, in some cases, historically inaccurate. While reporting from Kyiv on Friday, a day after Russia began its invasion of Ukraine, Dâ€™Agata said of the latter country, â€œThis isnâ€™t a place, with all due respect, like Iraq or Afghanistan, that has seen conflict raging for decades.â€ â€œThis is a relatively civilized, relatively European â€” I have to choose those words carefully, too â€” city, where you wouldnâ€™t expect that or hope that itâ€™s going to happen,â€ he said. â€œCivilizedâ€  A clip of the moment drew millions of views and condemnation from many people, including historians and journalism organizations. â€œAs someone who has lived through wars and invasions with the world watching, I deeply empathize with the Ukrainian people. The deeply racist coverage has been very telling as well,â€ Mostafa Minawi, an associate professor of history at Cornell University, wrote on Twitter. â€œI wonder what would lead someone like [Dâ€™Agata] to think it is ok to compare the value of peoplesâ€™ lives and who qualifies as â€˜civilized.â€™â€ Nader Issa, a reporter at the Chicago Sun-Times, tweeted, â€œIf thatâ€™s the version where he chooses his words carefully, was the alternative just going to be â€˜these are civilized white people and not uncivilized brown people.â€™â€ The Arab and Middle Eastern Journalists Association (AMEJA) released a statement in response to coverage of the Ukraine crisis, citing Dâ€™Agataâ€™s remarks as one of several examples of â€œracist news coverage that ascribes more importance to some victims of war over others.â€ AMEJA called on all news organizations to be mindful of implicit and explicit bias in their coverage of the war. Dâ€™Agata responded to the criticism during a Saturday report, saying, â€œI spoke in a way that I regret, and for that Iâ€™m sorry.â€ He said what heâ€™d been trying to convey was that Ukraine had not seen war on this scale in recent years, compared to conflicts heâ€™d covered in other parts of the world. Several other journalists and public figures have been called out for similarly troubling analyses. David Sakvarelidze, the former deputy prosecutor general of Ukraine, said in a BBC interview that â€œitâ€™s very emotional for me because I see European people with blue eyes and blonde hair being killedâ€ by Russiaâ€™s assault. The BBC journalist interviewing him did not challenge the comment. [Thread] The most racist Ukraine coverage on TV News. 1. The BBC - â€œItâ€™s very emotional for me because I see European people with blue eyes and blonde hair being killedâ€ - Ukraineâ€™s Deputy Chief Prosecutor, David Sakvarelidze  Daniel Hannan, a British journalist and former pro-Brexit politician, wrote in The Telegraph, â€œThey seem so like us. That is what makes it so shocking. War is no longer something visited upon impoverished and remote populations. It can happen to anyone.â€ And Al Jazeera English anchor Peter Dobbie said it was â€œcompellingâ€ that the refugees appeared to be â€œmiddle-class people.â€ â€œThese are not obviously refugees trying to get away from areas in the Middle East that are still in a big state of war. These are not people trying to get away from areas in North Africa,â€ he said. â€œThey look like any European family that you would live next door to.â€ In addition to accusations of racism, several critics called out the inaccurate implication that this type of conflict has been limited to countries in the Middle East, Africa and Asia in recent history, pointing to wars in Europe in the 1990s. In 1992, war broke out in Bosnia. 100,000 deaths, countless refugees, Sarajevo sieged. And before that, war in Croatia and Slovenia. After, war in Kosovo. Can we please stop calling Ukraine "the worst armed conflict in Europe since the Second World War"? It's deeply disrespectful  Al Jazeera later apologized for its presenterâ€™s comments, calling them unfair, insensitive and irresponsible. It added that the â€œbreach of professionalism is being dealt with.â€ The BBC and The Telegraph did not immediately return requests for comment. In its statement, AMEJA warned newsrooms not to make comparisons that â€œweigh the significance or imply justification of one conflict over another.â€ â€œThis type of commentary reflects the pervasive mentality in Western journalism of normalizing tragedy in parts of the world such as the Middle East, Africa, South Asia and Latin America,â€ the group said. â€œIt dehumanizes and renders their experience with war as somehow normal and expected.â€

Title: Rep. Lauren Boebert Says Canada And U.S. 'Need To Be Liberated' Like Ukraine
Text: As everyday Ukrainian people take up arms against Russian invaders in a desperate bid to hang onto their democracy, Rep. Lauren Boebert (R-Colo.) on Sunday compared their situation to protesting truckers in Canada who didnâ€™t want to get the COVID-19 vaccine. â€œI pray for Ukraine and I wish them the best. They have a great president right now who has really said clearly, â€˜Live free or die.â€™ He said, â€˜I donâ€™t need a ride, give me ammunition. The fight is right here,â€™â€ Boebert said in an interview with Fox News personalities Kayleigh McEnany and Pete Hegseth at the Conservative Political Action Conference that aired on the Fox Nation streaming service. â€œBut we also have neighbors to the north who need freedom and need to be liberated and we need that right here at home as well.â€ Lauren Boebert told Fox Nation at CPAC that Canada needs to be "liberated" along with Ukraine."We also have neighbors to the north who need freedom."  The gun-obsessed, extremist lawmaker had been referring to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyyâ€™s refusal of a U.S. offer to be evacuated from Kyiv, as Russian troops continued to press into the capital in an unprovoked attack that has shocked the world. Zelenskyy has vowed to defend the country with its citizens, saying, â€œWe are not putting down arms.â€ The cityâ€™s residents have sheltered in underground bunkers and subway stations and accepted weapons from the government to join the fight in the streets as Russian airstrikes rain down on the capital and other cities. Boebert made the outrageous comments after Hegseth brought up Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and called him an â€œautocratâ€ because he quashed anti-vaccine protests that had paralyzed international supply chains for weeks. The demonstrators were against vaccine mandates and an assortment of other measures intended to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Boebert claimed President Joe Biden is â€œjealousâ€ of the control that â€œtyrant Trudeauâ€ has, adding that the Ukraine crisis is â€œall because of weakness in America.â€ She did not mention the actual cause of the Ukraine crisis, Russiaâ€™s authoritarian president, Vladimir Putin. Boebert is notorious for making hateful, bigoted and false statements with potentially dangerous repercussions. On Jan. 6, 2021, shortly before a violent mob of Donald Trump supporters broke into the U.S. Capitol to try and overturn a democratic election, she tweeted, â€œToday is 1776.â€

Title: U.S. Citizens Urged To Leave Russia Immediately Amid Flight Cancellations
Text: The U.S. Embassy in Russia has urged all Americans to consider leaving Russia immediately amid concerns that airline travel out of the country during the countryâ€™s escalating assault of Ukraine may become even more limited than it already is. â€œAn increasing number of airlines are cancelling flights into and out of Russia, and numerous countries have closed their airspace to Russian airlines,â€ the embassy said in a security alert Sunday. â€œU.S. citizens should consider departing Russia immediately via commercial options still available.â€ The U.S. Embassy in Ukraine also advised American citizens to leave Ukraine using private transportation â€œif it is safe to do so.â€ â€œSheltering in place may remain the best option for some,â€ U.S. officials said, acknowledging the risk of people facing potential combat operations, destroyed infrastructure and hours-long lines at border crossings. Russia: Airlines are cancelling flights in/out of Russia; numerous countries closed airspace to Russian airlines. U.S. citizens should consider departing Russia immediately via commercial options still available. Our advisory level is 4: Do Not Travel.  The alerts came as the European Union on Sunday said it will impose a blanket flight ban on all Russian planes, whether they are â€œRussian-owned, Russian-registered or Russian-controlled aircraft.â€ Private Russian planes have also been banned from entering the U.K.â€™s airspace. The State Department raised its travel advisory for Russia to its highest level late last month, while urging U.S. citizens to avoid all travel there if possible. â€œDo not travel to Russia due to ongoing tension along the border with Ukraine, the potential for harassment against U.S. citizens, the embassyâ€™s limited ability to assist U.S. citizens in Russia, COVID-19 and related entry restrictions, terrorism, harassment by Russian government security officials, and the arbitrary enforcement of local law,â€ the department said at the time. The governmentâ€™s website reminds that U.S. citizens are subject to the local laws and legal system of any foreign country they choose to visit. In Russia, U.S. citizens have been arrested by Russian security services on spurious charges and have denied them fair and transparent treatment, including public trials.

Title: EU To Supply Weapons To Ukraine, Block Russian Aircraft And Kremlin-Backed Media
Text: The European Union has announced plans to purchase weapons for Ukraine, close its entire airspace to Russian aircraft, and ban two Kremlin-backed media outlets throughout the 27-nation bloc in an effort to rid â€œtoxic and harmful disinformation in Europe,â€ the EUâ€™s chief said Sunday. â€œThis is a watershed moment,â€ European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said while outlining the unionâ€™s efforts to deter Russian violence and support the Ukrainian people amid the ongoing assault launched by Russian President Vladimir Putin. The weaponsâ€™ planned purchase and delivery to a country under attack would be a first for the EU. We are stepping up our support for Ukraine.For the first time, the EU will finance the purchase and delivery of weapons and equipment to a country under attack. We are also strengthening our sanctions against the Kremlin. â€œSo let me be very clear, our airspace will be closed to every Russian plane and that includes the private jets of oligarchs too,â€ she said of the first of several tactics being rolled out. Plans are also underway to ban RT, formerly known as Russia Today, and Sputnik state media, said von der Leyen, who slammed both as part of the â€œKremlinâ€™s media machine.â€ Both outlets â€œwill no longer be able to spread their lies to justify Putinâ€™s war and to saw division in our union,â€ she said. It wasnâ€™t immediately clear whether the ban will be strictly on television broadcasts or on the internet as well. The EUâ€™s decision to supply Ukraine with military arms is a major turning point for the union, which had at times been split on how to respond to Russiaâ€™s aggression. It follows other Western countries stepping up their own military aid in recent days. President Joe Biden on Saturday instructed the U.S. State Department to free up an additional $350 million worth of weapons for Ukraine. The U.S. has already committed more than $1 billion in security assistance to Ukraine over the past year, said Secretary of State Antony Blinken. Germany on Saturday also reversed its long-standing policy of not sending weapons to conflict zones. Russiaâ€™s invasion â€œmarks a turning point,â€ German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said while announcing his decision. â€œIt threatens our entire post-war order. In this situation, it is our duty to do our utmost to support Ukraine in defending itself against Vladimir Putinâ€™s invading army. Germany stands closely by Ukraineâ€™s side,â€ he said in a statement. Scholzâ€™s decision didnâ€™t affect only Germanyâ€™s weapons contribution but other countriesâ€™ as well. Estonia had last month requested to send weapons to Ukraine that had been previously owned by Germany and Finland, but under international law, the Baltic state had to get permission from both countries to do so. Though the U.S. State Department cleared Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia to send U.S.-made missiles and other weapons to Ukraine, Germanyâ€™s government had refused, as The Wall Street Journal reported.

Title: Ukrainian Official Describes Teaching Kids 'Turtle Game' To Prepare For Attacks
Text: Kira Rudyk, a member of Ukrainian Parliament and leader of the Voice Party, described the difficulty of teaching children about the current Russian attacks on Ukraine. â€œThe most complicated thing is to explain to children whatâ€™s going on. So there is this little game thatâ€™s called the turtle game, to explain to them how to act during the attacks,â€ Rudyk told CNNâ€™s Wolf Blitzer on Saturday. â€œSo you tell them that you go down on your belly, you open up your mouth, you close your ears with your hands, and thatâ€™s how you pretend youâ€™re a turtle. And we had to pretend that we are turtles quite a few times today.â€ Kira Rudyk, a member of the Ukrainian parliament & a mother, describes the â€œturtle gameâ€ that parents teach their kids to do for protection in #Kyiv: â€œGo down on your belly, you open your mouth, close your ears with your hands, and thatâ€™s how you pretend that youâ€™re a turtle.â€  The game described by Rudyk is similar to duck-and-cover drills commonly practiced by U.S. students during the Cold War era. While stressing the need for more humanitarian aid, UNICEF said the attacks on Ukraine pose an â€œimmediate and growing threat to the lives and well-being of the countryâ€™s 7.5 million children.â€ Rudyk has spoken to several news outlets about attacks on Kyiv, including airstrikes, that have taken place since Russia invaded Ukraine on Thursday. Sheâ€™s also been active on social media, describing what itâ€™s been like to learn to use a Kalashnikov rifle and prepare to fight Russian forces. I learn to use #Kalashnikov and prepare to bear arms. It sounds surreal as just a few days ago it would never come to my mind. Our #women will protect our soil the same way as our #men. Go #Ukraine! ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦  â€œTwo days ago, before the war with Russia started, I wouldnâ€™t ever imagine that I would have to bear arms or get a weapon,â€ Rudyk said in a video she sent to BBCâ€™s â€œNewsnight.â€ â€œBut right now, I did, and I have, and I will.â€

Title: 'SNL' Teams Up With Ukrainian Chorus, Opening Show With Powerful Tribute
Text: In a moving moment of solidarity, â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ opened its show not with jokes but with a powerful tribute to Ukraine. The Ukrainian Chorus Dumka of New York took the famous Rockefeller Center stage to perform â€œPrayer for Ukraine,â€ a patriotic Ukrainian hymn and anthem, during the showâ€™s cold open. The sobering performance followed Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s military invasion into the country earlier in the week. â€œIt is a prayer to God to save Ukraine and to bless her with freedom, good faith and good fortune so that her people would love her for many, many years,â€ the choirâ€™s director and conductor, Vasyl Hrechynsky, told HuffPost Sunday of the 1885 song selection, which is also known as â€œGod Bless Ukraine.â€ â€œIt has continued to be a way that we express our faith in God and that He will allow Ukraine to persevere especially in this most critical time of aggression and war,â€ he added. â€œSNLâ€ cast members Kate McKinnon and Cecily Strong introduced viewers to the choir. Following the performance, the camera panned to white candles on a table that spelled out â€œKyiv,â€ the Ukrainian capital, as the audience sat in silence. Itâ€™s a rare event for the decadeslong comedy show to open with such a solemn act. The show previously broke from comedic tradition immediately following the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, after the 2015 terrorist attacks in Paris, and after President Donald Trumpâ€™s 2016 presidential election. McKinnon appeared in that 2016 instance, performing Leonard Cohenâ€™s â€œHallelujahâ€ on the piano as Hillary Clinton.

Title: Sen. Ron Johnson Says Nancy Pelosi Bears Blame For Putin Invading Ukraine
Text: Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) said Sunday that Democrats including President Joe Biden, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (Calif.) and Rep. Adam Schiff (Calif.) all are part of the reason that Vladimir Putin invaded Ukraine. â€œI donâ€™t think Vladimir Putin would have moved on Ukraine were it not for the weakness displayed â€• certainly by the Biden administration, but by the West in general,â€ Johnson said in a Fox News Sunday interview. â€œIâ€™m certainly hoping that Col. Vindman, Adam Schiff, Nancy Pelosi â€• who used Ukraine as a pawn in their impeachment travesty â€• are also recognizing and reflecting about how they weakened Ukraine, weakened the West, weakened America by the divisive politics that they play.â€ â€œThereâ€™s much blame to go around, but in terms of atrocities, that falls squarely on the shoulders of Vladimir Putin and his cronies,â€ Johnson added. Ron Johnson blames Vindman, Pelosi, and Adam Schiff for weakening Ukraine with Trumpâ€™s impeachment  Democrats did not randomly bring Ukraine into the 2019 impeachment trial of former President Donald Trump. They were not the ones using the country as a political pawn. That year, Trump held back almost $400 million in military aid for Ukraine in order to pressure the countryâ€™s president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, to dig up dirt on the Biden family. The money, which was approved by Congress, was intended to help Ukraine fight Russian aggression. Trump finally released the money after pressures from lawmakers in both parties. Zelenskyy had also desperately sought a meeting with Trump â€• which was never granted â€• as a show of force against Russia. He finally received his White House meeting last August, with President Joe Biden. Schiff, chair of the House Intelligence Committee, led the prosecution in the Trump impeachment trial. Col. Alexander Vindman was a top Ukraine expert on the National Security Council at the time, and one of the few people to listen in on Trumpâ€™s July 2019 call with Zelenskyy. Vindmanâ€™s testimony was a key part of Democratsâ€™ impeachment of Trump. â€œI did not think it was proper to demand that a foreign government investigate a U.S. citizen, and I was worried about the implications for the U.S. governmentâ€™s support of Ukraine,â€ Vindman told lawmakers. Rachel Vindman, Alexanderâ€™s wife, tweeted a defense of her husband Sunday, saying Johnson was â€œthe last person anyone would want in their foxhole.â€ Alexander Vindman retweeted it. On CNN Sunday, Sen. Mitt Romney (R-Utah) acknowledged what Trump did, calling it â€œvery sad.â€ â€œThere are many people who would like to ignore thatâ€¦This was Zelensky, now a world hero, asking for weapons. And it was an American president slow-walking the provision of those weapons,â€ he said. Johnsonâ€™s comments are in line with what many other Republicans are saying in response to Putinâ€™s aggression. On one hand, they condemn what the Russian leader is doing â€• while saying that Biden and Democrats bear responsibility for being so weak. Trump himself has repeatedly said that the invasion of Ukraine is happening only because of the â€œrigged electionâ€ â€• his lie that the 2020 presidential election was stolen from him. Other Republicans have blamed everything from Bidenâ€™s energy policies to his withdrawal from Afghanistan for opening the door to Putin.

Title: Prince William And Kate Release Rare Political Statement On Ukraine
Text: Britainâ€™s Prince William and his wife, Kate Middleton, on Saturday said they stand with Ukraine against invading Russian forces, in an unusual instance of the royal couple wading into political waters. â€œIn October 2020 we had the privilege to meet President Zelenskyy and the First Lady to learn of their hope and optimism for Ukraineâ€™s future,â€ the pair wrote in a tweet that was also posted to their Instagram page. â€œToday we stand with the President and all of Ukraineâ€™s people as they bravely fight for that future,â€ they wrote, signing the message with their initials. William and Kate met with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and his wife, first lady Olena Zelenska, in 2020 at Buckingham Palace. The British royal family is generally forbidden from taking sides on any political issue. But there has been a global outpouring of support for the people of Ukraine this week, as Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered his troops to invade, shelling cities and destroying civilian infrastructure. In October 2020 we had the privilege to meet President Zelenskyy and the First Lady to learn of their hope and optimism for Ukraineâ€™s future. Today we stand with the President and all of Ukraineâ€™s people as they bravely fight for that future ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ W & C The message from the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge mirrors a similar sentiment from their overseas family in California. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex shared a message of support for Ukrainians Thursday evening. â€œPrince Harry and Meghan, The Duke and Duchess of Sussex, and all of us at Archewell stand with the people of Ukraine against this breach of international and humanitarian law and encourage the global community and its leaders to do the same,â€ they said on their charitable organizationâ€™s website. Unlike William and Kate, Harry and Meghan attracted some criticism and mockery on social media and from British tabloids for their statement. As of Saturday, some 120,000 Ukrainians have fled the country for safe haven elsewhere, while others have become volunteer resistance fighters helping to bolster Ukraineâ€™s armed forces. In Kyiv, the nationâ€™s capital, many residents have sought refuge in underground subway stations that double as bomb shelters. A Ukrainian diplomat said at least one woman has given birth there. The countryâ€™s health minister says about 200 Ukrainians have died in the attacks this week, although it is not clear whether that number includes both military and civilian fatalities.

Title: U.S. And Allies Begin Cutting Russia Out Of International Financial System SWIFT
Text: The United States and key allies will cut Russian banks out of the global financial messaging system SWIFT and begin to target Russiaâ€™s central bank, according to a White House statement on Saturday. The move is the most drastic financial sanction yet on Russian President Vladimir Putin over his brutal, ongoing invasion of neighboring Ukraine. The statement said the U.S., top European economies, Britain, and Canada would disconnect selected Russian banks from SWIFT, which will severely hurt their ability to operate internationally, and prevent Russiaâ€™s central bank from using its foreign currency reserves to evade Western sanctions. The pro-Ukraine countries will also make it harder for wealthy Russians to obtain Western citizenship and launch a task force to freeze the assets of Russian elites â€” a bid to pressure Putin by hurting his friends. â€œWe stand with the Ukrainian people in this dark hour,â€ the statement continued. â€œEven beyond the measures we are announcing today, we are prepared to take further measures to hold Russia to account for its attack on Ukraine.â€ In a call with reporters later in the day, a senior Biden administration official said that between the new measures and previously announced sanctions, â€œRussia has become a global economic and financial pariah.â€ The U.S. expects the move to cause â€œmost banks around the world [to] simply stop transacting altogether with Russian banks that are out of SWIFT,â€ the official added, saying the list of affected banks would be released soon and will ultimately be determined by the European Union because Belgium administers the SWIFT system. The official noted that China, from which Russia has sought support despite the Chinese leadershipâ€™s uncertainty about Putinâ€™s plans, â€œhas tended to respect the force of U.S. sanctions.â€ While much of the international debate has recently focused on SWIFT, the steps against the Russian central bank and rich Russians could be even more striking and painful for Moscow. â€œWeâ€™ll go after their yachts, their luxury apartments, their money and their ability to send their kids to fancy schools in the West,â€ the official said. â€œThe ruble will fall even further, inflation will spike and the central bank will be left defenseless.â€ The announcement came as Russian forces continued to try to capture Ukraineâ€™s capital of Kyiv and strategic targets elsewhere in the country. It represents a significant escalation by Americaâ€™s European partners, many of whom worry about the economic toll their own countries will experience if they cut off ties with Russia. Earlier in the day, Germany â€” a key holdout on the SWIFT sanctions â€” signaled a harder position against Putin by sending anti-tank weapons to the Ukrainians and lifting a hold on the Netherlands doing so with German-made arms. â€œThe Russian invasion marks a turning point. It is our duty to support Ukraine to the best of our ability in defending against Putinâ€™s invading army,â€ German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said. The Biden administration official emphasized that the ultimate goal of the U.S. and its allies is to stop the fighting â€• not to continue punishing Putin and Russians. â€œThis is a sad outcome, this is not where we wanted to be,â€ the official said. â€œOnly Putin can decide how much more cost he is willing to bear.â€

Title: Ukraine's Zelenskyy Rejects U.S. Evacuation Offer: 'I Need Ammunition, Not A Ride'
Text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy turned down an American offer early Saturday to be evacuated from the capital city, Kyiv, which is under attack by Russia. â€œThe fight is here; I need ammunition, not a ride,â€ Zelenskyy said, according to the Ukrainian Embassy in the U.K. â€œThe fight is here; I need ammunition, not a ride.â€ - @ZelenskyyUa on the US evacuation offer. Ukrainians are proud of their PresidentğŸ’™ğŸ’› Russian troops continued to press into Ukraineâ€™s capital on the third day of the invasion, with Ukraine reporting 198 people killed and more than 1,000 injured. Residents of Kyiv took shelter after a night of explosions and street fighting on the cityâ€™s outskirts. An apartment building was hit by a missile strike Saturday morning. There were no reported deaths, according to the Kyiv Independent. Missile hit an apartment building in Kyiv this am. Target unclear; medical clinic across the street. Another indiscriminate bombing. Verified by @brenna__smith @muyixiao @sskerrr. More:  Zelenskyy appears determined not to leave the city, though he acknowledged he is a target for the advancing Russian forces. â€œThis might be the last time you see me alive,â€ he reportedly told European Union leaders on a conference call Thursday night. The U.S. concurs that Zelenskyy is a prime target for Russian forces. Zelenskyy â€œdoes, in many ways, represent â€• even personify â€• the democratic aspirations and ambitions of Ukraine â€• of the Ukrainian people,â€ U.S. State Department spokesperson Ned Price said Thursday evening. The Ukrainian president tweeted a 40-second video on Saturday morning from his phone, seeking to reassure people that he was still in Kyiv. â€œI am here. We are not putting down arms. We will be defending our country, because our weapon is truth, and our truth is that this is our land, our country, our children, and we will defend all of this,â€ he said, according to a translation by CNN. â€œThat is it. Thatâ€™s all I wanted to tell you. Glory to Ukraine,â€ he added. â€œDonâ€™t believe the fakes,â€ Zelensky says, dismissing rumors he had fled or ordered Ukraine to surrender. Heâ€™s talking a walk around Kyivâ€™s government district and vowing to keep on fighting. Another video, posted Friday night, showed Zelenskyy surrounded by other political leaders on a city block lit by streetlights. â€œOur troops are here, citizens are here,â€ he said, according to a translation by The Telegraph. Zelenskyy has maintained an active social media presence during the Russian attacks, tweeting about his contacts with world leaders and advocating for his desired outcomes. On Saturday morning, he urged that Ukraine become part of the EU. He also pushed for countries to exclude Russia from the global financial messaging system SWIFT, which links the worldâ€™s banks and allows cross-border financial payments to function. It is a crucial moment to close the long-standing discussion once and for all and decide on Ukraine's membership in the #EU. Discussed with @eucopresident further effective assistance and the heroic struggle of Ukrainians for their free future. The U.S. on Friday said it would impose financial sanctions on Russian President Vladimir Putin â€• a move that would probably be largely symbolic, since Putin holds much of his wealth outside Western nations. White House press secretary Jen Psaki said the U.S. is still considering cutting Russia out of SWIFT.

Title: Aid Groups, Friendly Countries Scramble To Help Ukrainians Under Assault By Russia
Text: As Russia escalates its invasion of Ukraine, bombardment, shelling and street-to-street military operations are transforming the lives of millions of Ukrainians, and thousands are fleeing the country. International aid groups and foreign governments are rushing to address what could become Europeâ€™s worst humanitarian crisis in decades. Supporters of the Ukrainians have been preparing to help for weeks as Russian troops have amassed along Ukraineâ€™s borders â€• but itâ€™s impossible for them to know exactly how desperate the situation will become, what resources they will need and how their ability to help may be limited. â€œWe already know from the 2014 incursion what the in-demand services are for people that are displaced ... receiving them at bus and train stations, providing information and referrals for things like where the closest pharmacy is, and providing a meal and a place to rest,â€ said Britton Buckner of the group Catholic Relief Services, which works with a network of Catholic charities called Caritas. â€œCoordinating with local governments and finding gaps has been taking place ... In parallel, weâ€™re also doing robust volunteer mobilization in 3,500 parishes.â€ Russia began intervening in neighboring Ukraine in 2014 by supporting separatist fighters, who took over parts of the countryâ€™s east and fought Ukrainian government forces backed by the U.S. and Western nations. Before the 2022 invasion, that conflict had already killed more than 13,000 people and displaced nearly a million. â€œThe situation now is very fluid ... The initial phase of displacement is people who have the means to move. As the situation unfolds, we will see where the safe havens areâ€ for others who are forced to leave home, Buckner said. She noted that within Ukraine, cash and fuel are already in short supply and many shops are running low on goods. At Ukraineâ€™s border with Romania, Buckner saw people coming across by foot and in taxis on the first day of the Russian assault, and in Moldova, her organization helped some families who were able to arrive by air before Ukraine ended commercial flights. On Saturday, United Nations refugee chief Filippo Grandi said more than 150,000 Ukrainians had now entered those two countries and neighboring Poland and Hungary. â€œDisplacement in Ukraine is also growing but the military situation makes it difficult to estimate numbers and provide aid,â€ Grandi tweeted. European leaders say they are ready and willing to shelter Ukrainians. In nations like Romania, Ukrainians can count on minority Ukrainian populations who share their language and may be especially keen to help, Buckner said. And some countries are unveiling new programs for the refugees: Slovakian official Livia Vasakova said her country will offer a special status that includes free health care, public transport and the legal right to work, for example. Russiaâ€™s recent pressure against its neighbors has given relief groups on the continent experience in helping not just Ukrainians but others â€• like people fleeing Belarus, whose Russian-backed ruler cracked down on his population in 2020 and 2021, Jonathan Katz, a former official at the U.S. Agency for International Development, told HuffPost. â€œThere would be an expectation, from the European Union aid mechanisms to U.S. and international systems, that... help would be needed,â€ said Katz, who is now with the German Marshall Fund, a think tank. The Biden administration has directed American troops in Poland to help open refugee processing centers, and has sent disaster specialists to the country. The White House is also asking Congress to approve $2.9 billion in funding for emergency humanitarian assistance for Ukraine â€• a step that experts say is important because there are so many other global crises that the U.S. has already committed to addressing. Some commentators have noted thereâ€™s a stark difference between the broad solidarity being shown to Ukrainians and the xenophobia and resistance that European governments like Hungary and Poland displayed toward people displaced by other conflicts, like the Syrian civil war. Inside Ukraine, the ongoing fighting and broader disruption are making life harder for Ukrainians as they struggle to keep their country independent. Doctors Without Borders has suspended its operations, and other aid groups are wary of getting caught in the crossfire, particularly since U.S. intelligence suggests Russia will target prominent figures in civil society to try to weaken Ukraine. Buckner said her Ukrainians colleagues are â€œpatriotsâ€ who are balancing their desire to be safe with their commitment to helping others. â€œWeâ€™re all living with fears that there would be targeting of many kinds, but thatâ€™s one of the elements of a faith-based humanitarian organization: Itâ€™s really a cause, itâ€™s really a calling,â€ she said. â€œThat doesnâ€™t make it easier, but it makes it more livable.â€ Many Ukrainians have not yet received their salaries for the month of February, she noted, worsening the economic toll of the war. Analysts say the most important humanitarian assistance is cash, because trying to buy and ship food, for instance, incurs administrative costs and threatens already dysfunctional supply chains. Meanwhile, thousands of families are facing the difficult decision of whether to separate or try to stay together. Ukraine is not allowing men between the ages of 18 and 60 to leave, saying they must stay to defend their nation. It is widely expected that Russiaâ€™s assault will only become more brutal. Despite Moscowâ€™s claims that it is only attacking military targets, The New York Times verified an instance of a missile hitting a residential building in the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv, and on-the-ground reports say combat is taking place in civilian neighborhoods. Russian forces repeatedly hit civilians and facilities like hospitals in their recent offensive in Syria. â€œI presume everyone understands we have not yet seen real war in Ukraine,â€ Artyom Lukin, an international relations scholar at the Far Eastern Federal University in Vladivostok, Russia, tweeted on Saturday. â€œItâ€™s obvious the Russian military is under the order not to harm civilians and the infrastructure. Real war begins once this self-restraint is lifted. I fear to think what follows after this.â€

Title: Videos Show Missile Hitting Kyiv Apartment Building, Injuries Reported
Text: Multiple videos show the moment a missile slammed into an apartment building in Ukraineâ€™s capital city, Kyiv. The missile strike took place Saturday morning as Russian forces continued their invasion of the country. Videos verified by The New York Times show the missile impact at several angles and the destruction left in its wake. Videos and photos verified by The New York Times showed a residential building struck by a missile in southwestern Kyiv, about 1.5 miles from Sikorsky Memorial Airport, on Saturday morning. Videos showed rescue and evacuation efforts underway.  The high-rise apartment building is near the cityâ€™s two passenger airports. Though no fatalities have been reported, a rescue worker said six civilians were injured in the attack, according to The Associated Press. One video published by The New York Times showed rescue workers carrying an injured woman. U.S. President Joe Biden has issued heavy sanctions against Russia and its leaders and oligarchs, including Russian President Vladimir Putin, in response to the invasion. Biden is now weighing whether to exclude Russia from SWIFT, a high-security network that connects thousands of financial institutions around the world, CNN reported Saturday. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has stood defiant against Putinâ€™s invasion of his country, and turned down an American offer early Saturday to be evacuated from Kyiv. â€œThe fight is here,â€ Zelenskyy said, according to the Ukrainian Embassy in the U.K. â€œI need ammunition, not a ride.â€

Title: Russian Vodka Is Getting Taken Off The Shelves Over Putin's Invasion Of Ukraine
Text: Some stores in the United States and Canada will not be selling Russian-made liquor for the time being, as a response to Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. New Hampshire Gov. Chris Sununu (R) signed an executive order on Saturday instructing all New Hampshire Liquor and Wine Outlet locations â€• state-run liquor stores that sell alcohol tax-free â€• to â€œbegin removing Russian-made and Russian-branded spirits.â€ This morning I signed an Executive Order instructing @nhliquorwine outlets to begin removing Russian-made and Russian-branded spirits from our liquor and wine outlets until further notice. New Hampshire stands with the people of Ukraine in their fight for freedom. ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ â€œNew Hampshire stands with the people of Ukraine in their fight for freedom,â€ he added. Also on Saturday, Ohio Governor Mike DeWine (R) ordered the stateâ€™s commerce department to â€œcease both the purchase & saleâ€ of Russian Standard Vodka, which he said is â€œthe only overseas, Russian-owned distillery with vodka sold in Ohio.â€ Today I directed @OhioCommerce to cease both the purchase & sale of all vodka made by Russian Standard, the only overseas, Russian-owned distillery with vodka sold in Ohio. Russian Standard's vodka is sold under the brand names of Green Mark Vodka & Russian Standard Vodka. Virginia State Sen. Louise Lucas (D) called for her state to take similar action. We need to take strong actions to support Ukraine, so I am calling on @GovernorVA to order the removal of all Russian Vodka and any other Russian products from our ABC stores immediately. In Canada, the government of Ontario ordered the provinceâ€™s Liquor Control Board to remove all Russian products from its 679 stores, Reuters reported. And the Newfoundland and Labrador Liquor Corporation announced Friday it had â€œmade the decision to remove products of Russian origin from its shelves,â€ mentioning â€œRussian Standard Vodka and Russian Standard Platinum Vodkaâ€ in particular. ğŸ“¢ The Newfoundland and Labrador Liquor Corporation, along with other Liquor jurisdictions throughout Canada, has made the decision to remove products of Russian origin from its shelves. These include Russian Standard Vodka and Russian Standard Platinum Vodka. Some privately owned liquor stores are also pausing the sale of Russian products. One store manager in Wichita, Kansas, told The Hill that he viewed taking Russian vodka off the shelves as a â€œtiny sanction.â€ Others in the food and beverage industries have reacted in different ways. One one Quebec restaurant raised some eyebrows when it announced in a since-deleted post that it would be removing the word â€œpoutineâ€ from the menu in solidarity with Ukraine. Though the Russian presidentâ€™s name is indeed written as â€œVladimir Poutineâ€ in French, he has no connection to the regional dish that consists of French fries, gravy and cheese curds. On Saturday, the assault on Ukraine continued for a third day, with Russian troops closing in on Kyiv. Ukrainian President Volodymr Zelenskyy had posted multiple defiant videos indicating he was remaining in the capital to fight. In Russia, Putinâ€™s decision to invade Ukraine has been met with massive anti-war protests, in which demonstrators risked arrest and harsh penalties.

Title: Jon Stewart Praises 'Grace' Of Comedian-Turned-President Volodymyr Zelenskyy
Text: Comedian Jon Stewart expressed admiration and respect on Saturday for Volodymyr Zelenskyy, who was a successful comedian before being elected Ukraineâ€™s president. The former â€œDaily Showâ€ host discussed Zelenskyy with writers Robby Slowik and Rob Christensen on his new show, â€œThe Problem With Jon Stewart.â€ â€œWe are comedians, and we know the general brand of cowardice that runs through our business,â€ said Stewart. That, he said, was in stark contrast to the actions of Zelenskyy, who has emerged as a strong wartime leader during Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. Zelenskyy has posted videos expressing his resolution to stay in Kyiv, the countryâ€™s capital, and fight, despite threats to his life. When the United States offered to evacuate Zelenskyy from the city, he reportedly said, â€œThe fight is here; I need ammunition, not a ride.â€ In a new video on Feb. 26, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky pushes back on what he says is misinformation: â€œWe aren't going to lay down our arms. We are going to defend our nation.â€  â€œWeâ€™re watching Shecky Greene transform into Churchill,â€ Stewart said, a reference to the nightclub comedian who was a frequent guest on Johnny Carsonâ€™s â€œTonight Show,â€ and former British Prime Minister Winston Churchill, who led the United Kingdom during World War II. Thoughts. Full video here.  He also imagined a darkly funny scene involving a group of comics complaining about the â€œhorrorsâ€ of their profession â€• like being poorly treated at a comedy club â€• before Zelenskyy chimes in to recount the genuine horrors of war. Stewart praised what he characterized Zelenskyyâ€™s â€œgraceâ€ under the circumstances. â€œWhat this dude is doing, it is incredibly moving,â€ he said.

Title: After 4 Years Of Helping Putin, Trump Claims He Was Tough On Russian Dictator
Text: ORLANDO, Fla. â€• Former President Donald Trump on Saturday continued to claim that Russian President Vladimir Putin would not have invaded Ukraine had Trump been in the White House â€• an assertion that ignores how Trump spent four years advancing policies that matched Putinâ€™s longtime goals. â€œIt would have been so easy for me to stop this travesty,â€ Trump said, while continuing to perpetuate his lie that the 2020 election was â€œstolenâ€ from him. â€œAs everyone understands, this horrific event would not have happened if there wasnâ€™t a rigged election and I was president.â€ Trump was speaking to a few thousand attendees at the annual Conservative Political Action Conference, all of them packed into the expansive main ballroom at Orlandoâ€™s Rosen Shingle Creek hotel, just off the main tourist drag south of the city. Earlier this week, Trump praised Putin as â€œsavvyâ€ and a â€œgeniusâ€ for seizing an entire country and suffering only â€œtwo dollarsâ€™ worth of sanctions.â€ Thirteen months after leaving office, Trump remains the most influential voice in the Republican Party, particularly among the sorts of activists drawn to events like CPAC. Hundreds of attendees wore â€œMake American Great Againâ€ caps, â€œTrump 2024â€ T-shirts and â€œTrump Wonâ€ buttons. The biggest, busiest vendors in the exhibit hall were the ones selling Trump gear. From the stage, the one person getting the most shout-outs and praise was the president who tried to overthrow the republic in his attempt to remain in power despite losing his election by millions of votes. â€œThis is Donald Trumpâ€™s party, and Iâ€™m a Donald Trump Republican,â€ said Rep. Matt Gaetz of Florida, a few hours before Trumpâ€™s arrival. Saturday night, Trump continued his attacks on U.S. and NATO leaders, blaming President Joe Biden, a Democrat, for Putinâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. â€œTheyâ€™re not so smart. Theyâ€™re looking the opposite of smart,â€ Trump said. â€œPutin is playing Biden like a drum, and itâ€™s not a pretty thing.â€ Trump repeatedly praised Putin for at least a decade prior to running for president as he tried to build a condominium tower in Moscow. In a 2007 letter, he told Putin he was â€œa big fan.â€ Trump continued to push his â€œTrump Tower Moscowâ€ project even as he ran for president in 2015 and 2016, and publicly praised Putin as a better leader than then-President Barack Obama. In 2016, Trump openly asked for Russiaâ€™s help as he ran against Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton. He subsequently used material stolen by Russian spies to attack Clinton every day in the final stretch of the race, even though he knew it had been stolen by Russian spies. Once in the White House, Trump repeatedly attacked NATO and the European Union â€• actions that aligned with Putinâ€™s long-term objectives of weakening or destroying both institutions. He falsely claimed that the military alliance created by the United States after World War II and the free-trade zone were somehow cheating Americans. He mused about withdrawing from NATO entirely, and reportedly intended to do so in a second term. Trump also continued to praise Putin and defend him, even telling the world in 2018 that he believed Putin over his own intelligence agencies regarding Putinâ€™s work to get Trump elected. A year later, he tried to have Russia readmitted to the G7 group of large democratic economies, from which it was expelled for invading and annexing Crimea in 2014. Trump said he understood Russiaâ€™s need to keep the Crimean Peninsula because it had built a base there for its â€œlarge and powerful submarines.â€ Also in 2019, Trump tried to extort Volodymyr Zelenskyy, then the newly elected president of Ukraine, into smearing Biden, at the time the Democrat he most feared as a 2020 opponent, using $391 million in congressionally approved military aid as leverage. The aid was released only after a whistleblower complaint about it became public, and the episode was the basis of the first of Trumpâ€™s two impeachments. Trump, despite losing the election by 7 million votes nationally and 306-232 in the Electoral College, became the first president in more than two centuries of elections to refuse to hand over power peacefully. His incitement of the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol â€• his last-ditch attempt to remain in office â€• killed five people, including a police officer. The attack also injured another 140 officers and led to four police suicides. Trump is now under investigation by federal and state officials in multiple jurisdictions. New York state Attorney General Letitia James has been conducting a civil probe of his family business, while the district attorney in Manhattan has been running a criminal investigation. Meanwhile, the district attorney in Fulton County, Georgia, has impaneled a special grand jury to focus on Trumpâ€™s attempt to coerce state officials to â€œfindâ€ enough votes to overturn his loss of that state to Biden in 2020. And the House Jan. 6 committee has been subpoenaing more and more former and current Trump aides to determine his precise role in that dayâ€™s events, while the Department of Justice has confirmed that it is investigating at least one element of Trumpâ€™s scheme to remain in power: the submission of fake Trump â€œelectorsâ€ in states that Biden won. At a Jan. 29 rally, Trump asked his followers to stage â€œthe biggest protests we have ever had in Washington, D.C., in New York, in Atlanta and elsewhereâ€ if prosecutors come after him, â€œbecause our country and our elections are corrupt.â€ Despite this, Trump continues to dominate his party and is openly speaking about running for the presidency again in 2024.

Title: Eurovision Song Contest Bans Russia For 2022 After Ukraine Invasion
Text: Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine is getting the country kicked out the Eurovision Song Contest. For this year, anyway. The annual contest was set to take place in Turin, Italy, from May 10-14. The European Broadcasting Union (EBU), the organization that puts on the event, announced Friday that no Russian act will be participating this year. â€œThe decision reflects concern that, in light of the unprecedented crisis in Ukraine, the inclusion of a Russian entry in this yearâ€™s Contest would bring the competition into disrepute,â€ the statement read. The EBU said it remains â€œdedicated to protecting the values of a cultural competition which promotes international exchange and understanding, brings audiences together, celebrates diversity through music and unites Europe on one stage.â€ Russiaâ€™s entry last year, Manizha, came in 9th with â€œRussian Women.â€ Many Russians objected to her appearance because of her support for womenâ€™s rights and the LGBT community. Ukraine is still participating and will be represented by a rap group called Kalush Orchestra. Although the EBU describes itself as an apolitical member organization of broadcasters committed to upholding the values of public service, Eurovision has gotten political at times. In 2016, the act representing the Ukraine performed a song that was politically directed at Russiaâ€™s deportation of the Tatars from Crimea. In 2014, Ukraine and Russia had dueling songs that referred to their ongoing conflicts that inspired this John Oliver explainer.

Title: Actor From Cringey 'Dear Putin' Video Says She 'Easily' Could Have Become A Dictator Herself
Text: Actor AnnaLynne McCord went viral on Thursday after posting a video on social media where she apologized to Russian President Vladimir Putin for not being his mother. Now, the former star of last decadeâ€™s â€œ90210â€ reboot is explaining why she chose to step into a serious geopolitical conflict with a message that if she had been his mother, he would have been loved so much heâ€™d never think of invading sovereign nations like Ukraine. The 34-year-old McCord told BuzzFeed that she herself could have become a tyrant if sheâ€™d had different life experiences. â€œI know how I could easily have moved in the direction of becoming a dictator myself,â€ McCord said. â€œIf certain circumstances of my life were different, were I a little less bent toward healing and more toward vindication, I could have been a darkly powerful person.â€ In the now-viral 2-minute, 20-second video, McCord explains in partial rhyme that if Putin had been her child, â€œThe world would have been warm / So much laughter and joy / And nothing would harm.â€ She told BuzzFeed she was inspired to record the Putin poem after waking up â€œin anguishâ€ over â€œthe children of the war.â€ McCord said she sympathizes with â€œchildren who grow into adults and become people who do historically horrifying thingsâ€ because she personally understands â€œearly life trauma.â€ Though the video was directed at Putin, McCord told BuzzFeed that her mission is raising awareness about the changes needed within â€œeducation systemsâ€ to â€œprotect children and stop creating dictators and abusers and enslavers and rapists and bullies.â€ BuzzFeed also revealed that McCord recorded a longer version of the video that she has only released on Vimeo, where she implores Putin to consider how a war could lead to more motherless children who grow up to be â€œcruel.â€ You can see that version of the video below:

Title: From 'Rigged Election' To No Keystone XL: GOP Shifts Blame For Putin's Invasion
Text: According to many Republicans, itâ€™s President Joe Bidenâ€™s fault that Russia invaded Ukraine. Republicans have turned Vladimir Putinâ€™s invasion into a political opportunity for the party, claiming that Bidenâ€™s weakness is the reason Putin went forward with his war. Some GOP candidates have even started fundraising off the Russian invasion. Erik Aadland, running for Congress in Coloradoâ€™s 7th District, quickly sent an email Wednesday night saying Putin was â€œwalking all over Joe Biden just like China and Iranâ€ and asking supporters to donate to his campaign to take the House back from Democrats. Virginia state Sen. Bryce Reeves, also running for Congress, sent a similar email saying Putin invaded because Americaâ€™s enemies â€œknow that Joe Biden is weak and depends on the support of the Woke Democrats for his political survival.â€ â€œJoe Bidenâ€™s weakness has helped bring the world to this point,â€ added Florida congressional candidate Brian Mast in his own fundraising pitch. But as Faith Hillis, a professor of Russian history at the University of Chicago said, â€œWhat matters is that Putin denies a sovereign stateâ€™s right to exist and to make its own domestic and foreign policy. And he invaded completely unprovoked (and even without the staged provocation that many expected). This is akin to Hitlerâ€™s invasion of Poland. Thatâ€™s it.â€ Here are some of the GOPâ€™s excuses for Putinâ€™s deadly, provoked land grab: Leading the way, not surprisingly, has been former President Donald Trump, who is a longtime admirer of the Russian president and his grip on the country. Trump has said Putinâ€™s invasion was â€œpretty smartâ€ and â€œsavvy,â€ even claiming that the Russian leader was going into Ukraine to be a â€œpeacekeeper.â€ And of course, Trump hasnâ€™t been able to resist the opportunity to tout his big lie that Democrats stole the presidential election from him through fraud. In an interview with Fox News on Wednesday night, Trump claimed that this whole situation in Ukraine is happening because of the 2020 outcome. â€œHe sees the weakness and stupidity of this administration,â€ Trump said of the Russian president. â€œAs an American, I am angry and saddened. It happened because of a rigged election.â€ These three things donâ€™t really seem related, but for Republicans, they all go together into one big reason why Putin invaded Ukraine. â€œPutin is a thug, and he has been empowered and emboldened by Bidenâ€™s disastrous withdrawal from Afghanistan and his approval of Russiaâ€™s Nord Stream 2 pipeline while killing Americaâ€™s Keystone XL pipeline,â€ Sen. Steve Daines (R-Mont.) tweeted Thursday. Sen. Marsha Blackburn (R-Tenn.) also argued that Putin â€œknew that during President Trump, he could not do this.â€ â€œThey watched what happened in Afghanistan. They watched the debacle that took place there. ... They have watched Joe Biden as heâ€™s made decisions like stopping the Keystone, ending drilling on federal land. Things that really hindered the U.S. and caused this inflation,â€ Blackburn said Thursday on Newsmax TV. Biden has not ended drilling on federal land. Rep. Lauren Boebert (R-Colo.) tweeted Wednesday that Bidenâ€™s â€œpathetic energy policiesâ€ are â€œessentially funding Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine by forcing Europe to rely on them for their energy needs.â€ Sen. Tommy Tuberville (R-Ala.) â€• the former football coach who didnâ€™t know why the United States fought World War II â€• told 1819 News this week that Putin was invading Ukraine simply to get more farmland. â€œHe canâ€™t feed his people,â€ Tuberville said. â€œItâ€™s a communist country, so he canâ€™t feed his people, so they need more farmland.â€ Itâ€™s hard to debunk something thatâ€™s just so off the mark, but there is absolutely no truth to this being the cause of the invasion. Russia has also not been â€œa communist countryâ€ for 30 years.

Title: Seth Meyers Reminds Trump: Ukraine's Invasion Isn't 'A F**king Real Estate Deal'
Text: Russiaâ€™s unprovoked invasion of Ukraine has shocked the whole world except apparently former President Donald Trump, Seth Meyers lamented Thursday night. â€œSo, if youâ€™re like most people, you were shocked and horrified,â€ he said. â€œBut if you were Donald Trump, apparently you were at Mar-a-Lago watching it with a bunch of Palm Beach plastic surgeons and their third wives and thinking, â€˜You really got to hand it to Vladimir Putin.â€™â€ Meyers pointed to footage of Trump at a super PAC fundraiser at his Florida resort Wednesday. As Ukrainians waited fearfully for its neighborâ€™s imminent assault on their country, Trump was on the event stage lauding the Russian presidentâ€™s strategy. â€œI mean, heâ€™s taking over a country for $2 worth of sanctions, Iâ€™d say thatâ€™s pretty smart,â€ Trump told attendees. â€œHeâ€™s taking over a country ... a great piece of land with a lot of people, and just walking right in.â€ Meyers expressed disgust at the property mogulâ€™s thinking. â€œFirst of all, stop talking about everything like itâ€™s a fucking real estate deal. Itâ€™s an illegal war against a sovereign nation, not an empty lot in Atlantic City,â€ he said. â€œSecond, if you ever find yourself at a fancy high-dollar fundraiser clinking Champagne glasses while the keynote speaker applauds an illegal and catastrophic war that will cause mass suffering and destabilize an entire continent, maybe take a moment to text your therapist and ask, â€˜Am I a bad person?â€™â€ Watch below on â€œLate Night.â€

Title: Ukraine President To EU Leaders: 'This Might Be The Last Time You See Me Alive'
Text: Ukraineâ€™s president issued a somber warning to leaders of the European Union as Russian forces continue to violently invade the country. â€œThis might be the last time you see me alive,â€ Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy reportedly told European Union leaders on a conference call Thursday night. Zelenskyy is currently hiding in Ukraineâ€™s capital city of Kyiv as more than 100,000 Russian troops continue to attack the country on Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s orders. â€œWe were supposed to talk on the phone this morning, but he was no longer available,â€ Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi told his Parliament Friday morning of Zelenskyy. Swedish Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson, who was also on the Thursday-night call with Zelenskyy, reportedly told the Swedish News Agency that â€œthis may have been the last time we saw Zelensky.â€ Zelenskyy said in an early Thursday-morning address that Russian saboteurs had entered Kyiv and said intelligence found â€œthe enemy has identified me as the number one target.â€ U.S. President Joe Biden issued more sanctions on Russian banks and high-profile oligarchs Thursday, but stopped short of sending troops in. â€œWe have no intention of fighting Russia,â€ Biden said during a press conference. â€œWe want to send an unmistakable message, though, that the United States and our allies will defend every inch of NATO territory.â€ More than 1,700 anti-war protestors have been arrested across more than 50 Russian cities in a rare display of public outrage at Putinâ€™s invasion.

Title: Europe Braces For Refugees As Russia Attacks Ukraine's Capital
Text: Russiaâ€™s military invasion of Ukraine, which reached the outskirts of the capital city Kyiv on Friday, has raised alarm in neighboring European countries that a humanitarian crisis is brewing on their doorstep. Speaking at the U.N. Headquarters in New York on Wednesday, U.S. Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield warned that Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, a country of 44 million, could â€œcreate a new refugee crisis, one of the largest facing the world today,â€ displacing up to 5 million people. â€œRussiaâ€™s actions could cause a spike in food prices and lead to even more desperate hunger in places like Libya, Yemen and Lebanon,â€ Thomas-Greenfield said. â€œThe tidal waves of suffering this war will cause are unthinkable.â€ U.N. Human Rights office spokesperson Ravina Shamdasani gave an account of the human toll of the attack on Friday, saying there have been at least 127 civilian casualties in Ukraine, including 25 people killed and 102 wounded as a result of â€œshelling and air strikes.â€ Shamdasani noted that this could be an underestimate. U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees Filippo Grandi said the agency is monitoring reports of people fleeing their homes.
