For the Biden administration and its partners, the coming days will involve complex diplomacy and likely pressure on Moscow â€• though officials and experts have struggled to craft an effective strategy given Putinâ€™s focus on the matter and frequently shifting narrative of the crisis. â€œItâ€™s hard to listen to this speech and believe that any of the partial concessions that have been suggested - withdrawing the possibility of NATO membership from Ukraine in particular - would have made any difference,â€ national security commentator Cheryl Rofer tweeted amid the Russian leaderâ€™s remarks.

Title: White House Wonâ€™t Say If Russian Movements Into Donbas Will Trigger Massive Sanctions
Text: WASHINGTON â€“ The White House promised additional actions in response to Russiaâ€™s decision to recognize the â€œindependenceâ€ of two separatist regions in Ukraine, but would not say whether troop movements there would trigger the massive package of sanctions President Joe Biden said would answer a further invasion. â€œRussian troops moving into Donbas by itself would not be a new step,â€ a senior administration official said Monday on condition of anonymity, following reports that Russian troops were crossing the border into eastern Ukraine. The official said that Russian leader Vladimir Putinâ€™s decision to offer military protection to pro-Russian separatists would get a further response Tuesday, beyond the sanctions the White House announced Monday to punish anyone doing business with the two enclaves. â€œWe will take further action tomorrow to hold Russia accountable,â€ the official said. He would not specify further about what the action would be. Russia has for years denied that it had forces in eastern Ukraine, but now appears to be doing so openly, the official said. â€œThere have been Russian forces in these areas throughout,â€ the official said, adding the United States would be monitoring events in the coming hours to see how far Putin goes. â€œWe will observe and assess what actions Russia actually takes and respond.â€ In a lengthy speech on Monday, Putin announced his decision to recognize Donetsk and Luhansk as independent states â€• an action the Biden administration considers an escalation of the Russian leaderâ€™s moves to surround Ukraine by some 190,000 forces in recent weeks. â€œThis was a speech to the Russian people to justify war,â€ the official said. â€œThis is Potemkin politics, President Putin accelerating the conflict that he created.â€ In 2014, Putin also invaded and annexed Crimea from its neighbor, which gained independence during the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991.

Title: Vladimir Putin Oversees Missile Tests Amid Rising Tensions Over Ukraine
Text: Russian President Vladimir Putin oversaw the launch of three ballistic and cruise missiles on Saturday as part of nuclear exercises amid rising tensions over the countryâ€™s possible looming invasion of Ukraine. Putin watched the drills â€• which saw the projectiles strike sea and land-based targets â€• in the Kremlin with Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko. Two of the weapons on display Saturday were designed to be able to slip past United States missile defenses, according to The New York Times. Russiaâ€™s Defense Ministry claimed the maneuvers, following Russiaâ€™s military buildup on its border with Ukraine, had been planned for some time. Russia does hold annual drills of its strategic nuclear forces, The Associated Press noted, although in the past they have been held in the fall. President Joe Biden on Friday said he is â€œconvincedâ€ that Putinâ€™s Russia would soon invade its neighboring country. Biden added that he believed the attack would focus on Kyiv, Ukraineâ€™s capital with a population of 2.8 million people. Hilary Hanson contributed reporting.

Title: 'I Hate This Sport': Silver Medalist Figure Skater At Olympics Says She'll Never Compete Again
Text: Russian figure skater Alexandra Trusova won a silver medal Thursday at the Winter Olympics â€• but apparently didnâ€™t take a shine to it. â€œI hate skating. I hate it. I hate this sport,â€ she shouted afterward, according to The Guardian. â€œI will never go out on the ice again!â€ Trusova was apparently annoyed that her five quadruple jumps didnâ€™t earn her gold over the winner, teammate Anna Shcherbakova. Shcherbakova performed a less-athletic routine in the long program, but was already ahead of Trusova from the short program. Of course, both skaters were helped by the implosion of scandal-plagued teammate Kamila Valieva, who fell from first place to fourth with a disastrous free skate. Valievaâ€™s sobbing set the tone for an emotional day among the Russians. Trusova cried, too, complaining that she was the only skater among the trio without a gold medal, The Associated Press reported. She did not compete in the team event, which the Russians won on spectacular efforts by Valieva. But that gold is now in jeopardy as the investigation continues into Valieva testing positive for a banned heart medication said to boost stamina. Trusova later said she was frustrated because she was not winning major events despite her many â€œtechnically challengingâ€ jumps, People noted. She said her comments about quitting were â€œemotionalâ€ and she missed her family. She did not commit to competing at the world championships in March, AP wrote.

Title: Biden 'Convinced' That Putin Has Decided To Invade Ukraine
Text: President Joe Biden said he is â€œconvincedâ€ that Russian President Vladimir Putin has made up his mind and plans to invade Ukraine. â€œAs of this moment, Iâ€™m convinced heâ€™s made the decision. We have reason to believe that,â€ Biden said at a Friday afternoon press conference. "Do you have any indication about whether Pres. Putin has made a decision on whether to invade?"Pres. Biden: "As of this moment I'm convinced he's made the decision. We have reason to believe that."  Biden spoke earlier in the day with allies to discuss Russiaâ€™s military build-up around Ukraineâ€™s borders. Citing â€œsignificant intelligence,â€ Biden said a Russian attack could occur in the coming days and would be focused on the nationâ€™s capital, Kyiv. Biden also said Russiaâ€™s â€œphony allegationsâ€ that Ukraine is planning to attack the separatist-controlled Donbas â€œdefies logic.â€ Biden added at the Friday press conference that there have also been upticks of cease-fire violations in eastern Ukraine.

Title: Kamila Valieva Takes 4th Amid Olympic Doping Controversy
Text: Russiaâ€™s Kamila Valieva, the teen star at the center of an Olympic doping scandal, took fourth in womenâ€™s figure skating at the Beijing Games on Thursday. The 15-year-old, who was allowed to compete in China despite testing positive for a banned heart medication in December, was the overwhelming favorite to win the marquee event. Russiaâ€™s Anna Shcherbakova and Alexandra Trusova won gold and silver, and Japanâ€™s Kaori Sakamoto took bronze. Valieva skated last after scoring 82.16 in the short program on Tuesday, but she disappointed with a total of 141.93 in the free skate. Her fourth-place finish means there will be a medal ceremony for the event. The International Olympic Committee said it wouldnâ€™t have held a ceremony if Valieva had medaled.

Title: Russian Speedskater Flips Double Bird After Beating U.S. And Makes Iffy Excuse
Text: Olympic speedskater Daniil Aldoshkin flashed a double bird after his Russian team beat the United States in the team pursuit semifinals on Tuesday â€• but he seemed to claim that he flipped off no one in particular. â€œI threw up my hands, I have the first medal, the first Olympics,â€ Aldoshkin said at the Beijing Winter Olympics, per RT.com. â€œI didnâ€™t mean anything like that. Iâ€™m sorry if this offended anyone.â€ The gesture added more tension to a Games now dominated by the doping scandal involving star Russian figure skater Kamila Valieva. Russiaâ€™s Olympic team was sanctioned for systemic drug offenses at the Sochi 2014 Games and is known as the Russian Olympic Committee in Beijing. So, maybe Aldoshkin was merely exhibiting defiance to the world, or declaring he and his teammates were No. 1 â€” twice? â€œEmotions took over at the finish line,â€ Russian Skating Union President Alexei Kravtsov said, per RT. â€œThere was no subtext in this action. We are sorry if someone differently perceived this situation and offended someone. On behalf of the Russian Skating Union, we offer our official apologies.â€ Turns out Russia wasnâ€™t No. 1 overall, anyway. The ROC lost to Norway and settled for silver. The Americans earned bronze. H/T USA Today

Title: Adam Rippon Shreds Russian Olympic Doping Scandal With 2 Blistering Words
Text: Former U.S. figure skater Adam Rippon on Monday slammed the womenâ€™s figure skating competition at the 2022 Winter Olympics as â€œa complete jokeâ€ following the Court of Arbitration for Sportâ€™s decision to allow Russiaâ€™s Kamila Valieva to still compete despite a failed drug test. â€œFuck this,â€ a furious Rippon tweeted in a lengthy thread calling for Valieva, 15, to be sent home and banned from the Games, while also showing empathy for the teenager caught up in Russiaâ€™s doping scandal that has seen its athletes banned from competing under their own flag in Beijing. Fuck this. â€œEvery other athlete in this competition is having their whole Olympic experience altered to accommodate an athlete with a FAILED test,â€ wrote Rippon, who won bronze in Pyeongchang in 2018 and is coaching U.S. figure skater Mariah Bell at the Games. â€œThe entire ROC should not be here. Theyâ€™ve exploited a child for results and continue to cheat and suffer no consequences.â€ â€œNone of this is fair,â€ he continued. â€œYou can be heartbroken for this 15 year old girl and at the same time be heartbroken that every other skater in this event will have to compete knowing that the competition is not clean.â€ On Monday, the International Olympic Committee said it would â€œnot be appropriateâ€ to hold a medal ceremony for the event if Valieva wins a medal. â€œI am so angry,â€ said Rippon. â€œThe ladies event tomorrow is a complete joke. Itâ€™s not a real competition and it most likely wonâ€™t even have a medal ceremony. So many Olympic experiences stolen from clean athletes who got here without the help of performance enhancing drugs. What a shame.â€ Read Ripponâ€™s full Twitter thread here: If they are truly worried about the irreparable harm, set her up with proper counseling to deal with the incredibly sad situation she finds herself in and SEND HER HOME. The irreparable harm that will be done is to the entire Olympic Games. She shouldnâ€™t be allowed to compete. Every other athlete in this competition is having their whole Olympic experience altered to accommodate an athlete with a FAILED test. The entire ROC should not be here. Theyâ€™ve exploited a child for results and continue to cheat and suffer no consequences. None of this is fair. You can be heartbroken for this 15 year old girl and at the same time be heartbroken that every other skater in this event will have to compete knowing that the competition is not clean. The infuriating fact is that everything that makes Kami an amazing skater (spins, flow, flexibility) none of it can come from a drug. But, her team didnâ€™t want to play by the rules. I am so angry. The ladies event tomorrow is a complete joke. Itâ€™s not a real competition and it most likely wonâ€™t even have a medal ceremony. So many Olympic experiences stolen from clean athletes who got here without the help of performance enhancing drugs. What a shame. Fuck this.

Title: Biden Keeps Up Pressure On Putin To Pull Back Russian Troops, End Ukraine Crisis
Text: WASHINGTON â€• President Joe Biden on Tuesday welcomed Russian overtures toward ending a crisis in Ukraine, but reiterated that he was ready to respond with overwhelming economic sanctions if an invasion occurs. â€œWe should give diplomacy every chance to succeed,â€ Biden said in brief remarks from the East Room of the White House. â€œWe will not sacrifice basic principles, though.â€ Those principles, he said, include Ukraineâ€™s sovereignty and its right to territorial integrity. â€œThe United States is prepared no matter what happens,â€ he said, noting that â€œan invasion remains distinctly possible.â€ Biden made clear to Americans that he has no intention of sending U.S. troops to Ukraine, though he has approved the training of Ukrainian troops and the transfer of weapons to the country. He also warned that should an invasion take place, there would be economic consequences in the United States, including higher gas prices. â€œI will not pretend this will not be painless,â€ he said, adding that he would try to alleviate such pain as best he could. Nevertheless, he said that in the event Russia invades, a response would be necessary. â€œIf we do not stand for freedom where it is at risk today, weâ€™ll surely pay a steeper price tomorrow.â€ Biden also at one point spoke directly to Russian citizens. â€œWeâ€™re not targeting the people of Russia,â€ he said. â€œWe do not seek to destabilize Russia. To the citizens of Russia, you are not our enemy. And I do not believe you want a bloody, destructive war against Ukraine, a country and a people with whom you share such deep ties of family, history and culture.â€ Hours earlier, Russian President Vladimir Putin, following a meeting with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, had indicated that he was ready for talks regarding Ukraine and military transparency. Prior to that, a Russian defense official had said some Russian troops would be leaving the area. Biden has spent much of his time in recent weeks working to dissuade Putin from further aggressive action toward Ukraine, and urging allies in Western Europe to present a common front. Last week, with Scholz at his side in the White House, he declared that a lucrative natural gas pipeline from Russia to Germany would never become operational if Putin moved further into Ukraine. â€œThere will no longer be a Nord Stream 2,â€ Biden said. â€œWe will bring an end to it.â€ Since then, he has again spoken to Putin, as well as to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, from Camp David. Putin has amassed more than 100,000 troops along Ukraineâ€™s border in recent months, raising fears of another invasion. In 2014, he invaded and annexed Crimea from Ukraine, which gained independence during the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991. He later moved into the eastern part of the country as well. In order to pressure Putin, Bidenâ€™s administration has relied on the strategy of releasing intelligence assessments about Russiaâ€™s preparations and its likely intentions. Last month, for example, the administration made public indications that Russia intended to release a video depicting a fake Ukrainian attack on its forces â€• including actors playing corpses â€• to justify an incursion.

Title: National Security Adviser Says Russia, Not U.S., Is â€˜Source Of The Alarmâ€™ In Ukraine
Text: White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan responded to claims on Sunday that the United States is sparking panic in Ukraine about a potential Russian invasion, stressing that it is Russiaâ€™s closing in of the smaller nation that is â€œthe source of the alarm.â€ The intelligence official appeared on CNNâ€™s â€œState of the Union,â€ where he spoke to host Jake Tapper about what has become the biggest security crisis between Russia and the West since the Cold War. The U.S. recently announced plans to evacuate most of its diplomatic staff from Kyiv and ordered 3,000 troops to Poland on top of the 1,700 who are on their way there in demonstration of American commitment to worried NATO allies. At a press conference, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said that â€œthe best friend for enemies is panic in our country. And all this information helps only to create panic. It doesnâ€™t help us.â€ When asked whether the U.S. is dangerously sparking panic in Ukraine, Sullivan said the White House is trying to â€œbe transparent to American citizens that they should leave Ukraine immediately, because there will not be a military evacuation in the event of an invasion.â€ â€œOnly one country has amassed more than 100,000 troops on the border of Ukraine. Itâ€™s not the United States. Itâ€™s Russia. That is the source of the alarm,â€ Sullivan said. â€œAnd we are trying to tell Ukrainians to prepare and be ready for this as well, as well as coordinate with our NATO allies and partners, so that we are able to defend NATO territory and deter any further Russian aggression should they move on Ukraine.â€ â€œBut fundamentally, our view is that weâ€™re not going to give Russia the opportunity to conduct a surprise here, to spring something on Ukraine or the world,â€ he continued. â€œWe are going to make sure that we are laying out for the world what we see as transparently and plainly as we possibly can, and share that information as widely as we can. Thatâ€™s what we have done. Thatâ€™s what we will continue to do.â€ Sullivan recently also warned that U.S. intelligence shows that Russia could invade Ukraine within days, and before the Winter Olympics in Beijing end on Feb. 20. The national security adviser told reporters on Friday that intelligence shows military action could start with missile and air attacks, followed by a ground offensive. Russia has continued to deny that it plans to invade, despite its continued buildup of firepower on three sides of Ukraine. National Security adviser Jake Sullivan tells @JakeTapper that Russian forces are in a place where an invasion could take place before the end of the Beijing Winter Olympics.â€œA major military action could begin by Russia in Ukraine any day now,â€ he says. #CNNSOTU  â€œThe hysteria of the White House is more indicative than ever,â€ said Russian Foreign Ministry spokesperson Maria Zakharova, according to The Associated Press. â€œThe Anglo-Saxons need a war. At any cost. Provocations, misinformation and threats are a favorite method of solving their own problems.â€ The Defense Department has publicly warned that Russian operatives were planning a false-flag operation, a plan in which the country would stage a fake attack on itself to have an excuse to intervene in Ukraine. Earlier this month, intelligence officials alleged there is a Russian plot to fabricate a graphic video â€• allegedly staged with explosions and corpses â€• as pretext for an attack on Ukraine. The claim received scrutiny from some reporters who called out the White House for not providing evidence for such a strong allegation. â€œFirst, weâ€™re not putting forward this intelligence to start a war, which has happened in the past, Jake. We are putting forward this intelligence to stop a war. And I think that fundamentally gives it, at the outset, a different level of credibility,â€ Sullivan said Sunday, adding that a false-flag operation is â€œconsistent with the Russian playbook.â€ Russia indeed has a history of using false-flag operations, one example being in 1968 when the Kremlin used its intelligence service to create false-flag incidents to justify Soviet military intervention in Czechoslovakia. â€œAnd then, third, if you look at Russian media, they are laying the groundwork for a potential pretext by raising the possibility of attacks by Ukrainian forces on either Russians themselves or Russiaâ€™s proxy forces in the Donbass,â€ he continued. â€œAnd then, finally, what we have said, stood at the podium and shared with our allies that we have information that we have gathered through intelligence that indicates that there is active planning for this. And itâ€™s not just the United States saying it. We have our NATO allies stepping out and saying it as well, because they have been able to review that intelligence, assess its credibility and reach the same conclusion we have reached. So, I do think the world should be prepared for Russia staging a pretext and then launching a potential military action,â€ he said. On Saturday, President Joe Biden held an hourlong call with Vladimir Putin in which the White House said he told the Russian president that invading Ukraine would cause â€œwidespread human sufferingâ€ and that the West was committed to diplomacy to end the crisis but â€œequally prepared for other scenarios.â€ â€œThere was no fundamental change in the dynamic that has been unfolding now for several weeks, but we believe that we have put ideas on the table that would be in our and our alliesâ€™ interest to pursue, that would enhance European security, and that would also address some of Russiaâ€™s stated concerns, just as we have been clear that we are committed to upholding Ukraineâ€™s sovereignty, territorial integrity and the rights of states to choose their own security arrangements,â€ said a senior administration official who briefed reporters about the call. â€œBut it remains unclear whether Russia is interested in pursuing its goals diplomatically as opposed to through the use of force,â€ the official said. Russia has been in aggressive conflict with Ukraine since 2014, when the latter nationâ€™s Kremlin-friendly leader was ousted by a popular uprising that has demanded a democracy more aligned with the West. Moscow responded by annexing the Crimean Peninsula and backing a separatist insurgency in eastern Ukraine, where fighting has killed over 14,000 people. France and Germany helped broker a 2015 peace deal that helped halt large-scale battles. However, regular clashes have continued with efforts to reach a political settlement having stalled. The current tensions with Russia come as NATO countries deliberate whether to allow Ukraine to enter the alliance â€• a move Russia sees as a major security threat due to its shared borders with Ukraine.

Title: Joe Biden To Speak With Vladimir Putin On Saturday About Ukraine
Text: U.S. President Joe Biden plans to speak with Russian President Vladimir Putin following Russiaâ€™s aggressive military posturing toward Ukraine. Biden plans to talk to Putin on Saturday morning, according to CNN. The call between the two world leaders will take place as Russian forces have increased at the Ukrainian border. And on Friday, the White House said that a possible invasion of Ukraine could take place in a matter of days. The Biden administration also issued a stark warning to Americans in Ukraine to leave the country within 48 hours. Biden also held a phone conference with NATO and European Union leaders on Friday to express his concern that a Russian invasion could be imminent, The New York Times reported.

Title: Security Guard Accused Of Drawing Eyes On Russian Gallery's Painting
Text: A security guard at a Russian art gallery is reportedly facing criminal charges after being accused of drawing eyes on an avant-garde painting from the 1930s that he had been hired to protect. â€œThree Figuresâ€ by Soviet artist Anna Leporskaya was on loan to the Yeltsin Center in Ekaterinburg when the guard drew eyes on two of the paintingâ€™s eyeless figures using a ballpoint pen, the center said Tuesday. Exhibition curator Anna Reshetkina told Russian website ura.ru that it was the guardâ€™s first day on the job, the BBC reported . â€œHis motives are still unknown but the administration believes it was some kind of a lapse in sanity,â€ she said. The painting, which was reportedly insured for roughly $1 million, was sent to Moscow for restoration. The center said the damage can be repaired. The vandalism was first noticed by two visitors in early December who then alerted a gallery employee. The Yeltsin Center reported the damage to police later that month but it was deemed â€œinsignificantâ€ by Ekaterinburgâ€™s ministry of internal affairs, which declined to press charges. A criminal investigation was opened last week after the ministry of culture complained to the prosecutor generalâ€™s office, The Guardian reported, citing Russian news outlets. The guard could face a fine and three months in prison if convicted of vandalizing the art, the BBC reported.

Title: Russian Figure Skater Kamila Valieva Reportedly Tests Positive For Banned Drug
Text: Fifteen-year-old Russian figure skater Kamila Valieva reportedly tested positive for a banned drug â€” news that came out just as Olympics officials vaguely cited legal reasons for delaying her team medal ceremony. Russian newspapers RBC and Kommersant said the teen tested positive for trimetazidine, a drug typically used to treat chest pain. USA Today and Reuters also confirmed the report. Kamila was part of the Russian Olympic Committeeâ€™s six-person team that dominated the three-day figure skating team event during the Winter Games in Beijing, coming in first on Monday ahead of the United States and Japan. The three teams were honored on the ice right after the competition, in which Japan placed third, the U.S. second and the ROC first. But Tuesday nightâ€™s medal ceremony was delayed after news of the Russian teenâ€™s positive drug test. The ROC did not immediately respond to HuffPostâ€™s request for comment. The 15-year-old Russian skating prodigy, heavily favored to win individual gold at the Olympics, delivered one of the major highlights of the Games thus far when she became the first female competitor to land a quadruple jump. The historic first occurred during her free skate, which helped the ROC win the team competition. â€œI do feel this burden a bit, this pressure, because this is my first season among adult skaters,â€ she told The Associated Press. â€œI believe that Iâ€™m coping with this pressure, and sometimes it even pushes me forward. It helps me.â€ Trimetazidine, or TMZ, is an anti-coagulant that increases blood flow to the heart and limits rapid swings in blood pressure. The drug is not approved for use in the U.S. and has been on the World Anti-Doping Agencyâ€™s list of prohibited substances since 2014. Dr. Sadiya Khan, a cardiologist with Northwestern Medicine, told Reuters that the theory behind using TMZ in athletics is that it can enhance blood flow in a healthy person. â€œThe idea behind it would be potentially if you enhance blood flow, you could improve somebodyâ€™s ability to exercise longer or exercise more efficiently by allowing the heart to respond super-normally,â€ Khan told the outlet, adding that thereâ€™s â€œno strong evidenceâ€ the drug gives a performance-enhancing benefit. On Tuesday, International Olympic Committee spokesperson Mark Adams said that the medal ceremony did not happen due to an ongoing legal issue with the International Skating Union. Adams said that the committee will give an update soon. â€œWe have athletes that have won medals involved,â€ he said. According to Russian media, Kamilaâ€™s test sample was obtained before she won the European championship last month in Estonia, where she soared in her performance and led Russiaâ€™s group of elite female figure skaters headed to Beijing. The positive test could cost the ROC its gold medal for the team competition and threaten Kamilaâ€™s chance to win the individual competition. According to the AP, the most famous case of TMZ in sports doping involved Chinese star swimmer Sun Yang, a three-time Olympic champion who ended up facing a three-month ban in 2014. Russian bobsledder Nadezhda Sergeeva tested positive for TMZ at the 2018 Pyeongchang Olympics, was disqualified from the two-woman bobsled event and faced an eight-month ban. Russian athletes are competing in Beijing as the ROC and not under the Russian flag due to a state-sponsored doping scheme at the 2014 Sochi Olympics.

Title: Biden Promises An End To German-Russian Gas Pipeline If Russia Invades Ukraine
Text: WASHINGTON â€” President Joe Biden on Monday reiterated his threat to cancel Russiaâ€™s lucrative, nearly completed natural gas pipeline to Germany should it further invade Ukraine, this time with Germanyâ€™s new chancellor standing beside him at the White House. â€œIf Russia invades, that means tanks and troops cross the border into Ukraine again, there will no longer be a Nord Stream 2,â€ Biden said during a joint East Room news conference with German leader Olaf Scholz. â€œWe will bring an end to it.â€ Russian dictator Vladimir Putin has amassed more than 100,000 troops along Ukraineâ€™s border in recent months, raising the threat of another invasion. In 2014, he invaded and annexed Crimea from its neighbor, which gained independence during the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991. Biden said that Putin still has the option of ending the crisis through diplomatic means, but that he cannot predict what Putin will do. â€œI donâ€™t know that he knows what heâ€™s going to do,â€ Biden said, adding that Putin and Russia will suffer if he goes ahead and invades. â€œWe will impose the most severe sanctions that have ever been imposed.â€ Scholz, who in December took over from longtime Chancellor Angela Merkel, agreed that a new invasion would be severely punished. â€œThere will be a high price for Russia,â€ he said. â€œEven Russia has understood the message now.â€ Scholz, though, did not specifically repeat Bidenâ€™s language about Nord Stream 2, despite attempts from reporters to have him clarify his position. He did say that Germany and the United States are in full agreement on the sanctions. â€œWe will be united,â€ he said. â€œWe are absolutely together.â€ The Biden administration has already adopted the strategy of releasing intelligence assessments about Russian preparations in order to pressure Putin not to invade. Last week, it made public indications that Russia intended to fake an attack on its forces by Ukraine â€” including actors playing corpses â€” to justify an incursion. White House press secretary Jen Psaki at Mondayâ€™s daily press briefing said Russia had a history of using such â€œliesâ€ as a prelude to its aggressive behavior. â€œWe have seen where they have used these tactics in the past,â€ she said. The natural gas pipeline â€” not yet operational â€” had become a sticking point in the discussions. Germany had resisted including it in the package of sanctions threatened against Russia should it invade, but in recent days has signaled that it would support scuttling the project entirely in the event of an invasion. Such a move would significantly damage Russiaâ€™s already hurting economy. â€œRussia needs to be able to sell that gas,â€ Biden said. Scholz, when asked how Germany would replace Russiaâ€™s gas, said his country has been aggressively moving away from fossil fuels to fight climate change, and this would hasten the work to switch to wind, solar and hydrogen. â€œWe are focusing on renewable energies,â€ he said. â€œWe will make sure that this is the profitable future.â€

Title: Biden Admin Officials To Reporters Asking For Evidence: Just Believe Us
Text: U.S. government officials on Thursday twice dismissed questions from reporters who asked for evidence to back up claims, suggesting that the reporters should take the government at its word. During a briefing providing the press updates on escalating tensions between Russia and Ukraine, State Department spokesman Ned Price referenced a report by intelligence officials last month that said Russia was attempting to create a pretext for its troops to invade Ukraine. On Thursday, Price said the U.S. had intelligence suggesting Russia was planning a â€œfalse flag operationâ€ propaganda video to justify an invasion. Associated Press reporter Matt Lee asked: Whereâ€™s the evidence? MUST WATCH: Heated exchange between @APDiploWriter Matt Lee and @StateDeptSpox Ned Price on recently declassified information from the US government that reveals Russia's ongoing propaganda tactics.  In a heated back and forth, Price repeated that Russia was planning to conduct a false flag operation in eastern Ukraine, citing a previous briefing where the plan had been discussed. â€œWhat is the evidence that the plan â€” I mean, this is like crisis actors, really?â€ Lee asked. â€œThis is like Alex Jones territory that youâ€™re getting into now. What evidence do you have that there is some propaganda film in the making?â€ Price said his comments were â€œderived from information known to the U.S. government,â€ again prompting Lee to press him for evidence. â€œI would like some proof that the Russians are doing this,â€ Lee said. Later in the more than five minute back-and-forth, Price suggested Leeâ€™s questioning of the U.S. government was playing into Russiaâ€™s plans. â€œIf you doubt the credibility of the U.S. government, of the British government, of other governments and want to, you know, find solace in information that the Russians are putting out, that is for you to do,â€ Price said. Lee would be right to, as Price puts it, â€œdoubt the credibilityâ€ of a government that has historically been known to lie. For instance, officials lied about weapons of mass destruction in Iraq as a pretext to invade the country in 2003. And the U.S. has a record of lying about civilian casualties, something White House press secretary Jen Psaki was reminded of by a reporter on Thursday. After the White House announced Thursday that a top ISIS leader had been killed, Psaki took questions aboard Air Force One, where she was pressed for details about the operation that left 13 people dead, including six children and four women. Earlier, President Joe Biden said top ISIS militant Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi detonated a suicide bomb that killed himself, his wife and his children during the raid. NPR White House Correspondent Ayesha Rascoe again asked a question reporters often ask: Can you show evidence? â€œJen, will there be any, like, evidence or, like, release to support the idea â€• I mean, I know the U.S. has put out its statement that, you know, [ISIS] detonated the bomb themselves,â€ Rascoe said, according to a press pool transcript of the conversation. â€œBut will the U.S. provide any evidence? Because there may be people that are skeptical of the events that took place and what happened to the civilians.â€ Hereâ€™s how the rest of the exchange unfolded: PSAKI: Skeptical of the U.S. militaryâ€™s assessment when they went and took out an ISIS terror â€• the leader of ISIS? RASCOE: Yes. PSAKI: That they are not providing accurate information â€• RASCOE: Yes. PSAKI: â€” and ISIS is providing accurate information? RASCOE: Well, not ISIS, but, I mean, the U.S. has not always been straightforward about what happens with civilians. And, I mean, that is a fact. PSAKI: Well, as you know, thereâ€™s an extensive process that the Department of Defense undergoes. The president made clear from the beginning, at every point in this process, that doing everything possible to avoid civilian casualties was his priority and his preference. I just reconfirmed, and I think our national security colleague who did a briefing this morning also reiterated that the individual who was the target detonated himself, killing his entire family. Given these events just happened less than 24 hours ago, weâ€™re going to give them time to make a final assessment. And theyâ€™ll provide every detail they can. When Roscoe said the U.S. â€œhas not always been straightforward about what happens with civilians,â€ she could have been referring to any number of times the U.S. has killed foreign civilians and attempted to hide it. When the U.S. government makes a claim, itâ€™s a reporterâ€™s job to ask for evidence. History has taught the destruction that can be wrought when reporters donâ€™t.

Title: Pete Davidson's Aaron Rodgers Is Back On 'SNL' â€” To Help With Kremlin Disinformation
Text: Pete Davidson reprised his vaccine-lying Aaron Rodgers character to help the Russians with their disinformation campaign about Ukraine invasion plans in the cold open of â€œSaturday Night Live.â€ Davidsonâ€™s Packers quarterback, who put his teammates at risk by fibbing about being vaccinated and contracting COVID-19, stars in an ad in which his car has broken down in Ukraine. â€œLike a good neighbor, Russia is there,â€ Davidson croons in a nod to Rodgersâ€™ gig as a State Farm insurance pitchman. But a military commander (Kenan Thompson) reminds him that 40% of Americans â€œthink you lost the election, so it kinda did.â€ Biden checks out some fake headlines floated by a savvy Kremlin, including: â€œUkrainian Border Encroaching on Russian Troops,â€ â€œAmerican CDC Strongly Recommends Russia Invade Ukraineâ€ and â€œNeil Young to Remove Music from Spotify Unless Ukraine Surrenders.â€ In another ad, a couple of fake Ukrainian students (Andrew Dismukes and Kate McKinnon) dream of all the opportunities in Russia â€œmining arsenic and potash.â€ Check it out in the video clip up top.

Title: Republican Attacks On Joe Biden Over Ukraine Are A Confusing Mess
Text: With the Ukraine crisis dominating headlines and sparking fears of a global conflict, Republicans are scrambling to convince voters that the tense geopolitical situation is President Joe Bidenâ€™s fault. But conservatives just canâ€™t agree on what Biden is doing wrong. The partyâ€™s most powerful elected figures, like top House Republican Kevin McCarthy (Calif.), say Biden is too weak. They want him to take tougher actions to frighten Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has deployed more than 100,000 troops to Ukraineâ€™s borders in recent weeks in apparent plans to invade. Biden has shipped military equipment to Ukrainian forces, threatened Putin with unprecedented sanctions and rejected Moscowâ€™s demand to forswear new alliances with countries such as Ukraine that were formerly part of the Soviet Union. But Biden has emphasized that he wants to defuse tensions diplomatically, offering to make concessions on Russian concerns, including U.S. deployments in Europe, and supporting European alliesâ€™ efforts at negotiation between the Russians and Ukrainians. Still, conservative luminaries (and GOP power brokers) Tucker Carlson and Laura Ingraham of Fox News say Biden is moving toward an all-out nuclear war with Russia to aid the hawkish military-industrial complex and argue Ukraine is irrelevant to Americans. Some of their far-right allies, notably commentators Candace Owens and Benny Johnson, claim the flare-up in Europe is being driven by shadowy elites, including Bidenâ€™s own family, whom Republicans have baselessly accused of profiting off U.S. policies in Ukraine. â€œThere is quite literally no Russian threat. Biden crime family is trying to expand their business empire in the region,â€ Owen tweeted on Monday. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.) endorsed that theory on Tuesday, saying Biden wanted to spark a war â€• as Moscow carried out fresh military exercises. Adding to the confusion, some Republicans want to have it both ways. According to Donald Trump Jr., Biden is both too feeble to deter a Russian invasion and too eager to start a war for his own corrupt reasons. The GOPâ€™s mess is the latest result of its ongoing identity crisis. That Republican dilemma could help Democrats shed their fear of being seen as soft on national security, allowing them to offer a strong alternative message, and could change the shape of the U.S. foreign policy debate for good. Breaking with Republican orthodoxy, former President Donald Trump slammed Americaâ€™s traditional claim to global leadership and its longstanding allies, instead frequently trying to withdraw from international involvement and endorsing the narratives of rivals, particularly Putin. That approach bolstered the minority in the party, chiefly libertarians, who want the U.S. to be more restrained abroad, and Trumpâ€™s constant repetition of those ideas highlighted them for GOP voters. Today, Trump still dominates the GOP. And whether from personal conviction or simply for ambition, some conservatives are still pushing ideas that echo his â€• often in shocking ways. According to The Washington Post, one Republican lawmaker serving on the House Foreign Affairs Committee recently outraged their colleagues by texting a group chain about an article on arms supplies for Ukraineâ€™s defense and asking, â€œWhy is Biden being allowed to provoke Russia?â€ Conservatives are creating sympathy well beyond Washington for Moscowâ€™s viewpoint, which overlooks the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2014 and Russian support for Ukrainian separatists to instead portray Ukraine and its Western partners as threatening Russia. On Monday, multiple people called the office of Rep. Tom Malinowski (D-N.J.) to urge him to support Russiaâ€™s position. Some callers said they learned about the situation from Carlsonâ€™s Fox News show, Malinowski told HuffPost in a Tuesday interview. â€œCallers are being spun up to believeâ€¦ that weâ€™re about to go to war with Russia for Ukraine, and of course thatâ€™s not true,â€ Malinowski said. â€œWeâ€™re taking Ukraineâ€™s side appropriately and mobilizing our allies to impose sanctions against Russia while giving Ukraine arms and ammunition to defend itself. That said, itâ€™s been Americaâ€™s policy in the world since World War II to try to prevent dictatorships from changing borders with tanks.â€ There is no obligation that could force the U.S. to enter a war to defend Ukraine. But, according to Carlson, who has millions of viewers, a conflict could occur due to American hubris and lobbying by Ukrainian politicians and U.S. defense firms. In his telling, Americans should not see any difference between Ukraine and Russia â€• or any Russian responsibility for potential bloodshed. Ingraham, who follows Carlson on Fox Newsâ€™ daily broadcast schedule, is telling her fans that the U.S. risks â€œanother hopeless crusadeâ€ and Republicans must â€œresist the war machineâ€™s temptation.â€ Ironically, it was during Trumpâ€™s presidency that the U.S. most recently neared the kind of â€œextinction level confrontationâ€ that conservatives now pin on Biden. In mishandling the complex U.S. relationships with Iran and North Korea, Trump flirted with major wars at least twice while elsewhere encouraging more brutal American military action abroad and impunity for violence by Americaâ€™s partners. Most elected Republicans have an entirely different narrative on Ukraine. Casting Biden as feckless, they are pushing for immediate new sanctions on Russia â€• an escalation before an invasion rather than the threat of punishment if Moscow does interfere further in Ukraine. But itâ€™s bizarre for the GOP to claim it is the party of standing up to Putin after Trump broke the law to blackmail Ukraine for his reelection campaign and told his foreign counterparts he believed Moscow was correct to claim Crimea, the Ukrainian territory it seized in 2014. â€œMost congressional Republicans agree with Democrats on the fundamental principle that we should be on Ukraineâ€™s side and what Putin is doing is dangerous and wrong, but there is this strain in their party â€• that Tucker Carlson is encouraging and that the former president was obviously sympathetic to â€• that asks, â€˜Why canâ€™t we be friends with Russia? Why do we need troops in Europe? Why canâ€™t the big countries just get together and carve up the small countries?â€™â€ Malinowski said. â€œA lot of my Republican colleagues, even those who are very strong on Ukraine, are in denial about the power of this strain in their party.â€ Dan Caldwell of Stand Together, a nonprofit group that often works with conservatives, sees the shift in Republican thinking on national security policy as generational and likely to continue. â€œItâ€™s more complicated than this just being a Trump phenomenon; itâ€™s a broader questioning across the right of American foreign policy over the past 30 years,â€ said Caldwell, the vice president for foreign policy at the organization, which is backed by longtime GOP donor Charles Koch. He pointed to a survey that his group conducted in December in partnership with the well-respected polling group YouGov. In asking Americans their view of a possible war with Russia to defend Ukraine, they found that 55% of Trump voters opposed that idea, compared with only 44% of Biden voters. â€œItâ€™s another example of how often Republicans in Washington are out of step with their base on these issues,â€ Caldwell said, adding that GOP lawmakers could instead say the U.S. should not take on more security commitments or reflexively oppose Russia. Shifting in that direction could align them on some issues with antiwar progressives, who, on issues like the U.S. role in the devastating civil war in Yemen, have worked with conservatives to force changes. Caldwell believes the split will become a major factor in the partyâ€™s selection of its presidential candidate for the 2024 election â€• and Republicans could then finally settle on a united direction on global affairs. For now, as Biden tries to defuse the tension in Europe and bolster his standing at home, the clear divide weakens Republicansâ€™ attacks on his policy of diplomacy and limited support for Ukraine. Itâ€™s not often that a Democratic president can tout that conservative thinker Sohrab Ahmari is boosting him in the pages of The Washington Post, arguing: â€œIgnore the hawks, Mr. President. Youâ€™re right on Ukraine.â€

Title: Trump Tried To Extort Ukraine. Now He Says He'd Be Better At Helping It Resist Russia.
Text: WASHINGTON â€” Three years after trying to extort Ukraine using $391 million in military aid as leverage and two years after being impeached for it, former President Donald Trump claimed on Monday that Russian aggression against the country would never have happened on his watch. â€œWhatâ€™s happening with Russia and Ukraine would never have happened under the Trump Administration. Not even a possibility!â€ he said in a statement released by his political committee. The statement made no reference to the scandal that led to Trumpâ€™s first of two impeachments, in which he held up delivery of U.S. military aid while demanding that Ukraineâ€™s new president announce an investigation into Joe Biden, then the Democratic primary candidate Trump feared most as a 2020 challenger. The military hardware was released when the scheme became public. In addition to using U.S. aid intended to deter further Russian aggression against Ukraine for his own benefit, Trump made a practice during his presidency of taking Russiaâ€™s side in the dispute between the two nations. For several years, he lobbied fellow leaders of the G-7 group of major economic powers to readmit Russia, even though it had been thrown out because of the invasion and annexation of Ukraineâ€™s Crimean Peninsula in 2014. At the G-7 summit in 2018, Trump told his counterparts that Crimea should belong to Russia because the people there spoke Russian â€” repeating comments heâ€™d made as a presidential candidate. â€œBut you know, the people of Crimea, from what Iâ€™ve heard, would rather be with Russia than where they were,â€ he told ABC News in 2016. In 2019, during a news conference following the G-7 meeting in Biarritz, France, Trump rationalized Russiaâ€™s insistence on retaining Crimea by saying it had built a military base there. â€œThat is where they do their submarine work and that is where they dock large and powerful submarines, but not as powerful as ours and not as large as ours, but they have their submarines,â€ he said, while also blaming his predecessor, Democratic President Barack Obama, for having been â€œoutsmartedâ€ by Putinâ€™s decision to invade Ukraine and take the region by force. While the U.S. government as a whole did try to punish Russia for its aggression in Ukraine, much of that was due to bipartisan majorities in Congress or career staff at executive branch agencies enacting sanctions. Other actions were largely symbolic. While the United States did supply Ukraine with anti-tank Javelin missiles, for example, they were provided under the condition that they not be deployed in areas where they actually could have been used against pro-Russian forces. Russian ruler Vladimir Putin, whom Trump repeatedly praised both before and after he took office, has amassed more than 100,000 troops along his border with Ukraine. Biden, now the U.S. president, has warned Putin that another invasion would be met with severe consequences, including harsh new economic sanctions. He has also been considering redeploying thousands of U.S. troops to Eastern Europe. In 2016, Trump accepted Putinâ€™s help to win the U.S. presidency by using documents that Russian spies stole from the Democratic Party and the campaign of his opponent, Hillary Clinton, even though he had been informed by U.S. intelligence officials that Russian spies had stolen them. Four years later, despite losing the 2020 election by 7 million popular votes and by 306-232 in the Electoral College, Trump became the first U.S. president in more than two centuries to refuse to hand over power peacefully. His incitement of the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol â€“ his last-ditch attempt to remain in office â€• killed five, including one police officer, injured another 140 officers, and was followed by four police suicides. It resulted in his second impeachment just a week before he left office. The former National Security Council staffer who testified against Trump during his first impeachment said Monday that Trumpâ€™s incitement of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol probably led to Putinâ€™s renewed aggression. â€œWhatâ€™s happening in Ukraine is the direct result of Trumpâ€™s attack on democracy. Absent January 6th, Putin would likely not be preparing to launch the largest offensive in Europe since WWII,â€ said Alexander Vindman. â€œPutinâ€™s sense of American weakness emanates from Trump-incited hyper polarization. Trumpâ€™s fondness for Putin infected the far right media echo chamber.â€ Despite Trumpâ€™s two impeachments and his literal attempt to overthrow American democracy, he remains the dominant figure in the Republican Party and is openly speaking about running for the presidency again in 2024.

Title: Rare Sea Eagle, Native To Asia, Turns Up In Massachusetts
Text: A Stellerâ€™s sea eagle, a rare raptor native to parts of Asia and eastern Russia, has been spotted mingling with bald eagles along a river in southeastern Massachusetts. The stunning eagle first turned up last week along the Taunton River, east of Providence, Rhode Island, and is believed to be the same bird that was previously observed in Alaska and Canada, according to a Facebook post from the Massachusetts Division of Fisheries and Wildlife. Stellerâ€™s sea eagles can weigh up to 20 pounds and have a 6- to 8-foot wingspan. They have large, cartoonish orange beaks and distinctive white plumage along their upper wings that resembles a splattered snowball. News of the sighting sent birders flocking to the area. One of them, Nick Lund, the advocacy and outreach coordinator for Maine Audubon, blogged about the experience on his website, called â€œThe Birdist.â€ Lund had been participating in a Christmas bird count in southern Maine when he received a text from a colleague that said â€œStellerâ€™s was just found.â€ Lund abandoned the organized bird count, hopped in the car with some fellow birders and drove the two hours south. â€œWe pull up to the tiny, private beach where the bird was last seen to the dreaded â€˜you just missed it!â€™â€ Lund wrote on his blog. â€œA birderâ€™s nightmare. It flew upriver somewhere and no one knows where it is.â€ With their car nearly out of gas, the group drove off in hopes of catching a glimpse. Eventually, they received word that the bird had been spotted at Dighton Rock State Park. â€œWe go, park haphazardly, and there it is, across the river with a bunch of Bald Eagles. Holy shit. Weâ€™re screaming,â€ Lund wrote. â€œAn absolute dream to be all of a sudden standing in this random park in southern Massachusetts looking at a wild, rare Russian monster.â€ On their way home, the group stopped to purchase a bottle of Russian vodka to â€œhonor our visiting Russian comrade.â€ HOOOOOLLLYYY SHIIIITTTTTTT  This bird of preyâ€™s odyssey thousands of miles from home has captivated scientists and enthusiasts. As The New York Times reported in November, the lost eagle has been slowly makings its way east across North America. It was first spotted along the Denali highway in southeastern Alaska in August 2020, and more recently in eastern Canada. It is even believed to have been sighted in Texas in the spring. â€œWeâ€™ve never had one here in this area of the world: the Northeast coast of North America or Massachusetts,â€ Andrew Vitz, a state ornithologist, told The Boston Globe. â€œThis is like the bird of the decade for people around here.â€ Birds turning up outside their normal range, known as avian vagrancy, is relatively common, often the result of an animal getting lost or blown off course in a storm. Vitz told the Globe that the eagle appears to be in good health and there is no plan to tag or capture it. â€œItâ€™s probably trying to find some familiar faces out there â€” others of its own species,â€ he said. The total population of Stellerâ€™s sea eagles is estimated at 4,000 to 7,000 individuals. The International Union for Conservation of Nature lists the bird as â€œvulnerable.â€

Title: Russian Antisatellite Weapon Test May Have Littered Space With Dangerous Debris
Text: A Russian antisatellite weapon test may have created a dangerous field of orbiting space debris that threatened the International Space Station over the weekend, unnamed U.S. officials told CNN. In a statement, U.S. Space Command (which is different than Space Force) confirmed â€œa debris-generating eventâ€ occurred, but notably declined to mention the cause or Russia. Two U.S. officials told CNN that Russia carried out an antisatellite test over the weekend, and one suggested a link to the debris. That scenario is bolstered by a report from Seradata, a private space data and analysis company that tracked a suspected ground-launched antisatellite missile strike from Russia. The missile struck a defunct Soviet-era intelligence satellite that had been in orbit since 1982 and scattered at least 14 pieces of debris large enough to be tracked, according to Seradata. If confirmed, it would be Russiaâ€™s fourth such antisatellite test. The seven astronauts aboard the ISS had to repeatedly take safety measures Monday, sheltering in their docked capsules while the station passed the orbiting junk. â€œWe are actively working to characterize the debris field and will continue to ensure all space-faring nations have the information necessary to maneuver satellites if impacted,â€ U.S. Space Command said. â€œWe are also in the process of working with the interagency, including the State Department and NASA, concerning these reports and will provide an update in the near future.â€ Last week, the ISS had to alter its orbit after a chunk of an old Chinese satellite â€• created by an antisatellite missile test by the Chinese in 2007 â€• came close to the station. Even tiny bits of space debris can be disastrous for the space station. In June, a 5mm (0.20-inch) wide piece of junk traveling at 17,500 mph punched a hole through a thermal blanket wrapped around the stationâ€™s 60-foot robotic Canadarm2.

Title: Trump Demands Pulitzer Prizes For Russian Election Interference Reporting Be Revoked
Text: Former President Donald Trump sent a letter Sunday to â€œThe Pulitzer Prizesâ€ demanding that journalism awards for reporting on Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election be â€œimmediatelyâ€ rescinded. The prestigious awards were given â€œbased on the false reporting of a non-existent link between the Kremlin and the Trump Campaign,â€ Trump baselessly wrote in his appeal to the interim administrator of the Pulitzer awards, Bud Kliment. The former president called the coverage a â€œpolitically motivated farce.â€ He argued that the reporting was â€œbased on shoddy, dubious, and manifestly false reporting,â€ and that Pulitzer officials must now â€œact accordingly.â€ The staffs of the New York Times and The Washington Post were awarded National Reporting Pulitzers for their work in 2018. The prizes were granted for â€œdeeply sourced, relentlessly reported coverage in the public interest that dramatically furthered the nationâ€™s understanding of Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election and its connections to the Trump campaign, the President-electâ€™s transition team and his eventual administration,â€ the Pulitzer board noted. Trump claimed in his letter that he was â€œexoneratedâ€ by the investigation into Russian campaign interference in 2016. That assertion is false. After a lengthy investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election and links to the Trump campaign, then-special counsel Robert Mueller noted pointedly in 2019 that the probe did not exonerate Trump. But he explained that under federal law, charging Trump, then a sitting president, was â€œnot an option.â€ Mueller emphasized: â€œIf we had had confidence that the president clearly did not commit a crime, we would have said so,â€ which the investigative team did not. The report found that the Kremlinâ€™s interference on behalf of Trump in the 2016 election was â€œsweeping and systemic.â€ Actions included a social media â€œinformation warfareâ€ campaign that â€œfavoredâ€ Trump, and the hacking of campaign-related related databases linked to rival Hillary Clinton. The hacked information was widely disseminated via Wikileaks. The investigation also detailed multiple interactions between representatives of the Kremlin or Russian President Vladimir Putin and the Trump campaign and Trump associates during the race for the presidency. The report noted that Trumpâ€™s associates repeatedly lied to investigators about their contacts with Russians, and Trump refused to answer questions concerning any of his efforts to influence witnesses or impede the investigation. Trumpâ€™s hand-picked Attorney General William Barr came under attack for failing to file charges against Trump, particularly for obstruction of justice. He downplayed the reportâ€™s findings in a statement about the investigationâ€™s conclusions. Trump has called the investigation the â€œsingle greatest witch hunt in American history.â€ A spokesperson for the Pulitzer board could not immediately be reached for comment. The former presidentâ€™s two-page letter to Kliment was posted by his aide Liz Harrington on her Twitter account. Trump has been banned from the platform for inciting the Jan. 6 riot. Twitter bars other accounts that serve as proxies for banned users, according to its policies, but apparently not in Trumpâ€™s case. Harrington has been posting all of Trumpâ€™s website statements on her Twitter account since she was hired in June.

Title: Democratic Lawyer Michael Sussmann Indicted, Accused Of Lying To FBI In Russia Probe
Text: A federal grand jury has returned an indictment against cybersecurity attorney Michael Sussmann, who represented the Democratic National Committee in connection with the 2016 Russia hack, accusing him of lying to the FBI about who he was representing. The grand jury indictment accuses Sussmann of lying when he â€œstated to the General Counsel of the FBI that he was not acting on behalf of any client in conveying particular allegations concerning a Presidential candidate, when in truth, and in fact, as the defendant well knew, he was acting on behalf of specific clients, namely, Tech Executive-1 and the Clinton Campaign.â€ The indictment, as The New York Times reported yesterday, was sought by John Durham, whom the Trump administration named special counsel to investigate the Russia probe. The indictment was returned just before the five-year statute of limitations expired. In a statement to the Times ahead of the indictment, Sussmannâ€™s attorneys said he â€œhas committed no crimeâ€ and that a prosecution â€œwould be baseless, unprecedented and an unwarranted deviation from the apolitical and principled way in which the Department of Justice is supposed to do its work.â€ â€œWe are confident that if Mr. Sussmann is charged, he will prevail at trial and vindicate his good name,â€ they said. Title: Biden Believes Putin Wants To Save Russia's Soured Reputation On World Stage
Text: Fresh off a face-to-face meeting with Vladimir Putin, President Joe Biden made the case that the Russian president knows he needs to improve the countryâ€™s reputation on the international stage. Putin is afraid, Biden surmised, that â€œhis credibility worldwide shrinksâ€ as Russiaâ€™s human rights abuses, attacks on the free press and reputation for meddling in foreign elections increasingly define how the rest of the world regards the country. â€œHow would it be if the United States were viewed by the rest of the world as interfering with the elections directly of other countries and everybody knew it?â€ Biden asked, referring to U.S. intelligence findings that Russia attempted to meddle in the last two U.S. presidential elections. â€œWhat would it be like if we engaged in activities that heâ€™s engaged in? It diminishes the standing of a country that is desperately trying to make sure it maintains its standing as a major world power.â€ Biden, speaking before reporters in Geneva shortly after Putin held his own press conference, said they had a productive conversation about avoiding conflict, agreeing to arms control measures, consequences of human rights abuses and the detainment of two American citizens in Russia â€• Paul Whelan and Trevor Reed. But moving forward on those issues requires a wait-and-see approach, Biden admitted. â€œWeâ€™ll find out within the next six months to a year whether or not we actually have a strategic dialogue that matters,â€ the president said. â€œWeâ€™ll find out whether we work to deal with everything from the release of people in Russian prisons or not. Weâ€™ll find out whether we have a cybersecurity arrangement that begins to bring some order.â€ But Putin, by Bidenâ€™s own admission, is far from a reliable negotiator. Biden confessed in 2014 that he once looked Putin in the eyes and told him, â€œI donâ€™t think you have a soul.â€ However, Biden bristled when reporters asked how he could trust Putin. â€œThis is not about trust,â€ he said. â€œThis is about self-interest and verification of self-interest.â€ The president grew visibly upset near the end of his press conference as reporters continued to challenge him on the matter, particularly when CNNâ€™s Kaitlan Collins asked how he could be â€œso confident [Putin] will change his behaviorâ€ when the Kremlinâ€™s leader just spent his press conference denying Russiaâ€™s role in any cyber attacks, downplaying the countryâ€™s human rights abuses and refusing to acknowledge Alexei Navalny, an outspoken Putin critic currently imprisoned in Russia. Biden snapped at the characterization. â€œI am not confident he will change his behavior. Where the hell â€• what do you do all the time? When did I say I was confident? ... I said what will change their behavior is if the rest of the world reacts to them and it diminishes their standing in the world. I am not confident of anything. I am just stating the facts.â€ Biden later apologized in front of reporters before boarding Air Force One. â€œI owe my last questioner an apology,â€ he said. â€œI shouldnâ€™t have been such a wise guy for the answer I gave.â€

Title: Russian State TV Hails 'Patriot' Capitol Riot Suspect Who Raided Nancy Pelosi's Office
Text: Russian state TV has hailed as an â€œAmerican patriotâ€ the infamous Capitol riot suspect who was photographed gleefully sitting with his foot on a desk in the office of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) the day of the Jan. 6 insurrection. Richard â€œBigoâ€ Barnett, 60, appeared in an interview that aired Sunday complaining about jail after his arrest on charges linked to the attempted overthrow of the presidential election, The Daily Beast first reported. The segment aired just days before President Joe Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin are scheduled to meet for the first time in Geneva on Wednesday. Special correspondent Valentin Bogdanov of Russian TV channel Rossiya-1 interviewed Barnett, a self-described white nationalist from Arkansas, via FaceTime. He described Barnett as â€œcolorfulâ€ â€” a word Putin has used to characterized Donald Trump. Bogdanov also falsely referred to the 2020 U.S. presidential election as â€œstolen,â€ a claim that has no basis in fact. Barnett has been charged with several crimes, including obstruction of an official proceeding, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon (a stun gun), and theft of government property. He allegedly took a piece of Pelosiâ€™s mail and left her a note, apparently calling her a â€œbitch,â€ though he misspelled the word. Hello from Judge Chris Cooper's virtual courtroom, where arguments are starting soon on Richard Barnett's motion for release â€” he's the one who told reporters he left Pelosi a note that said, "Nancy, Bigo was here, you bitch" (looks like "bitch" was misspelled on the actual note)  â€œI exercise my First Amendment rights every hour, every minute, and every day, and I will never stop,â€ Barnett boasted to Bogdanov. Barnett was released to home detention in April after complaining that being held behind bars wasnâ€™t â€œfairâ€ when other Capitol suspects were allowed to return home following their arrests. â€œTheyâ€™re letting everyone else out,â€ Barnett yelled during his hearing before U.S. District Court Judge Christopher R. Cooper, the Daily Beast reported. â€œIâ€™ve been here a long time. Itâ€™s not fair. This has been a bunch of crap.â€ A judge had turned down an earlier request, ruling that Barnettâ€™s â€œentitled behavior ... shows a total disregard for the law ... and the Constitution.â€ Barnett is due back in federal court for a hearing on Tuesday.

Title: Vladimir Putin Dismisses Joe Biden's Assertion That He Is A 'Killer'
Text: Russian President Vladimir Putin brushed off Joe Bidenâ€™s assertion that he is a â€œkillerâ€ days before an expected meeting with the U.S. president. In an interview with NBC News, excerpts of which the outlet posted Friday, journalist Keir Simmons noted that Biden was asked earlier this year whether he thought Putin was a â€œkillerâ€ and Biden said, â€œI do.â€ Simmons then asked Putin directly if this is true, to which Putin laughed and said: â€œOver my tenure, Iâ€™ve gotten used to attacks from all kinds of angles and from all kinds of areas, under all kinds of pretext and reasons, and of different caliber and fierceness, and none of it surprises me.â€ Simmons pressed further, naming political opponents of Putinâ€™s whoâ€™ve been killed, and Putin responded: â€œLook, you know, I donâ€™t want to come across as being rude, but this looks like some kind of indigestion except that itâ€™s verbal indigestion. Youâ€™ve mentioned many individuals who indeed suffered and perished at different points in time for various reasons, at the hands of different individuals.â€ .@KeirSimmons asks Vladimir Putin if heâ€™s a killer ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» Over the years, a number of Putin critics have been killed or sickened or have died in mysterious ways. British intelligence linked Russia to the 2018 poisoning of former Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter in England in a bold attack on foreign soil. In the interview with NBC, Simmons asked Putin to compare Biden to former President Donald Trump â€” whom critics accused of being soft on Russia â€” and Putin replied by calling Trump â€œtalentedâ€ and â€œa colorful individual.â€ Biden is â€œradically different from Trump,â€ Putin said, because he is a â€œcareer manâ€ who â€œspent virtually his entire adulthood in politics.â€ â€œIt is my great hope that yes, there are some advantages, some disadvantages, but there will not be any impulse-based movements on behalf of the sitting U.S. president,â€ Putin said. Biden and Putin are expected to meet in person at a summit in Geneva on June 16 amid heightened tensions between the two countries. The Biden administration has sanctioned Russia in response to the Russian governmentâ€™s interference in the 2020 U.S. presidential election, as well as its alleged role in the SolarWinds cyberattack, in which hackers accessed the data of several U.S. agencies and dozens of private companies. The Biden administration has also criticized Russia over its alleged poisoning of opposition leader Alexei Navalny, who is now imprisoned. Just weeks after taking office earlier this year, Biden said that heâ€™d communicated to the Russian president in a call that the U.S. would not be â€œrolling over in the face of Russiaâ€™s aggressive actions, interfering with our elections, cyber-attacks, poisoning citizens.â€ Trump was often called out for being too friendly with Putin, even as U.S. intelligence agencies confirmed Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election in an effort to aid Trumpâ€™s win. Biden is currently in Britain for a meeting with the Group of Seven leaders, including U.S. allies Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United Kingdom.

Title: Jimmy Kimmel Plays The 'Second Most Damaging Tape' Of Rudy Giuliani This Year
Text: Jimmy Kimmel thinks a new Rudy Giuliani tape could top the doozy from â€œBorat 2.â€ Audio recorded in July 2019 that CNN released this week showed Giuliani repeatedly suggesting to a Ukrainian official that Ukraine could have a better relationship with the United States if the countryâ€™s president opened an investigation into Joe Biden and his son Hunter.
