Title: Mitt Romney To Support Subpoena In Probe Into Ukraine's Burisma
Text: Sen. Mitt Romney (R-Utah) plans to vote in support of issuing a subpoena in the investigation into Hunter Bidenâ€™s work with the Ukrainian energy firm Burisma, a spokesperson for the senator said Friday. Romneyâ€™s vote will be the tipping point for the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee, giving Chairman Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) just enough support to proceed with a subpoena. The news comes despite the Utah senator telling reporters on Thursday that â€œthereâ€™s no questionâ€ the probe into former Vice President Joe Bidenâ€™s son and Burisma seems politically motivated, given Bidenâ€™s recent successes during the Democratic presidential primary. â€œSenator Romney has expressed his concerns to Chairman Johnson, who has confirmed that any interview of the witness would occur in a closed setting without a hearing or public spectacle,â€ Romney spokesperson Liz Johnson said in a statement. â€œHe will therefore vote to let the Chairman proceed to obtain the documents that have been offered.â€ Johnson is seeking a subpoena for records from Andrii Telizhenko, a former consultant who worked with Burisma. Telizhenko, a Rudy Giuliani ally, has indicated heâ€™s willing to cooperate with Johnsonâ€™s investigation. Romney said Thursday that before deciding to back a subpoena, heâ€™d need to see what information Johnson has. â€œI would hope if thereâ€™s something of significance that needs to be evaluated, it be done by the FBI or some other agency thatâ€™s not as political as perhaps a committee of our body,â€ he said. Last month, Romney was the only Republican to break from his party and vote to convict President Donald Trump in his impeachment trial for pressuring Ukraine to investigate the Bidens and Hunterâ€™s work with Burisma.

Title: Mitt Romney Says There's 'No Question' Hunter Biden Probe Appears Political
Text: â€œThereâ€™s no questionâ€ that a probe into Joe Bidenâ€™s son Hunter Biden appears politically motivated, Sen. Mitt Romney told reporters Thursday, adding, â€œI think people are tired of these kind of political investigations.â€ Romney, a member of the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee, could block an upcoming subpoena planned by committee head Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.). Romney said heâ€™d meet with Johnson to â€œsee what information he hasâ€ before deciding whether to back a subpoena. â€œI would hope if thereâ€™s something of significance that needs to be evaluated, it be done by the FBI or some other agency thatâ€™s not as political as perhaps a committee of our body,â€ the senator said. Johnson initiated a probe of Ukrainian energy company Burisma and Hunter Biden, who joined Burismaâ€™s board when his father was U.S. vice president. President Donald Trumpâ€™s personal attorney Rudy Giuliani has accused the Bidens of illegal actions linked to Burisma without offering any details, substantiation or evidence. Trump was impeached after withholding military aid from Ukraine while pressuring the countryâ€™s president to launch a probe into unfounded accusations against the Bidens. The former vice presidentâ€™s recent uptick in the Democratic primaries has rekindled threats of an investigation by the Senate. Johnson told Fox News on Wednesday that the investigation was not politically motivated. He hopes to subpoena a former Ukrainian Embassy official who worked for a Washington-based consulting firm that Burisma hired to combat accusations of corruption. Romneyâ€™s vote against the subpoena would result in a deadlock, blocking the action.

Title: Joe Biden: Trump And His Allies 'Like' Russia Interfering In U.S. Elections
Text: Former Vice President Joe Biden didnâ€™t mince words during an interview that aired on CBS Newsâ€™ â€œFace The Nationâ€ on Sunday, saying President Donald Trump and his allies arenâ€™t taking enough action to stop Russia interference in U.S. elections because they â€œlikeâ€ it. Asked if he believes there are lessons the Trump administration can learn on election meddling, Biden told host Margaret Brennan that the administration is â€œincapableâ€ of evolving on the matter. â€œThey like this,â€ the Democratic presidential candidate said during the interview. â€œCome on, letâ€™s be fair here. Theyâ€™ve known this for a long time, for three years.â€ â€œEvery intelligence agency has told them [that the Russians] continue to be engaged in this activity,â€ he added. â€œThere is not any question anymore. ... And whatâ€™s he doing? Zero. What is the Republican leadership in the United States Senate and Congress doing? Zero.â€ RUSSIAN ELECTION INTERFERENCE: @JoeBiden to @margbrennan: "Look, this administration is incapable of learning elections. They like this. Come on. Let's be fair here. They've known this for a long time, for three years."  The U.S. intelligence communityâ€™s top election security official reportedly told House lawmakers earlier this month that Russia wants Trump to win reelection in November. Separately, U.S. intelligence officials last month told Sen. Bernie Sandersâ€™ (I-Vt.) presidential campaign that the Kremlin was apparently also seeking to help the Democratic candidateâ€™s bid. Sanders denounced Russiaâ€™s interference and demanded Russian President Vladimir Putin â€œstay out of American elections.â€ Trump, in contrast, has attacked Democrats over reports that Russia is trying to help him win reelection, accusing those across the aisle of spreading â€œdisinformation.â€ Russian agents, during the 2016 campaign, hacked into the Democratic National Committeeâ€™s server and orchestrated a massive disinformation campaign to help get Trump elected, according to U.S. intelligence agencies. Biden on Sunday said heâ€™s been targeted by Russian bots on Facebook because the Kremlin doesnâ€™t want him to be the Democratic nominee. Asked whether it was Facebook or U.S. intelligence officials who informed him of this, Biden said he was alerted by his staff. â€œI have not spoken to the intelligence community, but I think the intelligence community should inform the rest of us who are running what they told Senator Sanders,â€ he said. Trump is â€œangryâ€ that intelligence officials informed Sanders and other members of Congress about some of Russiaâ€™s meddling efforts in the 2020 election cycle, Biden said, adding that the administration must do more to secure the integrity of our elections. â€œWhy in Godâ€™s name havenâ€™t we hardened the electoral process, provided ... hundreds of millions of dollars to states to be able to harden their voter rolls, make sure they canâ€™t be attacked ... as a consequence of cyber attacks?â€ Biden continued. â€œWhy havenâ€™t we provided the capacity for them to be able to have the money to have paper ballots in addition to that?â€ â€œThis is outrageous,â€ he said. The White House did not immediately respond to HuffPostâ€™s request for comment. Watch part of Bidenâ€™s interview on â€œFace The Nationâ€ below:

Title: Trump Security Adviser Unsurprisingly Says He's Seen No Evidence Of Russia Helping Trump
Text: President Donald Trumpâ€™s top security adviser claimed in a recent interview with ABC News that he hasnâ€™t seen evidence of Russia working to sway the 2020 U.S. presidential election in Trumpâ€™s favor. When asked by ABC Newsâ€™ George Stephanopoulos whether heâ€™s seen anything from the intelligence community that indicates Russia is working to bring about Trumpâ€™s re-election, national security adviser Robert Oâ€™Brien said no. â€œI havenâ€™t seen any intelligence that Russia is doing anything to attempt to get President Trump re-elected,â€ Oâ€™Brien said, noting that, as a national security adviser, he gets â€œpretty good accessâ€ to information from the intelligence community. The full interview with Oâ€™Brien aired on ABCâ€™s â€œThis Week With George Stephanopoulosâ€ on Sunday. A transcript was made public Saturday. "I haven't seen any intelligence that Russia is doing anything to attempt to get President Trump reelected," Robert O'Brien tells @GStephanopoulos amid reports that intel officials told lawmakers Russia is meddling in 2020, with a preference for Trump.  Oâ€™Brien called the reports a â€œnon-story,â€ despite Russiaâ€™s history of tampering with elections in Trumpâ€™s favor. The intelligence community concluded in 2017 that Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered cyberattacks on the Democratic National Committee with the ultimate aim of helping secure Trumpâ€™s victory in the 2016 presidential contest. The Associated Press, citing anonymous sources, received contradicting reports about whether there was intel on Russia pushing for Trumpâ€™s reelection. An intelligence official told the AP that intelligence officials did not tell House committee members that Russia was trying to aid Trumpâ€™s campaign. However, others familiar with that meeting said Russia was indeed trying to do just that. One source who was present at the meeting with the director of national intelligenceâ€™s team said that Oâ€™Brienâ€™s claims about Russia and Trumpâ€™s re-election campaign â€œdo not accurately reflectâ€ what they themselves heard at that meeting, CNN chief White House correspondent Jim Acosta reported. Speaking to Stephanopoulos, Oâ€™Brien did agree with reports that Russia is trying to boost the campaign of Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), a front-runner in the Democratic primary. Sanders has emphatically rejected Russiaâ€™s help. In his interview with ABC, Oâ€™Brien attempted to link Sandersâ€™ honeymoon, which took place in 1988, to Russiaâ€™s meddling. â€œThatâ€™s no surprise. He honeymooned in Moscow,â€ he said. Critics noted that Trump himself has taken numerous trips to Moscow and had business dealings there, including the Miss Universe pageant in 2013 and the Trump Organizationâ€™s previous plans to build a tower there. Yes Sanders honeymooned in Moscow as opposed to Trump who held a beauty pageant in Moscow, took money from Moscow investors, hired aides linked to Moscow, heaped praise on Putin, and publicly asked Russia to get his opponentâ€™s emails in the midst of the 2016 election campaign. The most ugly, xenophobic, and casually imperialist thing in here is the handwringing about how Sanders went to Nicaragua and the Soviet Union in the â€˜80s. On top of Cold War and dirty wars, itâ€™s this idea that these places are not worth going to at all This is actually terrifying. The New York Times reported earlier this week that intelligence officials briefed the House Intelligence Committee on Russiaâ€™s attempts to interfere in the 2020 race in order to get Trump reelected. Oâ€™Brien said he had heard of the reports on the House committee being briefed. He admitted he wasnâ€™t there, but claimed that he heard from those briefing the lawmakers that the reports were â€œnot what they intended the story to be.â€ When asked if he has a responsibility as the national security adviser to find out whether reports that Russia wants Trump to win reelection are valid, Oâ€™Brien danced around the question. â€œI donâ€™t know â€• these are leaks,â€ Oâ€™Brien said. â€œIâ€™m telling you I havenâ€™t seen the intel and I havenâ€™t seen the analysis.â€ Stephanopoulos interrupted, â€œHave you asked for it?â€ â€œLook, I want to get whatever analysis theyâ€™ve got and I want to make sure that the analysis is solid,â€ Oâ€™Brien said. â€œI mean, you know, from what Iâ€™ve heard â€• again, this is only what Iâ€™m seeing in the press â€• it doesnâ€™t make any sense.â€ Robert Oâ€™Brien repeatedly says he has â€œnot seenâ€ U.S. intel reports that Russia is meddling in 2020 to help Trump.@GStephanopoulos: â€œDonâ€™t you have a responsibility as national security adviser to find out?â€ Oâ€™Brien: "... I havenâ€™t seen the intel."  Oâ€™Brien also denied reports that Trump scolded outgoing acting director of national intelligence Joseph Maguire after he learned that House lawmakers were briefed on Russiaâ€™s alleged attempts to meddle in the 2020 election in Trumpâ€™s favor. Trump announced this week that Maguire was leaving his post, and named Richard Grenell, an ally of the president, as his replacement. Marc Short, chief of staff to Vice President Mike Pence, on Sunday echoed Oâ€™Brienâ€™s denials about Maguireâ€™s ouster as well as reports that Russia favors Trump. â€œI think that thereâ€™s not intelligence that said that the Russians are trying to help Donald Trump win election,â€ Short said during an appearance on â€œFox News Sunday.â€ â€œItâ€™s hard to see why they would be choosing Donald Trump over Bernie Sanders,â€ he added. Host Chris Wallace noted that Shelby Pierson, the U.S. intelligence communityâ€™s top election security official, briefed Congress earlier this month about Russia developing â€œa preferenceâ€ for Trump. Short said he wouldnâ€™t comment on the classified congressional meeting, but claimed the president did not receive such information during his own briefing on election security. U.S. intel says Russia is interfering in American elections to help boost President Trump and Democratic candidate Bernie Sanders. Marc Short weighs in on FOX News Sunday: â€œThere is not intelligence that said that the Russians are trying to help Donald Trump win an election.â€  On Friday, Sanders denounced Russiaâ€™s alleged interference in the election. â€œUnlike the current president, I stand firmly against their efforts, and any other foreign power that wants to interfere in our election,â€ Sanders said in a statement. â€œI donâ€™t care, frankly, who Putin wants to be president,â€ he continued. â€œMy message to Putin is clear: stay out of American elections, and as president I will make sure that you do. In 2016, Russia used internet propaganda to sow division in our country, and my understanding is that they are doing it again in 2020.â€

Title: Russia Wants To Help Bernie Sanders And Donald Trump. Only Trump Is Helping Russia.
Text: U.S. intelligence officials believe Russia is trying to boost Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) in the 2020 Democratic primary race as part of its interference in this yearâ€™s presidential election, according to Sanders and news reports on Friday. Sanders moved to quickly and firmly reject Moscowâ€™s involvement. His response was strikingly different from the way President Donald Trump has handled Russiaâ€™s meddling since the Republican first received Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s support in the 2016 election and then was informed earlier this year that Putin wants to see him reelected. â€œUnlike the current president, I stand firmly against their efforts, and any other foreign power that wants to interfere in our election,â€ Sanders said in a statement he issued after The Washington Post broke the news Friday of the Russian efforts to help him claim the Democratic nomination. â€œI donâ€™t care, frankly, who Putin wants to be president,â€ Sanders said. â€œMy message to Putin is clear: stay out of American elections, and as president I will make sure that you do. In 2016, Russia used internet propaganda to sow division in our country, and my understanding is that they are doing it again in 2020.â€ Four years ago, Putin used online support for Sanders to worsen splits within the Democratic Party as he sought to secure Trumpâ€™s election. His aim now could be two-fold: exacerbating Democratic divisions again to weaken the anti-Trump coalition while bolstering a Sanders candidacy some political analysts believe Trump would find easy to attack as extreme. Sanders in his response on Friday focused on the national interest in rebuffing the Russian efforts. Campaigning in California on Friday, he told reporters, â€œItâ€™s an ugly business, and all of us have got to say, sorry, youâ€™re not going to do this in this election.â€ Putin in 2016 could have viewed Sandersâ€™ relative silence on foreign policy beyond criticizing U.S. overreach as a sign he might be sympathetic to Moscow. But the senator has since articulated a vision of foreign policy thatâ€™s wary of Putinâ€™s aggressive ultra-nationalism and support for oligarchs. Heâ€™s shown that just because he is skeptical of muscular demonstrations of U.S. power like military interventions, he does not endorse forces trying to undermine the U.S. or spread disinformation on Washingtonâ€™s role in global issues like the Syrian civil war. In the 2016 campaign cycle, Trump denied receiving Russian support even as he openly invited it. His family and his advisors explored the possibility of such help privately and his aides ensured the GOPâ€™s convention platform adopted a position on Ukraine softer than Republican orthodoxy at the time and in line with Putinâ€™s interests. Once elected, Trump continued to reject the intelligence communityâ€™s conclusion that Russia had interfered in the election and did his best to denigrate and thwart special counsel Robert Muellerâ€™s lengthy probe into the matter. Trump continually has framed the concerns and findings about Russian interference as a personal attack on him by political enemies, and used the power of the U.S. government to push a conspiracy theory that exonerated Moscow. The New York Times reported last week that Trump became angry with Joseph McGuire, the acting director of national intelligence, for telling House lawmakers â€• especially Democrats â€• about Putinâ€™s 2020 interference efforts. McGuire was replaced as the acting intelligence chief on Friday by Richard Grenell, a staunch Trump loyalist. And in the Senate, Republicans are blocking legislation that would require campaigns to be more transparent about offers of foreign assistance.

Title: Watchdog Group Calls For Criminal Probe Into Rudy Giuliani's Ukraine Role
Text: A watchdog group is calling for a criminal investigation into Rudy Giulianiâ€™s alleged leverage of government funds to benefit the reelection of client Donald Trump. Trump has admitted that he sent Giuliani, his personal lawyer, to Ukraine to pressure officials to investigate unfounded accusations against political rival Joe Biden. During some of that time, Trump held up $390 million in military aid for Ukraine that had been approved by Congress. Giulianiâ€™s business associate Lev Parnas, who has been indicted for alleged campaign finance violations, has said that he followed Giulianiâ€™s instructions to tell Ukrainian officials that their nation would not receive any aid unless they announced an investigation into Biden. â€œEvidence suggests that Giuliani, who is President Trumpâ€™s personal attorney, manipulated federal funds â€” specifically aid to Ukraine â€” for partisan political purposes, which is prohibitedâ€ by the Hatch Act, said a statement Thursday by Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington. The organization filed a complaint Thursday with the Southern District of New York, which is reportedly already investigating Giulianiâ€™s activities in Ukraine. The Hatch Act prohibits, among other things, the manipulation of federal funds and federal programs to advance a partisan agenda. Trump was not the only person involved in the Ukraine scandal, and he's not the only one that should face consequences for it. Today, CREW sent SDNY a criminal complaint saying Rudy Giulianiâ€™s actions in Ukraine were illegal and should be investigated. â€œGiuliani and his potential co-conspirators likely violated the Hatch Act by threatening to withhold congressionally authorized security assistance to Ukraine to pressure Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to announce investigations that would be politically beneficial to Giulianiâ€™s client, President Trump,â€ the CREW statement added. CREWâ€™s executive director, Noah Bookbinder, said that Giulianiâ€™s work in Ukraine not only led to the presidentâ€™s impeachment in the House but â€œalso violated our countryâ€™s criminal laws.â€ Holding up the military aid was â€œdangerous and anti-democratic,â€ he said. Officials from the Southern District could not immediately be reached for comment. Read CREWâ€™s entire letter to the SDNY here.

Title: Intel On Russian Election Interference Must Be Declassified To Inform Voters: Ex-Ambassador
Text: Former U.S Ambassador to Russia Michael McFaul said Friday that intelligence concerning Russian interference in the 2020 presidential election should be declassified and made public so that American voters can judge for themselves whatâ€™s happening. He also suggested that House Democrats should consider holding weekly hearings on the threat with Richard Grenell, the new acting director of the Department of National Intelligence. McFaul said itâ€™s no surprise that Russia is again interfering this election season in a bid to sway the vote for Trump â€” as American intelligence discovered in the 2016 election. â€œIt is an intelligence assessment that Putin seeks Donald Trumpâ€™s victory again,â€ McFaul told Nicolle Wallace on MSNBCâ€™s â€œDeadline White House.â€ â€œTo me, thatâ€™s no great insight ... [itâ€™s] very clear.â€ But what needs to be disseminated is what â€œconcreteâ€ steps that Russia, under President Vladimir Putin, may be taking to help make that happen, he added. â€œLetâ€™s just start declassifying this stuffâ€ before the November election â€œso the American people know whatâ€™s going on. Thatâ€™s what the Obama administration was criticized for not doing in 2016.â€ McFaul also warned of the extreme danger of the â€œpoliticization of intelligence.â€ If all intelligence is â€œfiltered through partisan politics, that means that the president is not getting an accurate picture of the threats out there, whether itâ€™s pandemics, or nuclear weapons or terrorist attacks,â€ he added. Do not politicize intelligence ! #FactsMatter. Joseph Maguire was ousted this week as DNI acting director because Trump was reportedly furious that one of Maguireâ€™s deputies briefed the House Intelligence Committee last week that Russia was again meddling in the presidential campaign in Trumpâ€™s favor. At a Las Vegas campaign rally Friday, Trump blasted the latest Russian revelation as Democratic â€œdisinformationâ€ â€” even though itâ€™s based on information discovered by his own intelligence community. ProPublica reported Friday that Maguireâ€™s replacement, Grenell, a fierce Trump loyalist, worked in 2016 as a consultant for a Moldovan politician later accused of corruption by the U.S. Grenell also failed to notify the U.S. that he was working on behalf of a foreign politician, in apparent violation of the law, according to the online investigative publication. Check out the video above to hear McFaul discuss Russia and the presidential campaign beginning at 8:15.

Title: Mexican National Accused Of Spying For Russia In Florida
Text: A Mexican national arrested in Miami on Monday is accused of acting as a spy for Russia while digging up information on a confidential U.S. government source. Hector Alejandro Cabrera Fuentes, who is a resident of Singapore, was prevented from boarding a plane from Miami International Airport to Mexico City on Sunday following a search of his and his wifeâ€™s cellphones by U.S. Customs and Border Protection, the U.S. Justice Department said Tuesday. The search uncovered a photo of a license plate that belonged to the government source, who had been providing information to the U.S. about the Russian Intelligence Service. The photo had been deleted from Fuentesâ€™ wifeâ€™s phone, but not before it was sent to Fuentes through the messaging app WhatsApp, authorities said. The 35-year-old allegedly confessed that he had instructed his wife, who is from Mexico, to take the photo after he was recruited by a Russian government official in 2019. He told U.S. authorities he was recruited after his second wife and two children were detained by Russian customs officials during a visit in March, according to a copy of the criminal complaint. Itâ€™s not clear whether his two wives know about each other. Fuentes said that after his wife and children were detained, he traveled to Russia to see them and was approached there by an official he believed worked for the Russian government. That individual, in a later meeting, showed him a hard-copy printout of his Gmail account from 2015 and said that he knew Fuentes had been looking for real estate in the Miami area. Fuentes said he confirmed the authenticity of the printout and agreed that he had been looking for real estate, according to the complaint. The Russian official acknowledged the situation his family was in and allegedly told Fuentes that â€œwe can help each other.â€ The two men met again in Russia in September and Fuentes said he was instructed to rent property at a condominium complex in Miami where the U.S. government source lived. He was told not to rent it under his name or to let his family in Russia know about their meetings. Fuentes agreed to this deal and in December provided $20,000 to an associate to rent property in the building in the associateâ€™s name. When Fuentes and the official met again in Russia in early February, the Russian official instructed him to go to the condominium complex and locate the U.S. government sourceâ€™s vehicle using a description provided. He was then told to obtain the vehicleâ€™s license plate number and note its physical location in the buildingâ€™s parking lot. He was told not to take a photo of the vehicle. On Feb. 14, one day after flying into the U.S. from Mexico City, authorities said Fuentes and his wife were seen tailgating another vehicle to gain access to the gated condo complex where the government source resides. Once inside, he was confronted by a security guard who questioned his business at the building. Fuentes gave the guard a name of someone he was visiting but the guard did not recognize the name and asked him and his wife to leave. As this discussion was happening, Fuentesâ€™ wife snapped a photo of the license plate belonging to the U.S. government sourceâ€™s parked vehicle. Two days later, on Feb. 16, Fuentes and his wife traveled to Miami International Airport with plans to fly to Mexico City. He was arrested the following day. Fuentes is charged with acting within the United States on behalf of a foreign government without notifying the attorney general, and conspiracy to do the same. At a court hearing on Tuesday, Fuentes said he had a variety of jobs around the world. One of his jobs as a researcher at the National University of Singapore pays him $7,500 a month. Another job with an Israeli company based in Germany pays him $5,000 a month, he said, according to the Miami Herald. A LinkedIn page for Fuentes lists him as having studied biology and biochemistry at universities in both Germany and Russia. Fuentes was assigned a public defender after reportedly telling the judge that it would be difficult for him to acquire money to pay for his own defense attorney. â€œNone of my family knows Iâ€™m here,â€ he told the judge, according to the Herald. A pretrial detention hearing has been set for Friday morning.

Title: Trump Admits He Sent Rudy Giuliani To Ukraine After Denying It
Text: President Donald Trump now admits he sent his personal attorney Rudy Giuliani to Ukraine to dig up dirt on 2020 Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden and his son Hunter, a central part of Trumpâ€™s impeachment. Trump on Thursday explained why he chose to â€œuse Rudyâ€ in an interview for Fox News host Geraldo Riveraâ€™s podcast, perhaps feeling at ease after being acquitted by the Republican-led Senate earlier this month. â€œWas it strange to send Rudy Giuliani to Ukraine, your personal lawyer? Are you sorry you did that?â€ Rivera asked Trump. â€œNo, not at all,â€ Trump said. â€œHereâ€™s my choice: I deal with the Comeys of the world, or I deal with Rudy,â€ he continued, referring to former FBI Director James Comey, whom he fired in 2017 after the FBI began investigating his 2016 campaign. The investigation mushroomed into special counsel Robert Muellerâ€™s probe of Russian election interference. Trump said he has â€œa very bad tasteâ€ for U.S. intelligence officials because of Muellerâ€™s investigation, so he chose Giuliani to do his bidding. â€œSo when you tell me, why did I use Rudy? And one of the things about Rudy, number one, he was the best prosecutor, you know, one of the best prosecutors, and the best mayor,â€ Trump told Rivera. â€œBut also, other presidents had them. FDR had a lawyer who was practically, you know, was totally involved with government. Eisenhower had a lawyer. They all had lawyers.â€ In November, Trump denied that he sent Giuliani to Ukraine, despite congressional testimony from multiple witnesses, including career diplomats and government officials, who said Giuliani met with and pressured Ukrainian officials as part of Trumpâ€™s plot to coerce a foreign government into aiding his reelection. â€œNo, I didnâ€™t direct him, but he is a warrior, he is a warrior,â€ Trump said in an interview on former Fox News host Bill Oâ€™Reillyâ€™s radio show, when asked if he instructed Giuliani to â€œdo anythingâ€ in Ukraine. But then-ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sondland testified that Trump gave him â€œexpress directionâ€ to work with Giuliani. Giuliani also was mentioned in Trumpâ€™s July 25 phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, when Trump told Zelensky to â€œspeak to him.â€ â€œMr. Giuliani is a highly respected man,â€ Trump said, according to the summary of the call released by the White House. â€œHe was the mayor of New York City, a great mayor, and I would like him to call you. I will ask him to call you along with the Attorney General. Rudy very much knows whatâ€™s happening and he is a very capable guy. If you could speak to him that would be great.â€ Giuliani said this week his Ukraine snooping uncovered â€œsmoking gunâ€ evidence of the Bidensâ€™ involvement in corruption. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.), a prominent Trump defender, said Attorney General William Barr told him there would be an â€œintake processâ€ for Giuliani to funnel his dirt to the Justice Department.

Title: Rudy Giuliani: Dems 'Want To Literally Kill Me' Over Bonkers Ukraine Conspiracy Theory
Text: Former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani on Thursday spun a wild new conspiracy theory involving a â€œbunch of Democratsâ€ and Ukraine â€• and said they want to â€œliterallyâ€ kill him over it. Giuliani, the personal attorney to President Donald Trump, told Fox Business host Trish Regan he had â€œsmoking gunâ€ evidence of money laundering by Hunter Biden, son of Joe Biden, the former vice president now running for president. Giuliani did not present such evidence, but read an email on his iPad that he said was between the governments of Latvia and Ukraine detailing â€œa corruption affairâ€ involving the younger Biden. He also said the plot runs even deeper. â€œItâ€™s not just Biden,â€ he said. â€œBunch of Democrats. Thatâ€™s why theyâ€™re so crazy on the subject of Ukraine, and why they want to literally kill me.â€ .@RudyGiuliani says there is more to this #Ukraine corruption scandal than the #Bidens - #Giuliani says he has the proof, and he's ready to EXPOSE the corruption - and that's why people are after him, watch: #TrishRegan  Trump was impeached for withholding U.S. aid to Ukraine to pressure the nation into digging up dirt on the Bidens. He was acquitted by the GOP-led Senate. Giuliani has claimed heâ€™s been doing his own investigation on Ukraine. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.), a prominent Trump defender, said Attorney General William Barr told him there would be an â€œintake processâ€ for information from Giuliani on the presidentâ€™s political opponents. The House Judiciary Committee has complained that such a process is â€œa significant departureâ€ from the departmentâ€™s â€œtraditional channelsâ€ of investigation.

Title: John Kelly: Vindman Was Right To Report Trump's 'Questionable' Ukraine Dealings
Text: Former White House chief of staff John Kelly praised Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, a key witness in the impeachment case against Donald Trump, for reporting the presidentâ€™s â€œquestionableâ€ Ukraine dealings to his superiors last summer. â€œHe did exactly what we teach them to do from cradle to grave,â€ Kelly said during a speech Monday at Drew University in Morristown, New Jersey, according to The Atlantic. â€œHe went and told his boss what he just heard.â€ Vindman, an expert on Ukrainian affairs, was one of several National Security Council officials to listen in on Trumpâ€™s notorious July 25 call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. He testified during the Houseâ€™s impeachment inquiry in November that he was so disturbed by Trumpâ€™s efforts to get Zelensky to investigate Democratic rival Joe Biden that he reported it to the NSCâ€™s top lawyer. Trump removed Vindman and his twin brother, Lt. Col. Yevgeny Vindman, from the NSC last week, just days after the Senate voted to acquit the president. Trump also fired Gordon Sondland, another impeachment witness who had served as the U.S. ambassador to the European Union. Kelly told the audience Monday that Vindman was rightly disturbed by Trumpâ€™s call with Zelensky and acted as a good soldier by flagging it. He said Trumpâ€™s decision to condition U.S. military aid to Ukraine on an investigation into Biden marked a major shift in U.S. foreign policy and probably sounded like â€œan illegal orderâ€ to Vindman. â€œWe teach them, â€˜Donâ€™t follow an illegal order. And if youâ€™re ever given one, youâ€™ll raise it to whoever gives it to you that this is an illegal order and then tell your boss,â€™â€ Kelly said, per The Atlantic. After Kelly served as the homeland security secretary for about seven months, Trump tapped him to replace Reince Priebus as White House chief of staff. He held that position until he resigned in January 2019. Tensions between Kelly and Trump were widely reported during his tenure as chief of staff. The retired U.S. Marine Corps general once reportedly called the White House a â€œmiserable place to work.â€ Kelly didnâ€™t appear to hold back much during his appearance at Drew University on Monday. He condemned Trumpâ€™s infamous claim in 2015 while running for president that migrants crossing into the U.S. from Mexico are â€œrapistsâ€ and drug dealers. â€œIn fact, theyâ€™re overwhelmingly good people,â€ Kelly said Monday. â€œTheyâ€™re not all rapists and theyâ€™re not all murderers, and itâ€™s wrong to characterize them that way. I disagreed with the president a number of times.â€ He also hit out at Trumpâ€™s decision to intervene in the case of Eddie Gallagher, a Navy SEAL who was convicted of posing with the corpse of a teenage fighter for the self-described Islamic State. The Navy demoted Gallagher for his actions, but Trump reversed it. â€œThe idea that the commander-in-chief intervened there, in my opinion, was exactly the wrong thing to do,â€ Kelly said. â€œHad I been there, I think I could have prevented it.â€ Though heâ€™s tried to distance himself from some of the Trump administrationâ€™s most controversial policies since resigning, Kelly helped implement some of them during his time in office. For instance, he supported the notorious family separation policy that split up parents who illegally crossed into the U.S. from their children at the border. He has also come under fire for protecting then-White House aide Rob Porter in the face of domestic violence allegations made by his ex-wives â€• and for just being an all-around jerk. Trump lashed out at Kelly in a series of tweets Thursday morning, accusing his former chief of staff of being unable to â€œkeep his mouth shut.â€ â€œWhen I terminated John Kelly, which I couldnâ€™t do fast enough, he knew full well that he was way over his head,â€ the president wrote. â€œHe came in with a bang, went out with whimper.â€ When I terminated John Kelly, which I couldnâ€™t do fast enough, he knew full well that he was way over his head. Being Chief of Staff just wasnâ€™t for him. He came in with a bang, went out with a whimper, but like so many Xâ€™s, he misses the action & just canâ€™t keep his mouth shut,. ....which he actually has a military and legal obligation to do. His incredible wife, Karen, who I have a lot of respect for, once pulled me aside & said strongly that â€œJohn respects you greatly. When we are no longer here, he will only speak well of you.â€ Wrong! Head over to The Atlantic to read the full report.

Title: House Judiciary Goes After AG Barr Over Back Channel For Giuliani To Give Info On Ukraine
Text: The House Judiciary Committee sent a letter to Attorney General William Barr on Monday demanding answers regarding the Justice Departmentâ€™s new so-called â€œintake processâ€ to receive information from Rudy Giuliani about Ukraine and the Bidens. Rep. Jerry Nadlerâ€™s (D-N.Y.) letter comes hours after Barr admitted that the department would evaluate material that Giuliani, President Donald Trumpâ€™s personal attorney, had collected from Ukrainian sources claiming to have damaging information about 2020 candidate and former Vice President Joe Biden and his son Hunter Biden. Giulianiâ€™s gathering of such information was a huge part of Trumpâ€™s attempt to get Ukraine to announce an investigation into the Bidens ahead of the 2020 U.S. presidential election, which led to the presidentâ€™s impeachment (and eventual acquittal). Much of what the former New York City mayor has said to media outlets so far has consisted of conspiracy theories and misinformation. â€œAs you know, the Department has formal, established channels by which to receive information and begin investigations,â€ Nadler wrote in the letter. â€œThis new channel to Mr. Giuliani would seem to be a significant departure from those traditional channels.â€ NEW: @RepJerryNadler sent a letter to AG Barr to demand answers after @LindseyGrahamSC and Barr admit that Rudy Giuliani is sending information concerning Ukraine to the Department of Justice through a special intake process.  Nadler cited Sen. Lindsey Grahamâ€™s interview on Sunday with Face the Nation where the South Carolina Republican said Barr told him about a so-called â€œintake processâ€ in which Giuliani â€œcould give informationâ€ and that the Justice Department would â€œsee if itâ€™s verified.â€ Barr later confirmed at a press conference on Monday morning that the Justice Department does in fact have such a process to receive information relating to Ukraine and the Bidens, including â€œanything Mr. Giuliani might provide.â€ The attorney general and other Justice Department officials tried to hedge the answer by alleging that Giuliani was being treated the same as any other tipster. ICYMI: AG Barr responds to comments made by @LindseyGrahamSC on @FacetheNation Sunday where he said @TheJusticeDept "process" would let @RudyGiuliani turn over info from Ukraine. Barr says he has an open door policy to â€œanybody.â€ WATCH-->  â€œYour announcement also represents a significant departure from your past statements about Mr. Giuliani,â€ Nadler wrote. â€œOn September 25, the Department confirmed it had not been asked by the President to â€˜contact Ukraine â€• on this or any other matter. The attorney general has not communicated with Ukraine â€• on this or any other subject. Nor has the attorney general discussed this matter or anything relating to Ukraine, with Rudy Giuliani.â€™â€ â€œTo the extent that statement is no longer accurate, any official relationship between Mr. Giuliani and the Department raises serious questions about conflicts of interest â€• both for the Department, generally, and for you, specifically,â€ Nadler continued, citing Giuliani associate Lev Parnasâ€™ allegation that Barr knew virtually everything about communications with Ukraine. â€œWhether or not you are in league with Mr. Giuliani and his associates, DOJ guidelines and regulations exist to protect you and the Department from even the appearance of a conflict of interest or any impropriety.â€ A spokesperson for the Justice Department did not immediately respond to HuffPostâ€™s request for comment, though a department official told The Washington Post that Giuliani had â€œrecentlyâ€ shared information through the process described by Barr. The information is reportedly being vetted through the U.S. Attorneyâ€™s Office in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, according to the Post. Nadler asked Barr to answer a series of questions regarding the so-called â€œintake processâ€ for Giuliani and the attorney generalâ€™s relationship with the presidentâ€™s personal attorney. Barr has until Feb. 25 to respond to the questions. Giuliani is currently being investigated himself by the Justice Department, a case that has so far led to campaign finance charges against Parnas and fellow associate Igor Fruman. Both Parnas and Fruman helped Giuliani in his pursuits related to Ukraine.

Title: Internal Fox News Research Reportedly Warns About Fake News ... On Fox News
Text: An internal Fox News report on Ukraine scandal coverage warns about disinformation â€” on Fox News â€” by frequent guests, including Donald Trumpâ€™s personal attorney Rudy Giuliani, according to a copy obtained by The Daily Beast. The first page of the research briefing book was also posted Thursday on Twitter by a former Fox News freelance producer. Here's the front page of the internal Fox News Trump-Ukraine timeline. I'll start tweeting some of the highlights shortly.  Giuliani is described in the 162-page report, â€œUkraine, Disinformation & the Trump Administration,â€ as having a â€œhigh susceptibility to disinformation.â€ The report also singles out John Solomon, a frequent guest of Sean Hannity and a former right-wing columnist for The Hill. Heâ€™s widely considered the key source of baseless conspiracy theories concerning Ukraine, including that it was Ukraine and not Russia that interfered in the 2016 U.S. presidential election. Concerns about Solomon include allegations of â€œnon-disclosure of conflicts, use of unreliable sources, publishing false and misleading stories, misrepresentation of sources, and opaque coordination with involved parties,â€ the Fox report states, according to the Beast. â€œJohn Solomon played an indispensable role in the collection and domestic publication of elements of this disinformation campaignâ€ on Ukraine, according to the document. Married Trump supporters Victoria Toensing and Joe diGenova, lawyers who have been frequent Fox News guests, have also spread â€œdisinformationâ€ concerning Ukraine while employed by Ukrainian oligarch Dmytro Firtash. He is fighting extradition to the U.S. to face bribery-related charges. The research report was created by Fox News senior political affairs specialist Bryan S. Murphy, who produces research as part of the Fox â€œBrain Roomâ€ that provides information and data for network programming, according to The Daily Beast. The four people singled out in the report have appeared 348 times on Fox News weekday programs since 2018, according to Media Matters. About 203 of them were on Hannityâ€™s program alone. A Fox News senior vice president, Mitch Kweit, said the report was â€œbeing taken out of context and politicized to damage the network,â€ The Guardian reported. He called the briefing book â€œnothing more than a comprehensive chronological account of what every person involved in the Ukraine controversy was doing at any identifiable point in time.â€

Title: Alexander Vindman, Army Officer Who Testified Against Trump, Escorted Out Of White House
Text: Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, a decorated Army officer who served as the Ukraine expert on the National Security Council, was escorted out of the White House on Friday after reports surfaced that President Donald Trump would be punishing people who testified during his impeachment trial. Vindman is a national security official who testified about his knowledge of a July 2019 call with the Ukrainian president that set off Trumpâ€™s impeachment inquiry and proceedings. Up until Friday, Vindman worked in the White House and his term in the NSC would have ended in July. The White House planned to inform Vindman that he was being moved into a role at the Pentagon, The Washington Post reported late Thursday night, citing two people familiar with the plan. Vindman had previously told senior officers that he planned to leave his posting early, the Post reported, but Trump reportedly wanted to make him a target for his fury. The officerâ€™s lawyer confirmed to HuffPost that Vindman was escorted from the White House on Friday, adding that he was â€œasked to leave for telling the truth.â€ â€œThere is no question in the mind of any American why this manâ€™s job is over, why this country now has one less soldier serving it at the White House,â€ attorney David Pressman said in a statement. â€œLTC Vindman was asked to leave for telling the truth. His honor, commitment to right, frightened the powerful.â€ Vindmanâ€™s twin brother, Army Lt. Col. Yevgeny Vindman, was also fired and escorted out of the White House. â€œLt. Col. Yevgeny Vindman, a senior lawyer and ethics official at the National Security Council, and a decorated Iraq war veteran, was escorted off of the grounds of the White House, suddenly and with no explanation, despite over two decades of loyal service to this country,â€ Pressman told HuffPost. â€œHe is deeply disappointed that he will not be able to continue his service at the White House.â€ Hereâ€™s the full statement from Lt. Col. Vindmanâ€™s attorney saying he was escorted out of the White House today  Earlier on Friday, ahead of a trip to North Carolina, Trump hinted at Vindmanâ€™s dismissal when asked by a reporter whether he wanted to see the officer â€œoutâ€ of the White House. â€œWell, Iâ€™m not happy with him,â€ Trump told reporters. â€œDo you think Iâ€™m supposed to be happy with him? Iâ€™m not.â€ Vindman was the first person to testify in the Houseâ€™s impeachment hearings who had personally listened in on Trumpâ€™s July 25 call with the Ukrainian president, and he told lawmakers he repeatedly expressed concerns to his superiors that Trumpâ€™s behavior was inappropriate. Trumpâ€™s allies moved to smear Vindman at the time, despite his extensive military career and rÃ©sumÃ©, but the officer said he acted out of a â€œsense of dutyâ€ and did not fear retribution. â€œDo not worry, I will be fine for telling the truth,â€ Vindman told his father during his remarks at a House Intelligence Committee hearing in November. Despite hopes from some Republicans that Trump might have learned his â€œlessonâ€ after being impeached, the president has signaled that he plans to continue to target his political opponents. He attacked House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) as a â€œhorrible personâ€ on Thursday during what he called an acquittal â€œcelebration.â€ He called the investigations into his actions â€œevilâ€ and has all but assured that he plans to use the outcome to drum up support and fundraising going into his 2020 reelection campaign. The Post noted Thursday that Trumpâ€™s ire may extend throughout the White House to other administration officials who spoke or testified during the impeachment inquiry. During the House impeachment hearings, dozens of current and former officials detailed the presidentâ€™s demand that the leader of Ukraine announce that he was opening an investigation into political rival Joe Biden and Bidenâ€™s son Hunter. The story has been updated to note that Army Lt. Col. Yevgeny Vindman has also been fired from his White House job.

Title: Marie Yovanovitch: 'It Is The American Way To Speak Up About Wrongdoing'
Text: Marie Yovanovitch, the former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine who testified against President Donald Trump in the House impeachment inquiry, is hopeful that Americans â€œwill persist and we will prevail,â€ she wrote in a Washington Post op-ed published Thursday, after announcing her retirement from her decadeslong diplomatic career. Yovanovitch testified that she was the target of a bad-faith smear campaign by Trump and his allies, who wanted to â€œget rid of her,â€ and eventually ousted her. Trump issued threats against her on a July 25 phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, an incident central to the congressional inquiry against Trump. On the call, Trump asked Ukraineâ€™s government to investigate former vice president and 2020 Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden â€” effectively asking a foreign government to intervene in a U.S. election. In November, Yovanovitch and several other career U.S. officials testified before the House Intelligence Committee in the impeachment proceedings against Trump. She did it, she wrote, â€œbecause it is the American way to speak up about wrongdoing.â€ Her op-ed continued: I have seen dictatorships around the world, where blind obedience is the norm and truth-tellers are threatened with punishment or death. We must not allow the United States to become a country where standing up to our government is a dangerous act. It has been shocking to experience the storm of criticism, lies and malicious conspiracies that have preceded and followed my public testimony, but I have no regrets. I did â€” we did â€” what our conscience called us to do. We did what the gift of U.S. citizenship requires us to do. Yovanovitch implored Americans to do their part to preserve essential freedoms and stand up against wrongdoing. â€œUnfortunately, the last year has shown that we need to fight for our democracy,â€ she wrote. â€œâ€˜Freedom is not freeâ€™ is a pithy phrase that usually refers to the sacrifices of our military against external threats. It turns out that same slogan can be applied to challenges which are closer to home.â€ On Wednesday, Republicans in the Senate acquitted Trump on the two articles of impeachment, abuse of power and obstruction of Congress, on a largely party-line vote. Only one Republican, Sen. Mitt Romney (Utah), joined the Democratic minority in voting to convict Trump on the abuse of power charge. Read Yovanovitchâ€™s op-ed here.

Title: Steve Bannon Was 'Not Happy' About Story Of Kushner's Back Channel To Russia: Records
Text: Former White House strategist Steve Bannon was â€œnot happyâ€ when the media reported in 2017 that Jared Kushner had tried to establish a secret â€œback channelâ€ for communication with the Kremlin during Donald Trumpâ€™s transition into the White House, according to a new trove of documents obtained by BuzzFeed. â€œNeither Kushner nor [Michael] Flynnâ€ â€” then the national security adviser â€” â€œmentioned the meeting,â€ apparently referring to their sit-down with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak to discuss the plan, according to a summary of an interview with Bannon by investigators working with former special counsel Robert Mueller. Bannon, however, did not talk to Flynn nor Kushner about the issue, according to the summary. They were â€œnot exactly speaking at the time,â€ the summary noted, apparently referring to both men. .@LoopEmma @a_cormier_ & I have gone through the latest batch of the #MuellerMemos (FBI 302s) we obtained via our #FOIA lawsuit and despite all the redactions there are A LOT of new details that were not included in the Mueller report. STORY:  The information is buried in hundreds of pages of interview summaries obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request by BuzzFeed reporter Jason Leopold. Despite his concerns about the â€œback channel,â€ Bannon told investigators he didnâ€™t think the â€œstuffâ€ regarding Russian President Vladimir Putin and his links to the White House were â€œa big deal,â€ according to the summary. Russiaâ€™s â€œreach outsâ€ after the election were not â€œany different than any other countryâ€™s,â€ Bannon told investigators. â€œFor example, the Japanese prime minister wanted to fly over and have a cup of coffee,â€ he said, BuzzFeed reported. Bannon also noted that the White House transition was chaotic because few people had expected Trump to win. â€œPeople in the campaign thought it was not necessary to have a strong transition team going into the election, in part because they were so far down in the polls,â€ Bannon explained in Millerâ€™s office in early 2018, according to another summary. â€œTrump was also superstitious about things like that. Bill Hagerty, the director of the transition, had scheduled a trip to the Bahamas for after the election, assuming they would not win.â€ At some point, Flynn went to see Obamaâ€™s national security adviser, Susan Rice, and her deputy, Ben Rhodes, for advice about â€œhow to do things.â€ NEW: Steve Bannon told the FBI and prosecutors during a meeting at Mueller's office that after the election, Michael Flynn sought out Obama's national security adviser Susan Rice and her deputy, Ben Rhodes, for advice â€œabout how to do things.â€  Kushnerâ€™s name came up in Bannonâ€™s interview â€” but no details were released in his own interview. Nearly every single word was redacted in the five-page summary of Kushnerâ€™s November 2017 interview with FBI agents and federal prosecutors, BuzzFeed noted. NEW: We receivedJared Kushner's FBI 302 from the Mueller investigation. IT'S ALMOST ENTIRELY REDACTED#MuellerMemos  Read BuzzFeedâ€™s story and all of the released documents here.

Title: Rudy Giuliani Wants Trump To Investigate Joe Biden After Senate Impeachment Vote
Text: Rudy Giuliani said his client President Donald Trump should continue trying to investigate Joe Biden after his impeachment trial, even if the Senate acquits him Wednesday, as expected, on charges related to such behavior. The former New York City mayor sat with NPRâ€™s Steve Inskeep for an interview that aired Tuesday. Giuliani spoke about the Senate trial regarding the presidentâ€™s attempts to withhold military aid to Ukraine in exchange for the countryâ€™s announcement of an investigation into the former vice president and his son Hunter Biden. â€œBiden should be investigatedâ€ after the trial ends, â€œ100%,â€ Giuliani told Inskeep. â€œI would have no problem with him doing it. In fact, I would have a problem with him not doing it. I think he would be saying that Joe Biden can get away with selling out the United States, making us a fool in the Ukraine.â€ "Absolutely; 100%," Giuliani told @NPRinskeep. â€œI would have no problem with [Trump] doing it. In fact, I'd have a problem with him not doing it. I think he would be saying that Joe Biden can get away with selling out the United States, making us a fool in the Ukraine." Giuliani was central in the events that led up to the House conducting an inquiry that resulted in Trumpâ€™s impeachment in December. The presidentâ€™s personal attorney conducted shadow diplomacy for Trump with Ukrainian officials to get them to announce an investigation into the Bidens, the younger who served on the board of Ukrainian gas company Burisma while his father â€• who is now one of Trumpâ€™s 2020 rivals â€• served as vice president of the United States. Trump is accused of withholding congressionally approved U.S. military aid to Ukraine while pushing for the countryâ€™s president to announce the investigation. â€œHeâ€™s the chief law enforcement officer of the United States. He certainly shouldnâ€™t back away from it,â€ Giuliani said of Trump investigating Biden. Technically, the U.S. attorney general is the chief law enforcement officer, serving in the executive branch under the president. Giuliani told Inskeep that heâ€™s still looking into the Bidensâ€™ relationship with Ukraine, despite there being no evidence of wrongdoing by the Bidens. Asked if heâ€™s investigating Biden on the presidentâ€™s orders, Giuliani said, â€œHe hasnâ€™t told me not to do it.â€ The attorneyâ€™s comments to NPR come as the Senate prepares for a vote in the impeachment trial Wednesday that will likely end in the presidentâ€™s acquittal. All 53 Republican senators are expected to vote against convicting Trump on the charges â€• abuse of power and obstruction of Congress â€• after almost all refused to allow witnesses in the trial. Some senators, such as Lamar Alexander (R-Tenn.) and Susan Collins (R-Maine), expressed disappointment with Trumpâ€™s actions and said it was inappropriate to ask a foreign leader to investigate a political opponent. But both lawmakers still plan to acquit the president, with Collins saying Tuesday that she believes Trump â€œhas learned from this caseâ€ and â€œwill be much more cautious in the future.â€ Susan Collins, in saying she wonâ€™t vote to remove Trump, says he learned a lesson. Trump has repeatedly said he behaved perfectly and did nothing wrong. But Giulianiâ€™s remarks Tuesday signify otherwise: â€œI believe that it would be one of the great corrupt events in American history if this case is not investigated at the highest levels of two governments.â€

Title: Lindsey Graham Wants To Call Whistleblower After Trial To Ask 'How All This Crap Started'
Text: Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) told Fox News on Sunday that the Ukraine whistleblower will be called before the Senate Intelligence Committee after the impeachment trial because â€œI want to find out how all this crap started.â€ Graham is also threatening to go after former Vice President Joe Biden and his son Hunter when the trial is over, even though Donald Trumpâ€™s impeachment defense team failed to demonstrate a single ethics violation or crime by either man. As for the whistleblower, who is protected from retaliation by federal law, Graham told Fox host Maria Bartiromo: â€œThe Senate Intel Committee under [Sen.] Richard Burr (R-N.C.) has told us that we will call the whistleblower. Why is it important? I want to find out how all this crap started.â€ Graham, a vociferous apologist for Trump, added: â€œThe day of reckoning is coming.â€ Graham said he wants to know â€œif the whistleblower is a former employee [or] associate of Joe Biden,â€ or â€œwas working with peopleâ€ on Rep. Adam Schiffâ€™s (D-Calif.) staff. Republicans have presented no information that either case is true. â€œWeâ€™re going to get to the bottom of all of this to make sure this never happens again,â€ Graham said. The whistleblower did not testify at the House impeachment hearing (the Senate called no witnesses) because information the whistleblower provided was confirmed by other documents or witnesses under oath. Corroboration included Trumpâ€™s own rough transcript of his phone call last year with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky in which he pressured Zelensky to launch an investigation into unfounded accusations against Joe Biden â€” while Trump was withholding military aid from the nation. Federal law protecting a whistleblowerâ€™s identity is designed to encourage government employees with information of wrongdoing to come forward. Some Republicans and Trump supporters have revealed the identity of someone they claim is the whistleblower, which the whistleblowerâ€™s attorney has argued puts his clientâ€™s life at risk. At the Senate impeachment trial last week, Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) submitted a question to Chief Justice John Roberts reportedly naming the whistleblower in order to deliberately expose the personâ€™s identity. Roberts refused to read Paulâ€™s question. Republicans claim that Biden, who was pressuring Ukraine to crack down on corruption in the nation while he was vice president, was attempting to block investigations into Ukraine energy company Burisma while his son was on the company board. But the vice president was pushing Ukraine to oust a prosecutor widely viewed by U.S. and European allies as corrupt. A Ukrainian investigation into Burisma was closed before Biden came on the scene, according to reports. Check out Grahamâ€™s interview in the video above. He talks about the whistleblower at 7:26.

Title: GOP Sen. Lamar Alexander: Trump Made 'Mistake' By Pushing Russian Propaganda
Text: Sen. Lamar Alexander (R-Tenn.) on Sunday defended his key vote to block witnesses from being called in the impeachment trial, saying President Donald Trumpâ€™s dealings with Ukraine were â€œwrongâ€ but not impeachable. The Tennessee lawmaker told NBC Newsâ€™ â€œMeet the Pressâ€ that he will vote on Wednesday to acquit Trump, despite the presidentâ€™s â€œinappropriateâ€ actions and his â€œmistakeâ€ of echoing Russian talking points to Ukraineâ€™s president. â€œI think he shouldnâ€™t have done it,â€ Alexander said of Trump conditioning U.S. military aid on Ukraine investigating political rival Joe Biden. â€œI think it was wrong. Inappropriate was the way Iâ€™d say â€• improper, crossing the line.â€ Alexander, who is retiring instead of seeking reelection this year, said he believes Trumpâ€™s actions were â€œa long way from treason, bribery, high crimes and misdemeanorsâ€ and that American voters should decide Trumpâ€™s fate in the 2020 election. He said Trump, if he was truly concerned about Biden, should have asked Attorney General William Barr â€• not Ukraine â€• to look into the matter. WATCH: @SenAlexander says â€œmaybe [Trump] did not know how toâ€ call the AG to look into Bidens and Burisma. #MTP@chucktodd: â€œAt what point is he no longer new to this?Sen. Alexander: â€œWell, the bottom line, it's not an excuse.â€  Asked why he believes Trump didnâ€™t go to Barr, Alexander said Trump â€œmaybe didnâ€™t know how to do it.â€ â€œAt what point, though, is he no longer new to this?â€ host Chuck Todd asked, noting that Republicans often defend Trumpâ€™s controversial actions by saying heâ€™s a political outsider. â€œWell, the bottom line, itâ€™s not an excuse,â€ Alexander said. â€œHe shouldnâ€™t have done it. And I said he shouldnâ€™t have done it.â€ Todd then asked whether heâ€™s concerned that the Senate likely acquitting Trump could encourage the president to continue seeking foreign interference. â€œI donâ€™t think so,â€ Alexander said. â€œI hope not. I mean, enduring an impeachment is something that nobody should like. Even the president said he didnâ€™t want that on his resume. I donâ€™t blame him. So if a call like that gets you an impeachment, I would think he would think twice before he did it again.â€ WATCH: @SenAlexander says he hope Pres. Trump does not continue to engage in foreign interference. #MTP #IfItsSundaySen. Alexander: â€œIf a call like this gets you an impeachment, I would think he would think twice before he did it again.â€  Todd also questioned Alexander about Trumpâ€™s peddling of Russian propaganda during his infamous July 25 phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Trump had mentioned a debunked conspiracy theory pushed by the Kremlin that alleges Ukraine interfered in the 2016 election. The U.S. intelligence community has repeatedly rejected the claim. â€œDoes it bother you that the President of the United States is reiterating Russian propaganda?â€ Todd asked. Alexander said yes. â€œI think thatâ€™s a mistake,â€ the senator continued. â€œI think we need to be sensitive to the fact that the Russians are out to do no good, to destabilize Western democracies, including us, and be very wary of theories that Russians come up with and peddle.â€ Alexander, widely seen as one of a few swing votes, helped cinch the GOP effort to block a Democratic motion to call witnesses during the impeachment trial. He announced Thursday, after the final day of the trialâ€™s question-and-answer portion, that he would vote against the motion because he doesnâ€™t need any more evidence to know what Trump did. The Senate ultimately voted 51-49 to block witnesses. Just two Republicans â€• Sens. Mitt Romney of Utah and Susan Collins of Maine â€• joined Democrats in voting in favor of the motion. Republicans have been twisting themselves into knots to justify acquitting Trump. Sen. Joni Ernst (R-Iowa), during an appearance Sunday on CNNâ€™s â€œState of the Union,â€ danced around questions about whether Trump was â€œwrongâ€ to ask Ukraine to investigate Biden. â€œI think ferreting out corruption is absolutely the right thing to do,â€ Ernst said. â€œItâ€™s probably something that I wouldnâ€™t have done.â€ Host Jake Tapper noted that Trump never mentioned the word â€œcorruptionâ€ during his July 25 call with Zelensky. â€œIf itâ€™s not something you would have done, why wouldnâ€™t you have done it? Because it was wrong? Because it was inappropriate?â€ Tapper pressed. â€œI think, generally speaking, going after corruption would be the right thing to do,â€ Ernst said. â€œHe did it maybe in the wrong manner. But I think he could have done it through different channels.â€ "I think generally speaking, going after corruption would be the right thing to do, he did it maybe in the wrong manner. But I think that he could have done it through different channels," Republican Sen. Joni Ernst says about President Trump. #CNNSOTU

Title: Mitch McConnellâ€™s New Legacy: Impeachment Trial Rigger For Donald Trump
Text: WASHINGTON â€• Years after professing admiration for the â€œGreat Compromiserâ€ Henry Clay but then engineering a dramatic remake of the federal judiciary, Mitch McConnell is now earning a different legacy: The guy who rigged a Senate trial to protect a president impeached for trying to cheat his way to reelection. With even members of his own caucus agreeing that Donald Trump behaved badly by leveraging $391 million in taxpayer-funded foreign aid to damage a political rival, the Senateâ€™s majority leader is on the brink of acquitting Trump without hearing from a single witness â€• defying the three-quarters of Americans who say they want witnesses. â€œSadly, the constitutional travesty that he orchestrated here will serve as his legacy,â€ said George Conway, a prominent Republican Trump critic and husband of a top White House aide. â€œNot the legions of fine judges he has put on the bench, judges of the sort that would have been nominated by a President Pence even if Trump had been removed, as he rightly should have been.â€ An aide to Senate Republican leadership, speaking on condition of anonymity, rejected the idea that protecting Trump would become the most noteworthy part of McConnellâ€™s record. â€œIf you donâ€™t think his legacy on courts and the Merrick Garland decision will be at the top of his legacy then you just arenâ€™t in touch with reality,â€ the aide said, referring to McConnellâ€™s decision to block former President Barack Obamaâ€™s choice for a Supreme Court vacancy and instead to leave it open for the next president. â€œHistory is going to remember him not for being a great legislator, but as a wingman to Donald Trump. Heâ€™ll be seen as the leading sycophant to Donald Trump.â€ Other Republican defenders said McConnell was simply doing what both his constituents in Kentucky as well as most Republicans nationally wanted him to do. Missouri Republican Sen. Roy Blunt said McConnell handled the situation properly. â€œI donâ€™t think the leader is affected in any way by trying to figure out how to move through that and get to the work that needed to be done,â€ he said. â€œYou play the hand youâ€™re dealt,â€ said Scott Jennings, a Republican political consultant who has worked for McConnellâ€™s campaigns, adding that steering the GOP caucus toward removing Trump from office was never a possibility. â€œI donâ€™t know that thatâ€™s Mitch McConnellâ€™s decision to make.â€ Yet that was precisely the decision that Arizona GOP Sen. Barry Goldwater made in 1974, when he visited President Richard Nixon at the White House to tell him that he and many other Republicans in the Senate would not support him in an impeachment trial. Nixon announced his resignation the following evening rather than face removal for using the powers of his office to cover up his campaignâ€™s break-in at the Democratic National Committee. â€œItâ€™s like Nixon redux,â€ said Rice University historian Douglas Brinkley. â€œWhen the conservative leader of the Senate found out he had been lied to, he balked at Nixon. And he has a fine place in history. Mitch McConnell is going to be remembered as a lackey for Trump.â€ Thirty years after McConnell was first elected to the Senate in 1984, Republicans took control of the chamber, elevating him from minority leader to majority leader and thereby allowing him to realize a lifelong dream. Just a few years earlier, he had famously declared that his top priority was to make Obama a one-term president. Obama had nonetheless won reelection in 2012, and McConnell spoke in conciliatory tones about working with the Democratic president on bipartisan priorities. He spoke about his great love of Henry Clay, the 19th century Kentucky senator known for forging a string of major pre-Civil War compromises, and his respect for John Sherman Cooper, the mid-20 century Kentucky senator for whom McConnell had once interned. In a news conference after the 2014 midterm election, McConnell said he wanted the chamber to start working together for the common good again, as it used to. â€œThe Senate in the last few years basically doesnâ€™t do anything. We donâ€™t even vote,â€ he said. Whatever comity McConnell might have hoped for, however, dissipated when he essentially ended judicial confirmation hearings for Obamaâ€™s picks, and then vanished entirely when he refused to even acknowledge Obamaâ€™s nomination of Garland for the high court after Justice Antonin Scaliaâ€™s death. Then, when Trump unexpectedly won the 2016 election, McConnell suddenly had the opportunity to fill, assembly-line fashion, over a hundred federal court vacancies he had helped hold open with conservative nominees pre-screened by the Federalist Society. â€œThatâ€™s a long-term McConnell priority,â€ said Sarah Binder, a political science professor at George Washington University. â€œMcConnell has a very, very narrow agenda.â€ It is also a squarely mainstream Republican agenda, along with tax cuts and regulatory rollbacks â€• all of which Trump, who has little personal knowledge or interest in legislation, was happy to give him and House GOP leaders. â€œTrump comes along and McConnell comes along and their paths converge, and voila,â€ Jennings said. Which was the state of affairs right up until an intelligence community whistleblowerâ€™s complaint in August accused Trump of trying to coerce Ukraine into conducting investigations politically useful to Trump by withholding a White House meeting and $391 million in military aid. House Democratic leaders began an impeachment inquiry, then formal proceedings, and just before the Christmas recess, voted to impeach Trump â€• dropping the question of whether to remove Trump directly into McConnellâ€™s lap. On Friday, Rep. Jason Crow, a Colorado Democrat and one of the Houseâ€™s impeachment â€œmanagers,â€ asked at the trial: â€œWhat do you want your place in history to be?â€ If the question was designed to shame Republican senators, it appears not to have had that effect â€• and certainly not with McConnell, who wore a broad grin after Democratsâ€™ attempt to open the proceedings to witness testimony failed by two votes. That tally capped Senate Republicansâ€™ implicit approval of Trumpâ€™s unprecedented stonewalling of the House. In sharp contrast even to Nixon, Trump refused to turn over a single requested document and ordered all executive branch employees not to testify. McConnell openly telegraphed his intention to stand with Trump even as the House was completing impeachment proceedings in December. In a Dec. 12 appearance on Fox News, McConnell said there was â€œzero chanceâ€ Trump would be removed from office. â€œIâ€™m going to take my cues from the presidentâ€™s lawyers,â€ he said. â€œWeâ€™ll be working through this process hopefully in a fairly short period of time, in total coordination with the White House counselâ€™s office and the people who are representing the president.â€ Indeed, on Friday, McConnell made sure to get Trumpâ€™s approval of his plan to finish the trial with a Wednesday acquittal before announcing it on the floor. â€œMcConnell believes history will record Trump as his useful instrument. I think history will record McConnell as Trumpâ€™s useful instrument,â€ said Stuart Stevens, a former aide to 2012 presidential nominee Mitt Romney, who is now a senator from Utah and one of two Republicans who voted to hear from witnesses. â€œMcConnell will always be remembered as the majority leader who turned the United States Senate into a kangaroo court in order to save Donald Trump from being justly convicted and removed from office,â€ said Rick Tyler, a GOP consultant and former aide to Texas Sen. Ted Cruzâ€™s 2016 presidential campaign. Other Republicans, among them Trump critics, said McConnellâ€™s push to get conservative judges will ultimately outweigh his facts-be-damned acquittal of Trump. â€œIf the judiciary rules in a more conservative direction for the next 20 years, the trade-off for what a few insiders may view as a legacy seems unimportant in contrast,â€ said Rory Cooper, once a top aide to former House Majority Leader Eric Cantor. One McConnell supporter, a former Republican National Committee official who would only speak on the condition of anonymity, even cited Trumpâ€™s vindictiveness and the fanaticism of his core supporters to justify McConnellâ€™s approach. â€œRemoving Trump would have ignited a firestorm from which we will not recover,â€ he said. â€œI think prudence dictates they did what they did.â€ Historians, though, were dubious that McConnellâ€™s name will ever be disentangled from Trumpâ€™s, especially decades after they are long gone, when all the details of Trumpâ€™s Ukraine scandal will finally come to light. â€œMitchâ€™s hero was Henry Clay, his role model was John Sherman Cooper,â€ laughed Norman Ornstein, a congressional scholar at the conservative American Enterprise Institute. â€œNobody has done more to blow up the rules and norms of the Senate and destroy its integrity than McConnell. I knew John Sherman Cooper, and he would be appalled by his onetime protÃ©gÃ©. The way he has handled impeachment is in some ways an extension of his utterly immoral behavior, but very likely it will lead the obituary.â€ And Brinkley, the Rice University professor, said whatever thoughts McConnell might have had for being known as a Senate institutionalist are gone forever. â€œHistory is going to remember him not for being a great legislator, but as a wingman to Donald Trump,â€ Brinkley said. â€œHeâ€™ll be seen as the leading sycophant to Donald Trump.â€ Igor Bobic contributed to this report.

Title: Joe Biden Could Face Impeachment Over Ukraine If He Wins: GOP Senator
Text: Sen. Joni Ernst (R-Iowa) has warned that former Vice President Joe Biden could immediately face calls for impeachment if elected president. The first-term Republican went on the offense in an interview with Bloomberg News on Sunday, saying Bidenâ€™s prior dealings with Ukraine puts a target on his back. â€œI think this door of impeachable whatever has been opened,â€ she said. â€œJoe Biden should be very careful what heâ€™s asking for because, you know, we can have a situation where if it should ever be President Biden, that immediately, people, right the day after he would be elected would be saying, â€˜Well, weâ€™re going to impeach him.â€™â€ Ernst accused Biden of interfering in an investigation into the Ukrainian energy company Burisma. She said then-President Barack Obama tasked Biden with weeding out corruption, but that Biden ignored â€œBurisma because his son was on the companyâ€™s board making over a million dollars a year.â€ Bidenâ€™s alleged involvement in that Burisma investigation is based on an unsubstantiated claim made by President Donald Trump. Kurt Volker, the former U.S. special envoy for Ukraine, testified in the House impeachment inquiry in November that he saw no validity to Trumpâ€™s allegations of Biden being corrupt. Ernstâ€™s comments come as Trump faces his own potential ouster from office due to his dealings with money and Ukraine. Trump, whose impeachment trial in the Senate is set to conclude this week, has said that he withheld congressionally approved aid to the war-torn country due to his own concerns about internal corruption. In an interview with CNN on Sunday, Ernst said she will vote to acquit Trump on Wednesday, arguing that what he did does not merit being removed from office. "I think generally speaking, going after corruption would be the right thing to do, he did it maybe in the wrong manner. But I think that he could have done it through different channels," Republican Sen. Joni Ernst says about President Trump. #CNNSOTU  She added that Trump meant well but went about things in â€œthe wrong manner.â€ â€œI think, generally speaking, going after corruption would be the right thing to do,â€ she said. â€œHe did it maybe in the wrong manner.â€

Title: Someone Just Edited The Senate's Wikipedia Page In The Most Savage Way
Text: A prankster took a swipe at Donald Trump and declared the U.S. Senate to be â€œdeadâ€ on its Wikipedia page after Senate Republicans voted to block witnesses from testifying in the impeachment trial of the president. After the GOP lawmakersâ€™ move effectively ensured Trumpâ€™s acquittal over the Ukraine scandal, a moderator called Flyboyrob2112 edited the Senateâ€™s lengthy page introduction to just read: The United States Senate was formerly the upper chamber of the United States Congress, which, along with the United States House of Representatives â€• the lower chamber â€• comprised the legislature of the United States.
