Title: John Bolton Reportedly Says Trump Directed Him To Help Ukraine Quid Pro Quo Campaign
Text: Former White House national security adviser John Bolton claims President Donald Trump told him to assist in a campaign to coerce Ukraineâ€™s government into announcing investigations for Trumpâ€™s personal political gain, according to The New York Times. The Times published the bombshell report, which it attributed to Boltonâ€™s unpublished book, just before Fridayâ€™s resumption of Trumpâ€™s Senate impeachment trial on charges of abuse of power and obstruction of justice. It provides further reason for senators to hear from witnesses, particularly Bolton and the other White House officials he reportedly says were in the room. However, itâ€™s unlikely to change anything: Republicans already had enough votes to block witnesses, and are expected to do so later on Friday. According to the Times report, Trump during an Oval Office meeting in May allegedly directed Bolton to call Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to make sure Zelensky met with Trumpâ€™s personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani to discuss investigations targeting Trumpâ€™s political rivals. Giuliani was the point person in Trumpâ€™s shadow foreign policy mission intent on forcing Ukraine to investigate 2020 Democratic candidate Joe Biden, witnesses said during House imnpeachment proceedings against Trump. Bolton writes that he ignored Trumpâ€™s order and did not call Zelensky. The account of Trump involving Bolton in a quid pro quo arrangement with Ukraine adds further weight to the impeachment charges against the president. Bolton alleges that Trump directly orchestrated the pressure campaign, and had an obsession with Ukraine based on inaccurate information and conspiracy theories, the Times reported. Bolton also claims that White House acting chief of staff Mick Mulvaney, White House counsel Pat Cipollone and Giuliani were in the room when Trump ordered Bolton to call Zelensky. Trump denied Boltonâ€™s recounting of events in a statement and claimed the meeting Bolton described never took place. Giuliani called Boltonâ€™s description â€œabsolutely, categorically untrue.â€ The meeting Bolton describes in his book draft reportedly took place months before Trumpâ€™s July phone call with Zelensky in which he requested investigations targeting Biden. It alleges that senior Trump administration figures were aware of Trumpâ€™s quid pro quo campaign long before the details of that call became public as a result of a whistleblower complaint. Bolton has been a central figure looming outside of Trumpâ€™s impeachment trial, with Democrats demanding that he should be allowed to testify and Republicans seeking to block that from happening. The White House has also sought to prevent Bolton from publishing his book, and Trumpâ€™s lawyers in the impeachment trial have argued the manuscript is inadmissible. Republicans on Friday appeared set to vote against allowing witnesses to testify in the trial, forestalling the possibility that Bolton would become its star.

Title: Ex-DOJ Official's Chilling Warning: Donald Trump Will Do â€˜Far Far Worseâ€™ If Acquitted
Text: Former acting Solicitor General Neal Katyal on Wednesday warned that President Donald Trump will be emboldened to do â€œfar far worseâ€ if he is acquitted in his Senate impeachment trial. Neal Katyal, who served in the Justice Department role under former President Barack Obama, made the prediction on Twitter after Trumpâ€™s defense lawyer Alan Dershowitz argued during impeachment proceedings that â€œif a president does something which he believes will help him get elected in the public interest, that cannot be the kind of quid pro quo that results in impeachment.â€ â€œThe fact a President would send his lawyer out to say such grossly unconstitutional things highlights the need for impeachment,â€ Katyal tweeted in response. â€œIf he believes he can do anything, so long as 1 of his motives is to win reelection, he wonâ€™t just do Ukraine leverage again, heâ€™ll do far far worse.â€ The fact a President would send his lawyer out to say such grossly unconstitutional things highlights the need for impeachment. If he believes he can do anything, so long as 1 of his motives is to win reelection, he wonâ€™t just do Ukraine leverage again, heâ€™ll do far far worse. In a second tweet, Katyal noted how Trump will always be able to â€œassert his motives are pure/mixedâ€ and â€œbecause he thinks he can boycott the proceedings+bar all witnesses and testimony, incl his own, it means there is no way to test that, or impeach/remove him..â€ â€œIt reads the impeachment clauses out of Constitution,â€ he concluded. If he is ever accused, he can assert his motives are pure/mixed. And because he thinks he can boycott the proceedings+bar all witnesses and testimony, incl his own, it means there is no way to test that, or impeach/remove him. It reads the impeachment clauses out of Constitution. Michael Gerson, a former speechwriter for President George W. Bush, made a similar argument last week. â€œThe president never views a near-miss as an opportunity for reflection and reformation,â€ he said. â€œHe sees it as permission to indulge his every urge.â€ Trump is accused of withholding congressionally approved military aid to Ukraine in exchange for the countryâ€™s announcement of an investigation into his potential Democratic 2020 rival Joe Biden. Katyal earlier this month dared Trump to testify in the Senate trial. â€œThe fact that you donâ€™t speaks volumes and far more than your protestations of innocence on, ahem,Twitter,â€ he wrote. So come and testify and explain why 18 witnesses, many from your own Administration, have testified in Congress and thrown the book at you. So far, the count is 18-0. Your party controls the Senate. If you are innocent you should have nothing to fear. #SayItUnderOath If you really believed this, youâ€™d be trying to clear your nameâ€”clamoring for a real trial, with witnesses+docs, and you would testify under oath that you did â€œnothing wrongâ€The fact that you donâ€™t speaks volumes and far more than your protestations of innocence on,ahem,Twitter

Title: Sen. Lindsey Graham Was 'In The Loop' On Ukraine Scheme, Says Lev Parnas
Text: Rudy Giulianiâ€™s indicted business associate Lev Parnas accused Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) of being â€œin the loopâ€ on the scheme to pressure Ukraine to launch an investigation into unfounded accusations against former Vice President Joe Biden, a leading Democratic presidential candidate. Parnas, a Florida businessman who had donated to President Donald Trumpâ€™s 2016 campaign, said he was â€œ1 million percentâ€ certain that Graham was aware of the Ukraine operation. â€œRudy told me not once but on several occasions that he spoke to Lindsey Graham about the situation, that Lindsey was always aware,â€ he told Anderson Cooper in a CNN interview Wednesday night. Graham was â€œaware of what was going on going back to at least 2018, maybe even earlier,â€ Parnas said. (Check out the video above beginning at 1:30.) Parnas said it was â€œsurrealâ€ to watch Graham â€œtalking about all the stuff, that this is a sham, this should go awayâ€ â€” when â€œat the end of the day he was in the loop just like everybody else.â€ Graham could not immediately be reached for comment on Parnasâ€™s allegations. Parnas, who has been indicted for alleged campaign finance violations, has said that he worked to pressure Ukraine into announcing a probe against Biden and his son Hunter Biden to try to smear Trumpâ€™s political rival. He has alleged he was following the presidentâ€™s wishes as he worked with Giuliani, Trumpâ€™s personal attorney. Trumpâ€™s own pressure on Ukraine to launch a probe into the Bidens, along with other political conspiracy theories, while he was withholding U.S. military funds became a catalyst for the presidentâ€™s impeachment iinquiry n the House. The Trump administration initially insisted the president was merely seeking an investigation into corruption. But in a bombshell claim at Wednesdayâ€™s session of the Senate impeachment trial, Trump defense lawyer Alan Dershowitz argued that a president can essentially do anything to get reelected â€” apparently including seeking foreign influence in a U.S. election â€” if that president believes itâ€™s in the public interest. When a president â€œdoes something which he believes will help him get elected in the public interest, that cannot be the kind of quid pro quo that results in impeachment,â€ Dershowitz said. White House deputy counsel Patrick Philbin also argued in the Senate trial that Trump could take such action if the information he was pursuing was â€œcredible.â€ The Republicans have yet to substantiate any wrongdoing by Biden or his son.

Title: Trump Team Argues Anything Goes As Long As It's In Service Of Reelection
Text: WASHINGTON â€• The president of the United States can essentially do whatever he wants to get himself reelected if he believes that his own reelection would be in the public interest, a lawyer for President Donald Trump argued on Wednesday in a sweeping claim of executive power. â€œEvery public official that I know believes that his election is in the public interest,â€ Alan Dershowitz, one of the presidentâ€™s attorneys, said on the Senate floor during Trumpâ€™s impeachment trial. â€œIf a president does something which he believes will help him get elected in the public interest, that cannot be the kind of quid pro quo that results in impeachment.â€ It was an extremist view of executive power â€• instead of arguing Trump shouldnâ€™t be removed from office because he didnâ€™t do what witnesses and Democrats have accused him of, Dershowitz was arguing that he shouldnâ€™t be removed because he has the right to do basically anything he likes, as long as it doesnâ€™t violate a specific criminal statute. Heâ€™s the president, so no one can stop him. Dershowitz has argued that presidents can only be impeached for direct violations of the law. Heâ€™s argued that Trumpâ€™s pressure campaign to get the Ukrainian government to publicly announce an investigation into former Vice President Joe Biden, Trumpâ€™s political rival, doesnâ€™t warrant impeachment. On Wednesday, as members of the Senate sitting in Trumpâ€™s impeachment trial questioned the House managers and Trumpâ€™s defense attorneys on issues of fact and law, Dershowitz argued that the president had broad leeway to engage in conduct he thought might benefit his reelection and the national interest. â€œAll quid pros are not the same. Some are legitimate and some are corrupt, and you donâ€™t need to be a mind reader to figure out which is which.â€ The view extends from the attitude of Trump himself, who has said he has â€œthe right to do whatever I want as president.â€ If he can get enough of the U.S. Senate to agree to acquit him, he may be proven right. Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.), the lead House impeachment manager, pushed back on Dershowitzâ€™s argument, saying that the founders didnâ€™t write that the president could commit whatever high crimes and misdemeanors he wanted in his first term if it was in the interest of his reelection. He proposed a hypothetical situation in which the president withheld aid to a state in order to get a state attorney general to announce an investigation into a political rival. â€œIf you say you canâ€™t hold a president accountable in an election year where theyâ€™re trying to cheat in that election, then you are giving them carte blanche,â€ Schiff said. â€œAll quid pros are not the same. Some are legitimate and some are corrupt, and you donâ€™t need to be a mind reader to figure out which is which.â€ â€œFor one thing, you can ask John Bolton,â€ he added. The questions came the same day that the White House threatened Bolton, Trumpâ€™s former national security adviser, over the planned publication of his book, claiming it contains â€œsignificant amounts of classified information.â€ Boltonâ€™s unpublished manuscript reportedly confirms Democratsâ€™ core allegation: that Trump withheld military assistance from Ukraine in order to coerce that country into announcing a bogus investigation into Joe Biden, the top-polling Democrat running to unseat Trump. News of the Bolton book is hanging over the trial and a highly anticipated vote on whether to subpoena witnesses. Bolton has already said he would testify if he receives a Senate subpoena. â€œThereâ€™s no way to have a fair trial without witnesses,â€ Schiff said Wednesday. â€œTo turn him away, to look the other way, I think is deeply at odds with being an impartial juror.â€ â€œIf you have any question about it at all, you need to hear from his national security adviser. Donâ€™t wait for the book. Donâ€™t wait until March 17 when it is in black and white to find out the answer to your question,â€ Schiff said. â€œIf you have any question about it, you can erase all doubt.â€ Three Republicans who seemed open to hearing from witnesses signed onto the first question of the day, which suggested they believed Trump might have had mixed motives in withholding aid to Ukraine. Susan Collins (R-Maine), on behalf of herself, Lisa Murkowski (R-Alaska) and Mitt Romney (R-Utah) asked Trumpâ€™s lawyers how the Senate should respond if they believe Trump had more than one motive in withholding the military aid. Patrick Philbin, deputy White House counsel, argued that House managers had to argue that there was no possible public interest at all in an investigation into Joe Biden and his son Hunter. â€œOnce youâ€™re into mixed motive land, itâ€™s clear that their case fails. There canâ€™t possibly be an impeachable offense at all,â€ Philbin said. â€œThink about it: All elected officials, to some extent, have in mind how their conduct, how their decisions, their policy decisions, will affect the next election. Thereâ€™s always some personal interest in the electoral outcome of policy decisions, and thereâ€™s nothing wrong with that.â€ In a presentation on Monday evening, Dershowitz argued that Democratsâ€™ case is fatally flawed because their two impeachment articles â€• for abuse of power and obstruction of Congress â€• donâ€™t cite specific criminal actions by the president. He also said that even if Boltonâ€™s allegations are true that the president explicitly told him he was essentially extorting Ukraine â€• it wouldnâ€™t matter, because â€œquid pro quoâ€ arrangements are essential to foreign policy. â€œHe knows better.â€ Several Republicans have embraced the argument that it doesnâ€™t matter if the president engaged in a quid pro quo â€• something the president has forcefully denied for months, even though he has admitted he wanted Ukraine to investigate Joe Biden. â€œQuid pro quo doesnâ€™t matter,â€ Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) said during an interview with Fox Newsâ€™ Sean Hannity on Tuesday. On Wednesday, before the proceedings started, Dershowitz told reporters that heâ€™d received kudos for his Monday argument. â€œA number of the senators, as I was waiting for the elevator, just congratulated me on a good presentation, said I had changed some views,â€ Dershowitz said. Democrats strongly disagreed with Dershowitzâ€™s assertions. â€œHe knows better,â€ Sen. Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) said Wednesday after Dershowitz made his arguments about the public interest. â€œHe also said that ... the framers wanted us to have indictable crimes for an impeachment. Of course there were no indictable crimes at the time that they wrote that.â€ Sen. Chris Coons (D-Del.) said that Dershowitzâ€™s remarks were â€œpretty strikingâ€ and â€œdisconcerting.â€ Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) told HuffPost she plans to ask a question about the Trump teamâ€™s claim of â€œabsolute immunity.â€ She said the presidentâ€™s lawyers â€œare playing a game of whack-a-mole,â€ with the Justice Department saying the president canâ€™t be indicted and the presidentâ€™s impeachment lawyers arguing he can only be impeached for indictable conduct. She said Dershowitzâ€™s arguments were â€œnot consistent with what even he has said in the past.â€ Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-N.Y.) called Dershowitzâ€™s argument â€œbeyond absurd.â€ â€œI thought he made absolutely no sense because he essentially said that if President Trump believes his election is good for the American people, he can do whatever he wants.â€ Igor Bobic contributed reporting.

Title: The 'Useful Idiots': How These British Academics Helped Russia Deny War Crimes At The UN
Text: A group of British academics has sparked â€œwide and serious concernâ€ among diplomats after its work was used by Russia to accuse humanitarian workers in Syria of staging war crimes. A European diplomat this week joined Amnesty International in condemning the work of the Working Group on Syria, Propaganda and Media (WGSPM), saying its members were either â€œunwittingly and naively acting as agents of propaganda for the Russians, or actively support[ing] Russian disinformation.â€ None of the academics â€“ one of whom left his job last year after it emerged he was a supporter of 9/11 conspiracy theories â€“ is an expert in the Middle East, Syria or chemical weapons, and the group has previously been accused of â€œwhitewashing war crimes.â€ Yet speaking at the United Nations Security Council last week, a senior Russian official praised the â€œrecognized experts and reputable scientistsâ€ of the WGSPM, citing their work as he claimed a chemical weapons attack in 2018 never happened. The same day, another Russian official tweeted a link to the groupâ€™s work that accuses the civilian search and rescue group the White Helmets of being â€œactively involvedâ€ in murdering civilians to frame the Syrian government. There is no reliable evidence to support the theory and an investigation by the globally recognized Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) concluded that a chemical attack did occur. It is indeed very likely the victims at Douma were murdered captives. As such a potential warcrime and one that is being covered up by @opcw management, western governments and most of the mainstream media. But the truth is coming out. Although not mandated to attribute blame, the report found chlorine gas was released from two canisters that had been dropped from the air. Syrian government and Russian forces are the only ones equipped with aircraft meaning opposition forces could not have carried out the attack. It fits a well-documented pattern of chemical weapons use by the Syrian government of Bashar al-Assad against civilian targets. A European diplomat told HuffPost UK: â€œThere is wide and serious concern about the extent to which academics in the WGSPM appear to be pursuing issues which so closely overlay with Russian lies and propaganda, particularly on the use of chemical weapons in Syria. â€œRussia appears to be using these academics to amplify and bolster their own disinformation, particularly to undermine the OPCW and divert attention from their own activities. â€œIt is unclear whether these academics are unwittingly and naively acting as agents of propaganda for the Russians â€“ or they actively support Russian misinformation. â€œEither way, it is difficult to see how their involvement with WGSPM is compatible with having any official role in academia.â€ The WGSPM counts a number of academics among its members including professors Tim Hayward and Paul McKeigue of the University of Edinburgh, Professor David Miller of the University of Bristol and Dr Tara McCormack of the University of Leicester. It was established in 2017 by Piers Robinson, who used to teach at Sheffield University but left last year after HuffPost UK reported he was a supporter of 9/11 conspiracy theories. Robinson told HuffPost at the time that his â€œdecision to leave [...] was based on a number of reasons relating to both professional goals and personal circumstances,â€ and that he was not â€œcriticized or pressured to leave by the university because of my research or public statements.â€ Shadi Hamid, senior fellow and Middle East expert at the Brookings Institute thinktank, told HuffPost UK: â€œThese academics donâ€™t know enough about the Middle East to be able to sort through what is real and what is not real. â€œAnd because these people donâ€™t know a lot about the Middle East, they are susceptible to these kinds of bonkers ideas.â€ It is also an established fact that a) the White Helmets are basically Al Q (they provide most of the reporting from Jihadi held areas and b) that hospitals are used as bases by these groups. The WGSPM has published a number of papers that all echo Russian disinformation lines and suggest western governments or those working for them are actually responsible for events such as the Skripal poisoning. Some 40 people were killed in a chemical weapons attack in the Syrian town of Douma in April 2018. Shortly afterwards, the WGSPM set about trying to prove it had been staged by the White Helmets as a means of justifying the U.S., UK and French missile strikes against the Assad government that had followed. Eliot Higgins of the investigative website Bellingcat told HuffPost UK: â€œItâ€™s a theory without any evidence to support it. The â€˜working groupâ€™ are just useful idiots. â€œThis kind of denial of war crimes in Syria â€“ itâ€™s like saying vaccines cause autism, or that 9/11 was an inside job. â€œItâ€™s insane and the fact their universities still employ them is embarrassing for their universities.â€ The WGSPM does not provide any video, picture or documentary evidence to support its theory. Instead, its central argument â€” which it describes as â€œ[t]he clearest evidence that the White Helmets were actively involved in managinga massacre of civiliansâ€ â€” rests on a separate attack in 2017 which it argues Syrian jets could not have carried out because of its location. (The OPCW disagrees.) The Working Group, at something of a stretch, then concludes that â€œthe only possible alternativeâ€ is for the White Helmets to have been actively involved in â€œmanaging a massacre.â€ The WGSPMâ€™s claim that the OPCW report is wrong eschews experts and instead relies heavily on a number of dubious sources, many that the academics came across via Twitter, including: When asked by HuffPost UK about the sources the WGSPM has used in its research, Robinson stood by them all, adding: â€œWe do not â€˜rely onâ€™ these sources: in each of the instances you list, we have examined the original material and drawn our own conclusions.â€ The groupâ€™s conspiracy theory was given an apparent boost last year by a leaked internal report penned by an OPCW worker that appeared to cast doubt on the widely held belief that a chemical weapons attack had indeed taken place. But a source close to the OPCW told HuffPost UK that the document given to the Working Group was based on incorrect assumptions and ignored crucial evidence on which the OPCW investigationâ€™s final conclusions were based â€“ just one of the reasons it was not reflected in the eventual public report. A further source cited by the academics was a series of leaked anonymous emails apparently written by a different OPCW staffer questioning the organizationâ€™s work. HuffPost UK, however, has learned that much of the OPCWâ€™s investigation was conducted after the whistleblower, self-styled as â€œAlex,â€ left the organization. The OPCW has stood by its conclusion that a chemical attack using chlorine as a weapon did happen. Russia intervened in Syria in 2015 in support of President Bashar al-Assadâ€™s violent crushing of a popular revolution. It has subsequently sought to discredit and veto OPCW investigations that have directly accused its ally of a number of chemical weapons attacks. The Kremlinâ€™s version of what happened in Douma has changed numerous times, from â€œno attack happened at allâ€ to â€œBritish spies did itâ€ to â€œthe White Helmets did itâ€ and various theories in between. Kate Starbird, an expert in online disinformation networks at the University of Washington, told HuffPost UK: â€œIt has all the elements of â€˜throw as many different conspiracy theories at the wall until we find one that sticks.â€™ â€œItâ€™s taken a few years for them to find one that sticks but the techniques are so similar to what weâ€™ve seen in other events like the [downing of flight] MH17 and the Skripal poisoning.â€ Why do you refer to "Assad's Chemical Attacks"? Can you not distinguish speculation from established fact? In November last year Russiaâ€™s own OPCW representative addressed The Hague and praised the â€œdozens of experts, recognised and respected people, with remarkable international reputations, led by Professor Robinsonâ€ as it made its case that the OPCW had been hijacked by western nations in order to frame the Syrian government. Russian state media channels have been working hard to promote the narrative, and RT â€“ formerly Russia Today â€“ provided Robinson and McCormack with a platform to air their views. "You have a corruption of the independence of the OPCW"@PiersRobinson1, co-director of the Organisation for Propaganda Studies discusses war, propaganda and crushing dissent with @uniofleicester's @McCormack_Tara on @Renegade_Inc.MORE:  Caroline Orr, a behavioural scientist who specialises in disinformation networks on social media, told HuffPost UK the paper was â€œthe latest in a long line of misleading and defamatory claims from the â€˜working group.â€™â€ â€œItâ€™s done for the purpose of creating confusion about whatâ€™s going on in Syria,â€ she said, â€œto make people doubt the facts and, ultimately, to bury evidence of some of the most heinous atrocities and war crimes in modern history. â€œIf you look at the tactics they use, theyâ€™re straight out of a propaganda handbook.â€ Undeterred, Russia has stuck to the theory and last week reiterated the claim at the UN. If so, the question arises of who was involved in the staging? The White Helmets are an obvious candidate since they admit to have produced the film of the dead civilians and it is known that they were involved in arranging the bodies of the dead including children. Kristyan Benedict, Amnesty International UKâ€™s Syria campaign manager, told HuffPost UK: â€œDiscrediting the White Helmets is partly about discrediting war crimes evidence. â€œThe White Helmetsâ€™ filming at attack sites has meant theyâ€™ve built up a significant body of evidence of potential war crimes by pro-Assad and Russian forces â€“ something neither Damascus nor Moscow views kindly. â€œThe millions of Syrians whose lives have been devastated by years of barrel bombing, chemical weapons attacks, imprisonment, torture and killing deserve genuine truth and justice, not this squalid propaganda.â€ â€œThe millions of Syrians whose lives have been devastated by years of barrel bombing, chemical weapons attacks, imprisonment, torture and killing deserve genuine truth and justice, not this squalid propaganda.â€ Two days after Russia spoke at the UN, Robinson and Miller appeared at a briefing in parliament sponsored by Labourâ€™s shadow peace and disarmament minister, Fabian Hamilton. Hamilton has insisted he was unaware of who would be speaking when his office agreed to book a room for an anti-war collective â€œto discuss the OPCW report.â€ Hamiltonâ€™s spokesperson added that the shadow minister â€œdoes not support [the speakersâ€™] offensive and factually incorrect viewsâ€. His spokesperson told HuffPost UK: â€œFabian fully supports the OPCWâ€™s conclusions into the vile chemical attacks that took place in Douma in 2018. â€œAny suggestion that Fabian somehow supports the ridiculous conspiracy theories held by some of the attendees at this event are ludicrous.â€ Responding to questions from HuffPost UK, Robinson maintained that the OPCW report â€œcan reasonably be described as fraudulent by the standards applied to scientific reporting.â€ He added: â€œAs far as we know, no one is denying that the Douma incident and other alleged chemical attacks in Syria were war crimes. â€œWe are investigating these crimes, and making some progress in identifying the perpetrators and those in the media who collude with them.â€ (Infographics supplied by Statista)

Title: Trump Defense Can't Offer Evidence He Cared About Corruption Before Biden 2020 Run
Text: WASHINGTON â€• In a closely watched exchange during Wednesdayâ€™s Senate impeachment trial, President Donald Trumpâ€™s defense team struggled to point to any instances of his interest in rooting out corruption in Ukraine or Joe Bidenâ€™s involvement with that nation before the former vice president launched his Democratic presidential campaign last April. The key moment came in response to a question posed to Trumpâ€™s lawyers by Sens. Susan Collins of Maine and Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, two Republicans who may prove crucial to whether the chamber agrees to hear from witnesses and allow the presentation of new evidence in the case. For that to happen, Democrats need at least four GOP senators to break with their leadership The timeline of Trumpâ€™s interest in Ukraine corruption is potentially crucial to the validity of the impeachment charges against him leveled by the House: that he withheld military aid to the country in exchange for its government opening an investigation into Biden and his son, Hunter, who served on the board of an energy company there while his father was vice president. If Trump and his team can establish that he cared about the issue before Biden began his campaign, or was gearing up for his run, it would undermine the charge that the president was acting merely in his own political interest â€• his re-election. But deputy White House counsel Patrick Philbin acknowledged he couldnâ€™t point to a specific example of an earlier interest in the corruption matter by Trump, arguing that the presidentâ€™s defense was limited to addressing only evidence presented by the House impeachment managers. â€œThereâ€™s not something in the record on that. It wasnâ€™t thoroughly pursued in the record. So I canâ€™t point to something in the record that shows President Trump at an earlier time mentioning specifically something related to Joe or Hunter Biden,â€ Philbin said. Philbin did try to establish that Trumpâ€™s interest in rooting out corruption in Ukraine predated Bidenâ€™s presidential run because the presidentâ€™s personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, expressed a desire to travel to the country a month before Bidenâ€™s formally announced his presidential bid (speculation that he would run had been rampant for months). Philbin also argued that one could draw a â€œreasonable inferenceâ€ that Trump had simply gotten new information about the Bidens because of news coverage about his sonâ€™s business ties in Ukraine prior to the presidentâ€™s now-infamous call last July 25 with Ukranian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Trumpâ€™s prodding of Zelensky to investigate the Bidens kicked the impeachment push into gear. Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.), the lead House impeachment manager, rebutted Philbin by noting the presidentâ€™s lawyers could call a witness to offer evidence of Trumpâ€™s interest in Ukraine prior to Bidenâ€™s presidential run if they so chose. Republicans are eyeing a quick acquittal vote after senators later this week consider the issue of whether to call witnesses and allow for new evidence. Collins and Murkowski, along with Sen. Mitt Romney (R-Utah), offered the first questions of the day. They asked Trumpâ€™s lawyers how the Senate should respond if it could be determined that Trump had more than one motive in withholding the military aid to Ukraine. Philbin argued that House managers had to argue that there was no possible public interest in an investigation into the Bidens. â€œOnce youâ€™re into mixed-motive land, itâ€™s clear that their case fails. There canâ€™t possibly be an impeachable offense at all,â€ Philbin said. In response to another question from Romney about the specific date Trump ordered the hold on security assistance to Ukraine, and whether he gave a reason for doing so, Trumpâ€™s defense team again struggled to say. â€œI donâ€™t think there is evidence in the record of a specific date,â€ Philbin said, only pointing to testimony that U.S. officials were aware of the hold in early July. But Romney, a Trump critic who has expressed an interest in hearing from witnesses, wasnâ€™t satisfied with that answer. â€œIâ€™d like more information than they were apparently able to give, given the fact that that information was not in the record,â€ he told HuffPost on Wednesday.

Title: White House Issues Formal Threat To Bolton To Keep Him From Publishing Book
Text: The White House has issued a formal threat to former national security adviser John Bolton warning him against publishing an upcoming book that alleges Trump abused the power of the presidency, according to a CNN report. The warning â€• which CNN says came in the form of a letter â€• follows a New York Times report outlining key allegations of Trumpâ€™s misconduct believed to have been included in Boltonâ€™s soon-to-be-released book, â€œThe Room Where It Happened: A White House Memoir.â€ See the letter, via Associated Press reporter Zeke Miller, below: WH LETTER to Bolton lawyer claims his book as information classified at Top Secret level. Bolton and lawyer had maintained they didn't believe the draft contained any classified info.  The letter shared by Miller claims the manuscript of Boltonâ€™s book contains â€œsignificant amounts of classified information,â€ including information classified as â€œtop secret.â€ Trump posted multiple derisive tweets about Bolton on Wednesday morning, criticizing Boltonâ€™s time working for the administration and, without evidence, claiming the former national security adviserâ€™s book is â€œuntrue.â€ For a guy who couldnâ€™t get approved for the Ambassador to the U.N. years ago, couldnâ€™t get approved for anything since, â€œbeggedâ€ me for a non Senate approved job, which I gave him despite many saying â€œDonâ€™t do it, sir,â€ takes the job, mistakenly says â€œLibyan Modelâ€ on T.V., and.. ....many more mistakes of judgement, gets fired because frankly, if I listened to him, we would be in World War Six by now, and goes out and IMMEDIATELY writes a nasty & untrue book. All Classified National Security. Who would do this? Bolton is widely seen as a possible key witness in Trumpâ€™s ongoing impeachment trial, which centers on allegations Trump withheld aid from Ukraine to pressure Ukrainian officials to investigate pro-Russia conspiracy theories and former Vice President Joe Biden, Trumpâ€™s political rival. Several White House officials testified that Bolton disagreed with Trumpâ€™s conduct at the time and actively worked to stop it. On Jan. 6, Bolton announced he was willing to testify if called during the impeachment trial currently happening in the Senate. Trump and some of his allies in Congress have argued against Boltonâ€™s testimony, but on Monday, Utah Sen. Mitt Romney said it seems â€œincreasingly likelyâ€ GOP senators will vote to have Bolton testify. â€œI think itâ€™s important for us to hear from John Bolton,â€ Romney said.

Title: Republicans Now Say It Doesn't Matter If There Was A Quid Pro Quo With Ukraine
Text: WASHINGTON â€• Republicans now maintain President Donald Trump was completely justified in engaging in a quid pro quo with Ukraine after an extended period of time adamantly denying that it had ever happened at all. Last year, after the White House released a summary of Trumpâ€™s infamous July 25 conversation with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, Republicans insisted that they saw no evidence of a direct link between security assistance to Ukraine and the opening of investigations into former Vice President Joe Biden, a potential Trump opponent in the 2020 election. â€œIt clearly isnâ€™t a quid pro quo,â€ Sen. Kevin Cramer (R-N.D.) said in November after several top U.S. diplomats testified before the House that the Trump administration did, in fact, withhold aid to Ukraine in exchange for an investigation into a political opponent. Read the call record, they said over and over again, and itâ€™s clear that the aid and the investigations werenâ€™t linked. â€œIf you could show me that Trump actually was engaging in a quid pro quo, outside the phone call, that would be very disturbing,â€ Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) told Axios in October. Their position echoed White House talking points sent to Republicans on Capitol Hill (and mistakenly also to some Democrats) following Trumpâ€™s repeated denials on Twitter that there was â€œno quid pro quo.â€ â€œLetâ€™s be clear, there was no quid pro quo for Ukraine to get US aid in exchange for looking into Biden or his son,â€ said one of the talking points. But Republicans changed their story on the matter this week after The New York Times revealed the existence of a book manuscript from former national security adviser John Bolton. The book, which is due to be released later this year, alleges that Trump told Bolton directly that the aid to Ukraine was tied to the Ukrainian government opening investigations into Biden and his son. The revelation from a first-hand witness threatened to derail Republican desires for a quick acquittal of Trump in the Senate impeachment trial this week and upped the pressure on them to allow witnesses such as Bolton to testify and new documents to be presented during the proceedings. During their opening arguments in the Senate, Trumpâ€™s defense team contended that even if Boltonâ€™s account were true, it would not merit the removal of a president during an election year. Their argument opened the door for some Republican senators to acknowledge that Trump did, in fact, withhold Ukraine aid, but that it didnâ€™t merit his removal from office because he was morally justified in seeking investigations into the Bidens. â€œIt is clear to me that there is ample evidence for the President to be concerned about conflicts of interest on behalf of Hunter Biden and that Vice President Joe Bidenâ€™s failure to take appropriate action was unacceptable. This combination, in my view, undercut Americaâ€™s message on reforming corruption in Ukraine,â€ Graham said in a statement on Wednesday. Thereâ€™s no evidence that Biden or his son Hunter engaged in corruption in Ukraine. Kurt Volker, the former U.S. special envoy for Ukraine, also testified in the House inquiry that he saw no validity to Trumpâ€™s allegations against the Bidens. Trump and other Republicans only began inquiring about Hunter Bidenâ€™s role on the board of an energy company in Ukraine after his father announced his campaign for president. Other Republican senators were equally dismissive of Boltonâ€™s allegations, maintaining this week that Trump had an official reason to insist on an investigation into the Bidens, rather than a personal one. â€œQuid pro quo doesnâ€™t matter,â€ Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) said during an interview with Fox Newsâ€™ Sean Hannity on Tuesday. â€œ[Boltonâ€™s] point is what? That doesnâ€™t tell us anything,â€ Sen. John Kennedy (R-La.) added in a separate Tuesday interview with Hannity. Asked about Boltonâ€™s bookâ€™s account on Wednesday, Sen. Richard Shelby (R-Ala.) said, â€œI donâ€™t think there was any crime. I donâ€™t think it was an impeachable offense.â€

Title: Rudy Giuliani Goes After John Bolton For Book Revelations: 'He's A Backstabber'
Text: Rudy Giuliani said this week that John Bolton was a â€œbackstabberâ€ who should not testify in the Senate impeachment trial despite reports that the former national security adviser recalls President Donald Trump tying withheld Ukraine aid to an investigation into a political rival. Giuliani, Trumpâ€™s personal attorney who is integral to the allegations against the president, gave the bitter assessment of Bolton in an interview with â€œCBS This Morningâ€ that aired Wednesday. â€œHe never said to me, â€˜Iâ€™ve got a problem with what you are doing in Ukraine,â€™â€ Giuliani told CBSâ€™s Catherine Herridge. â€œNever once, never winked, never sent me a little note. He is a personal friend, I thought. So hereâ€™s the only conclusion I can come to, and itâ€™s a harsh one, and I feel very bad about it: Heâ€™s a backstabber.â€ NEW: President Trump's personal attorney @RudyGiuliani called John Bolton a "backstabber" and told @CBS_Herridge he doesn't think the former national security adviser should testify in the Senate impeachment trial. More on @CBSThisMorning Wednesday.  When Herridge noted the seriousness of putting such a label on a former White House official, Giuliani responded: â€œItâ€™s not serious. Itâ€™s true.â€ â€œIf your friend was complaining about you behind your back and didnâ€™t have the guts to come up to your face and tell you, â€˜I think youâ€™re screwinâ€™ up, Catherine,â€™ thatâ€™d be a backstabber,â€ the former New York City mayor said. â€œThatâ€™s classic backstabber. So I feel I got a swamp character here.â€ According to a New York Times report from earlier this week, Bolton wrote in a draft of his upcoming book that Trump told him he wanted to continue freezing nearly $400 million in congressionally approved military aid to Ukraine until the country agreed to announce an investigation of former Vice President Joe Biden and his son Hunter Biden. Tying the two actions together would reveal that the president attempted a quid pro quo with a foreign government for political advantage. â€œI find his testimony about the president pretty close to incredible,â€ Giuliani said. â€œI canâ€™t imagine that the president of the United States said that to him.â€ Giuliani also said he maintains regular contact with Trump and canâ€™t be part of the presidentâ€™s impeachment defense team at the Senate trial because heâ€™s a â€œpossible witness.â€ Bolton sent an unpublished manuscript to the White House for review in December as required of former administration officials writing books, and he has denied leaking the draft to the Times. WBUR reported Tuesday that Trumpâ€™s legal team said nobody outside the National Security Council has reviewed the manuscript. Trump himself denied Boltonâ€™s reported account. I NEVER told John Bolton that the aid to Ukraine was tied to investigations into Democrats, including the Bidens. In fact, he never complained about this at the time of his very public termination. If John Bolton said this, it was only to sell a book. With that being said, the... Part of Boltonâ€™s reported recollections included Giuliani himself. According to the Times, Bolton alleged that Secretary of State Mike Pompeo privately admitted there was no basis to Giulianiâ€™s claims that ousted U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch was corrupt. Bolton also reportedly wrote that acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney was present for at least one phone call in which Trump and Giuliani discussed Yovanovitch. Bolton also wrote that he expressed concern regarding Giulianiâ€™s shadow diplomacy role with Attorney General William Barr after Trumpâ€™s July 25 phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, when the alleged political â€œfavorâ€ was requested, according to the Times. The revelations led Democrats to repeat their demands for witnesses in the Senate trial, as Boltonâ€™s potential testimony could bolster House managersâ€™ argument that the president abused the power of his office to further his own political interests. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) privately conceded to fellow GOP senators late Tuesday that Republicans do not yet have the votes to block Democrats from summoning Bolton or other witnesses. With a 53-47 majority in the Senate, Republicans can afford to lose only three senators in a potential vote to call more witnesses. Hayley Miller contributed reporting.

Title: Bolton Reportedly Raised Alarm About Trump Granting Favors To China, Turkey Leaders
Text: John Bolton, the former national security adviser, told Attorney General William Barr that he was worried President Donald Trump had grown too friendly with the strongman leaders of China and Turkey, according to accounts in an unpublished book Bolton wrote that was obtained by The New York Times. In the manuscript, Bolton reportedly recalled the attorney general responding that he, too, was concerned about Trumpâ€™s affinity for Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and Chinese President Xi Jinping. Barr noted at the time that there were two Justice Department investigations into companies in the countries, and Bolton wrote that Barr was worried Trumpâ€™s fondness for the autocrats would make it seem as if the president was influencing what should be independent probes. The report Monday is the second bombshell revelation from the unpublished manuscript this week. Bolton also reportedly wrote in the book draft that Trump said he wanted to continue to hold nearly $400 million in military aid to Ukraine until the countryâ€™s leader agreed to announce an investigation into former Vice President Joe Biden and his son Hunter, the Times reported. The report, if true, counters Trumpâ€™s impeachment defense that the aid was held up merely because of concerns about general corruption and that the demand for the Biden investigation was a separate matter, not a quid pro quo. Trump has long heaped praise on both Erdogan and Xi, two leaders who have been accused of directing authoritarian regimes that crush dissent. The president said in November he was a â€œbig fanâ€ of his Turkish counterpart, just weeks after Erdogan sent troops to invade parts of Syria against U.S. wishes. Trump also cheered Xiâ€™s 2018 decision to end term limits in China. The cozy relationships have led both leaders to ask Trump for political favors. Xi personally appealed to Trump to lift sanctions on a Chinese telecommunications company, ZTE (he did), and Erdogan asked him to be kinder to a state-owned Turkish bank that was ultimately indicted last year. Trump has rejected the reported book account, writing on Twitter that he never told Bolton â€œthe aid to Ukraine was tied to investigations into Democrats.â€ â€œHereâ€™s a man who purports to care about the national security of this country,â€ White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham said Monday. â€œAnd to leave the White House and immediately go write a book, itâ€™s really disappointing ... We donâ€™t even know if whatâ€™s in the book is going to be true.â€ .@PressSec on Bolton: "Here's a man who purports to care about the national security of this country. And to leave the White House and immediately go write a book, it's really disappointing... We don't even know what's in the book is going to be true." Bolton has denied leaking the draft with the Times. The manuscript was submitted to the White House about a month ago for review. Trumpâ€™s pressure on Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky was the basis for two articles of impeachment in the House: one for abuse of power and the other for obstruction of Congress. The Senate is currently holding a trial to determine if the president should be removed from office. The revelations have been largely ignored by the presidentâ€™s attorneys defending him at his Senate trial. The lawyers have largely avoided referring to Bolton and continued to insist there was no link between the hold on the security aid and any investigation Trump wanted Ukraine to open. â€œWe deal with transcript evidence. We deal with publicly available information. We do not deal with speculation, allegations that are not based on evidentiary standards,â€ Jay Sekulow, one of Trumpâ€™s personal attorneys, said on Monday. Bolton has not testified before lawmakers but has said he would if subpoenaed.

Title: NPR Reporter Removed From State Department Trip After Pompeoâ€™s Ire, Press Group Says
Text: The State Department removed an NPR reporter from the press corps that will travel to Europe and Asia with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo later this week, just days after he angrily confronted one of the news organizationâ€™s journalists for asking questions about Ukraine. Shaun Tandon, the president of the State Department Correspondentsâ€™ Association, said Monday that Michele Kelemen, NPRâ€™s diplomatic correspondent, had been barred from the trip, which will see the secretary travel to Britain, Ukraine, Belarus and Central Asia. Tandon said the timing appeared to be direct retaliation after Pompeo unleashed a profanity-laden tirade toward another NPR reporter, Mary Louise Kelly, last week after she asked about the former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, Marie Yovanovitch. Yovanovitchâ€™s removal is a key piece of the two articles of impeachment filed against President Donald Trump in the House and his ongoing trial in the Senate. â€œWe can only conclude that the State Department is retaliating against National Public Radio as a result of this exchange,â€ Tandon said in a statement on Monday. â€œMichele is a consummate professional who has covered the State Department for nearly two decades.â€ The State Department removed NPR reporter Michele Kelemen from the press pool on â¦@SecPompeoâ© trip this week to Europe and Central Asia following his dustup w â¦@NPRKellyâ©. Read statement by â¦@shauntandonâ©, State Department Correspondents' Association president:  The State Department did not immediately respond to HuffPostâ€™s request for comment. Kelly, the co-host of NPRâ€™s â€œAll Things Considered,â€ said last week that Pompeo asked to speak with her privately after she pressed him about Ukraine in an interview. She said she was led to a living room near his office where the secretary â€œshoutedâ€ at her for about 10 minutes. â€œHe was not happy to have been questioned about Ukraine,â€ she told NPRâ€™s Ari Shapiro. â€œHe asked, â€˜Do you think Americans care about Ukraine?â€™ He used the F-word in that sentence and many others.â€ She said the secretary then asked if she could even find Ukraine on a map. When she said she could, he had an aide bring in an unlabeled map for her to prove it. Pompeo responded after Kelly shared details of the exchange, blaming what he called the â€œunhingedâ€ media and accusing the journalist of lying to him. â€œIt is shameful that this reporter chose to violate the basic rules of journalism and decency,â€ the secretary said in a statement. â€œThis is another example of how unhinged the media has become in its quest to hurt President Trump and this Administration.â€ Tandon called on the State Department to reconsider its decision to bar Kelemen from Pompeoâ€™s trip this week, saying the press corps that covers the agency is â€œdedicated to informing the public and holding this and every administration accountable by asking questions about the issues of the day.â€ â€œThe State Department has courageously defended journalists around the world through statements under its seal,â€ Tandon said Monday. â€œWe are committed to do our part to preserve a respectful, professional relationship with the institution we cover.â€

Title: Read Live Updates From Day 2 Of Trump Team's Arguments In Impeachment Trial
Text: President Donald Trumpâ€™s impeachment trial in the Senate continued on Monday with the second day of his defense teamâ€™s opening arguments. The House in December passed two articles of impeachment against Trump â€• abuse of power and obstruction of Congress â€• stemming from his efforts to get Ukraine to publicly commit to investigating political rival Joe Biden. Trump has denied any wrongdoing. Democrats are urging the Senate to call new witnesses who have direct knowledge of Trumpâ€™s handling of congressionally-approved aid to Ukraine, including former national security adviser John Bolton and acting White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney. Senate Republicans have been reluctant to do so. But an explosive report in The New York Times on Sunday that Bolton believed Trump tied the aid to Ukraine announcing his requested investigations prompted some key GOP senators to say they may vote in favor of calling such witnesses. Each side in the trial was allotted 24 hours over three days to make their opening arguments. The Democrats concluded their presentation on Friday. After Trumpâ€™s defense team wraps up its arguments, senators will have 16 hours to ask questions before voting on whether to call new witnesses. Title: Emails Show Mike Pompeo's Office Agreed To Discuss Ukraine With NPR
Text: Emails obtained by The Washington Post show that Secretary of State Mike Pompeoâ€™s staff agreed he could be asked about Ukraine in an interview with NPR, despite him later denying this and calling NPRâ€™s reporter a liar. The emails cited by the Post show that Pompeoâ€™s press aide, Katie Martin, agreed to allow the topic of Ukraine with reporter Mary Louise Kelly with the understanding that it would not be the focus of their conversation. This agreement followed some back-and-forth between the pair, as initially Martin wanted Ukraine entirely off the table. â€œIs that something we can agree to?â€ Martin asked Kelly, who co-hosts NPRâ€™s news program â€œAll Things Considered.â€ Kelly said she would like to largely focus on Iran but that she planned to also ask about Ukraine and any other hot topics that may arise before they met. â€œI never agree to take anything off the table,â€ she told Martin. The emails show Martin agreed with this arrangement. Kelly, in an email to HuffPost on Monday, said she can confirm the accuracy of the Postâ€™s report, stating reporter â€œPaul Farhi accurately describes my email exchange with Katie Martin at State.â€ In Kellyâ€™s later interview with Pompeo on Friday, the secretary balked when faced with questions about Ukraine, specifically regarding former U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch. Pompeo repeated that he only agreed to come on her program to discuss Iran. â€œI confirmed with your staff last night that I would talk about Iran and Ukraine,â€ Kelly told him. After the interview, Pompeo branded Kelly a liar in a statement released from his office that accused her of not only reneging on a promise to not discuss Ukraine but of reporting on a later conversation he had with her that he claimed was off the record. Kelly, in addressing that later conversation in her report, said that a member of Pompeoâ€™s staff asked her not to audio record their conversation but that she was never asked to agree that his words would be off the record. â€œShe did not say we were off the record, nor would I have agreed,â€ Kelly has said. According to Kelly, Pompeo yelled at her while using the â€œF-word and many othersâ€ because she questioned him about Ukraine. She said Pompeo accused her of not knowing where Ukraine is located and challenged her to point out where the country is on a map, which he ordered his staff to produce. Kelly said she correctly identified Ukraineâ€™s location when instructed. Pompeo has claimed that Kelly, who has a masterâ€™s degree in European studies from Cambridge University, was not correct. â€œIt is worth noting that Bangladesh is NOT Ukraine,â€ Pompeo said in his statement, appearing to refer to his map challenge. His statement did not deny that he yelled at Kelly or used obscenities. Pompeoâ€™s office did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Monday.

Title: Trump Lawyers Ignore John Bolton Bombshell In Senate Trial
Text: WASHINGTON â€• The bombshell revelation that former national security adviser John Bolton has written a book essentially confirming the Democratsâ€™ case against President Donald Trump went curiously unaddressed by the presidentâ€™s lawyers on Monday in the Senate impeachment trial. Boltonâ€™s book alleges that Trump tied the release of congressionally approved Ukraine aid to the Ukrainiansâ€™ announcing investigations of former Vice President Joe Biden and his son Hunter Biden, The New York Times reported on Sunday. The report caught Senate Republicans by surprise and upped the pressure for them to allow witnesses â€• Bolton included â€• to be heard and other evidence to be presented in the trial. Following the Times story, Sen. Mitt Romney (R-Utah) said it was â€œincreasingly likelyâ€ that at least four Republicans would join Democratic senators in passing a motion to subpoena Bolton. But Trumpâ€™s lawyers conspicuously avoided referring to Bolton during Mondayâ€™s arguments. Instead, they kept insisting there was no connection between the security assistance to Ukraine and any investigation desired by Trump, contrary to Boltonâ€™s reported account and the testimony of more than a dozen diplomats last fall. â€œWe deal with transcript evidence. We deal with publicly available information. We do not deal with speculation, allegations that are not based on evidentiary standards,â€ said Jay Sekulow, one of Trumpâ€™s personal attorneys, in a brief allusion to the Times story. Only Harvard Law School professor Alan Dershowitz, a member of Trumpâ€™s defense team, referred to the Bolton allegations, albeit in passing. He did so late in the evening in the middle of a one-hour lecture on why abuse of power isnâ€™t an impeachable offense â€• a theory contradicted by many experts, including Attorney General William Barr. â€œNothing in the Bolton revelations, even if true, would rise to the level of an abuse of power or an impeachable offense. That is clear from the history, that is clear from the language of the Constitution â€” you cannot turn conduct that is not impeachable into impeachable conduct simply by using words like â€˜quid pro quoâ€™ and â€˜personal benefit,â€™â€ Dershowitz said. In his remarks before the Senate, White House deputy counsel Mike Purpura said that nobody testified â€œin House recordsâ€ that Trump had linked the aid to Ukraine with investigations of the Bidens or with a White House meeting between Trump and Ukranian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Thatâ€™s not true. Gordon Sondland, the U.S. ambassador to the European Union, testified in the House impeachment inquiry last year that, based on his conversations with the president, it was his understanding that the Ukraine aid was linked to investigations of the Bidens and that â€œeveryone was in the loop.â€ Trumpâ€™s defenders have argued that Sondlandâ€™s statements were based merely on his own assumptions. The House asked Bolton to testify in October, but he did not appear because the White House did not authorize him to do so. House Democrats decided not to pursue the matter in court, arguing that doing so would have taken months of legal action. Now, Senate Democrats want to hear from witnesses like Bolton and acting White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney, who as firsthand witnesses could shed more light on the Ukraine aid delay. The 45 Democratic senators and two Democratic-leaning independents need four Republican senators to vote with them to support motions to subpoena witnesses and other evidence. Republicans, meanwhile, sought to dismiss the Bolton development and its potential impact on the length and scope of the trial. â€œTruly, thereâ€™s nothing new here. It does seem to be an effort to sell books,â€ Sen. John Barrasso (R-Wyo.) told reporters on Monday, suggesting Boltonâ€™s credibility was at issue. â€œRight now I donâ€™t see any need to have more witnesses, unless we have a lot more witnesses,â€ Sen. Kevin Cramer (R-N.D.) said. â€œI donâ€™t think itâ€™s appropriate to use the U.S. Senate as a fishing hole.â€ â€œMy view is witnesses would just be prolonging the same outcome,â€ Cramer said. â€œIâ€™m not so naive as to think the Bolton revelation didnâ€™t cause some people some pause, but I donâ€™t know what any individual is thinking one way or the other.â€ The presidentâ€™s defense team argued that Trump did nothing wrong during that July 25 phone call last year when he asked Zelensky to investigate Trumpâ€™s domestic political opponent. â€œAsking a foreign leader to get to the bottom of issues of corruption is not a violation of an oath,â€ Sekulow said. In the phone call, the president specifically asked for an investigation of the Bidens and did not mention any general concerns about corruption. But Trumpâ€™s attorneys described Hunter Biden as a one-man whirlwind of corruption for his role on the board of Burisma, a Ukrainian energy company, while his father oversaw Ukraine policy as vice president of the United States. â€œEvery witness who was asked about Hunter Bidenâ€™s involvement at Burisma agreed there was a potential appearance of a conflict of interest,â€ former Florida attorney general Pam Bondi said Monday, describing House testimony. However, Kurt Volker, the former U.S. special envoy for Ukraine, testified in the House inquiry that he saw no validity to Trumpâ€™s allegations against the Bidens. Other diplomats said pushing an investigation of the Bidens benefited Trump, not the U.S. national interest. Bondi said Democrats themselves had brought up the Bidens, and she frequently referred to media reports questioning Hunter Bidenâ€™s board seat, including a Washington Post story in which a controversial former Ukrainian prosecutor claimed that Joe Biden had urged the prosecutorâ€™s firing because heâ€™d been investigating Burisma. (In fact, the prosecutor was widely accused of being insufficiently aggressive in pursuing corruption.) â€œAll weâ€™re saying is there was a basis to raise this, to talk about this issue, and that is enough,â€ Bondi said. In the House impeachment articles, Democrats allege that Trump withheld military assistance, as well as a coveted White House visit, in order to get Zelensky to announce the investigations Trump wanted. Because Ukraine ultimately received the security assistance that had been withheld, and because Trump ultimately did meet with Zelensky, Trumpâ€™s lawyers insisted on Monday that no harm was done. Trump and Zelensky met in New York on Sept. 25, â€œall without anyone making any statement about any investigations,â€ Purpura said. â€œSo much for quid pro quo for a meeting with the president.â€ Zelensky never got the White House visit he wanted, however. At their New York meeting, he thanked Trump for an invitation but seemed to complain that heâ€™d been left hanging. â€œYou invited me,â€ Zelensky said. â€œBut I think â€” Iâ€™m sorry, but I think you forgot to tell me the date.â€ Ryan J. Reilly contributed reporting.

The Democratic House impeachment managers also released a statement regarding the Times report. â€œThere is no defensible reason to wait until his book is published, when the information he has to offer is critical to the most important decision Senators must now make â€• whether to convict the President of impeachable offenses,â€ the statement read.
