The former New York City mayor traveled to Ukraine and Hungary with a crew from One America News Network, a conservative cable channel and website that occasionally peddles right-wing conspiracy theories, to film a documentary meant to challenge the House impeachment inquiry. â€œHeâ€™s going to make a report, I think, to the attorney general and to Congress,â€ Trump said. â€œI hear he has found plenty.â€ Giuliani reportedly spoke to former Ukrainian prosecutor Yuriy Lutsenko along with other former Ukrainian officials â€• all of whom have faced accusations of corruption. The Bidens have been accused, without evidence, of using their influence to improperly meddle in Ukrainian affairs because Hunter Biden served on the board of a Ukrainian energy company around the same time his father was tasked with addressing corruption in Ukraine. Trump is thought to consider Joe Biden to be his chief rival in the 2020 presidential election. However, his Biden preoccupation has landed him in hot water: Members of Congress launched impeachment proceedings after becoming aware of requests the president made of Ukrainian President Volodomyr Zelensky. If Zelensky announced that his government was investigating the Bidens, his country would receive pledged military aid that was being withheld and he would meet with Trump at the White House. The president also asked Zelensky to look into a conspiracy theory positing that it was Ukraine that meddled in the 2016 election, not Russia, and that the country did it on behalf of Hillary Clinton, not Trump. American intelligence officials have consistently said the theory has no basis in fact.

Title: Senators Laugh Off Trump's Latest Explanation For His Call With Ukraine's Leader
Text: WASHINGTON â€• Lawmakers on Capitol Hill didnâ€™t appear convinced by President Donald Trumpâ€™s latest defense of the phone call with Ukraineâ€™s leader that led to the House impeachment inquiry. Some were literally at a loss for words when told that Trump was now claiming â€• more than two months after the White House released a summary of the July 25 conversation â€• that he was actually urging Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to help the United States when he pushed the foreign leader to â€œdo us a favorâ€ by probing former Vice President Joe Biden and a 2016 election conspiracy theory. â€œWhen I said, in my phone call to the President of Ukraine, â€˜I would like you to do US a favor though because our country has been through a lot and Ukraine knows a lot about it.â€™ With the word â€˜usâ€™ I am referring to the United States, our Country,â€ Trump claimed in a tweet on Wednesday. When asked about the tweet on Thursday, Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) doubled over in laughter. Pressed to voice his response in words, the Democratic whip declined, shaking his head in apparent disbelief before walking into a caucus lunch. Other senators on both sides of the aisle seemed equally amused by Trumpâ€™s latest explanation. Sen. Roy Blunt (R-Mo.) smirked when asked if he agreed with the presidentâ€™s reading of the call summary. But he declined to comment until the Senate receives articles of impeachment, which the House is expected to draft next week. â€œI think the safest course is not to start analyzing all this until the House decides to send over whatever they send over, if they decide to send anything,â€ Blunt said on Thursday. Sen. Mark Warner (D-Va.) reacted with a similar expression on his face. â€œIt would help if we actually have a full transcript,â€ Warner said, noting that the summary of the call the White House released was the product of contemporaneous handwritten notes and not a full transcript. But Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) said he viewed Trumpâ€™s call with Zelensky, including the portion for which the president was offering a new explanation, as unremarkable. â€œIâ€™ve talked to the president enough to have heard him say, â€˜Ron, do me a favor.â€™ Itâ€™s almost in some respects a verbal tick. Itâ€™s not an unusual thing to come out of President Trumpâ€™s mouth. I view that whole conversation as pretty benign,â€ he said. The House Intelligence Committee on Tuesday released a 300-page report accusing Trump of abusing the power of his office in his dealings with Ukraine by seeking to withhold military assistance until its government announced an investigation into Biden, one of Trumpâ€™s 2020 rivals. The Senate is expected to take up articles of impeachment against Trump sometime next month. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) has said heâ€™ll give the House case against Trump a trial, even though he does not believe there are enough votes in the upper chamber to remove the president.

Title: Joe Biden Snaps At Voter During Fiery Exchange: 'You're A Damn Liar!'
Text: Joe Biden apparently lost his temper during an intense exchange with a voter in Iowa after the man accused the former vice president of being too old for the Oval Office and of â€œselling accessâ€ to the U.S. president during his time in the Obama administration. Biden, 77, responded to the manâ€™s comments by calling him a â€œdamn liar,â€ defending his son and urging the man to do push-ups. The confrontation with the man, who identified himself as an 83-year-old retired farmer who is not a Republican, took place during a campaign event in New Hampton, Iowa, on Thursday. Bidenâ€™s campaign stopped in the city as a part of his â€œNo Malarkeyâ€ bus tour through the state, which is just two months away from its Democratic caucus. The Iowa man, who did not provide his name, began by arguing that Biden was too old to run for president. â€œYouâ€™re damn near as old as I am,â€ he said. â€œYouâ€™re too old.â€ He then explained his other objection to Bidenâ€™s candidacy: â€œWe all know Trump has been messing around in Ukraine. ... You, on the other hand, sent your son over there to get a job and work for a gas company and [he] had no experience in natural gas.â€ â€œYouâ€™re selling access to the president just like he is,â€ he added. Interrupting the man, Biden said firmly: â€œYouâ€™re a damn liar, man. Thatâ€™s not true.â€ â€œAnd no one has ever said that. No one has proved that,â€ he added before telling his staffers to allow the man to keep his microphone. Joe Biden lashed at an Iowa town hall after the man suggested he helped his son get a sweetheart deal in Ukraine and was â€œselling accessâ€ like President Donald Trump does:â€œYouâ€™re a damn liar. That's not true," Biden said. â€œGet your words straight, jack!â€  The manâ€™s accusation echoed Trumpâ€™s debunked claims that as vice president, Biden wielded his political power to stop an investigation into a major Ukranian gas company while his son Hunter Biden sat on the companyâ€™s board of directors. Trumpâ€™s own conduct with Ukraine, including a proposal that the Ukrainian government investigate the Bidens, is now the subject of the House impeachment inquiry. Hunter Biden reportedly made between $50,000 to $80,000 a month while he served on the board, but no evidence has surfaced to prove that the Bidens did anything illegal. The younger Biden maintains he did nothing â€œimproperâ€ while working in Ukraine, though in October he admitted to exercising â€œpoor judgmentâ€ by taking the role. At the Iowa town hall, Joe Biden also defended his physical health. â€œLetâ€™s do push-ups,â€ he told the man. â€œLetâ€™s run. Letâ€™s do whatever you want to do. Letâ€™s take an IQ test.â€ And then he turned his attention back to his son. â€œNo one has said my son has done anything wrong,â€ Biden said. The man cut in to tell Biden, â€œI didnâ€™t say you were doing anything wrong.â€ â€œYou said I set up my son to work on an oil company. Isnâ€™t that what you said? Get your words straight, Jack!â€ Biden retorted. After a few more heated comments, the man compared the former vice president to Trump, saying he didnâ€™t â€œhave any more backbone than Trump does.â€ Then he told Biden he wouldnâ€™t be voting for him, prompting the crowd to boo. â€œI know youâ€™re not, man,â€ Biden replied, before moving on to more questions. â€œYou think I thought you were voting for me standing there. Youâ€™re too old to vote for me.â€ A spokesman for Bidenâ€™s campaign declined to comment on the confrontation and pointed HuffPost to a statement put out by Bidenâ€™s senior adviser Symone Sanders. â€œThe reality is this - a reference was made to the â€˜newsâ€™ today and I think we all know which outlet has continued to peddle the debunked conspiracy theories cooked up by Trump and Rudy Guiliani about Ukraine,â€ Sanders tweeted. â€œThese lies will not go unchecked & weâ€™ll continue to lay out the facts.â€ Let's be clear RE: the exchange VP Biden had with a voter in Iowa earlier today: 1) the gentleman is a self identified Warren supporter who said he would vote for the VP in a general election 2) his facts were flat-out wrong and 3) the crowd backed VP Biden up in his response. To be clear: Any assertion VP Biden said a word about the gentleman's appearance is making this something it is not. In the latter part of the exchange, the VP began to say "Look, facts" then said "here's the deal." If you've been to a Biden event, you've heard this before. The reality is this - a reference was made to the "news" today and I think we all know which outlet has continued to peddle the debunked conspiracy theories cooked up by Trump and Rudy Guiliani about Ukraine. These lies will not go unchecked & we'll continue to lay out the facts. The retired farmer told reporters after the event that he was voting for Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) for the Democratic primary, The New York Times reported. The man also told reporters that he wasnâ€™t trying to cause any problems. The Iowa voter who Joe Biden called a "damn liar" speaks with reporters after their tense exchange: "At least he's not getting so old that he's senile."  Asked about Bidenâ€™s apparent aggression towards him, he said, â€œThatâ€™s good. At least heâ€™s not getting so old that heâ€™s senile anyhow.â€

Title: Ex-Intelligence Official Reveals The Challenges Of Briefing Trump
Text: President Donald Trump would often question the veracity of his intelligence briefings, telling officials, â€œI donâ€™t think thatâ€™s true,â€ or, â€œIâ€™m not sure I believe that,â€ according to the former No. 2 intelligence official. Susan Gordon, who until recently served as the principal deputy director of national intelligence, detailed her experiences briefing Trump at an event Tuesday by the Womenâ€™s Foreign Policy Group in Washington, according to CNN. (See the video above.) But beyond his doubting of intelligence information, she said, the bigger concern was that Trump often received his own information from questionable sources. â€œRemember, intelligence is fundamentally a craft of uncertainty and of possibility, so that doesnâ€™t put you off,â€ Gordon said. The difficulty was in â€œtrying to catch up to how you adjudicate the sources that led him to believe that, and how you respond to it.â€ Trump routinely parrots false information from right-wing conspiracy theories (often promulgated on his favorite cable news network, Fox News), such as rejecting the widely proven finding from U.S. intelligence officials that Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential election. He has also regularly attacked intelligence officials and agencies, suggesting they should serve him, not the country. Gordon, a career government official who worked under every president from Ronald Reagan to Trump, was ousted in August, despite being next in line to replace retiring Director of National Intelligence Dan Coats. Trump named Joseph Maguire as acting director, passing over Gordon. The president reportedly wanted someone he deemed more loyal. In a note accompanying her resignation letter, Gordon made her dissatisfaction clear, writing: â€œI offer this letter as an act of respect & patriotism, not preference. You should have your team.â€ Asked about her departure Tuesday, Gordon said she heard that White House officials were â€œnot comfortable with me continuing as the acting directorâ€ when Coats stepped down. When Trump was receiving intelligence briefings, she said, he would often ask questions like, â€œâ€˜Why is that true?â€™ â€˜Why are we there?â€™ â€˜Why is this what you believe?â€™ â€˜Why do we do that?â€™ Those sorts of things.â€ â€œWhatâ€™s different about this president: Number one, is, he is the first in my experience that had no foundational framework to understand what the limits of intelligence are, what the purpose of it was, and the way that we discuss it,â€ she said. According to Gordon, Trump â€œasked different questionsâ€ and often â€œdisproportionatelyâ€ approached the information using an â€œeconomicâ€ lens. â€œHe is much more economic in the way that he sees the world, and the intelligence community traditionally is much more political, military â€” purposely so,â€ Gordon said. â€œWe were scrambling a bit to try and produce intelligence that was foundationally useful for someone who is interested in making trades and deals.â€ While Trump was uniquely different in some ways, Gordon acknowledged that every president approaches intelligence differently, and itâ€™s up to intelligence officials to adapt their briefings to each person. â€œPresident Obama was a reader and just voraciously consumed it. JFK wanted 3-by-5 cards in his pocket,â€ she said. â€œYou have to figure out a way to convey the information because ultimately thatâ€™s what youâ€™re trying to do. Youâ€™re trying to present information in a way that is both heard and then can be used.â€ â€œI found him actually kind of a fun brief because he was interactive. He would challenge you,â€ she said of Trump. â€œThe role of intelligence is to provide wisdom, clarity and insight. You canâ€™t wish that the recipient were different from where they were. Your challenge is to present it in a way that it can be heard.â€

Title: Lindsey Graham Breaks Ranks With Trump, Declares Ukraine Conspiracy Theory False
Text: Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) has broken ranks with President Donald Trump and many of his GOP allies, declaring Tuesday that he is â€œ1,000% confidentâ€ that Russia, not Ukraine, interfered in the 2016 U.S. election. His view contradicts a conspiracy theory backed by Russian President Vladimir Putin and peddled by Trump and others in his party that Ukraine meddled in the presidential election and framed the Russians. â€œIt was the Russians. Iâ€™m 1,000% confident that the hack of the [Democratic National Committee] was by Russian operatives, no one else,â€ Graham told reporters on Capitol Hill. In a subsequent interview with CNN, Graham said he had â€œno doubtâ€ that it was the Russians who hacked the emails of the DNC and Hillary Clinton campaign chair John Podesta. â€œIt wasnâ€™t Ukraine. Russia was behind the stolen DNC emails and Podesta and all that good stuff,â€ the senator said. â€œSo as to the Ukraine, they had zero to do with the hacking of the DNC and the stealing of the emails. Whether or not people from the Ukraine met with DNC operatives, I donâ€™t know. All Iâ€™ve seen is press reports that no one has validated.â€ The senator joins Sen. Mitt Romney (R-Utah), who also told reporters on Tuesday that heâ€™d seen no evidence of Ukrainian meddling, in distancing himself from the theory floated by some of their Republican colleagues. The break comes amid the House impeachment inquiry, which was triggered by the presidentâ€™s dealings with Ukraine. At the center of the probe is a July 25 phone call to Ukraine in which Trump referenced the hacking theory to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, urging him to look into CrowdStrike, a California-based cybersecurity firm that had investigated the breach of the DNC email system. The president called into â€œFox & Friendsâ€ recently to again push the theory, claiming that CrowdStrike is owned by a â€œwealthy Ukrainian.â€ The company is U.S.-owned. Politico and CNN reported Monday that a GOP-led Senate Intelligence Committee found no evidence when investigating allegations of interference by Ukraine, according to sources with direct knowledge of the inquiry. Grahamâ€™s comments contrast with those of Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman Richard Burr (R-N.C.), who declined to directly refute the theory and refused to say whether he saw evidence that Ukraine interfered, despite his own committeeâ€™s conclusion that Russia had interfered in the 2016 election and was â€œovertly and almost invariably supportive of then-candidate Trump.â€ Graham is usually a devoted Trump defender. He has blocked a Senate resolution to formally recognize the Armenian genocide at the behest of the White House, opened a formal investigation into former Vice President Joe Bidenâ€™s work in Ukraine despite the claims of corruption being widely discredited and unsubstantiated, and repeatedly denied unfavorable but damning testimony against Trump during the impeachment inquiry.

Title: Romney Breaks With GOP Colleagues: 'No Evidence' Of Ukrainian Meddling
Text: Sen. Mitt Romney (R-Utah) distanced himself from some of his GOP colleagues on Tuesday, stating that there was no sign of Ukrainian meddling in the 2016 election. â€œI saw no evidence from our intelligence community, nor from the representatives today for the Department of State, that there is any evidence of any kind of that suggests that Ukraine interfered in our elections,â€ he told reporters on Capitol Hill. â€œWe have ample evidence that Russia interfered in our elections.â€ "We have ample evidence that Russia interfered in our elections."Sen. Mitt Romney says he won't comment on any GOP colleagues voicing debunked theory on 2016 election meddling, but adds, "We have to adhere to the facts as presented to us by our Intelligence Community."  Romeyâ€™s statement follows testimony from Under Secretary for Political Affairs David Hale, the third-highest ranking State Department official. Hale told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that Russian meddling was not a â€œhoax,â€ and that he knows of no evidence implicating Ukraine. The remarks are a stark contrast to those of Sen. Richard Burr (R-N.C.), who on Monday told NBC News that there was no â€œquestion that elected officials in Ukraine had a favorite in the election,â€ promoting a debunked conspiracy theory. â€œEvery elected official in the Ukraine was for Hillary Clinton,â€ the Senate Intelligence Committee chair said. â€œIs that very different than the Russians being for Donald Trump?â€ The comments echoed Sen. John Kennedyâ€™s (R-La.) claims on Sunday, when he speculated during a â€œMeet the Pressâ€ appearance that â€œboth Russia and Ukraine meddled in the 2016 election,â€ and that â€œitâ€™s been well documented.â€ The U.S. intelligence community has dismissed rumors of any role by Ukraine, reportedly briefing senators in November that the allegations are a talking point touted by Russia to divert attention from its own interference in the U.S. election. Less than two weeks ago, Kennedy suggested on Fox News that Ukraine may have perpetrated the 2016 Democratic National Committee server hack that exposed party emails. The senatorâ€™s claim promulgated a lie often peddled by President Donald Trump while blatantly ignoring American intelligence officialsâ€™ conclusion that it was Russia behind the hack. Kennedy recanted shortly after, telling CNN, â€œI was wrong.â€ â€œThe only evidence I have, and I think itâ€™s overwhelming, it that it was Russia who tried to hack the DNC computer. Iâ€™ve seen no indication that Ukraine tried to do it,â€ he said. On Tuesday, Sen. Angus King (I-Maine), a member of the Intelligence Committee, denounced the erroneous claims, telling CNN that he hasnâ€™t seen the slightest indication of Ukrainian involvement. â€œI bet I sat through 25 hearings, briefings, meetings, probably more on the question of what happened in 2016,â€ he said. â€œIn none of those meetings was there ever a hint, a breath, a suggestion, a word that somehow Ukraine was involved.â€

Title: Chris Christie Hit Trump With A Stark Warning In 2017, New Mueller Memos Reveal
Text: Former New Jersey governor and Trump ally Chris Christie warned the president in 2017 that the â€œRussia thingâ€ was far from over, despite Trumpâ€™s insistence to the contrary, according to a newly released cache of documents from special counsel Robert Muellerâ€™s investigation into Russian election interference. The documents, released by the Justice Department on Monday in response to a lawsuit by BuzzFeed News and CNN, included almost 300 pages of witness memoranda and notes from the FBIâ€™s interviews with key players in the Mueller probe. The documents included summaries of the bureauâ€™s interviews with Christie, former Trump lawyer Michael Cohen, former Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein and former White Hosue communications director Hope Hicks, among others. According to the memos, Christie told the FBI that heâ€™d discussed the Mueller investigation with Trump over lunch on Valentineâ€™s Day in 2017. â€œNow that we fired Flynn, the Russia thing is over,â€ Trump allegedly told Christie, referring to former National Security Advisor Michael Flynnâ€™s removal from office. Flynn resigned on Feb. 13, 2017, after misleading Vice President Mike Pence about his conversations with Russiaâ€™s then-ambassador to the U.S. Flynn later pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI. Christie told investigators that he â€œlaughedâ€ at Trumpâ€™s suggestion that the Russia problem was behind them. â€œNo way,â€ he recalled telling the president. â€œWeâ€™ll be here on Valentineâ€™s Day 2018 talking about this.â€ Christie, a former federal prosecutor, said he went on to urge Trump to keep his head down as the probe into Russian interference ramped up. Per the memos: [Christie said] he had been through both sides of investigations and there was no way to make it shorter, but there were a lot of ways to make it longer. Trump asked Christie what he meant, and Christie told him not to talk about the investigation and to keep his mouth shut even though it would be frustrating at times. Christie added that â€œif you get near a guy like Flynn, heâ€™s like gum on the bottom of your shoe, and you canâ€™t get rid of him.â€ Chris Christie told Mueller investigators that Trump said to him "Now that we fired Flynn, the Russia thing is over" and Christie laughed at him and said "no way."  Later during that same Valentineâ€™s Day lunch, Trump allegedly asked Christie to speak with then-FBI Director James Comey â€• who, at the time, was leading the bureauâ€™s probe into Russian election interference â€• and to tell him that Trump â€œreally like[s] him.â€ Christie told the FBI that he never made the call, saying he thought the request was â€œnonsensical.â€ â€œChristie said it would have been uncomfortable to pass on that messageâ€ to Comey, the FBI summary of the interview said. Comey was fired three months later. During a Q&A session last month at his alma mater, the University of Delaware, Christie called Mueller an â€œAmerican patriotâ€ and praised the special counselâ€™s final report as â€œvery thorough and fairâ€ given â€œthe complicated set of facts.â€ Separately, he said he believed Trump would be impeached by the House of Representatives over his dealings with Ukraine but would not be removed from office by the Republican-led Senate. â€œI have a very, what I call, practical view of this. He will be impeached. Itâ€™s just a matter of time. The Democrats didnâ€™t start this to not finish it,â€ Christie said, according to NPR. â€œThis is a political judgment, not a factual judgment. They will impeach him, and then it will go to the Senate, and the Senate will not remove him.â€ â€œEveryoneâ€™s got their uniform on,â€™â€™ Christie continued, referring to partisanship in Washington. â€œAnd 20 Republicans are not taking their red jersey off and putting a blue jersey on between now and January. And thatâ€™s what itâ€™s going to take, and I donâ€™t think itâ€™s going to happen.â€ Mueller witness interview memos, round 2. This time we're seeing for the first time FBI notes from: Rick Gates, Michael Cohen, Hope Hicks, John Kelly, Omarosa, Rosenstein, Chris Christie, Lewandowski, Mary McCordAll 295 pages here: The Mueller memos made public this week were part of a second release of FBI interview notes from the special counsel investigation. The Justice Department released the first installment of FBI interview summaries last month in response to a Freedom of Information Act request and lawsuit from BuzzFeed and CNN. BuzzFeed said Monday that the interview summaries are â€œsome of the most important and highly sought-after documents from Muellerâ€™s investigation.â€ Other highlights from the more recent document release include Rosensteinâ€™s admission to the FBI that he had been â€œangry, ashamed, horrified and embarrassedâ€ at how the White House handled Comeyâ€™s firing, and Hicks' claim that Trump was â€œangry, surprised, and frustratedâ€ when Mueller was appointed as special counsel. See the full cache of documents here.

Title: Tucker Carlson Goes There Again: Backs Russian Invasion Of Ukraine
Text: Fox Newsâ€™ Tucker Carlson went full-on Vladimir Putin comrade Monday â€” again â€” and sided with Russia in its violent confrontations with Ukraine, apparently including Russiaâ€™s invasion and annexation of Crimea. Carlson said something similar a week ago, but then disavowed it within the hour. This time, Carlson made the leap as he railed against U.S. sanctions against Russia for its invasion of Crimea and for an ongoing deadly border war with Ukraine. â€œI should say for the record that Iâ€™m totally opposed to these sanctions and I donâ€™t think we should be at war with Russia,â€ a serious Carlson told Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) on his program. â€œAnd I think we should probably take the side of Russia, if we have to choose between Russia and Ukraine.â€ He also wondered why Putin is â€œso badâ€? In another jaw-dropper, Carlson insisted that Putin â€œdoes not hate America as much as many of these people doâ€ after he attacked MSNBC news host Chuck Todd and the â€œrest of the dummies.â€ He criticized them for being incapable of speaking Russian. Title: Nicolle Wallace Quips Putin Must Have 'Lots Of Pee Tapes' For GOP To Push Kremlin Line
Text: A stumped Nicolle Wallace quipped on MSNBC on Monday that Russian President Vladimir Putin â€œmust have lots of pee tapesâ€ to get Republicans to parrot Kremlin propaganda. Wallace, confused by Republicansâ€™ insistence on pushing claims by Putin in â€œdefiance of factsâ€ uncovered by U.S. intelligence officials, was referring to an unfounded claim in a dossier gathered by former British intelligence agent Christopher Steele that Donald Trump watched prostitutes engage in â€œgolden showersâ€ in a Moscow hotel room in 2013. Such tapes could be used as blackmail, Wallace was insinuating â€” though not seriously. But how else to explain Republicansâ€™ strange insistence on stories that serve Putinâ€™s aims? Wallace guest and Bulwark editor Charlie Sykes accused Sen. John Kennedy (R-La.) of coming off as an â€œaddled Russian assetâ€ when he claimed Sunday on MSNBC that former Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko â€œactively workedâ€ for Hillary Clinton to skew the American election on her behalf. When an astounded Chuck Todd asked for the basis for Kennedyâ€™s claim, the senator responded: â€œJust read the articlesâ€ â€” though he identified no â€œarticles.â€ An exasperated Todd responded: â€œCâ€™mon!â€ Sykes, a conservative commentator and author, had no explanation for why Kennedy did a â€œfull Devin Nunes,â€ referring to the California congressman who defends Trump no matter what the cost. â€œIs this the price now to be paid for currying favor in Trump World?â€ he asked. He called Kennedyâ€™s â€” and othersâ€™ â€” Ukraine election claims â€œflat-out BS.â€ The insistence that Ukraine â€” and not Russia â€” interfered in the 2016 election serves to distract attention from the Kremlin just as officials warn Russia is already taking action to manipulate the 2020 U.S. election, critics warn. Former White House Russia analyst Fiona Hill testified last month before the House Intelligence Committee that the story that Ukraine interfered in the 2016 election is â€œa fictional narrative that has been perpetrated and propagated by the Russian security services themselves.â€ Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) on Sunday called Republican lawmakers the â€œmost important global assetâ€ of Russian intelligence. Check out the rest of the MSNBC video up top on Republicans pulling the Moscow party line.

Title: GOP Intelligence Committee Chairman Refuses To Knock Down Ukraine Conspiracy Theory
Text: Sen. Richard Burr (R-N.C.) on Monday refused to say whether heâ€™s seen evidence that Ukraine interfered in the 2016 presidential election, declining to directly rebut a debunked conspiracy theory floated by some of his fellow GOP lawmakers and President Donald Trump. Burr, the chairman of the Republican-controlled Senate Intelligence Committee, instead played a game of words with reporters on Capitol Hill who pressed him about an interview with Sen. John Kennedy (R-La.), who suggested the Ukranian government worked â€œactivelyâ€ to help elect Trumpâ€™s opponent Hillary Clinton. Trump later thanked Kennedy â€œfor the job he did in representing both the Republican Party and myselfâ€ on Twitter. â€œEvery elected official in the Ukraine was for Hillary Clinton,â€ Burr claimed Monday, according to NBCâ€™s Frank Thorp. â€œIs that very different than the Russians being for Donald Trump?â€ Asked if he had seen any evidence to back up the claim that Ukraine meddled in the 2016 election, Burr answered by addressing a different question, saying he didnâ€™t think â€œthereâ€™s any question that elected officials in Ukraine had a favorite in the election.â€ Russia didnâ€™t simply prefer Trump in 2016. The U.S. intelligence community has stated definitively that Russia hacked the Democratic National Committeeâ€™s servers and leaked thousands of emails in an effort to discredit Democrats and help Trump win the presidency in 2016. Trump has claimed, without evidence, that Ukraine was behind the cyberattack, however. Burrâ€™s own committee concluded that Russia used social media campaigns to sow discord among the American electorate in 2016, adding that the activity was â€œovertly and almost invariably supportive of then-candidate Trump.â€ The committee also looked into the theory that Ukraine meddled in the 2016 election but â€œfound no evidence that Ukraine waged a top-down interference campaign akin to the Kremlinâ€™s efforts to help Trump win in 2016,â€ according to Politico. But Burr did not mention those conclusions on Monday and continued to insist in an extended Q&A that a â€œpreferenceâ€ for a candidate is somehow on the same footing as a foreign government waging a systematic campaign to affect an electionâ€™s outcome: Here's the end of our Q+A with Senate Intel Cmte Chair @SenatorBurr:  In her testimony at a House impeachment hearing last month, former National Security Council member Fiona Hill, a top Russia expert, warned that Republicans were playing into Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s hands by pointing the finger at Ukraine. â€œBased on questions and statements I have heard, some of you on this committee appear to believe that Russia and its security services did not conduct a campaign against our country â€• and that perhaps, somehow, for some reason, Ukraine did,â€ Hill said at the hearing. â€œThis is a fictional narrative that has been perpetrated and propagated by the Russian security services themselves.â€ Nevertheless, Trump and his Republican allies on Capitol Hill have continued to seek to shift the narrative that Russia meddled in the 2016 election. Democrats on Monday slammed their GOP counterparts for â€œdisgracefullyâ€ repeating Russian propaganda. â€œThe charge that Ukraine had something to do with election meddling in 2016 is a lie spread by Vladimir Putin to get things off his back,â€ Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) said in a floor speech. Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) added in an interview on MSNBC: â€œMy hope has been all along that the Senate would be able to survive the Trump presidency, that we wouldnâ€™t be pulled down into this cesspool of lies and mistruths. Itâ€™s just sad to watch my colleagues willingly propagate these lies.â€

Title: U.S. Senator: Republican Party Is Turning Into Russiaâ€™s â€˜Most Important Global Assetâ€™
Text: Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) called out the Republican Party for advancing Russian conspiracy theories as it continues to defend President Donald Trump during the impeachment inquiry. â€œCall me old fashioned, but I think itâ€™s a little unsavory the Republican Party is becoming the most important global asset of Russian intel,â€ Murphy tweeted on Sunday. â€œI get it, Russiaâ€™s bonkers â€˜Ukraine did it, not Russiaâ€™ story is all the GOP has to defend their guy, but really?â€ Call me old fashioned, but I think itâ€™s a little unsavory the Republican Party is becoming the most important global asset of Russian intel. Murphyâ€™s tweet came hours after one of his Senate colleagues essentially repeated a debunked Russian talking point on â€œMeet the Pressâ€ on Sunday. â€œI think both Russia and Ukraine meddled in the 2016 election,â€ Sen. John Kennedy (R-La.) said. â€œI think itâ€™s been well-documented.â€ He also claimed that Ukraineâ€™s former president, Petro Poroshenko, had been actively working for Hillary Clinton. As host Chuck Todd pointed out, the U.S. intelligence community has implicated only Russia for 2016 election interference and recently warned senators that Moscow was trying to frame Ukraine for it. â€œYou realize the only person selling this argument outside the United States is ... Vladimir Putin?â€ Todd said. â€œYouâ€™ve done exactly what the Russian operation is trying to get American politicians to do. Are you at all concerned that youâ€™ve been duped?â€ â€œNo,â€ Kennedy replied.

Title: NBC's Chuck Todd Scolds GOP Senator For Pushing Russian Talking Points
Text: NBCâ€™s Chuck Todd on Sunday forcefully pushed back on a claim made by Sen. John Kennedy (R-La.) that Ukraine, like Russia, interfered in the 2016 election â€• a theory peddled by the Kremlin and rejected by U.S. intelligence agencies. â€œI think both Russia and Ukraine meddled in the 2016 election. I think itâ€™s been well documented,â€ Kennedy said during an appearance on NBCâ€™s â€œMeet The Press.â€ Though Kennedy has backtracked on his comments from last week, in which he appeared to suggest Ukraine may have been behind the 2016 cyberattack against the Democratic National Committee, he has continued to say the country interfered in the U.S. election generally. Todd pointed out that the U.S. intelligence community has said thatâ€™s not true. He also noted that Fiona Hill, the former top Russia expert in the National Security Council, testified before Congress last month that Ukraine did not meddle in the election. Whatâ€™s more, Todd said, senators were reportedly briefed by U.S. intelligence officials after Hillâ€™s testimony that Russia is behind the push to frame Ukraine for its own U.S. election interference. â€œThis is a Russian intelligence propaganda campaign in order to get people like you to say these things about Ukraine,â€ he told Kennedy. â€œAre you at all concerned youâ€™re doing Russian intelligence work here?â€ WATCH: @ChuckTodd asks @SenJohnKennedy if he is "at all concerned that he has been duped" into believing that former Ukraine president worked for the Clinton campaign in 2016 #MTP #IfItsSunday@SenJohnKennedy: "No, just read the articles."  Kennedy denied having been briefed on Russiaâ€™s efforts, and added, â€œDr. Hill is entitled to her opinion.â€ Todd fired back: â€œWhen does opinion become fact? Does 17 intelligence services saying it; does every Western intelligence ally saying Russia did this? Iâ€™m just sort of confused. At what point is it no longer an opinion for you?â€ But Kennedy claimed itâ€™s a â€œfactâ€ that Ukraine interfered on the election, pointing to past articles in Politico and The Financial Times that reported that Ukrainian officials criticized Trump ahead of the 2016 election given his Russia-friendly comments at the time. In July 2016, Trump hinted that he supported the 2014 Russian invasion of Crimea, which is internationally recognized as a part of Ukraine. Ukrainian officials swiftly denounced his remarks. â€œRussia was very aggressive and theyâ€™re much more sophisticated,â€ Kennedy said Sunday. â€œBut the fact that Russia was so aggressive does not exclude the fact that [former Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko] actively worked for [Hillary Clinton].â€ An exasperated Todd interrupted Kennedy, after his claim about Poroshenko, for which there is no evidence. â€œYou realize the only person selling this argument outside the United States is ... Vladimir Putin?â€ he asked. â€œYouâ€™ve done exactly what the Russian operation is trying to get American politicians to do. Are you at all concerned that youâ€™ve been duped?â€ â€œNo,â€ Kennedy said. Todd continued to grill him, asking if the senator believes thereâ€™s a difference between Ukrainian officials criticizing a presidential candidate who endorsed the invasion of their country â€” as Trump had â€” compared to Russia hacking the DNC servers. â€œLetâ€™s suppose â€• and I donâ€™t believe â€• but youâ€™re right and Iâ€™m wrong,â€ Kennedy said. â€œThen what harm would it do to allow the president of the United States, who has a demonstrated record of fighting foreign corruption, to introduce evidence?â€ Todd noted that Trump has been given â€œevery opportunity to provide exculpatory evidenceâ€ on the matter and hasnâ€™t done so. Kennedy then claimed the ongoing impeachment inquiry into Trump, which is centered on the presidentâ€™s efforts to get Ukraine to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, is â€œas rigged as carnival ring toss.â€ He also claimed Trump hasnâ€™t been able to call his own witnesses or have legal representation during the hearings. However, House Judiciary Chairman Jerry Nadler (D-N.Y.) asked Republicans last week which witnesses they would like to have testify on behalf of Trump. Nadler also invited the presidentâ€™s attorneys to come to the hearings as the impeachment inquiry proceeds.

Title: Justice Department's Internal Russia Inquiry Will Undercut Trump's FBI Spying Claim: Report
Text: The Justice Departmentâ€™s inspector general is expected to release a report dispelling claims that the FBI placed informants in the 2016 Donald Trump campaign and engaged in politically motivated wiretapping as the bureau investigated an alleged conspiracy between Trump and Russia, according to The New York Times. Inspector General Michael Horowitz will release a report on Dec. 9 undercutting claims from conservatives that the FBI exhibited systemic political bias against President Trump in its investigation, the Times reported, citing two people familiar with a draft of the inspector generalâ€™s report. This latest DOJ report follows an earlier one from Horowitz that indicated the FBIâ€™s handling of the Hillary Clinton email investigation in 2016 harmed Clinton, the Democratic presidential nominee â€• not Trump. On the matter of the investigation into Russian interference in 2016, two claims in particular have spread widely in conservative circles. The first arose in 2017, when Trump claimed that former President Barack Obama had ordered a wiretap of Trump Tower. Trump has since admitted he made the claim without evidence, and the inspector generalâ€™s report is expected to refute the claim officially. The second accusation from the presidentâ€™s conservative allies involves the approval of a wiretap on former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page; Republicans in Congress have said the wiretap, which was approved in a special court overseeing foreign intelligence surveillance, was politically motivated. The FBI sought the wiretap after the Christopher Steele dossier â€” a compilation of bombshell claims about a relationship between the Trump campaign and Russia assembled by a former British intelligence official â€” said Page may have been in contact with Kremlin officials. Horowitz will say the FBI was â€œcareless and unprofessionalâ€ in its pursuit of the wiretap, but his report ultimately finds the agencyâ€™s actions were not politically motivated, according to the Timesâ€™ sources. Trump, his campaign officials and Republicans have chafed at the Russia investigation since it was announced in 2017, repeatedly claiming that accusations Trump aided Russian interference in the 2016 election were meant to remove a â€œduly elected presidentâ€ from office. But, although former special counsel Robert Muellerâ€™s investigation couldnâ€™t find evidence of a criminal conspiracy between the Trump campaign and the Russian government, the Mueller report did find several instances in which Trump or his campaign officials showed willingness â€” even eagerness â€” to gain Russiaâ€™s help. (The trial of Roger Stone, a former Trump campaign adviser with ties to WikiLeaks, has shed more light on the potential backchannels used to coordinate the effort.) The president has asked his allies in Congress and members of the press to investigate the origins of the Russia investigation, suggesting nefarious activity had taken place. But the Dec. 9 report â€” much like the Mueller report before it â€” will say the FBI acted properly in opening the investigation, according to the Times. Republicans in Congress have also trained their focus on a Maltese professor, Joseph Mifsud, whom some have accused of being an FBI informant. The inspector generalâ€™s report is expected to dispel that claim, as well. Mifsud is cited in the Mueller report as the individual who first informed Trump campaign adviser George Papadopoulos that the Russians had dirt on Clinton. Mifsudâ€™s interactions with Papadopoulos â€” which Papadopoulos discussed over drinks with an Australian diplomat â€” were the catalyst for the Russia investigation, according to the Mueller report. The diplomat, Alexander Downer, allegedly precipitated the Russia investigation when he reported what heâ€™d heard to the FBI. So there were, in fact, taps involved in the earliest stages of the Russia affair â€” but they were apparently beer taps, not wiretaps.

Title: John Kennedy Admits He Was Wrong On DNC Election Hack: 'It WAS Russia'
Text: After a wild interview Sunday on Fox News, Sen. John Kennedy (R-La.) conceded Monday to CNN host Chris Cuomo that he was wrong in the earlier interview. Russia, not Ukraine, was responsible for hacking Democratic National Committee emails before the 2016 presidential election, he clarified. â€œI was wrong,â€ he said on CNN. â€œThe only evidence I have, and I think itâ€™s overwhelming, it that it was Russia who tried to hack the DNC computer. Iâ€™ve seen no indication that Ukraine tried to do it.â€ Asked by Fox Newsâ€™ Chris Wallace on Sunday if he thought Russia was behind the damaging cyberattack â€” as the U.S. intelligence community has concluded â€” Kennedy falsely claimed that nobody knows. When Wallace responded that the â€œentire intelligence community says it was Russia,â€ Kennedy answered: â€œRight, but it could also be Ukraine.â€ Kennedy, however, left some major wiggle room in his walk back. He told Cuomo he misheard Wallace as saying that â€œonly Russia had tried to interfere in the election.â€ Though he believed Russia was responsible for the hack, he was reluctant to rule out Ukrainian involvement in other election interference, Kennedy explained. But his clarification reveals how difficult it is for even one of Donald Trumpâ€™s staunchest supporters to swallow the presidentâ€™s narrative that the Democrats hacked their own emails with Ukraineâ€™s help so they could blame it on the Republicans. Fiona Hill, a former top White House adviser on Russia, testified before the House Intelligence Committee last week that the account is a â€œfictional narrative being propagated by the Russian security services themselves.â€ Check out the clip up top as Kennedy keeps explaining.

Title: GOP Senator Gives Cover To Trump's Debunked Ukraine Hacking Claim: 'We Don't Know'
Text: Sen. John Kennedy (R-La.) on Sunday suggested Ukraine may have hacked the Democratic National Committeeâ€™s servers in 2016 â€• an assertion that bucks the assessment of the entire U.S. intelligence community, and also happens to echo a debunked conspiracy theory often peddled by President Donald Trump. Asked during an appearance on â€œFox News Sundayâ€ whether Russia was behind the cyberattack, as the CIA and Department of Homeland Security have concluded, Kennedy falsely claimed that nobody knows. â€³I donâ€™t know,â€ he told host Chris Wallace. â€œNor do you. Nor do any of us.â€ Wallace interrupted to point out that the â€œentire intelligence community says it was Russia.â€ â€³Right, but it could also be Ukraine,â€ Kennedy said. On FOX News Sunday: Louisiana Senator John Kennedy reacts to President Trump saying Ukraine may have the DNC server, an idea that runs contrary to the intelligence community. Chris asks Senator Kennedy who he thinks is responsible for hacking the DNC. #FNS #FoxNews  The U.S. intelligence community has stated definitively that Russia hacked the DNCâ€™s servers and leaked thousands of emails in an effort to help Trump win the presidency in 2016. Trump has claimed, without evidence, that Ukraine was behind the cyberattack. In September, Tom Bossert, a former homeland security adviser to Trump, said that idea is â€œcompletely falseâ€ and â€œcompletely debunked.â€ â€œIt has no validity,â€ Bossert told ABC News. â€œThe United States government reached its conclusion on attributing to Russia the DNC hack in 2016 before it even communicated it to the FBI.â€ Several current and former State Department officials, while testifying before Congress as part of the impeachment inquiry, have also said the Ukraine hacking claim has no basis in reality. Fiona Hill, the former top Russia expert on the National Security Council, testified that Russia has pushed the Ukraine hacking theory in an effort to obscure its own role in the attack and sow discord within the U.S. political system. â€œOur nation is being torn apart,â€ Hill said. â€œTruth is questioned. Our highly professional, expert career foreign service is being undermined.â€ But Kennedy, a member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said thatâ€™s simply â€œher opinion.â€ â€œIâ€™m not saying that I know one way or another,â€ he said Sunday. â€œIâ€™m saying Ms. Hill is entitled to her opinion, but no rebuttal evidence was allowed to be offered.â€ â€œWe know that, at least that the Republicans in the House wanted to call a witness, a DNC political operative who lobbied the Ukrainian Embassy to be involved, get involved in 2016 election,â€ he continued. â€œWe donâ€™t know if Ukraine did that. We donâ€™t know to what extent.â€ Kennedy was apparently referring to Alexandra Chalupa, a co-chair of the DNCâ€™s Ethnic Council who worked with Ukrainian Embassy officials in 2016 to research former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafortâ€™s Russia ties. There is no evidence, however, that Ukraine coordinated with Chalupa or the DNC to influence the election. Wallace concluded the interview by telling Kennedy that itâ€™s â€œalways interesting to talk to you and even more interesting to listen to you.â€ Asked Sunday why Trump doesnâ€™t believe his own Justice Department and intelligence officials about the Russian cyberattack, presidential counselor Kellyanne Conway claimed he actually does. â€œThe president has said he accepts that, but also there are plenty of ways to interfere in an election,â€ Conway told CBSâ€™ â€œFace The Nation.â€ When host Margaret Brennan pressed Conway to answer specifically about Trumpâ€™s claims that Ukraine was behind the DNC hack, the White House aide pivoted to attacking Robert Muellerâ€™s Russia investigation and the media.

Title: Fiona Hill Shoots Down GOP Conspiracy Theories, Says â€˜Our Nation Is Being Torn Apartâ€™
Text: Fiona Hill, the former top National Security Council official for Europe and Russia under President Donald Trump, warned the House Intelligence Committee against spreading what she called false conspiracy theories that Ukraine interfered in the 2016 election during her impeachment inquiry testimony on Thursday. â€œSome of you on this committee appear to believe Russia and its security services did not conduct a campaign against our country â€” and that perhaps, somehow, for some reason, Ukraine did,â€ Hill said. Committee Republicans have endorsed numerous unfounded theories that Ukraine interfered in the 2016 election. Specifically, Rep. Devin Nunes (R-Calif.) has suggested that the â€œblack ledgerâ€ that revealed millions in hidden payments by the government of deposed President Viktor Yanukovych to Trumpâ€™s former campaign manager Paul Manafort is a potential forgery. Trump has also endorsed conspiracy theories that Ukraine, not Russia, hacked the Democratic National Committee servers and is presently hiding the server in Ukraine. These theories have all been disproven and Manafort was convicted in federal court of receiving illicit payments from Ukraine. On the July 25 call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, Trump asked Zelensky to â€œfind out what happened with this whole situation with Ukraine, they say CrowdStrike,â€ referencing the private firm that investigated the DNC hack. Trump incorrectly claimed that CrowdStrike was funded by Ukrainian oligarchs and that the DNC server was in Ukraine. â€œThe server, they say Ukraine has it,â€ Trump said. Hill described the theories pushed by committee Republicans as a â€œfictional narrativeâ€ that aims to implicate Ukraine and not Russia as the country that interfered in the 2016 election. She added that these disproven theories Trump floated to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky in the July 25 call were false. â€œOur nation is being torn apart,â€ Hill said. â€œTruth is questioned. Our highly professional, expert career foreign service is being undermined.â€ The conspiracy theories endorsed by Trump and committee Republicans are designed to muddy the waters about Russian interference in the 2016 election. Hill said that the Russian government supports these theories and that they have gained traction in some quarters of the U.S. independent of that support. She argued that the goal of Russiaâ€™s interference in 2016 and continued disinformation campaigns was to â€œdelegitimize our entire presidency.â€ â€œThe goal of the Russians was to really put whoever became the president [in 2016] â€¦ under a cloud,â€ Hill said. For Trump, that cloud is allegations that he was involved in the efforts by Russian intelligence to interfere in the election. But had former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, who was the target of said interference campaign, won the election, Hill noted, â€œShe too would have had major questions about her legitimacy.â€ Hill noted that representatives of other countries, including perhaps Ukraine, may have â€œhad harsh words for candidatesâ€ in 2016, but these statements did not add up to a concerted campaign to influence the outcome of the election. â€œI refuse to be part of an effort to legitimize an alternate narrative that the Ukrainian government is a U.S. adversary, and that Ukraine, not Russia, attacked us in 2016,â€ Hill said. â€œThese fictions are harmful even if they are deployed for purely domestic political purposes.â€
